reviews.review: Powerful exhibition . The museum describes the problem of landmines and unexploded ordinance remaining after the Vietnam War in Cambodia as well as the rest of the world, through the experience of one man who dedicated his life to the cause.
Very interesting and must do. We have visited this museum last weekend and it was an unforgettable experience. It's a must do when visiting Siem Reap.

Worth a visit when you need a break from temples. Aki Ra's story, told in a lot of detail throughout the museum, is a fascinating one. Worth the visit just to read about his experiences. The $5 entrance is nominal and supports great causes. It is a must see when you need a short break from temples.

Very Sobering. I was so interested in the information that was provided in this small museum. We went by tuk tuk and thoroughly enjoyed the trip there and the museum. It was worth the time to get there. Staff were very informative.

Worth a visit. We visited this museum on the way to some temples and were very happy we called in. It is very basic but the information and display of the work they do is obviously needed. One of the members of the funding committee spent a lot of time with us telling of their work and what they have achieved. Take the time to call in if you can.

Moving and educational part of my trip to Siem Reap. My tour guide would have skipped this had I shown no interest, but I am so glad I insisted - I stayed for 40 minutes and could have stayed for an hour. Saturated in beautiful temples and tasty food it can be hard to contend with Cambodia's recent chaotic and traumatic past. This is a small museum, consisting of a small group of thematic rooms surrounding a kiosk full of examples of munitions from the Vietnam War through to the period of the Khmer Rouge. It provides an inflinching and disturbing look at landmines, their role in the war, how they are made and how they kill and maim, brought up-to-date with descriptions of present international movements to end the production and distribution of landmines. The English audio tour (free with admission) was excellent.

Worth a visit. If you have a spare 15-30 minutes on your day trip around the Angkor complex I highly recommend dropping by this museum. Very sobering to read some of the stories about victims and see the work which is being done by various countries and charities to try and clear the landmines from Cambodia. The American tour guide was fantastic and provided some great insight into the details. The site also houses a school for poor, sick or orphaned children and provides housing, food and education (most students go onto university or trades).The money from the ticket goes directly towards helping clear landmines, raise awareness and support the children facilities.

A humble museum with deep story and disturbing truths. Landmine Museum is a small but disturbing place with a big story. Founded by a former Khmer Rouge child-soldier, who was ordered to lay the mines, later turning around and committing his life to removing the millions of landmines spread around Cambodia by various armed forces.I will not dwell into the history, it can be found in various documents and movies on-line (and is - obviously - presented in the Landmine Museum itself).I will write what you will see in the museum.First of all - you will see thousands of mines in all sizes, colors and shapes, from all the possible producers worldwide.Secondly - you will see what these mines do to people. Ugly.Thirdly - you will see the history of people who committed their lives to get rid of the landmine threat.The museum has just a few rooms (5?), there are some worn audio guides provided (2 of 3 I tried did not work).I definitely recommend the museum. It is humble, but very authentic and allows tourists to better understand the past and the presence of Cambodia, which is far more than good hotels and cheap entertainment easy to find in Siem Reap.
Sobering visit. As the title suggests, this is very informative but not for small children.Sadly, you see people with horrific injuries from these mines throughoutSiem Reap.Ian Gibbs
An informative Must Visit. All visitors should see this interesting museum set up by some really remarkable people. Sober reminder of the devastation great powers can reap on an innocent population.

Powerful and Necessary. You can't go to Cambodia without knowing about the horrible wars and genocide that took place. You just can't. Its part of the deal and I would consider it offensive if you didn't learn a little history. This museum was great. You got to see actual landmines and the real human cost of war. We always hear numbers on TV and they are easy to disregard (I do it too) but the see images of actual innocent children with limbs blown off by landmines puts a human face on it. The guide's father was killed by the Khmer Rouge. Everyone who visits Siem Reap needs to go here. Not recommended for little children though.
Nothing special. A lot of mines, old rockets,old photos but nothing more. really nothing. Ticket for 5$ for 10min visit.

Interesting Museum. We stopped here on the way back from Banteay Srei with our tour. Worth the stop to learn more about the history regarding the landmines in Cambodia and what's being done about them. Ended up coming home and donating! Best of luck to all of you.

Enlightening. Thank you so much to our American guide who greeted us, and who toured us (apologies for not getting your name) and explained the story of the burying of mines and this organisations endeavours to rid Cambodia of mines. His personal experience added something we could not have read, try to get a tour with him instead of head phones, he makes it real and can answer questions. No cost! Buy water from the locals before you travel back.
Sobering experience. This is a small museum, but the message is powerful and you will learn a lot. Well worth the trip to learn a little about history and contribute to a very important cause.

Make this one of your stops in Siem Reap. Small museum a little way out of town. Stopped in as part of a tour. A guy called Bob took us around and explained the museum. Even though it's small it's incredibly interesting. Bob is engaging and passionate. The work that they do here is fantastic. I could have easily spent an hour here listening to the stories. They are the only solely Cambodian operated mine destruction team - Go here and support them.

A small museum but so is a landmine.. This is a very small museum packed with defused ordnance,it's possible to walk around in 5 to 10 minutes,but listen to the free audio and read all the wall posters and it's easy to spend 1+ hours there. Some form of photo id is required for loan of audio and headset.Diagrams of various mines and which countries make and supply them i found interesting. Aki Ra the founder is a very brave man having defused thousands of mines, i keep thinking of the audio when he says "Never touch a land mine." long pause then "Never ever touch a landmine" his voice says it all. There is map of Vietnan/Cambodia covered in red dots, each dot is a bomb drop by B52s,incredible, it's a wonder any body survived.A very interesting place, well worth a visit.How some people complain about a $5 entry fee is beyond me as it all goes to a good cause.
Home spun museum with a very important message.. "mom and pop" museum delivering a very powerful lesson. On way to Banteay Srei; stop and support this valuable museum

Humbling experience.. This museum reminds os of the horrors we can inflict on someone ad the strength of the human spirit to overcome them. The efforts of one man in particular are nothing short of heroic, and the vision he inspires others to share are very moving. It's hard to come here and not feel awe. The children that this effort supports are proof of what one person can do to change the world. The exhibits are clearly marked in both English and Cambodian, and some are also in French. All of the items are genuine, and the stories behind each compelling. Highly recommended way to spend an hour or two, plus the gift shop supports the orphanage with a number of the items for sale actually being made by the children...worth a visit for sure.

Go here instead of the floating villages. We heard bad things about the floating villages, so we went here by Tuk Tuk instead. It was really informative and inspiring. Learned a lot about land mines in Cambodia and the world, how they are being found and diffused, and which countries still do not support the ban on production and use (ahem, USA). This place also is a refuge for children injured by mines, giving them a new lease on life. The entrance fee is $5 US, and all proceeds go back into the mine and the centre for the children.

Full of history. Amazing experience, full of history that is very powerful & eye opening. On the way to Banteay Srei so it would be silly not to stop! Consider asking your guide where else you can donate, because our tour guide let us know that all tourists donate here and there are so many villages & orphanages in need that do not get tons of donations. We still donated school supplies and games but were happy we also gave to other places since this museum is internationally recognized and very popular.

Educational for many visitors. Worth visit to understand the damage and heart ache mines cause ! Great that they run home for kids behind the museum . Shocked how many mines still exist in Cambodia !!

see history. Without understanding that foreign forces where using Cambodia as a base to exterminate the population you would never know from today's culture what they went through. I was there in 1976 helping refugees. I was nearly killed by the Khumer Rouge.

A must do! . Landmine Museum What an amazing man. Aki Ra founded the museum, he is responsible for clearing 50,000 land mines on his own. There are still an estimated 3-6million that are still out there. The museum has an audio tour available and it gives details and explains things clearly, my 10 year old was able to understand things well. It was a real eye opener and gave a greater understanding of the suffering faced by the Cambodian people. They run a school as well, and are on the look out for donations school supplies etc.. You may consider taking some things along. Highly recommend you visit, and take your kids along. They may not get too many details of the various bombings and the struggles but at least they will come away with growing sense of empathy.

Up close. This private initiative is a testimony of mankind's resilience. It offers an up close and personal view of the havoc war causes in personal lives. The audio guide is offering excellent information and the displays are powerful. Some of the photo's are fading fast and it may be time for an overhaul. This is the real thing - an authentic experience of the bane of landmines. I did a day visit on the back of a scooter to Banteay Srei and the River of a 1000 Linga and stopped at the museum and the Butterfly Centre.

Sad but true. We stopped off on our way to Siem Reap & I'm glad we did. Only a couple of us were interested in going but the whole group, 13 of us, ended up visiting and no-one regretted it. Aki Ra's story about how he cleared many mines is inspiring. He continues to be dedicated to his mission of clearing landmines & unexploded ordnance within his country. Sadly I also learnt that these weapons of destruction still exist in our world. Maybe one day...
Haunting. Cambodias history is at times unbearable to face. This was a wonderful inspiring place and I'm really glad I went.

Hair raising experience. Imagine you were present during the war, imagine landmines all around you, and bring yourself back to the present where you are safe. The museum was scary to me because of the landmines, but it was a good learning experience.

Educational. The thing I like best about this museum is that it supports further landmine clean up and poor Cambodian Children. The museum itself is interesting I've never seen a landmine before and learned a ton about what they look like, who makes them and uses them etc. it's a simple museum and won't take you long to go through - the gift shop has some beat items jewelry made from land mines and art from th children living there.I'd read there are often people there who share their experiences, but that was not the case on the Monday afternoon wee stopped by. We did see the museum founder come through with what looked like a group of employees training.

Makes you stop and think. This is an interesting place to visit. When first arrive you view a video concerning the work that has been done by the curator. He has spent a lot of time clearing mines and booby traps and UXBs without much assistance from the government. Most of the exhibits are of bombs rockets ammunition and mines that have been cleared. There are several photos also of the effects that mines can have on people which can be very confronting but is worth the visit.

Interesting . Good museum giving an insight into a problem which is really effecting Cambodia. Money goes towards demining and providing housing for disadvantaged young people from local villages too so all for a good cause

Sobering . I saw this place on the way back from Banteay Srei. We stopped for about 45 mins and wandered round.There are a number of exhibits of old weaponry and of course plenty of landmines. I'm definitely glad I went even if it was sad. It was great to learn about what went on (and is still going on). There was an American former serviceman there when I went...don't know if he's a permanent featured, but he was knowledgeable and friendly. It costs a few dollars to get in, but it goes towards making things better for Cambodians, so I was happy to pay it.
land mines. I did this trip out to the land mine museum 2 tears ago and I did the trip by tuk tuk. it was an eye opener.

Expensive, but for a good cause. I thought I'd gain a lot of understanding from this museum, but somehow, I didn't. It's a small place and there's really not much to see. When we were there, there was a group of Japanese students and their teacher, who was giving them an intense sounding lecture. We bought some jewellery purportedly made from recycled ammunition. This is a private museum, created by a Cambodian citizen who was part of the landmine clean-up. Entry is a bit expensive for what you get, but if it goes for the welfare of those affected by the landmines, it's for a good cause...

Broke my heart. What do you do when you walk into a museum and read about a war that you really never knew much about when it was happening (in the US it was kept pretty secret and away from the public) and so many people were hurt by your own country. One of the boards they have here show where bombs were dropped - describe how many people died and were maimed. I couldn't say anything, felt like crying.
Informative. Made me more aware of the reality and devastating impact these mines still have throughout Cambodia.
Sad and belongs to Cambodia. This is a very touching place and makes you sad or even cry. You will not meet anyone that has not lost a family member and they tell you the about it. Touching place....

An important visit. While many ppl are just in Siem Reap for the temples, this is an important stop to understand what Cambodians have lived to and continue to face. Listen to the full audio guide, and if you also have a guide we found ours was willing to answer many complex questions we had that were inspired by the museum.

Absolutely worth it! . This museum is small, but packed with great information! The entrance fee is $5. Kids under 12 are free. The audio tour is no additional charge, and it is very good. We (my husband and 11 and 13 year old sons) spent about an hour at the museum and my kids never complained. The museum helps fund a home and school for kids. Do not miss out on this informative and heart breaking (and warming) attraction.

Very interesting took me over 2hr's to see. We stopped off here after stopping just down the road a little bit at the butterfly farm first..and before we went 20 minutes further down the road at another Temple site which is in the week Temple pass sites and will let I use.again 3 in 7 days passABOUT HERE .NOTE it's a $5 US entery which goes to running this Museum and further XMO clearing and other things too.. ( what a great THAT $5 goes so far)..was meet at gate by every helpful young girl..( ALL THOSE who are writing up wrong notes about this private museum there is more than 1 war musuem in the Siem Reap area. So best not to be confused and do a bit better planning and trip advicer. .advice) as many notes on this trip advicer site is wrong and not for this place...Its mostly a personal tour.. with extra head sets if needed.. there are heaps of writtern up signs and history info..war stuff by the heaps.. I took my time to read it all. .plus there is about a 30 minute veido that is well worth taking the time to watch... there is a kids centre out back which is not open to tourist to disrupt them every 10 minutes.. for personal selfies..(which wont to make yourself feel better??)..YOU CAN MAKE FURTHER donations to clearing more land and even just but a T shirt which has a price factored in to clear more land..If your organised bring with you tooth brushes and cleaning paste ..soap.. kids thongs ..pens pencils .. any kids stuff..and donate it to the guy in the office at the entry or leave it with the girls at the fees entry box.. From what I can see the NGOs and Aid groups and red cross have instructed them not to let tourist interract with the kids any more as it's not good in the long term for this uncontrolled interaction that affects the kids to think every touriest has to give them something..all the time.1.Best to make a day trip is my advice.2. leave town very early in the morning stop off at 3 butterfly farm ..4 many interest road side sellers..along the way.. than this 5 XMO..was musium. .than go down the road to more 6 quieter temples.. and 7 more street farm sellers.. and return which every way you plan.. a full tuk tuk day trip. ..Heaps off interesting places to eat and buy cold drinks and fresh cocunut all the way...have a good day ..well worth the extra day to see.
hot day out. very interesting, it is worth going to support the locals, learn some history and enjoy the ride in the country side, we went by tuk tuk

Cambodians helping Cambodians. We saw this by accident and asked the driver to stop on the return fron Branley sire temple and we're glad we did.Here you can read and listen to the stories of a temputious past of Cambodia.Entrance fees and donations along with philanthropy support ensure the staff get a fair wage, children who have been affected by tradegy,an education while continuing to support the removal of land mines.A great story of hope

Educational and touching. A must visit place, especially if you want to have a feel of the human cost of war. The USD5 entrance fee goes to helping children affected by landmines, which is more reason to come and see the place. Recommended!

Amzing. We actually went to Bantey Srie temple, we passed this museum on the way and our taxi driver guide Hak has suggested us to visit because we drive back on the same way so we took his suggestion. We were glad we visited this amazing land mine museum. The place was so interesting. We learnt a lot about land mine in Cambodia during the war. We will remcomend this museum.

Sadness with hope. The stories here are sad but full of promise for the future. Aki Ra founded this place and has devoted his life to make life better for landmine victims and to make a safer Cambodia. The film and the exhibits are good but sometimes a little hard to follow in order. The audio explanations are excellent.I am glad I visited this place for the insightful information about a tragic time in Cambodian history.

History lessons. If you want to know more about the terrible history of Cambodia during the Khmer Rouge period visit this little museum on the way to Kbal Spean. It is very informative with one of the best audio tours. The entrance fee is for a good cause and I think it was only $5 afterwards you can donate some money to.Look at the photo in my review as they have a wishlist there. I wish I knew this before I visited because all of the hotels we stayed in provided toothbrushes and soap so it would been really easy to donate! Please see if you can give them anything of their wishes, some a really small!

Obsessive labour of love. I do not mean "obsessive" in a bad way. "Aki Ra", the founder's adopted name, established his unique museum of war weaponry, including landmines, to show the world the horrors of war; war that he experienced himself as a child and, then, adult soldier for, amongst other governments, the infamous Khmer Rouge.The museum itself deserves a good hour, or longer if you wish to read the texts scattered around the buildings.Equally important is Aki Ra's orphanage and school, off limits to the casual visitor, behind the Museum itself.Aki Ra no longer clear landmines himself, but supports those who do. Is there work left to do? Yes!Cambodian Mine Action Centre (CMAC) estimates that there a re between four and six million landmines and unexploded ordinance in Cambodia today. Yes, 4 to 6 million!For those with an ironic sense of humour (probably like Aki Ra himself), you can buy soap in the shape of a landmine in the Museum's gift shop: a unique gift.People normally take in the Landmine Museum on the way to or from some of the other temples outside the main Angkor Wat archaeological area.

Visit a different Educational Spot. While visiting Cambodia and viewing the astonishing Angkor Temples, knowing about the war ravaged recent history and the scars that the innumerable landmines had, would give you better insight of this country....specially since this is a privately run museum funded by tourist donations

Disappointing and not worth the visit. I read about this place online and was excited to go out there and learn about the landmines and the children in the orphanage. Under the relief center it said that if you were visiting there was a wish list for the children so we went shopping and brought toothbrushes, pens, pencils, combs etc to take out for the children. It is quite a way out and a bit rough in a tuk tuk. On arrival it cost 5.00US to get in each which is expensive for Cambodia entrance fees. The girl at the front desk appeared not to speak English, which is fine, but that doesn't mean she cant look up at us and at least smile or acknowledge us, we nearly left then.We were totally underwhelmed by the place, it was small and rundown, there is no argument that the work that Aki Ra has done in clearing landmines is fantastic but the museum actually lets his good work down.My husbands audio headphones didn't work so he took them back to the girl at the entrance who was now asleep and didn't seem happy she was woken, she swapped the headphones but put the ones that didn't work back on the shelf for the next person. There were plenty of donation boxes in this small museum that consisted of 4 tiny rooms and I did see a wish list on the wall but nowhere that encouraged us to leave the items we brought, it seemed money was more what they wanted.I understand that the orphanage is the children's home and that it is not appropriate for tourists to be visiting the children but I did think that we possibly could have visited part of the orphanage to see the work that is being done for the children and learn about the lives of these children without interrupted the kids (as the websites says when you visit the relief center). I did read on a sign that all children go on to do a trade or study at university but where were the stories about what these individuals have achieved. While I was standing there Bill from the relief center came out of the museum and I was standing at the gate by the relief center reading the sign, I smiled at him hoping to make conversation and thinking maybe he would stop and talk and I could pass on our supplies we had brought but he rudely ignored me and brushed passed and open the gate through to the orphanage without so much of any acknowledgement. I thought he was totally rude especially when they are wanting support from visitors. We then went in to the room where they were selling paintings to make money and the women in there couldn't even look up so we left and took the supplies we brought with us.I felt this place actually gave a bad reputation of orphanages in Cambodia and a lot of work is needed to make this museum enjoyable.

Shocking, eye-opening and informative. We had heard about this museum and it had good reviews on here so decided to visit. We were so glad we did. It's quite a way outside of Siem Reap city, but the tuk-tuk ride in the breeze was lovely! When we arrived, we were shocked to find that all of the ordnance collected was the work of ONE man! There must be tens of thousands of pieces, mostly different sorts of landmine. You learn a lot about this man, Akira (nicknamed so by the Japanese but a Cambodian former child-soldier) and his history mirrors the history of Cambodia. I was shocked to learn that Cambodia was carpet-bombed during the Vietnam War purely because Ho Chi Minh used the country to boost his supply line in Vietnam. What's worse, is the sheer amount of landmines left buried and live all over Cambodia. Anyway, you don't need to hear the tales from me, you need to visit the museum and hear them yourself, as well as see what war does.It is 100% worth visiting this museum.

A somber truth about the tragic history. Very well put together museum highlighting the horrors from history and war. Your heart goes out to all the innocent victims who have been dealt a short straw in life and who have had their lives changed forever by no fault of their own.

Don't Miss If You're Headed to Banteay Srei. It's small, it's hot (no AC), it's extremely humble, but don't miss this place - especially if you're on the road up to Banteay Srei. It's a great (if sobering) history lesson in the tragedy of land mines in Cambodia, how they got to be there, and what is now being done to remove them. You learn about the different groups and countries responsible for placing the land mines, as well as the countries and organizations today working to remove them. The story of the man who began the museum, Aki Ra (originally when he took it upon himself to begin removing landmines) is very inspiring. It also feels good to know that the entrance fee you pay goes towards removing more land mines and improving the lives of the people in the area. If you can, give a little extra by purchasing from the gift store.

Wheelchair accessibility (2016). Informative attraction that is mostly accessible. Entrance fee $US6. Some distance from Siem Reap, but you can combine this with a visit to the Butterfly farm and Banteay Srei (Womens temple).
Moving. The audio tour is very well done and the proceeds go to educating children with disabilities and further demining. An absolute must for anyone interested in the history of the region.

Go here to hear the real story of the mines and be deeply touched about the work for victims. The museum is about 40 minutes by Tuk-Tuk away from Siem Reap, not around the corner but definitely worth going. The stories of the children that are victims from landmines are hart breaking but so great to see how this museum helps them built a future. Still over 100 people a year get injured by landmines and UXO, this museum helps clearing mines and supports young victims - so go there learn and help the musuem with their great challenge.

Do stop and contribute! . My knowledge about land mines was almost zero. On the way to Banteay srei, one of the temples in cambodia, our tuk tuk driver, Mr Kim, made a stop here. It is a small museum i'd say. U do hv to oay entrance fee but its mostly dedicated to help the landmines victims. The museum was educational to me. The posters, pictures, demos and videos were very helpful in understanding the history and ongoing process of landmines cleansing. The museum also provides audio guide which u could get at the entrance for free. The museum has a few boxes for keen donors. U are most welcome to donate and help them to keep Cambodians safe from landmines.

Wake Up Call in the House of Landmines. The place, the country, the history - they will bring you to tears. The ugliest faces of the war and its aftermath. It shall enlighten your heart - for you to be appreciative of peace and loveRecommendation: Go with an open heart. Donate at your own will with your utmost capabilities. Cambodia is growing as a better nation, but she can surely use some extra helps from all of the world

Good Museum Clarifying Cambodia's History. Set within Angkor Park but away from Siem Reap you travel through the Cambodian countryside to get to the museum. Low cost entry which includes audio guide, although useful you could just read the words if you didn't want to listen. Well laid our. Explains the story of Aki Rah who made it his job to rid Cambodia of this terrible legacy. A very important place to go and learn about Cambodia's history.

Informative history and touching stories. As a teenager, I usually am not that interested with historical museum (such as the national ang'kor museum which bored me to death). Firstly, the landmine museum has a few small rooms and a yard area with a few posters. The rooms contained a lot of information about the Cambodian War against the Khmer Rouge, with quite a lot of insight from the founder Aki Ra as he participated in the war fighting for the Khmer Rouge, Vietnamese army and Cambodian national army. A lot of fascinating stories were shared and a lot was learnt. The posters in the yard displayed stories of people from different countries, how they saved others despite their differences.  Secondly, a lot of landmines, uxos and bombshells were displayed, also some weapons and a bomb disarming suit. There were a large variety of all of these. There were also a landmine simulation and some art constructed with weapons. Thirdly, it was very inspiring to see what Aki Ra was doing and how he was contributing to the society. I pay huge respect to him. Though he hurt a lot of people with landmines he planted, he is now helping a lot of unfortunate children whom are in need. Reading all the messages written by the children to Aki Ra really allowed me to understand how much heart Aki Ra has given to help these children, how badly the children's situations were and how much their lifes have changed after they were brought to the museum. I would definitely recommend others to visit this museum. Unfortunately, I didn't use the audio guide which means I might have missed out. It's worthy of your time and really help with the understanding of the landmine situation and the history of the war.

Necessary & important place to visit. The land mine museum was a heart-rending yet heart-warming place to visit. This modest yet extremely informative museum should be on every tourist to Siem Reap's list. It shines a light on the endemic problem of land mines both throughout the world and particularly in Cambodia, and tells the story of one man's mission in life to disarm land mines and heal the hurts caused by them.

Very Interesting. We stopped here on the way back from one of the Temples. Its really interesting with some personal stories included.. 10 year olds being given rifles .... There are guides available..Did buy my husband a land mine soap... a gift that helps land mine victims
great visit. small museum but very informative and effective.. definitely made me think..children also learned about the war too.. well worth a visit.

a must see in Cambodia. amazing what man can do to man (and still does)
This museum pulls no punches and the guided tour makes sure you understand the continuing pain of this dreadful landmine business

Moving & necessary place for learning about Cambodia past and present. What is good about this museum is that it is both impressive (lots of original bombs, mines, guns... displayed), pedagogical (with panels, information about landmines manufacturers, and today's users; information about past and present methodologies to remove the mines etc) and moving (personal testimonials, pictures etc). What an extraordinary man, A Kira, who founded this place! You can read a lot about his story in the museum. All the collected funds including the tickets fees (+ products sold a the museum shop) are used to support children in need who live in a center just next to the museum. We had the chance to exchange with a volunteer guide in the museum who was very knowledgeable and eager to share with the visitors.

Quiet small but interesting museum. This small museum consist of only 3 or 4 small rooms, might be small but full of historical information mainly about landmines in Cambodia and the civil war and even the Vietnam war and many kinds of mines and shells (yuo can spend one hour only reading the important information in each room), also there is a small video room showing the efforts of demining, how it costly, how it done and how it's dangerious you pay 5$ for entrance and it all goes for the demining efforts so it's another good reason to visit it.

Small but very informative museum. I visited the Landmine museum as an add on to the tour I had arranged with my Ankor Wat tuktuk driver. This is a small but informative museum created by former child soldier Aki Ra who fought for the Khmer Rouge from age 5 after they killed his parents. He later defected to the Vietnamese army and has since spent many years performing very dangerous job of clearing landmines. He is estimated to have cleared over 50,000 land mines and pieces of unexploded ordnance and this museum houses a few thousand of these (fully deactivated - don't panic!). Millions of landmines still scatter areas of Cambodia, leaving thousand of adults and children severely injured, and this museum explains why clearing them is such a difficult task. Aki Ra has also set up a free school for children affected by landmines. In one of the rooms you can read their touching stories, in their own words, on how they came to live at the school, what their life is like now, and what they hope for the future. The museum is a little out the way but I learned a lot from my visit and recommend spending an hour or so here.
Eye-opening. An eye-opening experience started by an inspirational character. Whilst it is only a small museum it tells an important story of the history and current situation in Cambodia.

Landmine history. To learn the history of landmine in Cambodia and how AkiRa have worked for several years to take these landmines in the area which caused both young and adult losing their legs/hands. What a sad history it was.

Heartbreaking and highly recommended. This museum provides a gripping exploration of the tragedy of war, as well as of the remarkable humanity demonstrated by the founder and others who dedicate themselves to clearing Cambodian lands of these deadly weapons. There is certainly pain on display, but the work this foundation does both to prevent new tragedies and to support children at risk is awe-inspiring. Absolutely worth visiting and supporting.

emotional but a must. The landmine museum is about a 40 min tuk tuk ride from the main town but well worth it. It is incredible and truly inspiring to see the work this one individual has done but also heartbreaking knowing the struggle will be forever ongoing. Get the audio commentary as it helps explain the historic events.

Poignant . Wasn't really sure if this was for me but really glad I went. Very poignant with a lot of very sad stories. Shocking to think people are still being killed and maimed in this day and age from land mines. Very informative and interesting and would definitely recommend everyone should pay a visit here.

Landmine museum. So sad to see the evil of landmines yet wonderful to witness the amazing work in clearing them. A must see addition to your temple tours. Well worth the five dollar entrance fee. Use the audio guide provided.

Eye opening. It was scary to see the number of landmines they have on display the minute you walk in. The museum had so much history and showed you how much work is being done to clean up the landmines in Cambodia.

Kept in the Dark. What can you say about a country riddled with landmines. A child is killed almost every day when they are illegally trying to find unexploded ordnance to sell to scrapmetal dealers so their family can survive.

A real eye opener . A very informative trip. The entrance fee is used towards helping the landmine victims. This trip really put into perspective the enormity of the landmine situation in Cambodia and how this has affected so many lives. Hopefully this will be a lesson to the leaders of countries to think about how the lives of innocent civilians are affected.

Curiosity. It was all about this Soldier who once planted the landmines and now is repenting by helping to remove them and helping children. My partner felt emotional after a few minutes so we had to leave. A little tacky because they were selling soap in the form of landmines
Welcome to the real Cambodian World. The presentation was stunning for all the right & wrong reasons, and a highly recommended experience

The ongoing legacy of the Khmer Rouge....... This museum gives information about land mines in Cambodia, and how one man set out to get rid of them, despite having been a child soldier and placing some of the mines in the first place. It it tells real people's stories about their lives after being damaged by a mine.

Very informative and amazing NGO!. Came to see the landmine museum and for more information on the NGO! The guide that we had was American and he told us about his background with the landmine museum. Very proud of the work that they are doing to de-mine mines in Cambodia! Keep up the great work!
Compelling. Learned more about a dark time in Cambodia's history and the heroic efforts to both clear land mines and help child- victims of land mines. Watch the video-- very informative.

Tourists Did You Know?. This place is depressing. However, I felt that it needed to be visited. The museum is small but informative. It is on the way to the temples of Banteay Srei. It takes a while to get there, but it is worth it if you have the time. There are many, many land mines still in Cambodia. There have been many victims of land mines. Unfortunately, there are more and more people still being killed or hurt. As you walk around Siem Reap and the temples of Angkor, you will see many bands of street musician who have been injured by land mines. Please stop and listen; donate what you can; and buy a CD to take home.

The sad reality. This is a sad place to visit. But it is nevertheless a part of the reality of Cambodia. It is a small museum, only four small rooms dedicated to the stories of victims, survivors and heroes of the landmines that litter areas of Cambodia as a result of the war and Khmer rouge regime. The displays are not like the kind you'd see in a large "professional" museum. But rather, many are handwritten on yellowed paper, tacked to the walls. The central showcase of landmines is an eerie sight. Behind the visitor area there are private areas where landmine victims live, work and learn. It's a somber place but it's good to know that people are being helped there.

Land mine museum. A very sobering experience - well worth the journey. Lovely route through Temple area to get there. Great work done by Aki Ra with clearing land mines and supporting at risk children

Aki Ra - A hero in his own right. If one wish to know about troublesome history of Cambodia, one should definitely visit Cambodia Landmine museum. One will sympathise with people of Cambodia and definitely feel sorry for them. This is a place where I heard about Aki Ra - who is now one of my heroes. His acts are worth infinite applause and awards.

Not that great. It's a great cause, however, was greatly underwhelmed. Quite a way out of the way which does not help. Information interesting but nothing you cannot read about in more comfort online.
interesting. it tells you about the landmines that are you still being found today and you can see the different sort of landmines,bombs and a few guns need

Good museum outside Siem Reap. We decided to take a ride to the museum, without visiting Banteay Sreai - tired of temples. Ride from the long-tour was about 30-40 minutes (pretty long), but it was worth it because you get to see some of the country side outside the touristy areas - there was a brick making factory and a wood-processing place (difficult to call them factories). The museum was itself small, the entrance fee was 5 dollars, but most of it goes to living of children that had suffered from land mines. They had a audio guide, which was very well spoken by a USA man, who I believe lives in the museum. The essays by the children who are housed there almost made me cry - very sad place, but it's totally worth it, because you feel the pain of the Cambodian people from the war. Highly recommend.
Worth a visit. Tells a lot about the recent war history. All the things that every tourist in Cambodia needs to know when visiting this beautiful country.

Worth the vidit. Worth taking a tuk tuk/remork out to see this museum.The scenery on the way is beautiful.The museum itself is informative and the entrance fee goes towards lots of good causes like schools for children. They have an on-site school too. I enjoyed learning the story about the man who set the museum up and the terrible landline situation and the work that is going into resolving the problem. I do feel that the maintenance and cleaning of the museum could be improved - maybe some volunteers would be happy to help out with that?

Revisit the Cambodian Past. Siem Reap is a fantastic place to visit. There are so many inspiring Prasats of the last millennium. For a break, during the trip to Banteay Srei and Phnom Kulen, you may also take a short visit to the Cambodia Landmine Museum, reminding ourselves the harsh path that Cambodians just recently passed through, reminding ourselves that there are so many works the Cambodian still need to do to become a "normal" country and inspired by the indomitable will of some people to do so.
very interesting. Great place to get to know history. Easy self paced with relics and informative boards. Small shop for souvenirs included.

Informative and Important. This museum is a definite must if you're on the way back from Banteay Srey. It gives great information about the wars and problems in Cambodia's past, present, and future. Interactive displays and some of the guides are fantastic

heartbreaking but worth visiting. this museum is run by a man who, during the war, layed landmines.. and now he has taken his expertise to help remove them and save lives and limbs all over the country. worth going to. Our driver Rithy Bou, who is also a landmine survivor, took us here and it was totally worth the few dollars to walk around and see.

Grim, very interesting. We were very lucky with our visit, as an American Vietnam veteran (Bill Morse, I think) had just started doing a tour when he arrived. His knowledge and anecdotes enlivened our visit.I'm not sure what visiting this museum would be like if you don't have the advantage of Bill; but many of the audio tours in Cambodia are good, and these are available here.

Very informative - worth the trip. Given the huge impact of landmines in Cambodia this museum is definitely worth a visit. A lot of displays and an excellent free audio guide. What a story Aki Ra has to tell - and what a hero. A reasonably long tuk tuk ride from Siem Reap, this could be incorporated into a trip to Banteay Srey and/or the Butterfly Centre. $5 entry fee - a tiny price to pay for such a worthy cause.

Impressive. Very special museum which is situated right next to the school.Impressive audio and graphics are really showing the problems Cambodia has with the mines in the country.Not the standard museum, thats what really worth visiting it.

Support their cause. The museum is a long way from Siem Reap but a good place to stop and visit while visiting local temples. It is not a large museum and does not take long to look around. There is a lot of information and stories to read within the museum. Proceeds from the $5 admission goes towards clearing landmines and helping those that have been affected.

Informative of the dangers of the mines and explanations. A good experience to inform yourself of what happened in Cambodia of recent history. Wasn't really aware of what was going or went on in Cambodia until after this museum. Highly recommend to visit if your in the area.

The drive out is also a highlight. Small museum about 45 minutes by tuk tuk out of Siem Reap. Drive out past the rice fields and through local villages gives a glimpse of the real Cambodia. The work still being done to remove land mines in Cambodia is inspirational.
Eye Opening. I wasn't sure what to expect visiting here. Though small I think it was worth the entry to see what war has left this country.

Sad reality. This place gives you a much better understanding of the cruelty this Culture has endured, and still are enduring. Its a Shame that peoples taxes pay for these cruel inventions!
When will this ever stop?

Eye opener . Worth visiting - we had a very knowledgable American called Bill who gave a comprehensive account of the Landmine situation and the effects ....I hadn't really realised how many were left and what devastation they have wreaked ...
Felt I had a much deeper understanding and the charitable trust seems to be making s difference .
So glad we went
Interesting. Good display of the weapons and machinery used in the regime. A nice outing to take a break from temple-hopping.
Interesting stop. A very interesting stop on the way to/from Banteay Srey. The free audio tour is well done. Well worth the stop if you have the time.
Amazing. It was a very depressing visit with the solemn material at hand. It was great to get more information and to support an organization who want to help people affected by land mines.

An important place to stop. Mines are truly an evil concept and their production remains the disgrace of some countries As ever it is left to the ordinary people to suffer and sort out the mess after warWe had a good tour by one of the team, bill morse , who had a few gems educating on the whole sad history of conflict in Cambodia. 20% of bombs/ordinance doesn't go off. So how the USA/UK/Russia and its pals can still go on with huge bombing campaigns is bad. They politicians need a walk around this place. Very moving. Give generously please.

A very important cause. If you are going to visit Banteay Srey you are going to pass right by the landmine museum -stop and check it out. This began as one man's quest to rid Cambodia of landmines,which is still a big part of it, and has morphed into an organization that provides schooling and care for children affected by landmines. A very worthy cause ,spend a little time here and you will be affected by what you will learn.

Amazing collection of land mines and bombs. Mr. Aki Ra a veteran of Cambodia's civil war and an expert on land mines has built up this museum in his own house to educate people about land mines and it's devastating effect on innocent civil population. There is a good collection of land mines and bombs.

Enlightening. An amazing story and an enlightening history of the challenges of the Cambodian people wr to the vast number of land mines planted through the the years. This is a small museum with a 5 entry fee. Worth stopping to see if you are heading elsewhere but not likely a destination itself given its 40 minutes or so out of town.

Very moving, highly informative, well organised. The museum was well-organised and provided easy- to-understand audio-guides (which were free with admission). The exhibitions gave insights into the history of land mines as well as current demining efforts. It took around 30 minutes to look at all sections of the museum and could be done before or after a visit to other sites such as Angkor Wat which is about 30km from the museum.

Visited with A group of Australian students.... I visited the Museum with a school group from Australia and it was an incredible experience. We had no idea about the amount of mines still in the ground and the extent of the bombing during the Vietnam War by the US etc... Bill was an amazing guide. The stories he told were both moving and engaging. Akira and his team are real life heroes!

And then the pain. At first I just thought this would be another day in the museum kind of thing but it wasn't, l the pain the people are exposed to every time a landmine is set off, the millions being used to detonate them compared to the hundreds even tens to make them. Good cycle tour too, about 5th before banteay srei and totally worth it

Interesting Museum. We enjoyed this small museum, which is perhaps more the story of one man's quest to rid Cambodia of landmines. The free audio tour is worthwhile since it provides more context to what you are seeing. My girlfriend and I saw the museum and listened to most of the audio in about 30-40 mins.

Sombre reminder of history. It's easy to be a tourist and justify the cocktails and pool side experience as needing a break from our busy lives at home. But engaging and learning about the history of the place is important, especially in a country that has had such a sad past as Cambodia. The nation is making giant strides but learning that there are millions of unexplored landlines still is confronting. The money raised from this museum goes towards land mine recovery and disposal, as well as contributing to the children's centre that looks after sick, wounded or orphaned children. This place is definitely worth a visit.If you don't want to make a trip just for this, consider combining it with a trip to the lovely Butterfly farm and Banteay Srei - it's a nice half day trip by car.

Interesting end educating. Great visit not only telling about the landmines but also about Cambodian history.We took a tuk tuk for 10$ (taking us there and back) and spend approx. an hour or so at the museum. Definitly worth a visit.
Confronting. Great little museum educating and raising money to remove landmines and educate children. Well worth a visit on a day trip to Banteay Srie.

An eyeopener. Our visit to the Landmine museum was an eye opener to Cambodia's history. We went from Siem Reap by Tuk Tuk which cost US$25 to and from the museum. . The cost of the museum was US$5, if you leave ID at the entrance the audio guide is free Proceeds from the gift shop and entry to the museum goes to the orphanage which is next to thee museum.A bonus to visiting the Landmine museum was to travel through Cambodia's countryside in a Tuk Tuk., you travel through some villages and passed rice paddies and seen local kids riding their bikes. I would recommend a visit to this museum

A small museum started by one man's grandiose efforts. Must visit.. Hats off to Aki Ra and his team for the selfless work being done there. A small museum with stories that will stick with you for life. Very informative .

heart wrenching. don't go with high expectations of something spectacular. it is a very simple museum which tells the heart wrenching agony undergone by the cambodian people with reference to the landmines. it is a simplistic narrative about why it happened and what is happening now.

Educational Stop. Work the time to stop by this on the way to or from the Lady Temple. Very educational stop. Only 5 USD entry and you learn a lot about the landmine and how they remove them. Get the audio guide.

Understanding Cambodian reality. An excellent museum that reflects on the horrors of landmines in Cambodia. Allow a couple of hours to walk through the self guided walk or listen to an excellent commentary provided by the staff. It's a really enjoyable 30 minute drive by tuk tuk through the countryside and villages to get to the museum. Definitely a must see.

An interesting insight to an important chapter of Khmer history. The Landmine Museum is a long way out of Siem Reap - I think it was a $20 tuktuk ride return journey. Given this investment I would have liked to get more information about the clearing of landmines in Cambodia, the contribution that has been made by Cambodia to the technology of mine clearance and latest developments in the rate of clearance possible. My husband also commented that he would have liked to have had more information on how landmines are put together. The museum is an interesting reflection of one person's valuable mission in Cambodia but could be so much more given the extent of the clearing operations for Cambodia.
Meaningful. This is an excellent museum, but it is definitely a sad one. It is a little outside of town, but it is definitely worth the trip and the $5 entry fee.

Recent History of Cambodia. If you are coming to Cambodia its hard not to visit this Museum. It tries to show you just what happened during the civil war and the aftermath of the mines.There you can see all the different mines and get an idea of the techniques they used to use to clear minefields. You also see statistics of how many people, up until last year are still being injured from these weapons.The museum is self funded so its not big or fancy but it is educational.
too sad but interesting. Landmine Museum was stay on the way go to Lady temple .you just spend 5$ for ticket go in there .Had many kind of mine on the world .they was found many of cambodia .

Story behind and what it showcases are quite a worth parts of the visit. Honestly, the structure of the Museum is not that impressive - Too small and simple. But the story behind and what it showcases are quite a worth parts of the visit.

Very eye-opening experience. The place is a must to see when you are in Siem Reap! It is really tragic how much landmines there are in Cambodia, but also in other countries! The most impressive and touching is Mr. Aki Ra with his unconditional dedication to mine removal. Once as a child who had to place the mines, he has been the main driver to start mine removal in Cambodia over the last couple of decades.

Unique. Great job done by the team that worked so hard to unearth myriads of landmines from the wilderness. This museum showcases a wide variety of landmines deactivated in the region and saved so many lives. A good break from the monotony of temples and more temples. A good-to-visit.

Make a Donation. I found this place VERY interesting. I had no idea of the extent of injury and damage and destruction that the landmines have caused to the innocent people of Cambodia. The audio guide is really interesting and eye opening. Aki Ra is a truly incredible man - he has dedicated his life to clearing the landmines in Cambodia - he is an inspiration. If you can not donate buy something from the shop, the proceeds go to a fabulous cause.

Worthy of a visit.. It won't hurt to understand just how truly horrifying land mines have been for the people of Cambodia. If nothing else, the small $5 ticket goes to support the care and welfare of those injured by the mines and the orphaned children who live on the site.

Very educational and great audio. Spent over an hour here yesterday morning. Abt a 30min tuk tuk ride from SR centre but i loved seeing everything and immersing in the culture even more. Museum was hot!! Not to busy in the morn. Take a photo id for a free audio tour guide. I am shocked at what I did not know abt the severity of landmines in cambodia...i will never forget what i learned. A must visit if u are really interessted but I still preferred the war museum and it was closer to town.

Excellent look at the Land Mine problems over the last thirty years. make sure you get a guide when you come in, Bill and American whom has devoted his life to Cambodia is a fabulous guide and takes tours through the museum and will answer any questions. There is a great range of UXO and Landmines all identified. The museum entry fee supports a proper Cambodian run school and orphanage out the back. As it is quite a trip from Siem Reap in a Tuk Tuk, $20 not out of the question, make it a full day by visting the Womens Temple nearby and stop along the way and visit the Sugar Palm climbing villages and basket weaving stalls along the way. For the more adventurous ask the lady stall owners to have lunch and visit a village especially in low season

Really interesting museum with a very personal feel. This museum is great. It gives you humbling insight into Cambodia's tragic recent history whilst simultaneously reinforcing your faith in humanity by highlighting the amazing efforts of the many modern-day heroes involved in the safe removal of landmines and support of landmine victims. You will see many different types of landmines, all real and all personally recovered by Aki Ra, who founded the museum. For me, the most moving bit was reading essays and seeing artwork by young landmine victims who grew up at the museum, under Aki Ra and his wife's care.

Worth the trip. I loved this place. It taught me so much that I did not know about the lasting effects that the Cambodian people have been through! I loved that it is pitched from a historical and political point of view, not a sob story even though the stories are horrifying.I also love that they use the entry fee for good and explain to you exactly how it is used.Also the history behind the man who established it is fascinating. A remarkable man who is doing remarkable things for his country!

Worth a vist. We combined this with a day trip to Kbal Spean and Banteay Srei. The entrance fee is $5, This is used to support the attached children's centre, help with projects to improve life in small villages and to clear land mines, as well as the upkeep of the museum so it is money well spent. The museum gives lots of information. The audio guides were very good - they are free but you need to leave a photo ID as a deposit. Although there is still a lot more to be done, it was good to learn that the number of deaths and injuries caused by landmines in Cambodia is decreasing.

A challenging but worth while experience. The land mine museum is some distance from Siem Reap but is well worth the effort. The layout encourages not simply curiosity in the exhibits on display but reflection on the story that is told on the notice boards in each room. Art work and objects testify to the reality of the Khmer Rouge years and the story of the man who, as a boy was trained to place land mines and as an adult used his skills to uncover and remove them is remarkable. The balance of horror and dignity that is present here will challenge even the toughest visitor.

Very impressive what a change one man can make,. We visited the museum on our way back from bantaey srei.. Together this is a good half day trip and we thought it was very worth it.The landmine museum is impressive in the way that it shows what one man can achieve. It is informative and also quite educating on how landmine work, where they are from and what damage they did and still do to the people living in cambodia.I think it is a must do if you are interested in cambodia.

not much to see. it was a 50 km (approx.) trip by tok tok from siem reap to get there $10 dollars I think for admission and to be honest its abit off a ripoff, I was there for about 15 minutes and had seen everything

Well presented museum. We visited this museum on the way back from bantreay srei temple. It is well laid out and is very informative of what happened in the war, how this has affected Cambodian people and how it will affect them in the future. The entrance to this museum is about GBP 2 and goes towards helping the Cambodian people incapacitated from landmines and removing remaining landmines. I would recommend this to all visitors to gain an insight into the history but to also help the people, especially when the entrance fee is so low. I take my hat off to the people who remove and destroy these landmines.
sady and interesting. A lot the mine was different come from many country that time red Khmer .Landmine Museum was interesting with history and very sad

you ought to go.. We visited the museum after seeing Banaey Seri. It was very eye-opening. I kind of had an idea about landmines in Cambodia but I realised very quickly how little I knew once stepping into the museum. Its a pretty no-frills affair but that should not, and does not, detract from the depth of important information the museum shares. The museum essentially tells the story of one man's efforts to get rid of landmines and provides the contextual information relating to the Khmer Rouge, US bombings, etc. The entrance fee of 10usd goes towards helping those affected by landmines, as does the proceeds from the gift shop.

Interesting and Tragic. We stopped here on our last day in Cambodia. It is a small museum but really packed with information. Heartbreaking and eye opening - I hope every traveller in Cambodia takes the time to visit

Informative and Interesting. Our family really enjoyed our visit to the Museum and highly recommend combining it with a visit to Banteay Srei. We hired a TukTuk (USD20.00) and found the trip to get there both relaxing and a nice way to see the countryside.The museum was very interesting and as others have noted you will be supporting a good cause.Our kids (14 and 16) both talked about it on numerous occasions and it really struck a note with our son in particular. In fact he much preferred it to visiting temples.

Must see helps there great work . This museum is only small but it really opens your eyes on the history of Cambodia 's brutal past. Get the earphones and key in the operate number and it fills you in on all the different types of bombs and story lines about the running of the center. Give yourself around 1 hour for this visit.

Grim reminder of our social responsibility. while exploring temples its easy to forget that Cambodia has a very violent past.. one that has left many families torn and desperate. The Landmine museum serves as a grim reminder of a country trying to right itself.. trying to rebuild after everything.. and that the country side is still a serious risk in some places.

The sad side of Cambodia!. Located near Siem Reap this is worth the stop on your return from the Lady Temple. It depicts one mans life as a victim of the wars that surrounded him and his transition to helping his nation move on. This shows the rudimentary mine detecting through to modern NGO's trying to remove landmines and bombs. Landmines have reeked havoc on an innocent nation and still do!Looking at this display makes you want to help in some way. There is an school attached to the centre that teaches children injured by mine explosions. There is a list inside the door that asks for donations of equipment for these students. Begging is frowned upon in Cambodia but school supplies toothpaste and brushes sandals etc are welcome donations. Other contributors may be more eloquent and descriptive on the museum, however I was struck by the plight of the kids

Well worth the visit. Apart from educating us about man's inhumanity to man, we were shocked to realise that the US still uses landmines. Demining is still ongoing throughout Cambodia and farmers are still losing limbs when ploughing new fields, although most tourist spots have been cleared. There are some good souvenirs at the shop (landmine soaps etc) that help fund demining and other projects aimed at helping those affected by mines.

Amazing owner and story, lackluster experience. We came to the museum late on a Friday afternoon. The museum is farther from siem than I expected, but it is an interesting tuk tuk ride through small villages. It can get dusty, so bring something to cover your face. The information covered here is very moving. We did not see the English speaking guide mentioned in other reviews. Also, remember to bring photo ID. We were not able to rent the audio tour because we left our ID at the hotel, even though we offered a cell phone or money for collateral. Would have liked more interaction with the staff, but it could have been bad timing. Still worth a visit!
Inocent victims. A sad but interesting window on Cambodia's tragic recent history.A small museum but well worth a visit. The modest entrance fee will help to clear more mines.

A good place to see a piece of the dramatic dark ages of Cambodia. A small museum where are gathered some remaining of all the possible landmines used in Cambodia with all the damages it had caused to the people and the land. All well supplied by China, the USA, Russia.... Also a place to think about the human creativity in matters of wars and pain.

A good stop after Banteay Srei. I've been at the landmine museum several times, and have always found it interesting. It's located about ten minutes (by car) away from Banteay Srei, so it's a good place to stop on your way to or from that temple. This is a small museum and probably needs only 30-45 minutes to explore. But, it's an important place, at it provides an excellent overview as to an unfortunate but significant part of Cambodia's history.The entrance fee is only a few dollars, and by buying a ticket, you'll be supporting a good cause. -- John Shors, bestselling author of Temple of a Thousand Faces: A Novel of Angkor Wat
good to see. this was interesting history very sad that time red khmer about 40 years ago ,Have a lot kind of Mine on the wold they was found many place in cambodia .

A museum with spirit. I was surprised at how I was touched with emotion and found this visit to be spiritual. You must spend time here to grasp what the local people endured and how it is is still a serious factor they deal with. Knowing an area or field is safe to walk through must be amazing. Americans don't have to think about this and I found myself being grateful for basic safety. They run a small school here and could use practical donations so give what you can. They are doing good work here.

A must visit for all those interested in the history of Cambodia, the Vietnam War and the Khymer Rouge.. A small but excellent museum built on temple grounds. Admission is $5.00. You will find many types of ammunition and land mines. It tells you the history of one of the men who planted many of the mines then changed sides in the war and helped the people find the mines that he had planted. His house is beside the museum.

Poignant and Interesting. Such a profound and honorable little museum on the outskirts of town. Was a welcome detour from the crowds at Angkor and gave good insight into Cambodia's brutal and recent past. Lots of good information on landmines, Cambodian's involvement in the Vietnam war, and what is being done today to make the country safer. $5 USD entry, and would recommend donating a bit more if you can afford it.The landmine museum is about a 45 minute tuk-tuk ride from the center of Siem Reap, but a beautiful drive through a more rural scene, and very close to Banteay Srei temple. I would highly recommend visiting both in the late afternoon, as a nice (and less crowded) way to end the day. We were at the museum from about 3:30pm to 4:30pm and were the only ones there, then headed to Banteay Srei from 4:45pm to 5:30pm and only saw about 15 other people at the temples. Really enjoyed the ride home through villages at dusk.

Really interesting place and amazing story. Good museum with lots and lots of bombs / bullets / mines etc to grab the attention. However it is the story of the people impacted that really gets the attention - well worth the trip from Siem Riep.

Veri interesting but VERY hot. The story of the genocide period is one you simply can't escape in Cambodia and this museum is an example in a very in your face way of the terrible atrocities of the time. there are only four rooms to walk through but beware there is not air conditioning or even fans and no toilet facilities so make sure you are prepared.

Land Mine museum - get Senyth as a guide. The land Mine museum is looking a bit tired, very tired actually as most of the exhibits as rusting hulks. BUT if you are lucky enough to get Senyth as your guide you will have a most informative and entertaining visit. They call him the cat as he should have been dead multiple times, but somehow he has survived. He has multiple shrapnel pieces visibly imbedded in him and the toll of war on him is abundantly clear from the missing lower leg to the loss of sight, a remarkable man whose life has been captured by author ? Levy who I was lucky enough to meet at the Museum while I was there.

Educational and worth the visit. This location is a bit out of town but it is something that is unique in Siem Reap. On display are hundreds of landmines (inactive), which have been removed from around the country. The center director used to be a Khmer Rouge soldier and now dedicates his life to removing land mines and, educating people who come to his center.I learned a lot about the worldwide problem of landmines after visiting here.

Great museum. Logical follow-through, good information, great audio guide (if a little out of order with the display - listen to the lot first and then go see the museum). Fantastic little museum, if very sobering in content. Glad I went. Took over two hours, but most people would take up to one.

Small museum. This was a small museum that explains a lot about Akira (ex-Khmer Rouge troop that is now deactivating the land mines in Cambodia for mankind). Took around 1-2 hours to see the entire museum.If you plan to visit Banteay Srei - you should include this museum in the itinerary as this is like 20-25 mins from Banteay Srei temple. Really like the idea, although Akira now is housing the children victims of Cambodian war, he didn't allow the tourist to get in touch with the children. The shelter for this children is located behind the museum.

An interesting charity but poignant reminder of past atrocities. This museum was one hour's pleasant drive by tuk-tuk from my hotel in Siem Reap. Having passed part of the vast Angkor Complex, we continued through rural countryside which for me was an "eye-opener" to see how villagers live. On arrival I found a small, but comprehensive museum founded by Aki Ra as a charitable organisation. He decided to help his countrymen by defusing land mines, knowledge he gained during the Pol Pot regime. It is not a highly professional museum however the charitable efforts do convey the horrors of land mines which still occur to this day in parts of rural Cambodia. Exhibition rooms housing ordnance, clothing and photographs along with two outside static displays, radiate from a central gazebo which houses a vast collection of assorted land mines defused by Aki Ra. One of the static displays shows small anti-personnel mines connected by trip wires hidden in foliage which highlights the danger of wandering off into the jungle to this day.The small entrance fee of $5 includes a multi-lingual audio headset. Behind the museum is a Relief Centre where child victims of land mines are housed and fed along with education at local schools and universities. There is a small souvenir shop where some products and a collection of original paintings all made by the children are on sale.The entrance fee, sales of souvenirs and other donations go to the relief work. You will either like or dislike your experience but I found it a fascinating but sad reminder of times under Pol Pot. Not really ideal for children.

Interesting history and for a good cause. Was interesting to see, although not as extensive as we expected. Still for a great cause, entry cost was $5. Particularly enjoyed reading about the foundation to educate young victims which they have on site. Staff could have been friendlier but no biggie.

Landmine Museum - a sobering experience. A private museum that successfully (if that word is appropriate) portrays the horrors of the random and destructive power of landmines - what scared us the most is the number of landmines that still exist.We took the audio Tour (part of entry fee) - need to do it. The audio tour sheds history on a horrible war that was not that long ago. Agree with another Tripadvisor contributor that it is a little home- made - but perhaps that makes it more meaningful.Highly recommend a visit.

Everyone sould visit this museum. When you travel around, you check the country, the history online, in the books, televison ... but nothing is the same as seeing with our own eyes. It's not an easy visit, to see all the horrors that have been happening, but everyone should see what a human being is capable off - bad stuff and good stuff.All the best to Aki Ra and his team for their effort.

Use the audio or guided tour, not child friendly. Probably obvious, but not a place for kids. Not because of anything explicit or graphic, but, at age 5 and 7, the historical significance is missed. The museum itself is small. Another mistake we made was that we did not take the guided tour or use the audio tour. I feel like I missed so much because of that. If you want information about helping the kids living there, look online before you go, there was little interaction with the people selling tickets. I would skip the museum completely if I were to re-do our travel. It's hard to write a review about such a heavy topic, as I want to rate it highly, but the experience for me did not warrant one (not interactive nor is it visually educational).

Not to be missed!. An excellent exhibition that explains the life of one man stolen from his family and introduced to war at a very young age. Very informative. A must if you are in Siem Reap. The $5 entry is well spent and the breakdown of where your money goes is explained on entry.

An eye-opener. If you want to shed a tear learning about a really great man and his efforts to help his country then come here and look through it thoroughly.It's a bit home-made as far as decor and surrounds but don't just scoot past on your way to Banteay Srei, actually drop in.IT IS WORTH A VISIT

Very Interesting place. So much history on display at this museum. If you want to understand the impacts of the Vietnam War and the KR in Cambodia this museum gives you such a great insight.It does not take long, allow maybe 2hours - a half day trip from Siem Reap

Very informative and INTERESTING. It was really an interesting experience and filled with information on different types of land mine, the history, the different army, etc. and mostly i love how the guides are kept up to date and relates the landmine issue to current situation (landmine being widely used in Syria currently, etc).They have also put up essays written by the kids and youd just be devastated reading all their writings. USD 5 per entrance of which USD 3 will be used to pay the staff and childrens education, etc another USD1 used to funds responsibile for clearing the landmines which is still widely available in Cambodia and the other USD 1 i forgot what it was for. A MUST GOT as it was really really interesting!

I would really try to come here on a trip to Siem Reap. Our tour guide took us to this place, on the way to one of the temples. It is a quick stop that shouldn't take more than 30-45 minutes to see. But was nice to see this place which makes you realize how lucky you are to be alive. Our tour guide was very good in explaining to us what happened during the Khmer genocide.

Very interesting museum. Very important and educative visit, however also very sad, this museum was created by a former khmer soldier that was recruted when we was a kid and early in his life helped to install many of thousands of landmines troughout cambodian territorry during the civil war, believing he was fighting the enemy. After the war, he converted into a hero and since the nineties, because of his acquired explosive and TNT handle technique, he has dedicated his life to make his country a safer place by finding and disarming thousands of thousands of landmines.  The museum shows his work, his life, pictures and stories of mutilated child and older people and examples of landmines such as those lethal ones made by the soviet and chinese armies and used by the khmer rouge. The legacy of this silent job is priceless and was recognized worldwide. Today, there are still thousands of active landmines at the cambodian territory and nobody certainly know how much and exactly where they are. Specially in the country side, hundreds of people still suffer accidents and get hurt, wounded, dead or mutated by landmines. Very recomended to get to know this story.

Interesting displays of land mines and other weapons. We just did the basic tour - no tour guide, no audio guide. This place may even alter some of your previous views/ opinions of said historical events. Fascinating and moving.

A reminder of what this beautiful land endured, and still endures. It's the Wandering Yank here. Mrs. Yank and I spent 3 wonderful days touring the Angkor area. One the way back from one of our stops we saw this and asked our driver to stop. It was very worthwhile, and I highly recommend it as a contrast to the beautiful sights of Angkor.You will learn the story of the Cambodian, an ex-Khmer Rouge child soldier, who founded an NGO to search for and remove landmines from the country's civil war period. You will learn the history of landmines and see many examples of them as well as dud American bombs. And you will learn something about the impact of landmines on Cambodian civilians up to the present day. The NGO also supports needy children in a complex behind the museum. There is an admission charge, and an audio tour is available which Mrs. Yank used and appreciated.2 thumbs up.

Sadder than sad. On the way to Bantay srei. Is the land mine museum.One could easily miss this little clue to atrocities the people of Cambodia were subjected to.Although commendable and prestigiously recognized internationally I was troubled by the poor upkeep of the place.Its a museum so a little effort into the place would be welcomed.Entrance fees are USD5 and again just like The UNESCO sites of Angkor enjoys international patronage.

A welcome reminder. This formed part of an organised day and after the killing fields in Phnom Penh was not sure.Glad we went. This is simply laid out with good quality audio guide. The visuals are straightforward but not less powerful for this.As always makes me embarrassed at what was allegedly done for my sake by my government.However you come away with hope and with the knowledge that great and inspirational people can come from any background.Take some time out from temple bagging and go here.

An absolute must when in Siem Reap. The Landmine Museum is one of those attractions that sticks with you for years. Not much due to it's grander or look, but the fact it has such a permanent impact on one. This is a great place to build the foundation of ones learning process and gives a unique and informative look at Cambodia's troubled years. One of the best parts about the Museum is they do a great job of staying relevant and updating their information on the world landmine issue, not just Cambodia's problem. Bill and Aki Ra are BOTH great inspirations for the next generation of educators, travelers and leaders.
