One man's inspiring story. The are still millions of live mines in Cambodia and thousands of people who have lost limbs to them. This museum tells the story of one man's crusade to make his country safe. Inspiring and also a sad reminder of what humans can do to each other.

You learn more here in one hour visit than on school history books. Enlightening place made possible by Aki Ra, who was forced to disseminate mines around when he was a kid. When he further realized the gravity of his actions, he started removing mines throughout the country, and he still does. The work they do here is inspiring and truly moving. The museum is very small but rich in content and history of course. Very friendly guides willing to share their stories and knowledge, this is a great place to visit (for only $5, supporting the work of landmine removers) and learn more about the history of the Khmer Rouge, the same great empire that built the amazing temples, probably the main reason why you are here, have disseminated horror and death among civilians. IT is extremely important to know what the country has gone through in recent times. A very humble set up which an extremely intensive force: very educational, sincere and genuine.

Inspiring Story. The museum is quite far from where we're staying but the 45 mins drive is so worth it. The entrance fee to the museum is 5 usd: The museum might be small but is very informative. It houses different kinds of landmines retrieved by Aki Ra. His story and what he did for Cambodia is very inspiring. I suggest using the audio to guide you during the tour.
Museum of Land Mines. A place where you can seen hundreds of Land Mines and other weapons used to kill innocent cambodian by Pol Pot

Definately worth a look.. We stopped at this museum as an optional extra on our 3 day Urban adventure tour through Intrepid tours. We were all exhausted form the heat but decided to make the effort. Boy are we glad we did. It gave us a better understanding of what the Cambodians have had to deal with and it was very interesting. It was too hot to spend amymore than probably an hour there but the incredible work that the founder and his late wife have done needs to be seen.

Tragic Reminder of the war. The museum is about 20 km from siem reap and although small is a grim reminder of the worst elements of the war.On display are all the different types of mines used along the cambodian/vietnam border of which about 6 million still remain.At the back of the museum is a refuge for children injured by mines and all money goes to support the refuge.Well worth a visit.

Confronting place, enlightening. What a confronting place, having never seen anything like it, it was quite a shock to see such weapons and read the history. Well worth a visit. The good work they do is inspiring.

Great to see the good work being done in cleaning up the landmines. Nice little museum showing the terrible things that landmines can do and have done in the country, but with a very positive message that a lot of good work is being done to clean up the mess.

History of war torn Cambodia in museum. my return trip from Bantea srey temple visit I just dropped in Landmine museum.It's a small private museum with 5$ entry ticket and audio guided tour..I was really moved on seeing the pathetic turmoils of war torn Cambodia and the teenagers and rangers engaging in removing the landmines and shells..the museum houses lots of landmines, shells, mortars, and brief description of the types of land mines and its has a photo gallery ..there is a rehabilitation center behind the museum for those affected in landmine blasts and their children orphanage centre. The museum is now a recognized by the international community and has received funds and support around the world and its being maintained by Aka..dedicated solider during Khmer Rouge reign..now dedicated himself recovering and removing the landmines from the war torn soil in Cambodia...we could feel the pains and turmoils that the Cambodian people ve undergone in war zone...
Wvery moving museum. One of the most moving museums I have been to. Just awful what these poor people went through and some still are. This museum explains so many unknown things. Well worth a visit.

A must see. This is a great place to visit and learn about the history of the Khmer Rouge. It's very sad to learn about it but the money it costs to enter goes towards removing land mines and children.

filling in the gap. From the glory of the Khmer Empire that built the amazing temples, to the present poverty-stricken Cambodia (not Siem Reap, the city is quite prosperous) - the landmine museum filled the gap. Pledged to educate the world the horror of landmines and cluster bombs which still haunt Cambodia and unfortunate lands around the world, Landmine Museum is a sincere, genuine museum, little, but heavy. A must visit. We went on our way to Banteay Srei.

Necessary Visit to the Land Mine Museum. We had a wonderful guide -- an American gentleman who had been in Cambodia for many years. A very graphic place to visit and gives you an idea of the scale of slaughter than was inflicted on this country.

Must visit. If you are in Siem Reap, I would definitely suggest a visit to this Landmine Museum. A very humble set up, founded by Aki Ra, a Cambodian deminer. You will be moved by the story behind Aki Ra and Cambodia, and develop a much stronger appreciation of what the country has gone through in recent years. Allow 1 hour. You can easily stop by on the way to Banteay Srei.

Interesting. A small museum not far from Banteay Srei. The visit is self guided but easy to follow and well signed. Small and interesting although a bit depressing when you see what the landmines a]can do
Terrible. Not representive of the current nature and extent of the mine and uxo problem in Cambodia. Nor of the efforts being made by the agencies in this sector.

Worth a stop. This is a small museum but worth a stop. It is close to Banteay Srei, and Pre Rup is on the way, so you could combine them. The museum is well done and we especially liked the story of the man who founded it. He had been a child soldier, when he was the same age as my kids, so they found it very interesting. There is a free audio guide but there are also English signs and a man was there giving tours in English as well.

A bit of a schlep, but worth it. Go. If you can email ahead of time and find out when Bill is giving a tour, do it. He and his wife are great, and really bring the museum and the history to life. And their commitment to the cause is infectious.

Humbling Visit. While visiting Siem Reap, I suggest you stop at this museum and learn about the work that is being done to help landmine victims. They have English audio guides for every exhibit, making the visit even more worthwhile. The photos and descriptions gave you a good idea of what the local people have had to (and still have to) endure. Don't miss this!

Very informative. This is a must-see for those who want to learn more about the terrible impact of conflict Cambodia has suffered from. You'll also discover inspirational stories of victims of mines who have achieved individual success in spite of their disabilities.
Don't miss on this place. Don't miss on this place if you visit in Siem Reap. location outside from city but not to far, visit the museum and need to know the effect from the war.

Cambodia Landmine museum by Aki Ra. This museum helps you understand, what happened in Cambodia during the Red Khmer tyrant, but it doesn't give the answer, why. Anyway, it is great work that the ex- Red Khmer, Aki Ra is doing. Visit here and support his work.

Amazing!!!. A passionate effort of a couple to initiate the elimination of landmines in Cambodia. Excellent audio guide, eye tearing stories of victims, mind blowing efforts by the team to eradicate landmines. A place close to the heart... Every fee is your contribution towards the victims. A must see in seam reap!

A great break between temple seeing. When you've seen about enough tourists and awe evoking temples, this was a great break from the large loop. It helped me to see a day in the life of a Cambodian. It is hard to realize that this history is a part of my time line as well. Their pursuit of life and victories bring new revelations for me in the phrase "same same". The path that these children took towards education and having food on the table is amazing.

Combine with Butterfly visit to see a different side of the Siam Reap area. Its best to combine this with a trip to the Butterfly place about 1 or 2 K I would say it NOT a must to do but glad I went. An American guy who works there provided a valuable insight on the Cambodian history of 70-80's and also impact of people since then.

Educational. Heavy information, relatively difficult to get to. Worth a visit if you are interested in the recent history of Cambodia. Charity support from donations. Rather informative. Get the audio tour

Worth the visit and worthy cause. We spent an hour here and found it really interesting. From reading factual and personal information, to seeing the many land mines discovered, to the students experiences linked in with their artworks, it was well worth the visit. $ 20-25 return for 2x 45 min tuk tuk ride. My only regret was not knowing what was on the wish list before we went. It would have been easy to have bought toiletries, tooth paste and tooth brushes, stationary etc to donate if only we'd know ahead of time. Also we had no photo ID so could not get the audio sets-something that would have been good to know before hand too. Great cause, amazing man and Organisation.

Thought Provoking Museum. Really sad view of all the suffering that Cambodia has suffered and continues to suffer. The uplifting part is the people who are working to make things better. Very interesting and makes you think not only of the war but the after effects that people have to live with. It was encouraging to hear of the bravery of the Cambodian people to clear up the mines and help some of the unfortunate children.

Off the beaten track but worth a look. A really interesting place to see. It took us around an hour from the City River Hotel by Tuk Tuk but was well worth it. The work these people do is amazing in supporting people of all ages affected by the horrors of land mines. Probably about 45 minutes to an hour to get around all the displays and there is a short film to watch as well. Very reasonably priced - entry is $5. Kids may find it a little confronting.

Excellent opportunity to learn. We visited on the way back from Banteay Srei temple. It was sad to learn about the tragedy of land mines, not just in Cambodia, but all over the world. It encouraged me to learn more about the work people are doing to help victims of landmines, and also to see what can be done to prevent them from being used in the future. Very somber but hopeful place.
Educational. Learned so much! Since I was born in the 80's I really had no knowledge of Cambodias past. It was very sobering.

Not to be missed. We visited the Butterfly Farm first, then the Landmine Museum, and finally Banteay Srey. I was doubtful that this would be an interesting visit, but I was wrong! The guide was an American who has come to Cambodia to live due to his commitment to the removal of all landmines in Cambodia. He spoke with such enthusiasm,commitment and knowledge. A visit that made a deep impression on me and a determination to support this cause. Thank you for being a great guide and I would recommend this as a definite place to visit when in Cambodia.

a must do, gives you a good impression of the horror of landmines. We liked it a lot, because it gives you a real good impression of how landmines work, how they were uses. It's an exposition, that is very good. The entrance fee you pay, goes to a foundation who helps people who were injured by landmines. They also have a little shop for that foundation. It is some variation between the temples you visit.

Touches the heart. A lot of history is packed into this tiny museum, with the free audio guide giving a synopsis of the violent events that took place in Cambodia from the sixties to the late nineties. People in the countryside, many of them children, are still losing limbs and lives from hidden mines planted during the wars. And there are over 30,000 of the mines (defused and certified safe) on display in the museum. On the bright side is the story of the man who started the museum who, after being a child soldier for the Khmer Rouge, made it his mission to clear tens of thousands of these deadly weapons. Not only that, but he takes in orphans and amputees and provides them with a home, an education, prosthetic limbs, and hope for the future. The displays may be low-budget, but they touch your heart. Can be combined with trip to Banteay Srei. Donations welcomed.

Small but powerful. Not much here, as it is linked to an orphanage. But still worth going. If you are going please consider bringing something to donate. They have a wishlist on the wall. We met one girl who had been living there for 10 years after being injured while working in a field and finding an old link mine. She was making the bracelets for sale there. It is worth a visit but make sure you have other things planned also.

Sobering visit - Awesome accomplishments. This visit was well worthwhile and very sobering. The work of Aki Ra is impressive. It breaks your heart in seeing the tragedy of landmines (or any other form of warfare and genocide, for that matter). But it is uplifting to see how much

worthwhile cause. a bit far but it's nice to see the countryside on the way. This place is ell organized and worth the five dollars you pay to get in. Yes-cambodia's ancient temple history is important but so too is the contemporary history.

A humbling place to visit. This brings the reality of life in the 1950s through 1970s to life by telling the story of the thousands of land mines planted throughout the countryside and the man who led the way clear them to make the Cambodian people safe

A great little museum. What an interesting place! To see the work of Aki Ra was humbling. It offered us another perspective on the life of the Cambodian people and the turmoil that they have had to endure since the Pol Pot years.

Very interesting and informTive. I had not idea how many mines were placed in Cambodia! There are still 100's not found yet. The man who started this was a child soldier and then dedicated his life to finding and removing landmines

What one man can achieve. The museum is a little disorganised, but when looked at as a whole the owner has put a lot of work into it. It is virtually a story of his life whch he has spent finding landmines and defusing them. See the film and see how a very dedicated person spent his lifetime trying to clean up the terrible mess left by the US, Thailand and VietNam armed forces and the massive amount of land mines that were not only placed in Cambodia but by the US forces were literally scattered around the country in order to dispose of them when the conflict in VietNam was coming to a close.

Make a stop on your way to Banteay Srei. Must do if you have the chance. The museum is telling the important story about this country and the struggles the cambodian people have been throught. Aki Ra - the founder of this museum is a living legend. I am so glad I had the opportunity to come here.

Your donation will go directly here.. This is a site that many people blow off in their hurry to get to or from the temples. It is a small complex with several exibits featuring the history of the landmine situation and the efforts by one man to clean them up and educate people foreign and domestic about the dangers.I was lucky enough to arrive here when there were few people in attendance. Once the room gets crowded it is hard to read the exibits without feeling rushed by people . There is an audio tour which is free. It is helpful, but not necessary to enjoy the exhibit, as much of the recordings are on the placards in front of each display. But it enables you to step away from the exhibit space and have some space.The displays are interesting and well designed. There is a display of a minefield in the garden. There are weapons and mine displays. The gift shop is good! If you are going to spend some money, even 5.00 dollars---do it here! The money is going to a really good cause, as there is a relief center with child victims in the rear of the complex. (not for visiting.)

Eye-opening break from temples. This museum is small but powerful, and a moving testimony to one man's determination to ride his country of these terrible weapons. If you want to do more than temples, and learn something about Cambodia's recent history it's well worth half an hour of your time. I learned that one in 300 Cambodians has a landmine injury.Profits from the museum go towards the children's home out the back, which takes in children injured by landmines or otherwise disadvantaged. The home is, thankfully, not open to visitors, but you can read some of the children's stories in one room. One room has a striking display of false limbs, some of them heartbreakingly tiny, which is quite harrowing. It's worth getting the free audio tour, as it gives more detail about the posters and displays. You just had in your temples pass as a deposit. The museum is by the road leading out to Banteay Srei temple. If you've got a driver just ask them to wait outside for half an hour or so. I managed to pick up a motorbike taxi back to Siem Reap outside - it took about 45 minutes and cost $13.

Amazing little museum . Brilliant meuseum. I'm into all my history but my girlfriend who normally gets dragged round these sorts of things actually loved it and we both found it really informative. Free audio guide is always a nice bonus and the cost of entry goes towards some local charities (I think about 2 dollars of the 5 but I could be wrong) overall if your heading that way for the butterfly sanctuary and the temples it's well worth an hour or so.

Aki Ra is doing all the right things. It was enlightening to visit this little museum. Having once been a soldier laying mines Aki Ra and his team have dedicated their lives for many years now to ridding Cambodia of land mines and helping less fortunate children have a good upbringing, love and education. Worth a visit and a few dollars if you can to support this very worthy cause.

sad relicts of hoppefully gone times. part of the sad history of the Country - but still worthwhile to visit. While there not only view the exposed objects - but do read the posters and comments on the walls: quite informative.

Interesting break from the temples.... ...and good opportunity to get an understanding of history of Cambodia. It is a long tuk tuk ride but we enjoyed the journey as lots to see and can be easily combined with the temple of Banteay Srey - although by this point we didn't as we were templed out.

Thought provoking. Interesting little stop off, created by one man who in the wars, planted the land mines and now is dedicated to removing them. Also acts as a place for people affected by the land mines (children) to live and school. Fascinating pictures and stories. A free audio and ear phones available by leaving some photo ID which is collected on its return. Well worth the visit to understand how devastating land mines are and the painstaking process to remove them.

Can see landmines. Quite interesting, would be better if the museum is bigger (there are 4 major rooms only). I spent less than 1 hour to walk through the museum (and I managed to listen to most of the audio-guide and read most of the information on wall).

Ask for the recorded commentary!. I've been here a few times with friends usually coupled with another activity - going to Banteay Srey, the butterfly House or ACCB. The most recent time I asked for the recorded guide, I didn't have my passport or any photo ID but one of my friends did and so they allowed me to take it. It was brilliant and I learnt a lot that I hadn't read about on my previous visits. Its well worth visiting and gives some additional insights into Cambodia's recent history.
informative. awesome! historically accurate, be prepared to get emotional, a must see, every american should make a stop
Interesting. This is very interesting and worth stopping by if your are in the area. It's on the way to the Banteay Srei, I would not make a special trip to visit it.

Part of the ongoing struggle of Cambodia.. If you would know more about the difficulties of this culture, stop here on the way to or from Banteay Sray Temple. A rather rustic setting. A somber learning experience.

A must for anyone visiting Siem Reap. An inspiring, informative and deeply moving experience. This museum is a mouthpiece for the incredible work being done to clear land mines and to rehabilitate and educate the victims of these atrocities. As their mission had made great impact on the numbers of land mines, so lessening (but not eradicating) the number of victims, still their work continues,not only in clearing, but in supporting and educating the next generation of children in need. If you are very lucky as we were, you will have the work of this amazing project and the history of the Cambodian situation clearly explained to you by the inspirational Bill, an American working for the project. Please go and support!

Sobering visit. This was a shocking and sobering look at how western countries harmed Cambodia during the Vietnam War. The number of landmines and UXB is a disgrace, so this is a great reminder of what the west has done and how we can help to fix it.

Worth a visit if you are passing. We were passing by the museum on a motorcycle tour, so stopped for a visit.The museum is small, but it does a good job of explaining the carnage caused by landmines and the ongoing threat that they pose to the local population.It is worth a visit if passing by - but probably not worth a significant detour just for the visit.

worth to visit.. if you are a history lover............ I have visited Landmine museum last week. A small but nice place. My collection of Mines and war weapons. 5$ entry fees. I stayed there around half an hour.

A must if you are staying for than 3 days . This is a great place to visit if you are staying in Siem Reap for more than 3 days. Otherwise it is quite far (especially via tuk tuk which is around an hour from pub street one way - we paid $15 for a return trip). It's a great cause and a great museum without a doubt. I just wish it was closer to the city. The staff have done a great job with the children and presenting all this information.

An eye opener.. A very small Museum, that throws a big powerful punch. It's a bit unnerving, and bordering on unbelievable, to learn of the number and different types of mines that were laid during that dreadful era. It's even more so to learn that some small parts of Cambodia are still off limits.A bit out of the way to warrant just a visit to the Landmine Museum, but when tied in with a trip to Banteay Srey Temple ..5 miles further on....it's a must.Also a good excuse to stop and buy a fresh chilled coconut from the vendors outside.!!

needs to be seen and supported. It's a tad off the main tourist track but needs to be seen. Run as a charity it's a sobering reminder of a not long ago history of the country. It's one mans life work.....be generous with a donaton
Reminder of reality. Important information to be had at the musem. Mostly things to read and many different mines and bombs to see.

Enlightening. A reasonable drive out of town but still worth a visit if you have the time. The museum brings home the plight of the many victims of the unexploded land mines that are still being found in Cambodia today.
Skip. You can skip this. It is socialist propaganda. It is true that in the wars many landmines were used but that was not a critical weapon.

Worth going out of your way to see the unintended costs of war. Heard about this small museum from a colleague who had worked in the Peace Corps in Cambodia. When planning the trip, I asked our driver to include this on the itinerary. A generation after the war, people still are maimed and killed by mines and other unexploded ordinance (UXO). Terrible but shouldn't be surprising since bombs and shells from WWII and even occasionally WWI are found in fields and cities of Europe today. The museum is run by an NGO started by a former Khmer Rouge Child soldier, Aki Ra, who taught himself how to disarm landmines. It has a few rooms with exhibits on mines, shells, and the history of the war. The most moving exhibit for me was one of the simplest - the small pavilion in the courtyard enclosed by metal mesh and containing piles of deactivated landmines, shells and other weaponry. The museum also has a school on the premises to help children who were injured by landmines learn job skills and enter the work force. The children designed the faces and figures of life-sized mannequins dressed in the uniforms of the various combatants involved in the Cambodia Civil War. Highly recommend making time to see this extraordinary museum.

Thought provoking. It is too easy to forget when visiting Cambodia, with its beautiful countryside, friendly people and World Heritage Sites that this country experienced years of conflict. The landmines are still a danger and a visit to the museum assists in funding their clearance.
An important place to visit. A must visit. The madness of war and its aftermath. Really brings it home to you in a well explained way
Worth going but it's far.. . Great experience, definitely worth going. Only negative would be it's about 45 mins by tuk tuk, it cost us 14$.

Heart-breaking but interesting, well worth an hour of your time, learn & help at the same time. On the road to Banteay Srei temple (big circuit), this museum and NGO is well worth an hour of your time. Its heart-breaking to learn of the 40,000+ amputees in Cambodia and the 4-6 million active landmines still hidden. The museum is small but very informative, it costs $5 which goes towards the NGO, pick up a free audio visit (English) which is takes about an hour. My 8 year old really enjoyed it, its sad but not gory. They also have an "orphanage" and school on the premises for kids affected by landmines & polio. These guys are doing a fantastic job and every visitor helps.

Moving experience. The Landmine museum is a testament to how the determination of just one person can become infectious and create larger change. His story is very moving. Get the audio guide and you will learn much. If you are lucky, you will find yourself in a deeper conversation with some of the people who work there and get even a deeper understanding. Definitely worth the 1/2 to 1 hour to visit. On your way to or from Banteay Srei temple.

MUST SEE. I just can't adequately describe how important this place is, and your money is very well spent. Provides insight in a way you are not likely to find anywhere else. If possible, take a guided tour, but even without it, an audio guide is very helpful. The money goes to a charitable cause for children and removal of landmines. The history presented and the actors involved will leave you surprised. The lives that are changed for the better, after experiencing breathtaking trauma, will leave you stunned, if not tearey-eyed. I know I'm being a bit dramatic, but so are the events which took place and the work this organization is doing to make things right again. Go. It's on the way to a popular (ladies) temple, and worth the price of your ride to get there, even if you don't go to the temple. They'd be closer to town....... if they could be. (For the guy who seems to doubt that the information is real, they have been vetted by the U.S., Canadian, and Cambodian governments, not to mention the numerous other legit participants involved.)

Emotional place to visit. This is quite an amateur museum compared to european ones but it packs a punch, please visit, learn what this country and its people have suffered in the last 40 years yet you will leave with a feeling of admiration and hope

A dark story that is still relevant today.... Tourist, stay here between temple visits and get an insight into the foolishness that is still present today in the most brutal manner. Absolutely worth a visit.

historical and humanical important to visit. Landmines are a part of cambodian rural life. If you like know about the country and his people, you need to visit this museum. There is a lot to read. The organisation who care for the people who suffers from exploded landmines do need every entrance fee

Not interesting/ Tourist Trap/ Though they do provide good service *. * Assuming they are telling the truth. They claim that there is a orphanage behind the museum that supports children who have polio and were victims of Landmines. I saw lots of photos of smiling children etc. But didn't see any children near by. I understand they cant be put on display but there is a part of me that thinks this is another tourist trap. Especially after how hard they tried to sell me the "children's paintings". The American gentleman who manages/overseas the museum was clearly targeting Caucasians by giving them a lecture and being all friendly, trying to get a donation. The asian/indian tourists and me [American who isn't white] were just ignored. Stood there for 15min next to him listening to his lecture and reading the material on the wall and he didn't even say hello. There is a bunch of rusty landmines and bombs from the vietnam era on display. Didnt find it very interesting. They need to present it better. Would be more interesting if there is a video of Aki Ra sharing his story. Ticket is $5. I hope it really does help the children because I wont be going back there again.

Must not miss. This landmine museum may be small but everything in it is very informative. It's nice to see the temples in Siem Reap but one should not miss visiting this place so you can also have an idea about the history of Cambodia during Khmer Rouge..though sad and dark. Ask them for the audio guide which comes with the $5 entrance fee (as I noticed some staff don't really offer unless you asked for it). Coming here is also for a good cause as the fee goes to landmine victims particularly for kids so they can go to school. I think though it's high time to refurbish this museum as the place looks old and dusty. Coming here takes 40 minutes by tuktuk or less if by car/bus from the town proper. Or you can come here as a side trip when you do the Big Circuit Tour (including Bantay Srei).
Cambodia Landmine Museum. Feb. 2016Found the museum, housekeeping not to good, everything is under dust.The emphasis are on the support of the children that were left homeless because of landmines.
Interesting. Wonderful work done by an incredible man....a great thing to support and extremely interesting, suggest tying it in with butterflyfarm as they are fairly close by!

Eye Opener. The visit to the museum was engaging. The American project manager was very articulate with the explanations about the museum. However our Cambodian guide said the entrance fee goes up every year.
Inspiring. This small museum is very informative and interesting, if not confronting. Its founder is inspirational and there are tons of ordnance of all types. A deserving NGO !

A story that needs telling. Until i visited this museum, i had no idea there were still millions of live land mines still in Cambodia, as well as unexploded bombs from civil war and the Vietnam War.This museum was set up by Aki, who used to be a child soldier that laid land mines. He has dedicated his adult life to clearing Cambodia of these horrible relics of war and helps and supports those affected by mines today.There are hundreds of deactivated mines and bombs on show, Aki's story of how and why he set up the museum, and facts and information about which countries still manufacturers and uses them, and who doesn't.Thought provoking.

Informative museum. An informative visit to this educational lad mine museum. The audio accomplement is informative and interesting. Displays include land mines, photographs and examples of bullets/mines.

Not your usual tourist destination. If your on your way to Banteay Srey Temple. This is well worth the stop. The guide will give you some insight into the darker and sadder side of Cambodia. The whole tour will last maybe a hour, but you will walk away with another perspective of the country and people.

Must go. First, don't expect it is a grand museum with water fountain in the center and special light effects on exhibited items. It is nothing like that. It is small , around 2000 sq ft and exhibits are not displayed in an museumly-organized or glamours manner. BUT it is definitely one of the most memorable museums I have ever visited. It provides up-to-date information about landmine: what is it; how it was made; why and where it was used; what effects it brings up to date, what the globe has done about it etc. Information and data is provided in several languages. Free audio guide is provided and I would say it is the second best audio guide I have ever listened to after the award-winning one in Alcatraz. The script is question led, easy to follow and informative. We spent close to an hour there and learnt so much. I am a museum person and have been to many museums where they leave nothing to you. You walk, you see and you forget. But this one is the opposite. It gave me a vivid lesson and left a mark in my heart. It is a living museum founded by a group of kind souls determined to help end this danger, which would not be succeeded without our awareness and help.

Go. This little museum is worth a stop if you are in the area. It is on the way to Banteay Srei if you are seeing this temple.This museum gives you an understanding of what a terrible impact land mines have had on the Cambodian people. The entrance fee is $5 U.S. $1 of every ticket goes towards clearing more land mines.

Hate giving this Museum an average as parts are excellent and it is worthy cause and worth seeing. I do not regret going to the landline museum as it has some really interesting information and Aki Ra's life history is amazing and what he has done for his people is inspiring. We were not offered audio equipment which would have been helpful and probably made the whole experience a lot more interesting. Sadly a lot of the displays are dusty and unloved which is really sad when this work is so vital to saving lives from being maimed or killed. Please visit it is an amazing cause and hopefully someone will realise that some deep cleaning could make this a better place.

Excellent audio tour . The landmine issue is something that really interests me so I may be a bit biased, but this museum was absolutely awesome. It's small but the free audio tour is quite extensive and makes up for it. All the information is definitely worth a read and it's really well set out! All for a very worthy cause as well - Aki Ra sounds like quite the amazing man!

Worthy cause. Great project and worth a stop on your way back from Banteay Srei. Very eye-opening and informative place briefly explaining the history of Cambodia and the massive problems landmines still cause today! Aki Ra is an inspiration and you can hear his story, starting from his beginings as a child soldier to dedicating his life to clearing land mines and supporting those affected by the war.

So inspiring. I had no idea about Aki Ra or his amazing work prior to going here. I was so inspired at the the great progress he has made especially considering his background. Definitely recommend everyone to stop in here and donate any loose change. Maybe carry a couple tissues when you do the audio tour.

An Eye Opener. A visit to this place shows you the reality of the aftermaths of war and how a single man's crusade to save his own people from the danger of leftover mines got recognition and help internationally. A must visit in any travel schedule to Siem Reap

Chilling window on a grim past.. ONLY recently three villagers and a buffalo died when they triggered a landmine.The chilling thing about this whole situation is that there are still millions of mines lying out there, all capable of maiming or killing, enough to give one mine to every living person in Cambodia.So I was very interested to learn more about what is being done to find and deal with this explosive legacy of civil war and made a point of making a trip out to the Cambodia Landmine Museum.A little kiosk was open to take my $5 for an entry ticket when I arrived and I was immediately struck by a poster next to a row of ordnance lining the entryway.It said: “Cambodian Self Help Demining is an all Khymer NGO established in 2008 to clear small villages throughout the Kingdom of Cambodia. CSHG is comprised of ex-child soldiers, widows, mothers, fathers, villagers and university graduates all working together to make their country a safer place for all.”You can’t help but be affected by such a message, particularly as the civil war concerned was years ago but its terrible aftermath is still blighting lives.I was in quite a grim mood as I walked in to be halted in my tracks by a huge container full of mines and munitions in the middle of a water display.Other rooms and displays also showed mines, how they are used, hidden and the devastating effect they have. There are also audio guide headphones available.The museum, which includes toilets and a souvenir section where you can actually buy a defused mine, was founded by Aki Ra, a former child soldier with the Khymer Rouge.It was originally at a different site and has now moved to its current facility where it cares for dozens of children.Aki Ra says he must have laid thousands of mines himself, the clock turning full circle because he is now credited with clearing more than 50,000 mines.The loss of life caused by mines is on an unimaginable scale, but clearance, community help projects and this museum are all doing what they can to tackle the mine legacy. A really worthwhile place to visit and support.

Definitely worth a visit. It is unfortunate that this museum is so far from the main temples of Siem Reap, but I would highly recommend making the slightly longer journey north of the temple complex to visit this museum. It is really well run, with informative displays and a very detailed headset to guide you through. Some days you can be lucky to catch the guide there too to add more information. Aiki Ra is a great guy who set about demining Cambodia after the war, and this museum is a tribute and testament to his hard work which still continues. You learn a lot about landmines, and the war and see displays of all the deactivated mines and bombs they have found. Also on site is an orphanage and childrens school and centre, but you are not allowed visit this out of respect for the children. Great to combine a visit to the Landmine museum with Banteay Srei women's temple for an afternoon.

Must see visit on way back from Banteay Srei. We called into the landmines museum on our way back from Banteay Srei The Lady Temple.With a small entrance fee, going to charity. it's definitely worth a stop off visit!With over 6 million mines still active in and around Cambodia, this place really does bring home the need for funding for kids affected by such a tragedy and will open your eyes to the horrors of mines past and present. The exhibition has a variety of shells, bombs and of course landmines to view.The shop has a few things for sale. We bought an actual sign from the fields that are no longer mine ridden. All monies raised here going to providing more schools and educational facilities for victims of past conflicts.

Really brings the problem home. We weren't sure what to expect but this is a fascinating (if you can call the subject fascinating) place. It was a real eye opener to the problem Cambodia still faces & was very educational.

Disappointing visit due to staff and locked doors.. We only had one hour on our way to Banteay Srey to visit here and couldn't fit in with our other schedule. I went to Cambodia 8 years ago and never got the chance to visit so I really wanted to go here once. Despite the terrible reality of landmines and the good done shown in the museum, my experience here was very poor indeed. We arrived and nobody was at reception to buy our $5 ticket, which I was happy to pay after eventually finding someone who took our money and disappeared again. But then no information. I could see the audio guide headphones but no guides and nobody to ask. All of the rooms off the central display (with all the landmines displayed) were locked with padlocks. There was one woman half heartedly "cleaning" (moving dirt from one place to another) and we gestured about the lock and just pointed and was obviously annoyed by us. Eventually one man came in and just shook the lock a few times and pushed the door and the disappeared without saying anything. Such a shame for the story behind the museum is quite heart-warming and heart breaking at the same time. What a shame it has ended up in this condition. I hope this was just a one-off experience. This was in the morning at peak season though!

Outdoors, no guides. Sad, chilling stories that Cambodians are eager to share in the hopes of preventing another series of horrors like the killing fields and forced relocations under ruthless dictator Pol Pot.

Worthwhile Visit. The land mine museum is about an hour away from Siem Reap by Tuk Tuk and it is well worth visiting. It was an educational and informative experience. Very eye opening. If you are planning to visit the museum they are always in need of extra supplies such as toiletries and school supplies. We did not know this before we went and would have definitely brought some supplies if we had known. Figured we would pass on the message for future travelers.

Land mine museum a must do. We had been told some background about the founder of the museum and stopped there on our first day visiting temples. Only a small museum but the audio tour (free) explained it all very professionally. The info was up to date and the real purpose behind the museum was simply to save people's lives.
INTERESTING. This only takes about 30 minutes to go through. It was interesting but not sure I would go out of my way to see this.

Terrible but interesting. Landmines are really terrible and that will you see what they can do to people and animals. Specially that landmines still take or hurt people, so many years after the war. Make a visit and you will learn and know more about the landmines in Cambodia.

Interesting insight into some individals stories. First off, this attraction is a long way out of town. We went by tuk-tuk and it was around 45mins to a hour, one way. The displays themselves are starting to look rather tierd, faded from their exposure to the elements and some now almost unreadable, however, there is still a lot of interesting reading to be done there, especially some of the stories from different individuals and the circumstances they faced in war.If you are into this kind of stuff, or even just a little curious on history and events, it is worth a visit, especially considering the money does go to a good cause. I just wouldn't make it the sole attraction for the day, but rather part of onward or return journey from another.
Very good information. This museum is worth visiting if you happen to be in the area. Museum gives very good information about the horrors of land mines in Cambodia.

Sobering. Worthwhile stop on the journey through the area. A very personal journey through the horrors of landmines and unexploded ordinance in Cambodia. Give yourself an hour+ to read through the story of the placement of these weapons and the efforts to remove them from harm's way.

An Eye Opener. Loved our visit to the Landmine Museum.It puts a great perspective on the horrors of war and what people had to endure especially children.Met the Advisor Bill Morse, friendly and devoted to the cause of the children.If you visit make sure you use the Audio guide...Its very good.Do remember to take a few knick knacks like stationery or books as your contribution to the children.

Small but interesting. This location is run by an ex Khmer Rouge boy soldier. There is a nominal entry fee to go inside and look around at the exhibits.On display are an assortment of landmines which are used in many countries throughout the world. There is also a world map that shows who the biggest suppliers of landmines are.The man who operates the museum is actively involved in removing landmines from the district and trains others on how to remove mines and, he has a small orphanage at the back of the property where he helps support children who have lost both parents. There are some interesting back stories that are worth reading and taking time to reflect on - the stories are written on large posters on display inside the museum.

This is the reality of war. A home made museum about one mans ( and later his team) efforts in trying to clean up after the aftermath of war at one time in Cambodia there were 2.5 mines for every person in Cambodia ..... Why cause there was profit in selling them to the waring factions .These guys were very brave in what they did demining and setting up school sanctuary for mine victims It's well worth a visit

Spend some time understanding Cambodia. This is a nice place to start to understand about Cambodia actual moment. Don't go there expecting to see an incredible museum. Visit this place with your mind open and save some time to support them. Every visitor in Cambodia should go there. It is a mix of feelings see those pictures and hear their story. Great experience

Well Worth a Visit. This museum is a great place to learn more about the (sadly tragic) recent history of Cambodia. There are multiple interesting exhibits and on several days there are excellent English language tours lasting about 45 minutes. The nominal admission fee goes to the very worth causes of supporting de-mining efforts and children who have been maimed by landmines. Highly recommended.
Heart breaking but interesting. Small museum...but very moving. Nice people to explain the situation. Run by a guy that won the CNN humatarian award.
Thought provoking. Allow just under an hour. About 5 rooms to bring home the amount of munitions scattered about the place.

Another powerful experience in Cambodia. The story of the man that founded this museum is striking. This site and the organization that it runs are an extraordinary cross section of Cambodian history. Some facts that you learn there are difficult to digest and comprehend. Despite its intense nature this place is a must see.

A little known but very worthwhile institution. Compared to the major sights in Cambodia, this one is relatively less well known. It nevertheless tells a sad and shocking story in a matter of fact but affecting way. The museum helps to fund clearances and support land mine victims so a visit is doubly worthwhile.
Man's inhumanity to man. Extremely well presented exhibits on a tight budget. Time to reflect on what the human race has come to,

Important stop. This museum is very small but thoroughly worth the visit to understand this important part in the turnaround of Cambodia from the Khmer Rouge days. Behind it is a shelter for children affected by landmines which you can see into but, of course, do not go into. I really enjoyed visiting here though some of my friends thought it was too small for the 5USD entry. Every penny (cent I guess) of that goes into supporting the staff and children. Absolutely non-profit, small organisation.You could visit here during a day at the temples as it's near Banteay Srei; or, as we didn't want to pay 20USD for another day of temples, you could go here and the butterfly sanctuary for a morning. We spent about an hour here maximum. Drive took maybe 40minutes from Siem Reap.

Worth the visit . Really enjoyed our visit here and the information we found out. We got a tuktuk from the town centre ($20 return journey) which did take quite awhile but we enjoyed the fresh air and the sights we saw along the way. The museum has alot of interesting facts and information. We listened to the audio tour which is a great idea. My personal favourite was the stories written by those who came to live there. Very moving and sad at times, but hopeful for a future made better by the work done to remove any landmines remaining.

Great holiday in Siem Reap. Great place for meeting people and chilling. The dormitory rooms are high class for a hostel. Food not so expensive. There is also a cinema if you are already tired of going around and feel like being by yourself. Wifi is excellent too.

Historic place, learned a lot and saw a lot of landmines. I visited this while backpacking with my friend.I don't know much history about the Khmer Rouge, so this was incredibly eye opening and interesting visit. You see a huge amount of explosives and landmines, but also learn about how big of a problem this is in Cambodia today. Great staff and volunteers, and includes a free audio guide which is very helpful.A must see for a visit to Siem Reap, hands down.

This is a must see museum for everyone. The landmine museum is a fascinating view into the horrors of war in Cambodia. The story of the founder of the museum is compelling and the work done with children and the demining efforts are truly amazing. The tour is self-guided with a free audio guide. Fantastic stories and perspectives on what has happened in Cambodia over the last 50 years. The location is a short drive from the main Angkor Temple area (maybe a total of 45 minutes by TukTuk from Siem Reap), but it is absolutely worth the visit. If you want to start to develop an understanding of the ongoing cost of war, this is a must see.

A tad left field but worth a visit. Ok so a Landmine Museum might not be on most people top 10 places to visit. But if you can call in on the way to one of the more remote temples its worth a stop. Its a very practical setup, but more importantly your money goes to supporting their good work. The layout of the place is a tad homemade jam, but that adds in my opinion to the feel of the place. No frills just the brutal reality of landmines and their aftermath. Please support this place if you can.
Very moving. Very moving exhibit of how land mines and war has impacted the lives of Cambodians with a small display of how war has affected others in the world. I thought it was worth visiting.
A must see. Visit this museum about 20-30 km from Siem Reap. It is worth the visit for the stories, and just to support the cause of these people.

A must visit place in Cambodia. I honestly think that this place is as important tourist wise as the angkor wat. The eye opening experience of seeing the scale if landmine accidents in Cambodia really should be part of the visit of every person who comes to Cambodia. Sure, this is an old school museum with ni interactive exhibitions, but the story it tells is a thousend times more important than the angkor wat, in my opinion.

Worth the visit. Greater maintenance needed.. We visited today. The work of this man and his team is truly to be commended. More care needs to be taken to maintain the exhibits and clean the glass cabinets. They were very misty the day we went with lots of cobwebs. It's such an important contribution - it just needs to be maintained.

Interesting. Interesting story and information about the plague that landmines are to Cambodia. Good information as to why there are so many amputees. The work that they do to clear landmines is also very good.

A sobering stop. As we were moving from temple to temple our guide Mr. Hin Hiek told us about the Landmine Museum. The museum was right on our route. We wanted to stop. We had seen a Nat Geo special before we left on the Landmine Museum. This is a small private museum that powerful in its information. Also on the grounds is housing for children that have been injured by these hidden landmines. The museum provides an MP3 style electronic guide that is easy to use. this is sad commentary to our recent history.
Interesting Museum. This museum tells a lot about the history of landmines and organizations that are trying to find and locate these landmines. It was a great learning experience.

Interesting and informative . We took a tuktuk here and the ride through the countryside was lovely. It would be even nicer in the wet season when the fields of rice are growing. The museum itself is a real eye opener. It costs $5 each entrance and that includes an audio. All the information inside is in English and Cambodian. I did see some french tourists who did not stay long and looked unhappy at there not being anything available for them. You might need to check on the museum's website to find out whether the audio is available in other languages. This museum is defiantly worth the visit. There are a couple of restaurants outside too.

Worth a stop. The owner of the Landmine Museum has put a lot of effort into bringing more attention to the issue of Landmines in the region, and to providing a place for visitors to learn about the issue.

A sad part of recent history. A must if you have time its not a large place , but very informative and lots of facts which I did not know or have been covered up by the west powers, only takes 1/2 hr and ya done but if time worth a look
Great place to visit on way to Banteay srei. Very informative and lots of information about the history of Cambodia. I loved it! The audio guides were good as well. Well worth the entrance fee.

Moving visit. A must visit museum. It's informative and inspirational. It's an emotional visit, and gives a wonderful overview of a man who knows what it was like to suffer as a child, the experiences he had, and how he has overcome some horrendous events to make his country proud of him.

Well worth the time. This was a sobering but important place to stop at. The displays are not high tech or polished but the perspective they provide on the aftermath of the conflicts that the Cambodian people have endured and the story of the founder of the Museum (Aki Ra) are compelling. There is a very good audio commentary that brings the exhibits to life. Entry fees and purchases from the museum shop go towards supporting the NGO set up by Aki Ra to support children in need and to run the land mine clearing operation.

Good History Lesson Here. This is probably of interest mostly to those who still have a memory of the Vietnam War (referred to as the American War in this part of the world). It's a sad testimony to part of America's history and gives evidence to the destruction of the Cambodian people that occurred during that time. It's a small, but mighty museum and brings you the reality that the Cambodian people still face due to undetonated land mines that have been placed throughout their nation.

nice to visit. a story of the mines that have been difused in cambodia a very sad story of mass genicide by the kymer rouge..the museum is fairly small still millions of mines in cambodia awaiting disposal

Worth the 40 minute drive. This will help you better understand the horrible conflict this country went through in the 70's & 80's - a real education on the horrific use if lame mines and how that are still killing & maiming people today.
Fantastic Museum, Vital Cause. This is such an important center to learn about the Khmer past, and present hardships. A must see during your Angkor explorations.

A sobering reminder of Cambodian history. The landmine museum takes about 45 minutes to walk around, with a free audio guide. It is a reminder of the very recent horrors Cambodia has been through, and how Western governments took sides with the Khmers Rouge. A very interesting place, you will leave having definetly learned something. The 5 dollar entry fee goes to keeping the museum, but also to helping the home for children in need that is just behind the museum, so even if it seems a bit expensive for what it is, remember this is all for a good cause

Great to learn the shocking history of landmines. The land mine museum was a real eye opener. I had no idea of the total devastation that these horrendous things have caused to Cambodia and are still in some places. It is wonderful to know that they are working hard to eradicate them.

It could be so good. This Museum is close to being a fantastic experience, however, it is very dated and lacks details of the exhibits. The audio guide could have provided a lot more information, but I understand that most of the money goes back into the community. However, to put more money back would take a small amount of investment to attract more visitors.

A humbiling experience. This was a very humbling experience to visit this museum. A modest entry fee of US $5 and where the proceeds go to worthy causes such as clearing landmines, building schools, and building wells and more.The history of this place revolves around Mr Aki Ra who established the Cambodian Landmine Museum in 1997. He was an ex-child soldier who planted thousands of mines. He saw the devastating effects of these land mines and later returned to remove and defuse them with his homemade tools. Walking around the streets in Siem Reap one can witness many the surviving victims of these landmines and their devastating effects on them.At the museum you are provided with a headset where you can listen to the commentary and explanation of the various exhibits on display. Well worth visiting and combining with the outlying temples tour.
Well worth an visit. Much more interesting than I thought it would be, though a bit confusing getting around with the audio tour. The history is fascinating and the stories heartbreaking. Do visit.

Only when you are really into this. We stopped briefly. Nice exhibits about the war and the landmines which have been dug up and are still out there. So many other things to do .. personally wouldn't spend too much time here unless you lost someone in the war or are otherwise deeply interested in this part of the country's history.

Sobering but important to experience. Dropped in on way back from Banteay Srei. Well worth the stop. Aki Ra, the founder and self-taught mine removalist extraordinaire, is an amazing and heroic man. The Museum is not 'flash' but doesn't need to be. It offers some very sad and uplifting messages about the effect of landmines (still....even after many years have passed since the country was littered with them) and notes that amongst those countries that have not signed their support of eradicating the manufacture and use of landmines is the USA. Unfathomable and unforgivable - particularly in light of the assessment of three very senior US generals that are quoted there! Worth the small entry fee and worth an extra donation to help the continued care and schooling of those who have suffered the loss of limbs or sight.
Small yet Powerful. This small museum details the horror caused by landmines in history and today. It was difficult seeing the pictures of so many people severely injured and killed from landmines.

Fascinating. My group had the good luck of running into Bill as soon as we entered the museum: an American who lives with his wife in Cambodia, working on de-mining and educating children in Cambodia. He enthusiastically gave us a full tour of the place with all the historical information we could have asked for. He's a very engaging speaker and the history of landmines in Cambodia is both horrible and fascinating. It makes for a very educational trip and a nice diversion from temple visiting.

Informative tribute to de-mining Cambodia. This museum is a wonderful tribute to the efforts to remove landmines. Get the free audio guide to hear the story of how these horrid devices from all over the world have devastated this country and how one man's efforts have helped turn this around.
Good information. The landmine museum is full of good information that gives you a history of Cambodia and all the efforts to clear landmines.

Most informative. Learning about Aki Ra, founder of the museum and attached orphanage was highly inspiring. Orphaned by the Khmer rouge at the age of five, they made him a child soldier at ten. He defected to the Vietnamese army in his mid teens, and later served in the Cambodian army as well. When the civil war finally ended he used his expertise with laying land mines to begin single handedly dismantling them. The story goes on from there.

Special place built by special people. Went there yesterday and was lucky enough to have Bill Morse as the guide. Aki Ra is an amazing human being, but Bill to me is as amazing as. Gave his life to the cause and Cambodian people and is really humble. Well, small museum, but a lot of information and eye opening. Worth a 1h stop back from Banteay Sre. Invest time listening to the audio tour and reading everything, surprising how little us westerners know about this side of the world

Worth a Stop. Although we were on our honeymoon, I didn't want to spend time in Cambodia without reflecting on the relatively recent troubles the country has come through. The Landmine Museum gave us that chance, walking through the history of the war seen through the eyes of a child soldier who went on to become an activist and prominent de-miner. It's worth a visit, especially in combination with nearby Banteay Srei.

OK - exoerience may deopend on your guide. I was a solo traveller and was asked if I'd mind joining another group, which I didn't. However I was placed with a large group that had already left. The guide didn't wait for everyone to be at the point of the next exhibition before starting the explanation. The explanation was more about the capability of the equipment and effect of the land mines, rather than the history of the conflict - which is what I'd expected. Others may have different experiences with other guides.

Dropped in on way back from Banteay Srei. We stopped here on the way back from Bantreay SreiIt informed visitors about the amount of land mines that were laid , their destruction and the efforts being made to clear the minesWorth a visit if only to contribute to the cause

Educational . This is an hour out of town by tuk tuk. You need some form of ID or they won't give you the audio guide. Which is necessary here to make it more informative. I had no ID, luckily my tuk tuk driver gave them his drivers licence. Staff were rude, not helpful and spent their time chatting to each other, on their cell phones, playing with an iPad watching gang ham style- loud, or putting on makeup. Not appropriate behaviour when they should have been helpful, showing me around and instead of ignoring me. I emailed their management. It's a really really worthy cause and I would have donated extra above the entry price, but I was too irritated. Having completed my rant. It's worth a look if you have the time and interest. It's an eye opener just how many land mines are still there and are around the world. Chilling. The ride out by tuk tuk was a great ride. I really enjoyed it.
Very good museum, worth visiting. Great museum. Spent an hour here listening to the audio tour. Great cause needing more awareness and support.

Very Educational but depressing. It takes about one hour to visit and I am glad we did. It educates you on the atrocities that were inflicted on the Cambodian people. I have attached a picture of a wish list of things that if you do visit you can bring as donations for the museum to help distribute to those in need.

Need photo ID for audio guide. We could not get one since we had no photo ID, even offered cash as a deposit but no go. Nevertheless we were so glad we visited. We were all moved, humbled and informed after a brief tour. Highly recommended.

Small but worth the stop if your in the area. What this guy has done and continues to do is truly remarkable. What an amazing human being. It's just a shame that the small shop is not really inviting. They need to tidy it up and offer more variety. I really wanted to buy something to help support, but what was on offer was minimal and some it was not attractive. We did however donate.

Uplifting and educational at the same time. Went with a couple of teenagers and a partner, not all of whom are usually keen museum visitors. Everyone came away feeling moved by the vision of Aki Ra (former child soldier and museum founder) and the other stories of 'rescuers'. This is a must if on Siem Reap as it manages to balance the facts and devastation of the war (and other countries involvement) with the story of how individuals can make a difference.

A Moving tribute to a difficult time. We did not know what to expect when we entered this small, rather modest museum but left with an appreciation of the challenging times the Cambodian people have faced from both internal and external forces. The audio tour clearly explains how mines were used to destroy armored vehicles but more importantly people. The founder of the museum is a former Khmer Rouge fighter who laid down thousands of mines only to become a leader in deactivating these mines. If you go bring various toiletries, pens and pencils and notebooks to help support the various students that benefit from the funds generated from the museum

Excellent and a must visit site. Very informative, very confronting but also very inspiring and educational. We took a tuk tuk out here and it was about 50mins each way with the roads being ok but bumpy in some areas however having the cool breeze and seeing the country side was amazing. The museum taught us a lot about what has occurred and what still is going on in regards to land mines. The owner is just amazing given his past with the the former Khmer Rouge and how one can turn over a completely new chapter. It's ok for families and alike but whatever your plans are in Siem Reap make the trip out here.

Visit if you can. I found the museum and its contents to be surprisingly informative about Cambodias widespread landmine and the heroes who risk to clear them. The audio tour is worth taking the time to listen and hear firsthand how man who created the museum, came to disarm landmines for a living. I highly recommend visiting since it is an important subject to discuss and learn.

Culturally impacted. Wow what a place, the stories you read as you go through the small museum are sad, inspiring and impacted me deeply. While a somber morning tour I'm glad I know have this knowledge and hopefully can be apart of the solution. Entry is $5 per person so a bit pricey for the size but the funds go to a very worthy tour. To fill our day we joined this with a quick visit to the butterfly centre and the animal conservation centre.

Worth the Visit. Very educational museum, one of the men who's been involved with demining in Cambodia for 10+ years answered any questions we had and talked about life in Cambodia in general for a good amount of time which we really appreciated!

Must do. This was part of the tour arranged by our guide. While we live here we had family visiting and we thought to was important to take them here even though they only speak Italian. Our guide translated the tour. Overall, the museum should be on everyone's travel plans. It is well worth the visit and the tour doesn't take very long. Admission and donations go to a great cause.

Must Visit. What Aki Ra has done here is amazing and his story is one that ppl need to know. Looking after the kids hurt by land mines and what your entrance $5USD does will help this cause continue to do what they do...We stopped by on our way back to Siem Reap from Banteay Srei but definitely worth the visit and the self guided tapes was perfect...

Worth a visit to this small museum. This small but important museum is worth a short stop. The admission fee and donations go to a great cause and there is a lot to learn even for the biggest 'expert'. I recommend the professionally made audio tour guide available in a variety of languages to get the most out of the visit. The museum does a good job of describing the curse of landmines in Cambodia and the world and I believe is making a positive contribution to solving this problem. This museum can be visited going to or from Banteay Srei temple and is also very close to the butterfly farm. The three stops together make for a good half-day+ trip from Siem Reap by tuk tuk.

Worth a detour. Make arrangement with your tuctuc driver and stop by back from the temples trip. They tend to ignore this site, possibly for selling you a dedicated trip. Worth seeing it for remembering where you are.

worth the drive. It took us a long time to get out because our tuk-tuk couldn't go very fast and kept overheating. That said, well worth it. Our guide it Phnom Penh told us about Aki Ra, so seeing the museum helped to round out the story. If you have the time, definitely a must-see

Highly recommend if traveling w kids 10+. Small but powerful museum. Had a real impact on out 10 and 13 yr old kids and on mom and dad too. The history of Cambodia is so sad and this is a great place to introduce that to your kids.

An educational experience in a current world problem. Land mines are affecting millions of people worldwide. This small nonprofit museum, which takes about an hour to see, is a very worthwhile and educational experience, not to be missed. I'd say that it's suitable for elementary school aged kids and their families.

Small but inspiring. This museum was very informative and provides more background to what the Cambodians lived with, and still live with today. Proceeds all go to helping others as well and worth the trip. Visit the Butterfly Centre nearby while you're there.

Impressive . By visiting this museum you're also supporting demining in Cambodia. They have a school for children affected by mines or that cannot afford school so the fee and donations also go to this cause.

Small scale museum - visit if you're passing. The best thing about this museum is that by visiting and paying an entrance fee you are helping the landmine clearance charity. The museum is interesting but very small so it won't take you long. There are plenty of knowledgeable volunteers on hand so you can ask any questions. Visit approx. 30 mins.

Aki Ra is inspiring. I've known about Aki Ra and the Landmine Museum for years now through Project Enlighten, a small NGO that does a lot of great work in Cambodia. When Aki Ra was nominated for the CNN Heroes award I knew I definitely wanted to go visit. It cost $5 and the proceeds go to the continued efforts of Aki Ra and his team to clear more landmines, and also goes towards the 20ish kids who live in the compound behind the mine (for their living expenses and education). Most of the information is just typed laminated papers so with extra donations, I'm sure they could get everything up to higher standards, but it's definitely very informative and great to know that your money spent their goes to a great cause.There's a small gift shop there, as well, which also helps support the children living there.

Important stop. Museum is organized into 4 different rooms... each one having good information about the history of landmines and violence in Cambodia. It's an important place to visit and on the way to Bantaey Srai.

Sobering Yet Wonderful. Sobering because it tells a true horror story of the destruction that land mines wreak on people for hundreds of years after they have been laid! Wonderful because of the brave and amazing work of Aki Ra. Go and learn and make a difference with your contribution. This place was absolutely worth visiting.

Worth a visit . Went to visit the landmine museum on the way back from Kulen mountain. It's ok and does what it says on the tin but it's about 45 minutes to an hour from Siem Reap. Wouldn't visit a second time but it's a good educational visit

A worthwhile place to visit . Take the time to visit this museum whilst you are in Siem Reap. The $5 entrance fee not only provides a good insight into the history of Cambodia, & the ongoing problem of landmines in Cambodia and worldwide, but the money raised is used to support disadvantaged children & pay the staff a decent wage.Before we went we saw the wish list on the website so we were able to take along some simple items like toothbrushes, toothpaste, soap, books and pencils. Take photo id to get an audio guide - it really enhances the visit.

Worth a visit to understand the history of Cambodia, at least part of it.. Worth a visit on it's own. However, if you already have plan to visit Banteay Srei, just drop by as it is on the way. Entry fee is USD5.

Fascinating history but sad. A must see in Siem Reap. We spent over an hour there and really well presented. Combine Landmine Museum with a trip to Banteay Srei which is a very different and fascinating temple and also well worth the longish trip out there. If doing both suggest by car but tuk-tuk fine if only going to Museum.

Sobbering must do. As upsetting as a visit here might be you really should attend here as part of properly understanding the context of this beautiful country.Landmines still kill/maim and the work this organisation does to try and prevent this is truly inspiring. Every visit helps the cause.Do take your time to read all the displays; this is not big museum with lots of exhibits it is the story supporting by the munitions that makes the point.

負の遺産に目を向けて　Look at the legacy of tragedy (The Cambodia Landmine Museum). 内戦時に敷設され、回収された地雷が展示されています。中央のケースにうずたかく積み上げられた地雷を見ると人間の愚かさ、恐ろしさがひしと伝わってきます。私が行ったとき大人一人５ドルで、うち１ドルが地雷除去に使われるようです。また寄付代わりにお土産を買うこともでき、地雷型の石けんが売っていました。You can see thousands of the landmines which were settled during the civil war. Ticket price is $5 for a adult. $1 of each ticket is used to clear landmines. You can buy souvenirs. I was impressed with the soup shaped landmine.

Very informative, but quite far from town. This museum has a great story, lots of information about landmines (eg. they do not *click* like in the movies), and showcases many hundreds of disarmed landmines. At US$5 for the entry, it's a good value and takes 1 hour to listen to the audio tour.Note that it is 27km from Siem Reap, so a tuk-tuk ride will cost about US$15 roundtrip and takes 1 hour each way.

Though provoking place. The museum is very small but the impact that the exhibits have on you is great. If one wants to find out more about the impact of the various wars on the lives of ordinary Cambodians one must visit the museum. The displays are simple but extremely thought-provoking. Remember to carry your passport with you or else you won't get an audio guide. The museum is outside Siem Reap so remember to carry plenty of water and snacks. A trip by tuk tuk should be $10. The ride to the museum is a great photo opportunity as one passes through rice fields and villages.

Multitude of muntions.. Seeing the evidence of what the country was subjected to over a number of conflicts which are still taking their toll on farmers and children each year even now. Engage one of the disabled war veterans as a guide to get a fuller explanation of the many exhibitions.

Worthwhile visit. Informative to see how Aki Ra, former child soldier and now land mine detection and disarmament expert, established a method to help rid his country of land mines. The audio guide helps explain the various exhibits. The glass house that looked so pretty from a distance, on closer inspection contained the various land mines and weapons that had since been safely disarmed; I found this to be a sad reminder of how many local people have been injured or killed by hidden mines. We stopped here on the way back from the Pink Temple. At only $5 entry fee it is recommended to visit. Part of the fee goes to supporting the work of disarming land mines. Our tour guide said Aki Ra was a national hero, and I can see that he is certainly deserving of this appellation.

A fascinating and insightful view of the history of the Cambodian genocide. Visiting the museum was 5 dollars, which was well worth it, you get given an audio guide at the beginning and walk around the various exhibits which are numbered. There are photos, weapons, landmines which have been extracted by a former child soldier (the owner of the museum) and other volunteers. It is quite emotional however extremely insightful and it is lovely to learn about the genocide. An event which was not that long ago but is hardly known of around the world. It is great to learn about the country and know it in a different light. It allows you to appreciate how brave and courageous the people of Cambodia are, rising above the horrific events they faced. I would definitely recommend people visit the museum, it cost us (four people) 16 dollars in total from our guest house (Bou Savy- close to town) to get there and back which as reasonable considering how out of town it was.

Educating and riveting. Great place to learn some valuable information about an amazing man, his incredible journey and the thousands of lives he had saved and changed. Really eye opening and ours kids aged 10/12 loved it too. There are tapes to guide you through or guided books that even my 10 year old girl followed to take her through the museum. We were all so moved. This is one not to be missed!

Equally sad and inspiring. The museum is about 45 minutes out of Siem Reap near Bantea Srei temple and well worth the effort. We added it to our full day Bantea Srei/Kulen Mountain/Beng Mealea tour. Ticket sales go towards maintaining the centre and supporting landmine victimsWe got there at around 9am and it was really quiet and peaceful with just us there, which gave us a chance to easily read through all of the exhibits.Aki Ra the founder tells his amazing life story as a child soldier for the Khmer Rouge before devoting his life to removing landmines throughout Cambodia and caring for young landmine victims. It's equal parts sad and inspiring to see the work of Aki and his team - highly recommended.

Great reality check. This well set museum with guided head sets is a grim but worthwhile look into these ridiculous devices and how they have effected this county. It's great reality check for my students away from the world of temples and market shopping.

Stop here and try to meet Bill Morse if he is at the Museum. If you have enjoyed the UXO Museum in Luang Prabang, Laos, you will appreciate a stop at this small but great museum, where you can learn about a sad side of the Cambodian History and have a broader view besides the ancient ruins and temples.You can ask your tuk tuk to take you there while coming back from Banteay Srei temple, as it is on the way to Siem Reap. There are about four rooms, but there is a lot to read and it is all very well explained. If you are nerdish, you can easily spend 1 or 2 hours there in reading the explanations or in listening to Bill Morse's stories.We were very lucky to meet Bill at the Museum and this made our visit special. He is a former US Army soldier, and retired teacher and business man. Bill has helped Aki Ra, an ex-Khmer Rouge soldier, in the demining work and he is helping in running the Museum and the project behind, which also includes teaching to orphans with his wife Jill.
