Worth a visit. This museum provides a lot of information about Cambodia's war-painted history, land mines and weaponry, effects that these weapons still have on the population today, and a serious look into the de-mining efforts.

Sad but a must see.... If you'd like to understand the last 60 years of Cambodia and also see how individuals can change over their lifetimes (I won't give a spoiler, but the founder of the museum has an incredible life story), this is the place to go to.

Don't miss this place - Well worth a visit.. We called in on the way back from a temple visit and I am so glad we did. Granted the museum is not large but you need to remember that is museum is not run by a large corporation or local government. This museum is a great example of less is more. The audio guide is well worth a listen. One reviewer commented that the museum was anti american. I didn't see this at all and in fact throughout my stay in Cambodia this was not apparent. It did suprise me as after visiting the museum I did some research and discovered that the USA dropped 2.5 million tones of bombs on Cambodia for four years without congresses approval. Nixon gave the order and it was done in secret. Consider that 1.5 million tons where dropped on Europe by the allies and shows the extent of the bombing here. I would thoroughly recommend this museum because despite it's size it is very worthwhile. If you walk around it will take 5 mins BUT if you really visit the museum and read the description and listen to the audio guide you will need 45mins to an hour. In summary it's a must do (as is the War museum in Siem Reap), they are both worth a visit.

Getting Real. If you want a deeper Cambodian experience stop here and have a look at what the locals have been through over the past 50 years. It will challenge all that you take for granted in your life.

Eye-opening . After seeing the beauty of the temples in Cambodia we had a day of visiting museums. (See my other reviews)We hired a tuktuk for a few hours and this museum was our first stop, it's extremely informative with plenty to read and see. The story of the curator is sad and after buying a book in the shop on site about the children of the killing fields and their true stories under the rule of the Khmer Rouge it helps you understand much more what the people of Cambodia went through and what some are still going through even now. 1 USD to make and lay one landmine, 1000 USD to find one now and disarm it, just think about it. On the whole make the effort to come to this museum and see what mines are really like.

Humbling Experience. Like many others, I stopped here after visiting the temple at Banteay Srey. $3 for entrance and $3 for the audio tour. I highly recommend the detailed audio guide. The guide will keep you gripped for about an hour if you breathe in all the detail. You will learn about an important part of history that everyone should know. The museum maybe small physically but the message relayed and the work they do is immense. Aki Ra, a true hero among men.

Very Somber. A tough but inspirational memorial. Cambodia has a very complex history and landmines are a huge part of that, many still active in some areas. The money goes to survivors and removal. You can see art from survivors and read stories from those effected.

Humbling - definitely worth a visit . We went here on our way back from Banteay Srei as it is a bit out of Siem Reap so would recommend combining the two.Whilst in Cambodia you can't escape the evidence of what a destructive impact the land mines have on the people here, and it was humbling and inspiring to see the great work that is being done here to help.Absolutely worth a visit, highly informative and very well done!

Really great (small) museum and NGO. Really glad we stopped here today between temples. Very informative and great to see the work being done here. Helps give context of Cambodia more recently, which is really important when visiting. Loved how they did it - has the feel of something authentic to a small NGO (a bit "mom and pop") while also feeling professional and well done. I recommend the audio guide and budgeting about 45 min (should definitely give at least 30 and could see taking an hour). Also price is $5 now but still sort it and you walk away wanting to give more for their work.

Don't miss this short stop!!!. $3 ticket, not much but goes towards the relief facilty for adults and children set up by Aki Ra is a small price to pay.If you don't know the story of on this place you are in for a lesson that will change your world view! Donation at the door and free guide that walks you thru the museum. About 30 to 45 minutes long. If you go to Bantrey shrei it will be about halfway from Seim Reap. You will see the human spirit at work in this place. There is also a very good shop, proceeds again go towards the facilty.

Must See. We called in on the way back from Banteay Srei The history of the man who started the museum is incredible and inspiring and gives hope for man. He became part of the Khmer Rouge at a very young age and laid land mines, later he joined the Vietnamese army and fought the Kymer Rouge. Today he finds and removes land mines. I found the talk very moving and cannot understand why anyone would complain about the museum. Everyone should call in and leave a donation even if they are not interested in looking at land mines. The donations also go towards educating children

Very glad I went. Don't miss!. There's some great info and visuals here, and a phenomenal story behind the guy who runs it to boot. If you like history or learning about the war or military stuff, go here. Also for a great cause.

Really interesting place. This was a really interesting museum. It is tiny but there is a lot of information, audio guides and guidebooks in different languages. Aki Ra's life story is incredible. This is a good half hour-hour stop on the way to Banteay Srea.
A very interesting place to visit... Spend some time to listen to the narrative & you will learn a lot. Improving all the time with it's facilities & information.

Incredible work they do!. It is HOT to do this in the middle of the day, but so worth it. The ride to the museum is a lovely way to see the countryside and traditional way of living. Stop by the roadside stands and buy some scarfs or small baskets - it will be much more helpful to the people to buy here than in front of the temples where many tourists go. Audio tour of the museum is free and absolutely worth doing. What great work this organization is doing! A truly inspiring story of people doing what is right and hard in order to make the world a better place. Please check out the photo I shared regarding their current "wish list" at the children's home. I wish I knew about this in advance so I could have brought in a bagful of soap or something.

Informative visit. We went here with our tour guide Rany on our way to Banteay Srei, it was $5 dollars each entry fee and the money goes to a good cause.We found the displays and information clear and easy to understand.There are various rooms to visit and it took us around an hour to cover everything as it was not overly busy.This museum is such a worthwhile visit as it highlights the horrific devastation caused by the landmine's, there are still so many landmine's that need clearing and many people still get killed or injured on a regular basis.This is such a worthwhile visit for a worthwhile cause.

Please come!. Totally worth your time (1 hour from Siem Reap) and money ($2). Go for the free audio tour. Informative, emotional and eye-opener! Your trip to Siem Reap is not complete until you visited Cambodia Landmine Museum.

Must see. After visiting so many tempels, it was time to see something different. I am happy we took the time to listen to one of the guides at the museum about what this place is about, how they help with the clearing of the mines, and what horrible things have happened here not so long ago. It is something that must not be forgotten. It is great to see how so many people are showing their devotion by helping out in any way they can. This place makes a difference.
Interesting, great insight to the local history. A must visit for anyone interested in the history of Cambodia. Very inexpensive visit with all proceeds going to further efforts

Basic but Important . Basic but important part of Cambodian history. Disappointing as I had opportunity to go to that landmine museum in Laos where the focus was more on prosthetics for kids and adults still suffering. Friend commented the collection of mines and weapons made it look like an armory with rusting artifacts. Maybe a focus on how they are helping landmine victims would be great

Interesting and worthwhile supporting. A short visit for us with a little tour. Good history lesson. A great organization to raise money and awareness, plus the good works with victims. We brought a donation for the school and you can also buy art buy the students in the Giftshop .Very amazing stories here !
Well worth a visit. You can visit here as part of your tour of the area ,well worth looking in to see how much distruction land mines cause.
Educational. Informative. I'd recommend it if you haveno had your fill of information on the genocide that took place here. True personal stories of Cambodians.

Inspiring. Although a very serious subject this museum tells an inspiring story about a fantastic man who converted from boy soldier to a local hero removing the land mines he had previously been part of putting out. As well starting up an orphanage. Truely impressive.

Very basic but a must see, for the history alone.. The museum is quite tired but when you start reading the history of Cambodia, their struggles and the estimated amount of landmines still there, it is worth going as your entrance fee goes to good causes. Very humbling.

Educational and moving. The museum is actually very small, but we probably spend an hour and a half working through the displays and listening to the audio recordings. If you have a tok tok for the day at the temples and have plans to go to the lady temple, the land mine museum is on the way and would provide a nice break from templing.Bring picture id as security deposit to allow you to borrow an audio device. They accept Angkor passes as security deposit.

Worth the drive. Confrontingly simple. A real eye opener to the horrors that still plague Cambodia today. Lovely exhibits, and you can see where the children play in the school on site. About $5-6 entry from memory
You'll really learn something.... Should be on everyone's top 10 list. You'll leave Siem Reap having learned something and meeting people who have truly devoted their lives to making a difference.

Money from ticket goes to good cause.. This museum is very small, but important.The $5USD entrance fee is good as it goes towards victims, orphaned children who live at the museum and goes towards the removal of the land mines still in the areas.There was an american man discussing how people are still effected by the landmines. Its seriously horrible. They have landmines from several nationalities.If you're in the area, visit, it is very important to understand what the khmer rouge has done.It was on my way to some temples, so visit.

sad and moving museum. if you like weapons, this museum could change your opinion or enrich you a different perspective at least. if you want to know some sad stories from the past of Cambodia, this is the place.

Small and moving place to visit. Be sure to stop here. It is a bit out of town but very worth your time. While it deals directly with difficult matters it focuses on getting things done and looking forward. A place not to miss.
Great local story. We returned again after visiting last year. It is more about the story than the museum itself. Nice to see locals helping locals.

Thoughtful place to stop and contemplate very recent history in the midst of one's temple visits. Small but poignant archive and history of the use of landmines against soldiers and civilians, in Cambodia and elsewhere. This place really made me so grateful for the extremely gentle and friendly aspect of all the Cambodians I met during my visit, it really helps one believe that people can be better than they have been thus far, especially for these very deserving people

A Stunning Picture of the Inhumanity of War. Aki Ra founded this organization. He was conscripted as a child by the Khmer Rouge and before 12 was killing and planting land mines in Cambodia. Once Pol Pot was defeated and the wars in SE Asia ended, he was repatriated and has spent the rest of his life personally locating & deactivating land mines. He has also established several school/orphanage complexes where the very poor village children with and without parents can get an education, live and be fed. The sheer variation of landmines and other incendiary weapons Aki Ra has deactivated and has on display is terrifyingly real. And audio histories are available as you complete the tour. You won't forget the visit here, especially as you encounter locals with missing limbs, hands, feet and eyes. Even logging elephants have been killed or maimed by the remaining mines. We saw 3 at Lek's Elephant Nature Park in Chiang Mai, Thailand, who'd been rescued by Lek

Insightful, interesting, important. . Very good museum. Although not big there is a lot of information worth knowing inside. The sad but very recent history of cambodia is felt in the stories and photos of the students that go here and the amputees who recieve help from this organisation. The man who is responsible for this lovely place started off as a forced child soldier for the khemer rouge,and later on it became his mission to get as many landmines found and removed from the country as possible, which he physically does himself. His story is amazing, and when I left the museum I felt amazed at what hes accomplished and shocked at how most people will not know of him.Removing the amount of landmines so far has taken many years and a lot of hard work and sadly they still have a long way to go. While we were in Battambang there was a story in the news about an anti tank mine that exploded killing one man and injuring two others. This museum is important to the current time of cambodia as well as their past and worth a visit.

Go see this and donate!. A disturbing but in other ways very inspiring visit to this small but well appointed active memorial to the toxic legacy of landmines in Cambodia. We are all, in some way, responsible. We all need to assist this NGO and others to fix the problem forever.

must visit. For all who born in the 90's unaware of the tragic civil war that happened in cambodia, this place is an eye-opener on some of the really bad stuff that happened in this country. During the vietnam war and then later civil war between khmer rouge and the army, lots of landmines and unexploded bombs dropped from the air were found in the jungles numbering in millions. they are still present nowadays numbering around half a million. this is the story of akira, the boy soldier who was initially recruited for khmer rouge(the rebels) and who himself planted tons of land mines and then once the khmer rouge was defeated, felt sick and took upon himself and started removing all the mines he planted. There is an AV guide that explains each of the landmine and photos that were taken at various points of time. This place is definitely a must visit place to remind us of a dark episode in history.

Interesting array of land mines and the noble cause to clear them. The museum was set up by a person who served with the Khmer Rouge and then with the Vietnamese army, but after the war, he wanted to clear the country of the landmines planted during the war in order to make the country safer.

Recalling tragedy chapter of Cambodia history. We need something different from the temple icons of Siem Reap then ask the local agent where to go. Visit the Land Mine Museum in Siem Reap for a sobering look at Cambodia’s relatively recent history under the Khmer Rouge. It's located near from Banteay Srei (I wrote another review), and can be combined with Banteay Srei in 1 day excursion. This is the museum of Mines and Missiles existing there since 1970s, but newly been disarmed since 1998 after Pol Pot passed away. Three thousand people are currently working in Cambodia, removing landmines. The museum gave us a new perspective on life in Cambodia.

Sobering . Being ex-services and from an older generation, I already know a little bit about mines.Notwithstanding this and dispite the crude amateurishness of the presentation, I was moved, saddened and sobered by what I saw here.The cause is good and I've contributed to it.

Sobering Must See. Capturing 50 years of history, landmines, and sad reality these things create. Run by a charity organisation, not funded by the government, which also looks after initially children who were the victims of land mines, but more recently orphaned and children with disabilities. The museum is a detailed explanation of the history of the country and the impact of warfare. Worth the $5 entrance which includes a guided tour/audio. Telling the story through the eyes of the man who runs the charity and has personally removed thousands of mines over the years!The organisation is also doing an amazing job looking after the children, so if you can take along some or one of the items they really need, such as stationery, toothpaste, flip flops (5-24), soap, hair shampoo etc. that would really help...A good and worth while 1-2 hour exhibit.
A lot of Info. The museum is about 7km south of Benteay Srei Temple. A lot of documentation. A privately accumulated collection of War Mines & Military Equipment.
Good museum.. Its a sad reality that landlines are a constant problem. This museum displays this really well. Highly recommended.

Mindblowing visit. A place with lot of historical stories & pictures. Mind blowing. If you are going, you may consider to bring along items they need: handsanitiser, toothbrush & toothpaste, writing notebooks, laundry soap, handbar soap, shampoo, pen & pencils, flipflop etc. My friends and I gave away all the stationery we brought to Siem Reap to the kids here.

A Must See. This small museum had a big impact on us! It is a bit out in the country between some of the temple ruins, but is well worth the trip. Admission is only $5 US . You will learn about the tragic history of Cambodia there, but also the hope that has come with the help of many heroes.

An interesting museum and a must see place to visit. I found this important museum to be very informative about the history of land ines and poor victims who were hurt or killed by theses cruel weapons. I handed in a donation class posters, pencils, erasers and various art equipment, along with hand steriliser. As I was walking arou GD the museum, it was such a moving and emotional experience to see my donated parcel being taken to the school for poor primary students and orphans who are taught in an adjacent property to the museum. Some of proceeds of your ticket will help the poor and needy. Donations , no matter how small are greatly appreciated. Highly recommend this small museum run by local communities.

A sobering reminder of the aftermath of warfare. The story behind the founding of the museum is inspiring. There are several small buildings in the museum with lots and lots of different kinds of deactivated mines and ordnance. You get a new appreciation for what happens when the armies disband and go home and leave behind all the mines which can kill and maim farmers, hikers, and explorers. You can get an audio guide that provides more information about the exhibits.

Excellent collection of material and exhibits. We visited by Tuk Tuk - it is far out into the countryside but worth the pleasant journey. The story behind the once boy soldier turned peace keeper and his endeavours to free his country from the explosives he used to place us fascinating - it explains some of the difficulties the people of Cambodia faced without having a choice - well with the visit and excellent ongoing work with amputees and an orphanage next door which you cannot visit incidentally if that's not your kind of thing...

Must visit!. The landmine museum is much more than a building with old landmines. It is also a community project for landmine victims and a charity for orphaned children. The trip is best done on the way to some of the outer temples, but make sure you stop by this attraction on the way. The tour costs $5 (all proceeds to charity) and has a detailed and free audio guide. A fantastic visit not only on landmines, but also covering the Cambodian struggles over the past 50 years up to the present day.Go!

Very interesting and unique museum . I really enjoyed my visit to the land mine museum. It is a very small space with only a few rooms but the information is very detailed and explains the history and present land mine situation in Cambodia. The guy who founded the museum is a inspirational man and it was great to read about his life and the others who work at the museum. It also has a orphanage (not for visitors) so visiting and buying a tickets really does go to help people. I would really recommend this museum.

Must see. The ride to the museum alone is worth it, seeing the rural countryside. The museum experience was informative and a bit heartbreaking but also heartwarming. A must see if you're in Siem Reap and want to know more about the history.

One of many highlights of trip to Cambodia. We were fortunate that one of the directors showed us around this museum. Though small it had a powerful impact. Seeing how little the mines cost to produce, the damage they can do, and how much money and effort to clear them.Madness and greed on the part of those producing and laying them, untold harm to those who are affected by them, indifference on the part of many countries in clearing them! Our thanks to those in Cambodia and elsewhere who are making an effort to clear the mines at great risk to themselves.

Interesting. It looks like a giant scrap yard but there is plenty to make it worth a visit. We strolled round on our own but there are war veterans who are happy to give a you a guided tour if you want. Nice way to spend an hour or two and get your hands on some weaponry!

Have to visit!!!. A huge insight into the history, not just of cambodia but also of the planets use of landmines. Inspiring to see. Ask if Bill is available, he does a great tour, no extra cost but donations appreciated.

Great to visit and to learn more about the recent history of Cambodia. This is a small-ish museum about 30-45 minutes north of Siem Reap by tuk tuk and best combined with a visit to Banteay Srey. I found the exhibits interesting and informative and I appreciated learning about the more recent history of the country in the progress. We ran into an American expat there who was helping run it and he was very informative as well.

Sobering. The final stop on our long tour of the area's temples. Whilst you marvelled at the skills of the temple builders and the beauty of their work and also how nature had regained the land you could not be further away from it than at the Landline Museum. How many countries made these deadly weapons which are not targeted but indiscriminately kill farmers well after the end of the civil war. The work of the people at the centre is the beacon of hope and this is a charity well worth supporting. This is a place well worth visiting.
Don't miss it! . A place you have to add to your itinerary. The museum gives good insights in the terror of war and describes the work of the NGO.

A MUST. I went their based on some positive comments here on Tripadvisor and I was so happy I did. This is a very small but very informative expo on the topic of land mines and the devastating impact those mines had and still have on Cambodia and its people.The place is also kind of a charity as it offers some "disadvantaged" children not only a home but also a school. Great project which deserves our support with the entrance fee and some additional donations. I usually never donate money (yes, shame on me for that) bit I donated quite a big amount at the end of my visit there. If you visit this place, do not miss the letters written by the young children who attended or are still attending school there. Their stories are very, very moving to say the very least. The person who doesn´t get emotional when reading these letters must have a heart of stone. Excellent visit!

Heartbreaking history but a wonderful place.. Small museum with fabulously informative audio tour. Heartbreaking stories but with wonderful endings.What a Man Aki Ra is! Felt good to be able to make a donation that will go some way to helping these wonderful kids who reside there. Well worth a visit.

5 for Aki Ra. The museum is far from the Angkor temple complex which you cost you more transportation money. However it is definitely somewhere you should go! It is very simple and has a "beautiful" story behind it. It gives a very good insight on the Vietnam war and civil war in Cambodia which are both fairly recent. It costs 5 dollars entrance which are for donation. Try to add this to a "big tour" package or don't miss it if you visit Banteay Srei, since it is on the way.

Landmine museum. I know a lot of people might not want to visit this on holiday They might both think it aporpriate, but given the history if Vietnam it deserves a visit and although small still has a powerful message and because of all the trouble they have gone to set it up deserves a visit .There is a shop selling hand made goods and the money raised goes to the help of the upkeep of the orphanage attached next door.This deserves a visit.

Be prepared to be confronted by the horrors of war. Everyone should come here to be immersed in the horror of war, and the goodness of the heart. Want to know all about these discriminating killers that lurk in fields for decades, then injure children? Here's the story, including thousands of de-fused anti-personnel landmines and larger implements of war. It may not turn you into a pacifist, but it may force you to question how we go to war.

Very interesting museum, which is for such a good cause. I am so glad that we managed to fit this museum into our busy schedule. It was very interesting and gave you lots of information about land mines and the devasting affects they have. It also goes through the inspirational work that Aki Ra has done for landmines and victims. Your ticket money goes to help victims of landmines which is such a good cause and you can make further donations if you wish.

Thought provoking. Landmines and their effects on populations have always been something that I've taken an interest in so I was really pleased to finally get chance to visit here during a recent trip.It's a reasonably small but to the point museum with a reasonable amount of information to work through and audio guides available, but all in all a very sombre and poignant place to visit, it's certainly nice to see the huge progress being made in clearing away and lessening the impact of these devices, and read the stories of the people involved.

Take time to visit. This is such an interesting museum that is doing amazing things with the money it receives from the small entrance fee. It was enlightening, sad, and hopeful at the same time. There is an audio tour that helps guide you through the museum. There is also a volunteer from the US who gives a wonderful history lesson while personalizing his experiences and work at the museum. Make this a stop while in Siem Reap--it will help you understand Cambodia and its people much better.
Landmind Museum. Entrance ticket is 5 Dollar. Nothing much to see at the museum. I am fine with the ticket in the name of charity. I do expect more things from the museum.

Very interesting. Very interesting - everyone should see this once - opens your eyes to what war is, and how cruel and wicked people are to each other in these situations. Maybe the gift shop could be painted and some new stock at a more reasonable price - as I am sure people would buy things to support the victims of landlines and their families ..behind the museum. Well done though.
really sobering place. A really personal view of land mines and their removal by the person who has done more than anyone else to remove land mines and raise awareness of them

Informative & insightful - worth a visit. We travelled by tuk-tuk (about an hour out of Siem Reap) and both enjoyed the trip and appreciated the Landmine Museum. It offers a personal insight into the landmine problem through the eyes of a former Khmer Rouge soldier and later in life, a prolific de-miner. Both the museum and the non-profit that operates it are relatively small but pack a punch. Be sure to pick up the free audio guide (only photo ID required) to make the whole thing more meaningful. The commentary is very good. The non-profit that operates the museum also operates a home for children and youth from disadvantaged backgrounds and seems to do a lot of good work. Your $5 admission and any donation you choose to make will further their endeavours.If you have a half day to spare, you would likely really benefit from a visit here. You can combine it with the Banteay Srey Butterfly Museum, which is on the way back to SR. Also a worthwhile stop and a good pick-me-up. Alternately, it could be combined with a visit to Banteay Srey temple.

Gives a glimpse of the miseries suffered by Cambodians. Aki Ra, the Do-it-yourself deminer has done commendable work by devoting his life in removing landmines. This landmine museum deserves a visit, if for nothing else, to salute the hero. Audio tour available for those interested in learning more. Definitely recommended.

Interesting museum, lots of very interesting information. The museum was user-friendly, interesting, cost-effective and well laid out. Surprisingly non-biased. All proceeds towards the orphanage attached. Learning about the modern day Cambodia is a perfect complement to seeing the centuries-old Khmer temples.
Old and little dated. The "owner' is inspirational. The exhibits a - should it be are dated and a little weak. Go there for the great - should it be great - exprience

Small Museum but worth a visit to understand the damage left behind by landmines. The museum is small and displays a range of landmines that were used during the various wars waged in Cambodia. Even if you aren't a weapons enthusiast, it is worth a stop on the way back from Banteay Srei. The displays highlight the damage (both physical and psychological) that the landmines have caused to the local population.

Museum Visit. A fascinating museum with a wide range of artefacts. It was interesting to read different personal stories and gain a better understanding of the history of Cambodia and the conflict the people have experienced. A small museum and very interesting and engaging.

A must in Siem Reap!. Just a great story of Aki Ra - the ex child soldier of the Khmer Rouge and his quest to rid Cambodia of landmines. I'll let you find out more by yourself but the museum itself is beautifully arranged with 4 main rooms detailing his quest and more information on the cambodian history. The landmines are well presented and really hit home while the stories of the 18 or so children they help to support, although not related to the mines, are great and give an insight into the growing young cambodian society.A big plus was meeting Bill, an american who now works at the museum and for the foundation full time, and giving us a first hand idea of what the quest to rid the countgry of land mines entails. Having been to Phnom Penh and the killing fields/S21 this tied in nicely but if you're only going to Siem Reap then this is a must to visit to understand the country and its brutal recent past. Well worth the travel there (if you're going to Bantea Srey perfect to stop at on the way)!

Well worth a visit!. It took about 45 minutes to get there from town in a tuk tuk and whilst entertaining it was a little uncomfortable. Perhaps a taxi would be better. The trip takes you along the perimeter road to the temples and far beyond. The museum is captivating - it has a very comprehensive explanation about what has occurred in Cambodia with land mines and what is currently occurring. This is a 'privately' run museum with a modest entry fee (a few US dollars) and has an orphanage at the back where land mine victims children are cared for. So many places in Cambodia and Vietnam encourage you to visit schools where the children have there study time disrupted by well wishing tourists the kids 'perform' for the tourist.....yuk. What I loved about the Landmine museum is that you don't see the school...the children are treated with respect and privacy. This experience felt genuine and I highly recommend it.

Great attraction for history buffs. When I arrived at the Cambodia Landmine Museum I was a taken back by just how many different types of landmines actually found in Cambodia. This attraction is very informative and tells the story of the history behind Cambodia's dark past and how people were affected during the Vietnam War. It also speaks of the affects it had on victims whom found these deadly weapons the movement of one man and a team to rid Cambodia of these dangerous time bombs.

It Made Me Cry. This is not the place for travelers who do not want their vacation to be interrupted by the unpleasant nature of real life, ut for those who are out in this area near Banteay Srey and want to learn more about the horrific struggle Cambodia has faced and still faces with landmines and unexploded ordinance, then stop for a brief visit here. I had no idea who many casualities are still being experienced.

Not a fun trip but an essential one in Siem Reap. The museum itself is not large, but the admission price (USD$5) is effectively a donation to a more than worthy cause. The content and information is too important to ignore and should be mandatory for all first time visitors to Cambodia in order to gain a better understanding of the (sadly too recent) social and historical context of this complicated country. There is an audio guide available with photo ID, as well as information, photos, and stories about the first hand consequences on those affected by landmines around the country. Not a fun trip, but an important one all the same.

Living History. Didn't think that we would get so much out of our visit but took the headphone tour and listened intently at each display, based around one mans Herculean effort to rid Cambodia of all forms of land mine - Aki Ra.What an absolute hero. Having fought with three different armies since being able to hold a gun, he then set off to put right a lot of the things that he had personally been involved with and a lot that he wasn't.Whilst I remember the struggles of the country under the Khmer Rouge I had no concept of the magnitude of the bombing that the country received from the Americans as part of their war on Vietnam. Absolutely shameful. You can only hope that developed nations would never allow such wrongs to happen again.To top our visit I got to shake the hand of Aki as he was filming a part documentary for a foreign company and happened to be at the museum.Overall a sobering experience but will help you to understand how the country has developed.

Visit it to understand Cambodia. Whilst it is not a large museum, or interactive, it does provide insight into the recent history of Cambodia. You visit all the temples and marvel at the architectural wonders, but here you are jolted back to the recent past (and current challenges) which is the foundation of the current Cambodian society. It is heart-rendering to visualise the atrocities experienced, but then it also forces the following question to mind "what strength of human spirit is needed to overcome such cruelties?".It is a short stop, but well worth it.

A simple museum. This was one of the must see place when you try to search what to do in Siem Reap. The place is near Bantey Srei. So when we did the temple tour we told our tuktuk driver to also pass by this museum. What we are expecting was the usual huge museum but unfortunately the land mine museum is just small. You can see the place in 30 minutes or less... When we went inside we were not provided by the tour recording which is part of what we had paid. But then we saw new comers coming in and they were provided one so we asked the lady if we can avail of those tour recordings and that's the only time she gave us one. We thought for a 5 usd charge as entrance fee it may be not worth it at first since the place is just small but the cause where the fee goes is all worth the penny.

Must to go. It is not so big building, because of private museum, but you must to go and donate.
5 US dollor per person but contributing for need or victim are payable as foreigner.
Free explanation earphone are ready but English only.
I realized very much about Cambodia.

Terrible Story that just has to be told. The landmine museum is one of the most moving experiences you can have. The recent history of Cambodia is so sad and the tragedy that befell these beautiful people is well documented here. If you were ever compelled to donate to a good cause then this is the one. Aki Ra we salute you.

Wow! . Our kids loved the tour with the American retiree working here. He brought the museum to life and they just couldn't get enough. We initially walked in and thought "ok, fifteen minutes tops" and left an hour and a half later. Lol. It was the highlight of our oldest son's day. It was also really convenient to visit from the woman's temple (Banteay Srei) - literally just down the road.

Moving and Important. Went here with a group of 10 folks from 15-72 and everyone was moved by this. Reading the stories and seeing the amazing good this man has done is remarkable. Looking at all the different horrible ways we can hurt each other is disturbing. This does not take long and is well worth the stop on the way to other things.

Worth a look. It's staggering the amount of ordnance dropped or buried in Cambodia. The museum is modest but powerful. A percentage of the ticket price goes to support the orphanage in behind the museum. Very informative and quite overwhelming.

Worth a stop, particularly if Angkor Wat is your only Cambodia visit. If you are travelling extensively in Cambodia and visiting many of the memorials etc. in the country you may find this museum a little tame after the shocking and haunting exhibitions and memorials elsewhere but if Siem Riep is your only Cambodia stop then really recommend it.On the way back from Banteay Srey the museum costs 5 dollars and consists of 4 rooms dedicated to the story of Cambodian ngo clearing land mines. It is particularly worthwhile taking time to read the essays of children who have been hurt touching mines in the country, or who are now staying at the centre associated with the NGO. Moving without being gory it is also ok to bring children inside.

A must visit to understand Cambodia. This little museum was high on my list of places to visit. The museum gives a history of the battles of the khmer rouge and an understanding of how and why they fought. It also entails how many land mines were planted and why, even now, people are still being injured by this hidden menace. The museum also provides an education for under privileged children. make sure you leave enough time to get the whole story. we only had 30 mins in a packed agenda and i would have happily stayed for a lot longer

Interesting testament to one mans passion!. A reminder of a darker recent past of this beautiful country and a shining example of what a difference one person can make. Don't miss the opportunity to explore this inspiring place.
Confronting museum. This museum is not large and is quite a drive out of town, but well worth the visit. What sort of people invent a weapon whose only use is to maim people???????

Humbling . We visited the Cambodian Landmine Museum today. The stories there had me crying my eyes out. Carpet bombing 60,000 target zones with 120 bombs dropped on each target, not to mention over 4 million land mines still not cleared: 1 in 300 Cambodians are a victim of land mines. The charity here at the museum have set up a school and living arrangements for children orphaned or abandoned in the area. They give them somewhere to live, they give them schooling, and at the end of it everyone gets a university scholarship. The founder Aki Ra, began dismantling land mines by hand years ago and spearheaded the missions to rid the K5 belt and beyond, it's resulted in a major decline in Landmine accidents, deaths and amputations. What they are doing at the centre and all of the volunteers there is amazing and moving. And to Bill, thanks for arranging the audio tour and what you and your wife have done is commendable. Really makes you appreciate how lucky we all are!

Don't miss this. Don't miss this fascinating insight into a massive problem largely unknown by many. It won't take you long and you will come away with a much greater appreciation of the challenges faced by those who live in the country and the brave people who go out to clear the mines. You will also discover that there is no safety net for those unfortunate enough to be injured by mines except charity.

Wow. If you are a history buff this is a must. There are 4 exhibit rooms. The entrance fee is $5.00. A lot of interesting stories. Cambodia still has a lot of land mines in the fields. There is a lot of information to take it. Make sure you bring some sort of picture id because you are given a headset to listen to. You can rent there by tuk tuk or by car there is no public transportation.

Horrific. The cruelty that man can inflict on is totally evident here, with thousands of examples of land mines and the carnage they cause. Cambodia had the highest concentration of land mines on earth.

Must visit in Siem Reap. What an amazing place. Only $5 entry fee. The museum has an amazing story and founder. Very sad to read some of the stories but the charities hard work has helped so many people. At the back of the museum is a large area which had a school, accommodation and more for victims of land mines. All proceeds go towards the charity and the people it helps.

Well worth a visit!! . This is a small yet very telling museum! You get a lot of information out of each of the 4 rooms that it holds! It's amazing the work that is happening in all around cambodia at the minute and how much these guys are helping! Get the audio guide that they give for FREE it quides you around the museum at your own pace! Amazing place for the children that live there as well. We'll done guys!

Fascinating, educational and moving..well worth a visit!. We stopped off at the Landmine museum after a morning visiting the Bantay Srei temple. It is fairly unassuming and if you didn't know it was there you'd probably pass it without noticing. On entering the museum you are bombarded with information from pictures, letters, newspaper cuttings, posters, old land mines and diffused bombs. There are audio guides available in English which help you to condense some of what you can see and these are very informative and helpful. Learning about the Khmer Rouge and the fascinating story of the museum's founder Aki Ra who used to plant the land mines as a Khmer Rouge soldier and now removes mines all over Cambodia, really brought it all to life. It really is shocking when you realise that land mines are still killing and wounding people, usually children and farmers, across Cambodia. Aki Ra adopted children who were either themselves victims of land mine accidents or orphaned in the same way. There are now numerous orphans and disadvantaged children who live at the centre, receiving an education and a much more prosperous chance in life. Tickets are only $5 and it is nice to know your money is being put to good use, providing a liveable wage to the staff who work there, an education and better quality of life to the orphans at the site and more importantly saving lives and limbs through contributing to the funding of land mine removal in Cambodia. This is well worth a visit if you are in Siem Reap.

Eye opening. This place offers a walk down the aisle of history. You'll leave understanding why Cambodia is still riddled with landmines and explosives from the cold war era. It really provides context to those "This Angkor temple is free of explosives and safe for tourists".

Sobering experience. Definitely worth a visit. Borrow an audio guide, it's free. You just need to leave an ID at the reception. Make sure you visit all the rooms (there are 4). Take time to read the essays of the children, it's very touching.

Cambodia Landmine Museum. We found this to be an amazing place with great information about this aspect of the war. The man who set this museum up was just a very special person who also fought in the war and then helped single handed to start to remove these landmines to give the land back to the people. It is a simple place but with great information to read for those of us who did not experience it.

Skip if you're schedule is full. I thought the landmine museum was interesting, but the exhibits were small and not very in depth. One of the people who works for the foundation was giving a tour to a group of students, so I stuck around and listened to him tell the stories - he was very good, and much better than just reading everything. Unfortunately, I dont think he gives tours often.If you feel like you HAVE to go to this, make sure to have your tuk driver stop at Banteay Srei on the way out or back. They are fairly close to each other and out of the way of everything else. Shouldnt cost too much extra.

Sobering but educational. . A good way to donate to the land mine removal cause in Cambodia. Our visit was a quiet one, we soaked in all of the information (in English) and learned a lot about removal, the school behind the museum and the efforts to date. This place is one you should visit.
Not worth a visit. This place is supposed to show the dark history of the landmine use during the civil war in 1980s. The exhibits are quite simple and the descriptions are not very elaborate.

Heart breaking and heart warming. This is a very small museum but the free audio device was really very helpful in explaining the displays. We learned a little more about the war in Cambodia and in Vietnam, the landmines and unexploded munitions left behind and how wide spread they are. That was all horrific but it was so good to know that there are people who care enough to try and remove them and rehabilitate the victims and their families. The museum does such excellent work and I feel privileged to be able to contribute in a small way with the entrance fee and donation. To visit Cambodia and ignore such history within living memory would be such a shame.
Very good, very interesting.... Really enjoyed this. So very interesting. They give you a cassette player with ear phones and you can listen to the stories of each room of the museum.

A moment to see the reality of what we normally only hear in the news.. It is a great place to visit and not only just to visit. By visiting it, you also help the local community and children who need the help. It is shocking to see, what damage this things can do to people and how cruel we can be for each other. Worth to see if you visit a country like Cambodja

it is only worth a visit if you have time. This museum is a nice way to learn about part of the tragic history of Cambidia. It summarizes the efforts of removing landmines in rural areas. It is a small museum so do not expect outstanding infrastructure. If you have time to go (it is around 30km away from Siem Reap) then go (or you can plan the visit with one of the temples in the grand tour). If you are running out of time, then skip it.What i found very attractive was the countryside. You can finally see rice fields, animals, farmers, other cropland and remnant forest.

Amazing museum, bring photo ID. Fantastic museum. You really learn a lot about the landmine issue plaguing the world. You won't see kids panhandling here. Tickets are $5 and go towards the effort to clear landmines in Cambodia. All the landmines cleared by the owner as well as guns and bombs are displayed on site. Audio tour is free and highly recommended, but you need photo ID to get one.

Find the time to drop in and absorb. On the way to Banteay Srey and Kulen Mountain.. If you have time, go here to catch a glimpse of recent Cambodian history.....you might come away with a different perspective of today's people.
Well worth a visit.. We visited this museum on our way out to Banteay Srie Temple. Your are given an audio set and headset to wear and listen to as you look around. very interesting.

Back again. We visit each time we visit Cambodia .still find it a very sad lace even after multiple visits . The story is shocking and we all should know it . Good to visit if you can to support the work and those that live there

Very interesting place to visit.. Very interesting place to visit. This guy is incredible. I learnt a lot. Land mines :( so sad to see the impact this has had on Cambodia. It says here that hopefully we will learn from this but unfortunately the world has not.

A truly moving place to visit . A small but excellent museum stocked with a collection of weapons from the darkest days of modern cambodia history. Founded by aki ra (a once child solder in the Khmer rouge) and his wife you see a first hand account of life under this oppressive regime from a forced child solders perspective. Aki ra has been removing thousands of land mines since he defected to the Vietnamese army after pol pot was over thrown and his collection is on display. Well worth the trip. Buy his little book it is truly amazing, his story from the years of cambodian genocide and life after.Entry: $5 Free headset Book: $3 all proceeds support the local school he has established behind the museum.

Thought provoking experience. This is only a small museum but certainly worth the visit. Inexpensive entry fee but all proceeds go to supporting land mine clearance and building schools in remote areas.

How a Landmine looks like.. This is my second visit after seven years. The entrance fee used to be USD1. This time they charged USD5! I would say it was an overkill! At this price I would not recommend this place. It was mentioned that 3 or 4 dollars were meant for charity. A fair price of 1USD plus a dollar for charity would be more appropriate. Though they do provide some good displays and quite informative, it was a rather small museum and certainly not worth that price.

A must see. Stop off here on your way back from the temples. It is a lovely museum that is definitely a labor of love. It is amazing what they have done for clearing landmines and helping children affected by them.

Social-political eye opener. This is the reality of Cambodia that most people may not be aware of. The Cambodian Landmine Museum brings forth the actual numbers and size of the suffering Cambodians endured during and after years of Civil War bloodshed. Created by one man and his journey to save and protect his people from the millions of undetected land mines, the museum brings into light his work and dedication he and others like him have shown. Although it is a about a 20 minutes drive from the other attractions and the city of Siem Reap, this unique museum is definitely worth a visit.

An eye opener. Although it's a little further, one can couple a visit to this place with Bantey Srei temple. It is an amazing place with alot of history and information on the Khemer Rouge era, landmines and the incredible ongoing efforts to counter this situation. Not to be missed!

These people are saving the world. We did this on the way to Banteay Srei, the Lady Temple. We met Bill, the tour guide, and he gave us a low down on the landmine situation in Cambodia. The people that work / volunteer here are genuinely inspiring. While we are busy leading our lives these people are busy saving the world, one defused landmine at a time.

thought provoking.... The landmine museum is a bit of a way from Siem Reap but worth the trip out to learn about how much of an impact the Vietnam War and Pol Pot had on this beautiful country.Its a small museum with a lot of local involvement. I was happy i made the trip out. ( no toilet facilities but cold drinks available outside )

Preferred the war museum close to town. Some interesting information but we both felt the National War Museum only just out of town was more informative and better presented. Both museums help mine victims and amputees - the Landmine Museum gives a good recorded tour for free, the war museum provides a free person. At the end of the day it really depends on whether you are only interested in land mines or want a bigger picture. Probably there is a case for merging the two, and visitors really should make the effort to visit at least one of them

Landmine history. A real eye opener, really could appreciate the magnitude of this problem. The personal, family and community involvement in this museum is great and really to be admired. Will probably go back and

Educational. It's a bit away from the town centre. The children loved it so much! It's a small museum but with enough information for you to absorb in one hour. The children read most of the information and asked so much for details about war and landmines. The display of used landmines and some photos have successfully given them a brief lesson on the painful aftermath of a war. They enjoyed listening to the audio guide (can be borrowed for free) too. I would say it is really educational.
A must visit. A small museum but an absolute must see if you are visiting the Siem reap area. A reminder of the challenges this country has faced in the past and continues to face.

Tired of Temples?. If your tired for Temples, then head to the Landmine Museum. It's a 35/40min Tuk Tuk ride from central Siem Reap and we only paid $15US there and back. They now have audio guides to accompany your walk around - so there is no pressure to donate money as previously mentioned in some reviews. However, your ticket ($5US) and any additional money helps run the adjoining school for children effected by landmines in Cambodia - so I'd highly recommend stopping buy the gift shop after the tour to pick up a bracelet or two which were made by the school children!

Impressed!. Our guide urged us to stop by the Landmine Museum on our way home from visiting the Angkor temples. I originally was thinking about skipping it, but my husband was interested. So glad we went in! We did the audio tour, which gave a concise story of Cambodia's history and the life of Aki Ra, the famed landmine remover. Aki Ra is an amazing man who has done so much good for Cambodia. All of the collected (and defused) landmines and deactivated weapons are on display in the museum. It was quite impressive to see. The whole tour took less than an hour and was a great break from the temples. This is a must see!

Landmines history. if you are visiting Cambodia, must visit this place to know about what country has faced . Good education about landmines, world war history, roles of different countries and stories of great souls who are cleaning up these mines,

Very well set up. Interesting to see especially on the way to or from Bantaey Srei Temple. What these guys are doing for victims of landmines and what they do now with children with disabilities is admirable and worthy of note. A $5 entrance fee that goes to the NGO running it is certainly worth it.

A passionate group of people committed to ridding Cambodia of landmines. It is nice to see a group of people committed to getting rid of landmines, providing support and education to survivors and families while educating the public.

A worthwhile and informative stop. If you make the enjoyable and worthwhile trip out to Banteay Samre, you will go right past the Museum and it's worth stopping and taking a short time to look around. Eevn if you read all of the panels and testimonies you can probably do the Museum in around 45 minutes, and paying the entrance fee alone supports a great cause; helping child victims of landmines. It answered my 16 year old daughters questions about the turbulent power politics of the 1970s that led to the tragedy of the Khmer Rouge take-over, and their subsequent eviction by the Vietnamese, and added to my knowledge too.
GO. Great place to learn everything you dont want in your life, learn do no harm to another human or creature.

Life During Wartime - and Beyond. The rather ramshackle nature of this museum lends a strangely appropriate immediacy to its subject. A more professional presentation of facts would obscure the lingering horrors of war on display here. All the more important, given that this is less a catalog of the past and more of a call to action in the present.

The same person who plant and digging them out again.. The place is small but with the audio, the place is worth 1-2 hour. A pleasing story where the person is trying his best to dig out the mine that he himself planted long time ago.

An opportunity to learn more @Landmine Museum. UXO's are a problem that has serious consequences for many in Cambodia (& Laos). As we were passing on our return from Kbal Spean & Banteay Srei we thought we should drop in and support. The audio tour was very good and our family group of 6 adults found this museum very educational and worthwhile- as well as knowing our entry fee was assisting a very good cause.
Moving and absorbing. This place is well worth a visit. It provides a graphic insight into the country's ongoing, but thankfully lessening, problem of hidden ordnance.
Sad but true. Learn about the terrors of war and why land mines should be banned worldwide. Very informative and interesting.

Worth visiting - educational and supports the locals. I am horrified to see that anyone has written negative reviews of this museum considering what it represents for the local people. This place represents one mans struggle to help support the local people of Cambodian get better education and also educate us on the atrocities of land mines. Yes it's not a new large westernised building but that's part of its charm. This place is an hours drive out of the city, and the photos are slightly old but it's the information and the story behind this that is what makes this so worth while. If someone goes around it in 10 mins they aren't reading the information properly. It took us an hour and it was really educAtional. What this guy has done and dedicates his life too is inspirational. all proceeds go to the children who have been victims of landmines or whose families have been victims and they support the children and educate them in the place behind the museum. This is the second time I've been here and I will keep going back and supporting it. One note, they have a wish list for the children on the board as you walk in which we wish we had known about - I've attached a picture - things like pencils, shampoo etc for donations so if you go it's worth taking some of these things with you.

Modest 'museum', compelling story. This is a very modest museum. The creator's personal story is very compelling and the museum provides a good education on the variety and impact of landmines in Cambodia. It's essentially a series of small rooms with exhibits situated around a central landmine display case in the middle of a small pond.
Max 10mins to complete the museum. Actually the place was really small. You can complete it with in 10mins. Photos displayed were old and some were not able to see clearly.

Heartbreaking education. The museum was not a high priority on our visit to Siem Reap, but we were so glad we did it.We stopped here whilst on a tuk-tuk adventure to Beng Mealea.The museum is small. The audio guide was clear. The displays informative. It broke our hearts to read the essays of the orphans residing at the complex.Overall a very sobering visit. Highly recommended!

Very interesting and heartbreaking. This is a very worthwhile museum to support. An audioguide taught us so many things that we didn't know about landmines. We left feeling far more aware and uplifted by the capacity of the human heart and spirit.

A real eye opener. The museum is small and simple but a real eye opener to the story of the American bombing of Cambodia during the Vietnam war as well under Khmer Rouge rule. Next to the museum is an orphanage that looks after around 20 kids,many of whom are land mine victims. All proceeds from the museum go to helping the orphans and the continued demining of Cambodia

Worth a stop. Landmines are horrific tools of war, and this museum displays it well even if it is very basic. There is a little too much self promotion of its founder Ari Ka (for my taste) in all the exhibits, but the cause is worth it. To this day, landmines kill and injure kids in the Cambodian fields, so the $5 is money well spent as parts of it goes toward the landmine removal program. We all learned a lot.

Eye opener. What an story this place has to tell. Well worth the visit to get a feel for what has happened in the past and what is currently being done in Cambodia in regards to landmines and rehabilitation.Very informative, terrifying, sad and facinating all together
Small yet educational. It's a small museum located very far away from the city centre and as well as other temples. However it's worth the visit. Very educational.

Well worth a detour. This museum is a wonderful example of how one person can change the world. The inspirational story of a soldier who spent many years laying land mines before dedicating himself to getting rid of them is incredible. The audio visual tour, included in the admission price, is up to date and very interesting. The museum does well to lay out the facts without ever accusing or assigning blame to any one army.This is well worth a visit or a detour on the way back from Banteay Srey temple. US$5 to get in feels more like a donation to the continued good work this team does in ridding Cambodian villages of land mines.Don't miss it.

One man's heroic effort. This is a tribute to the efforts of de-mining in Cambodia. This museum showcases the efforts of the heroic in providing a safe land by de-mining. Housed at the site are landmines, information about the damaging impact of mines on people, children, lossed ones.

A Sobering Visit. It's a moving experience visiting the Museum; the scale of damage done to Cambodians is very hard to fully appreciate, it only becomes evident when you begin to tour around the country and see so many badly damaged by mine explosions.The museum is compact yet with an enormous amount of material to read and absorb; it is worth taking your time as you meander from room to room. It is also quite moving when you read of what happened and continues to happen to those who inadvertently find unexploded mines.It is about an hour's tuk-tuk drive from Siem Reap and well worth the effort.

A real eye opener!!. What to say? Being both ex military and walking around this place sent shivers up our spines. Very informative and a great cause for the money to go to.We spent time with a couple of the kids who had been out catching fish to fill the centre pond with, they spoke really good English and seem to be getting a head start in life.Bought some t shirts from there shop which the money go's back into the charity.Take the time if your in the area to visit.

Impressive and Thoughtful. Excellent small museum driving home the impact of landmines on Cambodia and the world in general. All of the money of admission ($5) goes to funding orphans, paying staff decent wages & further demining activities. It is a sobering visit, but important to remember what the world did to Cambodia by selling and encouraging the use of landmines.

A Museum of Human Stories. This museum deals less with landmines themselves and more with the stories of those (tragically numerous) cambodians who have dpent their lives planting, digging up, or having suffering visited upon them by landmines.In particular, it tells the story of one lost soul who has dedicated his life to demining an entire country and protecting, housing, and educated the children hurt most by the civil war.

Chilling, but essential in understanding the effects, and after-effects, of war. This compact little museum is a sobering but educational look at the horrors that dog Cambodia and Southeast Asia long after the wars and proxy wars ended.Just seeing the vast array of land mines, remnants of bombs and other weapons of the period will leave you shaking your head.An audio tour is free -- just leave some form of ID -- and admission is $5US, and it goes to help the victims of the land mines at an adjacent facility (off limits to visitors).Getting there involves a lovely tuk-tuk ride through the countryside and there are places to eat not too far away -- every good tuk-tuk driver can get you there. The museum has bathroom facilities but they are pretty primitive.Worth going.

A great piece of history and wonderful effort by all involved.. The museum is not that big but the history included is massive. Many kinds of displays and stories are fitted into the museum and gives you a stunning insight of what life was in Cambodia back in the day and even now. The landmine has always been a big problem in this parts. To cover everything will take about an hour but it is worth the history and time.
Lots of information in a small area. Interesting place, great to see how one person can make a difference and get a history lesson at the same time. Worth getting the audio guide.

It's worth seeing. It's not on the same level as the killing fields or the Vietnam war museum but it does show an interesting side of Cambodia's history and is worth seeing like much of the country's history it's quite sad.

Recent History. This is one thing I knew I had to experience in Cambodia, and I'm glad we went. We just did the basic tour - no tour guide, no audio guide - but the story of this place is so compelling it tells itself. Since most of these events happened in my lifetime I could really relate to how relevant they are to my generation (born in the 1960s). Hard to believe that this country is only 20 years removed from direct conflict/war, but still living with the harsh realities of it every day. "Only" 86 people in Cambodia have been killed by land mines year to date of this review, but that is far too many. This will truly show you what the true costs of war are.

Insight into the tragic Cambodian past.. This museum offers great insight into the not-so-distant history of Cambodia. It is mind-boggling and completely eye-opening! This place may even alter some of your previous views/ opinions of said historical events. Looking through this museum allowed me to draw my own conclusions, which further illustrated Cambodia's current social, political and cultural environment.

Most inspiring story!. To set expectations based on other reviews, this is less a museum than an inspirational story of an incredible man doing amazing work in the country. Interesting displays of land mines and other weapons, with helpful history of the events that led to their introduction to Cambodia.Aki ra's story is unforgettable, as are those of the land mine victim children who now reside at the museum. The visit here complements what you may learn in larger museums with a very personal perspective of the atrocities this country has endured.Highly encourage everyone to include this brief stop in your way to beng Mealea or other northern destinations. You will leave inspired and wanting to do more good in this world!

Confronting but a must-see. This mesuem has been set up really well. Take a headset and listen at each stop. Really informative about such a heartbreaking topic. This is a must see place. We combined it with a trip to bantaey srei ($15 for a tuktuk to both places).

A sobering but must-see visit. Just got back from the Cambodia Landmine Museum. It's about 50 mins drive in a motorbike rickshaw north of Siem Reap (about $15-20 return). It's a small charity run museum (so don't expect some polished commercial museum selling cappachino and ice-creams in cafe on the way out) but it is very well run. And the fact that it isn't commercial, adds to the impact of the place. Simple, clear and sobering. Not humanity's finest moment. Whilst I was there, nobody spoke - they seemed deep in the own thoughts, listening to the free audio guides and just trying to take it all in. Aki Ra, the founder of the museum, de-miner and next door school for landmine injured and disadvantaged children deserves Nobel prize for what he has done here. You should also watch a video at the end - all shot on a handheld cam with thought-provoking cutting between filming Aki Ra as he finds and deactivates landmines with no more than a stick and pair of pliers, the tortured history of Cambodia and the smile of little local children playing football or on a rope swing over a river - kind of puts your own life into perspective

Landmine museum. Fascinating and moving. You need about an hour and a half to absorb what this amazing man has done in a country peppered with landmines. We visited on the way to the animal sanctuary and called in again on the return.
The war museum is better value. The landmine museum is more about education than exhibits. We got given an English language recorded audio tour, which I turned off half way through.

Eye Opening. As said in previous reviews the museum is a little way out of Siem Reap but well worth the effort to go to. The good cause that this museum supports is reason enough, but also the insight into the devastation caused by this type of weapon. The trip there and back is also very sobering as you see the squaller that many are forced to endure to survive.

Very informative. After reading reviews visited this museum and found it very interesting. The headphones ( included in admission of $5) provide a commentary as you move around the museum. What an amazing man Aki Ra is. Than you for sharing your story.

Must see part of Cambodias tragic recent history. The museum is a fair distance fro Siem Reap where most people will be staying but well worth a visit if you are visiting the temple ruins at Banteay Srei.In addition to the genocide of 1975 - 79 land mines have killed and mamed many Cambodian people. This museum gives visitors a first hand view what is still being done to try to clear land mines from around the countryside.

Informative and emotional visit.. We stayed at Pavillon d'Orient Hotel in Siem Reap that included a tuk tuk with our room so we used that to get to the museum which took about 40 minutes, should be 30 but a road was closed for maintenance. The route took us through lovely countryside, villages and past temples. Sadly we had an afternoon flight out so could not stop but there were some handicraft stalls and sugar cane areas that would have been good for a short stop en route. This is a small museum which aims to inform about land mines, the way they were used in Cambodia, the work being done to clear them and also about the children that the money raised here provides to look after local children that either have been orphaned or who can not be looked after by their parents. Take the time to read some of their letters, they are truly humbling. It does not cost much for admission, $5 I think but please, if you can, donate more either in cash or take things with you, on their notice board it said they needed - soap, hand sanitiser, pens, pencils, tooth brushes, tooth paste as well as other items that I can not remember now. This is a little place trying to do a lot, take the time to visit and find out what the people of Cambodia are living with.

Small but Informative. It was a small museum. Since the entrance fee goes to the needy families that was affected by the mines, reckon it was well spent. They house different types of landmines and artillery shells. Good to know more about landmines and how it affected people's lives. Worth a visit and on the way to Baeng Meila. Entrance fees $5.

People making a difference . Small but informative museum.Really worth going to, I walked away with a much better understanding of the past and an optimistic view of the future.People dedicating their lives to helping other people...little children who have had a difficult start to live finding a safe place to live....going to school then going to university.Aki ra you are to be commended....a world with no landmines would be a wonderful thing. When you visit please take some supplies for the children if you are able....soap, hand sanitizer, toothbrushes pencils, pens and some balls or games etc would be so appreciated. ...their is no hard sell out there...just a board stating any of things would be appreciated. ...wish we would have known beforehand so we could have loaded up with some supplies....we will next time.The trip takes about an hour in a tuktuk and we paid $20. We stayed at Damnak Kunthea and had a lovely driver Mr. Somnang (Very safe and friendly) it was wonderful seeing the real life as we meandered through the countryside. ..smiling children, people going about their business...and people resting contently in their hammocks. Magic!

Dont know what to say. This is quite a small museum but the story it tells is sobering. The Camboians have endured so much and continue to do so. They estimate that there remain 3/6 million pieces of unexploded ordinance and thousands are injured every year. Despite it all the Camboians remain smiling and polite and welcoming.We caught a Tuk Tuk from Siam Reep to the Museum about an hour 20 dollars and very good value and we got to see a part of the country we would not otherwise see.People visit Cambodia I promise you will not be disappointed.

Educational and sobering place. In between temple visits this was a family-run spot that shows just how indiscriminate the numerous countries were that supplied ordnance to anyone who wanted to pay for it.Afterwards go eat at Bong Thom Homestay just down the road and support local business.

A window into Cambodia. Hire a tuk-tuk to take you out to this must-see museum. The bonus is you get to see much more of the Cambodian landscape than if you hire a car. The museum brings you face to face with the atrocities of war in an unpolished yet powerful presentation. Visit the gift shop and buy a few things to help support the cause. Before leaving, be sure to walk into the garden, where you will find a re-creation of a mined area.
Memory of a sad saga of cambodia!. US arms have been killing millions and these weapons tell this sad story - well arranged in sections . People suffered enormously and evidences are there to witness

Definitely worth a visit. This muesuem offers a view you don't often see or hear about but it has an important story to share. It is about 45 mins from town on a tuk tuk but it's lovely to seethe villages and countryside. I highly recommend this museum.

Sad past and good cause. The Landmine Museum is a must see in Siem Reap. I didn't know all the things they do for the community, especially those suffering the aftermath of land mines, until I visited the museum. It's a simple set up but very impact full. Its a sad place to be but worth a visit. Just make sure you do something more uplifting after.

worth a visit. yes this is a tiny museum about 25 kms from siam reap but well worth a visit, the trip out & back in a tuk tuk is thru lovely countryside (we stopped in a tiny village on way & learnt how palm sugar was made) the museum is very "humble" but a real reminder of the true history of cambodia.we also stopped at the butterfly museum on the way back..........which was also small but the owners were so delightful..........they are trying to encourage tourists to stop & help them become self sufficient

Inspiring Museum, definitely add to your itinerary for Siem Reap. This was one of the most interesting experiences in Siem Reap and I would highly recommend a visit to anyone. Aki Ra's story is totally inspiring, it taught us so much about Cambodia and the work that the NGO are doing to make Cambodia safe for all Cambodians. If you can, get on one of the guided tours, Bill imparts a lot of information, very quickly and you leave knowing a lot about Cambodia, landmines, the children, the schools and Aki Ra.
Interesting. Worth getting the audio, very well done. It is included in the admission price but you need to leave photo id, your Angkor pass is sufficient.

Sombre & Real. We were deciding between this and another place (the killing fields). We chose this because my son been to the other one. Absolutely no regrets. It was well organised and with the Self-help device, you can take your time to absorb what the museum wants to tell you. Dress light. Pretty warm. And mosquito repellent like patches and sprays are must-haves. It's quite far out. We got a tuk tuk to bring us there and back. Worth the ride. The journey there and back was fun too because we got to soak in the scene.

10/10 - One of the best museums in the world. If you take the time to immerse yourself in all the museum has to offer, it really is an amazing experience. It's mainly text based, but if you read the many thousands of words on the exhibits, there is much to learn.It's very well set up, with 4 rooms focusing on various aspects of the various conflicts, types of landmines still active in Cambodia, the children being taught at the school, and the process of disarming and clearing the fields that is still ongoing.The $5 US entry is well worth it, and there are some excellent gifts and books at the shop, all of which goes to help the children.It's a decent distance outside Siem Reap, but definitely worth it. Please go and donate to such a worthy cause!

Sobering reminder of an unreported war. This is the result of the efforts of an exceptional local man, who not only continues with mine clearance but has also established and maintains an orphanage - all without international funding. The story is worth the visit alone, and the nominal entry fee contributes to the ongoing effort. Every trip to this area should include a visit to this unassuming and quiet effort to make Cambodia a safer and better place.

Watch your step. Very interesting museum! The museum is located 25 km from Siem Reap. The trip takes approximately 50 minutes by Tuktuk and takes you through the countryside and small villages. Once there you witness unexploded ordnances in the driveway! The entrance fee is 5$. The money ensures the staff a reasonable wage, runs an orphanage and supports the struggle against land mines. Inside the museum you will be offered a free audio guide (very informative). Posters in English are explaining the history of land mines, the consequences of the land mines, essays from victims and the struggle to remove the mines. The museum runs an orphanage for handicapped children and victims to the mines. Visitors are encouraged to bring toys, balls, pencils, toothbrushes etc. The museum is run as an NGO that seems genuinely sympathetic. Highly recommended.
