Worth the price of admission. The country has only relatively recently come out of civil war and is museum is just one of the blunt reminders of that fact. In fact, if you explore the Ankor area you will find some warnings not to stray off the path since there are still some areas with active mines. It's not a very big museum and it will only take you an hour or so to see everything but the story of Aki Ra is an impressive one. In addition to his story having cleared over 50,000 mines and UXO's (unexploded ordinances) you will find many of them at this museum (explosives removed of course). The cost is only US$5 and of this only $3 of that goes to paying the staff.

An honest reflection. This museum is small but it is also genuine and features the work of someone who selflessly had attempted to clear landmines for years with a knife, a stick, his intelligence and determination. If it were a movie, it would be unbelievable, but as is the case with many things in Cambodia, it is too bizarre to not be true. I wish there was more info on the present clearing team. There was tonnes of articulate and grim information on the past and present challenges on mines today in Cambodia. It infuriates me that these maiming devices are still produced and used so strategically around the world. Can we not do better in 2015? For those that complained that the museum is 'small' and perhaps not as slick as they wanted, I wonder what they think about the rest of the country: They might be better off watching NatGeo or going to the MOMA. The money from the museum goes to support a school and various projects versus propping up a pseudo democratic dictatorship, cronies thereof, or foreign corporate interests. I agree it is not glossy but it is a best effort, quite good actually, at educating people of non-glossy realities.Worth it and has a very low cost. Saw several staff around that appeared to be the actual Khmer mineclearers. Allow yourself 30 min to an hour,

"How sad". This is a rough little diamond but I guess you shouldn't put any spit and polish on such a horrific subject.How sad to see a country so tragically laid out with mines.Warning - the girls in the shop have some serious attitude!

needs an upgrade. We went here with recordation and sorry it did not deliver. We found the trip to get there more interesting. Though I understand the great work that has been achieved and the wonderful cause it helps I personally could not say it was worth it and treated the entry fee as a donation to the work , a major upgrade is required!
Disturbing. How can humans be so greedy to make profit off something that causes so much suffering. The courage of the people who are working to remove the mines is incredible

A vivid reminder. The landmine museum tells the story of landmines in Cambodia. Founded by ex child soldier and deminer Akira. It is a vivid reminder of the devasting impact that landmines have had on this beautiful country.

Worthwhile visit. A visit to Banteay Srei will bring you pass this museum. A stop here is worthwhile. The USD5 entrance fee goes towards support programs in the land mine clearing effort. The displays here reminds us of the atrocities of the Khmer Rouge and the hardships of the people.

Very interesting!. This is about a 45 minute tuktuk ride out of Siem Reap. Well worth it though with a free audio headset in language of your choice, or you can just read the information if you prefer, it's all in English (cant remember if it was in other languages)

Definitely worth a visit!. My family of five visited the Cambodia Landmine Museum as well as the nearby Butterfly Farm. We're so glad we stopped in! The 25 minute drive via tuk tuk was enjoyable -- so much to see on the way. While I'm sure it's not for everyone, we felt that it was an important reminder of what the Cambodian people have been living through. It's so easy to get caught up with busy day to day life, that you don't realise the challenges, sorrow and pain others have been through. It was very sobering and grounding.It was wonderful to hear the great work the museum's founder has been doing removing landmines from Cambodia. We thought our $5 entry fee was well worth it. Kids 12 and under are free -- but I would have happily paid.Of the $5, $1 goes towards efforts clearing landmines, $1 goes towards support programs in local villages and $3 is used to support the children who live at the museum, as well as paying the staff a fair salary.It's open every day from 7:30am-5:30pm. The tuk tuk cost us $22 USD for half the day, organised via our hotel.

A touching display. This museum can be incorporated into a visit to Banteay Srei temple but is quite far out to travel to solely for the museum IMO.It's cheap entry that goes directly back to charity. Several informative rooms, grab a self-guide booklet and lead yourself around.It's a bit thrown together but very interesting and I learnt several things I previously didn't know!

Informative yet touching. We had the best tour of the museum by a US citizen, who moved to Cambodia with his wife and now have dedicated their lives to this cause. He gave us a thorough tour and made the visit worthwhile - we left with so much more appreciation for what the country has been through.

So worth while!. Great place! Amazing history from a U.S expat. They also house orphans and disabled victims, help finish their schooling and help them find jobs. Bring pencils and things the kids can use.

Save your time. Although interesting with its assortment of old mines, guns, grenades, bombs and other assorted relics from ancient wars, you feel the distinct impression that this place is very anti-American, or at least I felt that way. If I hadn't gone there I would not have missed anything.

Sad but also uplifting!. I have now been here twice and it is an amazing place with an incredible story of hope and strength in extreme adversity. It's a great place to learn more about Cambodian history as well. I did cry the first time I went, not because of tragedy but because of hope!

Very interesting museum, go visit!. This museum is a real treasure, documenting the efforts of one man's life work in removing the landmines from Cambodia. It's on the way to Banteay Srey, a beautiful temple. Combine the two in a half day out from Siem Reap.

A sobering experience. Aki Ra is an inspiration to all who choose to do something about a significant issue like land mines which are a blight on humanity where ever they are used to maim and destroy. The experience of the visit was profound bringing us to tears. Glad to see so many travellers visit and in doing so help with the majestic work this NGO continues to do.

A genuinely interesting little museum. While the main attraction in Siem Reap is obviously the temples, getting outside the main temple complex a bit can really provide you with some quality side excursions. This is one of them. Though small, it provides a solid history of the challenges Cambodia has had with land mines. Too, if one of the English speaking staff are available you can get some really helpful additional information that might be missed on a personal walk through. One thing that was particularly appreciated was their purposeful choice to not allow people to tour through the children's residency area. As can often be the case, touring orphanages or like settings often benefit the management but not the children. Their sensitivity to respect these important boundaries was a good thing.

small museum but eye opener. we went here as part of a tour with a tuktuk driver, it is little out the way and not very big, so dont expect a high class museum - it is basic, but informative and has a school next to it with the children who have been affected by landmines.

History = His Story . Actual I don't know much about war and history. I just follow my friends to visit the Landmine Museum the last day in Siem Reap. There I saw many articles about those war Khmer people had with French and khmerroug Pol Pot. I find it not very interesting but my friends loved it.

Very informative and inspiring place. Small museum just outside Angkor wat. Aki Ra was a child solider in Khmer Rouge, but defected and has since dedicated his life to removing land mines from Cambodia. Museum provides a audio tour with accounts from his life and a review of the history of land mines in Cambodia and use across the world. Very interesting, informative and inspirational. Ticket revenue go towards continued removal of land mines in Cambodia (millions remain) and taking care of injured/orphaned children.

Humbling and very good cause. I went with a friend and went to this museum based on the reviews here. The landmine museum is very informative and Aki Ra's work is truly heroic. Definitely worth the visit if you have the time.

A touching reminder of the courage of the Cambodian people. We went to the Landmine museum with our children today. The journey to the museum is part of the Cambodian experience as it gives people the opportunity to enjoy the Cambodian country side. The distance is really not that far from Siem Reap, it took us 30mins on a tuk tuk. The museum is very well presented, it is easy for children to read all about the history and full of very informative explanations. The display of the soldiers in uniform with the papier mâché heads, as well as all the paintings made by the kids of the museum orphanage are amazing. We enjoyed our ride over and certainly found the museum a must when visiting Siem Reap as this keeps the legacy alive and is a great way to show the world the amount of suffering Cambodian people have endured.

A Must for the Compassionate Traveler. I went mainly due to my research interests, but stayed much longer. The museum outlines the story of Aki Ra, a Cambodian man who fought as a child soldier with the Khmer Rouge but later dedicated his life to de-mining Cambodia. Lots of info on how mines work, what types can be found, how the US bombing of Cambodia effected the country, etc.The museum has a lovely gift shop where proceeds go back to helping children and families effected by landmines, and this is a Cambodian-run NGO that also builds schools and supports scholarships for children in need. Very good place to go while you're in Cambodia. They were working on audio guides for guests while we were there (to be used in the future) but the staff is awesome too. Exhibition of items aimed at all age groups, $4. Village nearby known for its yummy noodles!

Sobering & Informative. The work of Aki Ra is beyond comprehension. What an amazing man. The Cambodian Landmine museum gives the visitor a snapshot of the horror the Cambodian people had to go through...there are still millions of landmines still active. The closed off orphanage for the children was a refreshing idea- these poor children have either lost their families or been victims themselves & I commend the museum for not putting them on show. Congratulations Aki on successfully getting your message out there without exploitation.

Excellent. This is a must see. The staff are doing a wonderful job educating visitors on the landmine threat in Cambodia. As soon as the promised electricity is delivered by the regional government then Internet and an audio tour will be available. Until that time they need your support to fund these ventures.
Interesting. This trip we did because we had nothing else booked for the day, hired a tuk tuk & went to a few places this was one.

Important documentation of the aftermath of war. This is not a pretty museum. In fact, it looks a bit dusty and neglected because of the surroundings. Ignore these superficial details and you see a testament to the magnificence of the human spirit, and the kind of obstacles people can overcome. It shows how Cambodians became victims of the Vietnam war, and the damage it suffered was anything but collateral. This collateral damage gave birth to Cambodia's homegrown monsters, who then went on a killing rampage that was barbaric even by the bloody standards of the 20th century with its two world wars. A former child soldier of the Khmer Rouge decides to spend his life trying to undo the damage, risking his life to clear the country of landmines. There is an orphanage supported by proceeds of the museum and other NGOs. Deeply moving.

Important to visit. We were lucky having a private tour with Bill who were telling us the amazing work they are doing, not only with clearing landmines but also what they are doing in helping all the kids. I'm amazed by these people giving up their own lives to help the ones who need it most. This museum is very important for us to visit, getting a glimpse of what the war did to Cambodia.

Important for tourists to apprecaite what Cambodians went thrrough. Pay homage to the suffering of Khmer people...horrific and sad..needs to be acknowledged by tourists..so a well set out display that reflects the efforts of people to make people aware of the history. So many people and animals no doubt maimed and killed...shows many different types of landmines...awfully sad reflection on human nature. Worth a visit.

In a state of disrepair, but important to visit. As others have said here, the landmine museum is important to visit. It gives you a glimpse into some of the hell that Cambodians went through and still go through as a result of landmines, and the small fee funds landmine victim support programs.

Important on going NGO. Very important museum for showing and financing the ongoing work for clearing landmines in Cambodia.
The museum also finances an attached school for about 25 disadvantaged children

Important for understanding Cambodia. It's a small museum and on the way to Banteay Srey, so easy to visit on the way there, but in my opinion it would even be worth the trip itself, just to learn more about the issues with landmines. Bill, an American ex-army guy and our guide was fantastic and his devotion to the project was very clear. Bravo for all the fantastic work they do.

Amazingly moving place. This place really moves you, not only explains a terrible reality but shows evidence of the terrible problem land mines are. We had the fortune of having a volunteer that walked us through everything and answered all or questions. It is a must place to visit, as I think its part of Cambodia's history.

No tour guide!. The mine was the first place we went to after stepping out of the airport. We reached by 4 pm (few hours before closing). There was no tour guide available. So even if there was a lot of history, we weren't getting first hand information. We lost interest in the first 30 minutes because we didn't understand why each machine was used.

Respect For A Great Job But .... The work this man and his team did was awe inspiring and helped the Khmer people resume some normality. The museum is a long way out of town. It is small and all you really see is a lot of old landmines and bombs. There is sign boards explaining the landmine clearing process and the type of devices found. All in all, this museum could be made to be an informative and maybe interactive but unfortunately it is just several small rooms with old bombs and a poor display of Khmer Rouge soldiers. This is really not worth the stop and is quite disappointing.
History from someone who was there. Really worth seeing. The guide is open and provides his very personal knowledge and first hand experiences. Small simple but well worth it

A grim reminder of the past but hopeful optimism for the future.. Attach a visit to the Landmine Museum if you intend to visit Banteay Srei temple as it is on your way. Even now you are warned not to stray from previously trodden paths or wander off into the forest , as there may be landlines with-in a few hundred metres of the temples. The story of this museum and how it come about is fascinating and it's worth visiting just to find this out. The museum is of course a history of warfare during the Khymer Rouge period and in particular one man. It displays in a rough simple setting drawings, posters, land mines (now made safe) in two or three rooms. Attached to the museum is an orphanage for young adults who have been maimed by land mines . You are not allowed to enter this section but inside the museum students stories are related. It is these which gives you the optimism that from destruction, through nurturing reconstruction and a bright future is within each students grasp. Your support contributes towards this worthwhile programme. You leave reflecting on so many things. Unsophisticated -yes but if there is an example of human suffering caused by war and the compassion that can come out of it then the Cambodia Landmine Museum is right up there in greatness but above all humility.

Aki Ra - world hero. Stopped here during my trip to Banteay Srei and left feeling a whole lot of something. The museum does its best to show the impact and unexploded devices have had on the people of this country. Maps, charts, pictures and even a few paper mache soldiers tell the story quite well. Well worth the visit even if to open your eyes a bit on this history and ongoing tragedy.

Must-see. I have a hard time understanding how people come to Siem Real just to see the temples when there are so many other things to do here. The Landmine Museum is a small but extremely informative group of four rooms that explains how landmines work, how they are cleaned up, and the effects that landmines have on the country. The man who started this project is amazing. I especially enjoyed the garden at the end and the acknowledgements of "rescuers," people in genocides (Cambodia, the Holocaust, Rwanda, Bosnia & Herzegovina) who risked their lives to help those being persecuted. $5.

Should not be missed. Aside from angkor wat and the phare circus, this is another must-see attraction. About 20-40 minutes away from the main hotels, here you can learn about the sad stories of the cambodians (wars, losing limbs due to land mines) and what is being done to help them. Visit the butterfly garden when you're done, as it's just nearby.

Heartbreaking. This museum is small but packs one hell of a punch.If you're in the vicinity you owe it to yourself to visit as it sheds so much light on the dark historical backdrop to Cambodia.Location wise it's a bit far out, but we combined our trip with Banteay Srei and Angkor Centre for Conservation of Biodiversity (a must see!) - so it was all completely worthwhile.PS Expect to leave having enormous hatred for Pol Pot and Henry Kissinger.

Extremely well done visitor centre and a worthy cause. I really enjoyed my time at the landmine museum. It felt so important to learn that the war - which many see as history- is still impacting people on a day to day basis in rural areas. There are an amazing number of landmines on display. They have booklets in a number of languages that have all the information on it so I could let it sink in at my own pace. Be sure to visit the souvenir store, they have some great items and all proceeds go back into the landmine program. A must see when in Siem Reap

very interesting. we visited the landmine museum, what an eye opener, what these people have lived with all these years, and the damage these land mines have done, the guy giving the talk was very interesting , great to see how some of the people affected by these mines have progressed in life due to the support of this landmine centre, A must visit place

Small and worthwhile . Small museum and not like we're used to in developed countries but interesting, sad and your money goes to their efforts to continue removing land mines in this beautiful country and their orphanage. Must see.

A real eye opener!!!!.. We visited the land mine museum because this is as much a part of cambodia history as angkor. We allowed a couple of hours to appreciate this small but well layed out museum but only needed an hour to read the information and see all the displays, this left us with a greater understanding and much more informed than any book could do. It's a must when visiting siem reap.

Combine a trip there with the outer temples. I saw the landmine museum as part of a trip to Banteay Srei and Banteay Samre. Since all of the sites are further out, I hired a sedan for the trip. Besides the sites, the longer trip outside gave me a chance to see some of the countryside especially since I was advised the water levels were too low to see the villages. I thought the landmine museum was a valuable experience both for the opportunity to see some of he difficult history of land mines in Cambodia (and many other countries) as well as to support the amazing efforts going on there. The museum is self-guided and consists of four small rooms which have maps and diagrams of land mines. In all it takes 15-30 min to see. Well worth it.

Learnt a lot at Cambodia Landmine Museum.. We found this little museum to be a great and very interesting place to learn about the sad history of Cambodia. The operator Bill was very passionate and good at getting his information across. We learnt alot of interesting facts about Cambodia that we did not hear about anywhere else. Well worth a visit and if you have some spare cash you should make a donation as it might not seem like alot of money to us but it makes a world of difference to people of Cambodia. Joel.
Memorable. A small but memorable museum reminder of terrible events. Learn about the costs to civilians in warfare and the efforts of those who work to clean it up and memorialize the victims

Very small, very quick visit. The museum is touching and a great monument to the work of the founder. However it is $5usd per person and would take 15min on average to see the entire museum. We took about 25-30min.We went on a supposed tour day and during tour hours but didn't receive a tour. This being said we read everything there was to read and reflected and still it only took 25min.I certainly would not go out of my way to see it but if it's on your way and you're not cash-strapped it can be a quick side trip.

an enjoyable visit. I intended this as a stop off for an educational and support visit to a good cause. However, I was delighted to hear from my 13 year old daughter that after the 1/2 hour guided tour which she religiously listened (as did my 10 year old daughter as well) that she said this was the highlight to her 5 day tour to Siem Reap. I myself listened for 5 mins to the tour and then did my own walk about as did my wife, but both found it very informative.

Don't miss - a humbling experience. It is what it is - the work of Ari Ra is an inspiration to us all. He planted the mines as a 10 year old and then help diffuse them. The museum also helps those who lost limbs. Definitely a modern offset to all the amazing Wats in the area.

Well worth the trip to the museum. Do note that on certain sites, the address may be wrong. It is located to the north-east of Angkor Wat, 7km south of the Banteay Srey Temple and about 45mins drive away from city area. Would recommend taking a car instead - I took a motorcycle and was under the hot sun, faced with dusty roads and a ride filled with bumps.It was really an emotional experience for me, I could really feel the sufferings that Cambodians are going through even till now - landmines are still a real threat in this present day. The negative parts:1) the museum is not exactly big - just about 4 rooms around a middle showcase of ordnance (as shown in the picture).2) the children's center/home behind is not open to public - I can understand their rational that the children are not exhibits and all, but perhaps good to show some photos of the center? We can then see the kind of lifestyle they are having.3) distance - it is really very far away from town. However there are 2 attractions nearby for one to consider as well: Butterfly Center and Banteay Srey temple. Entrance fees $5 will be well spent by them to help fellow Cambodians. Thanks Aki Ra for your heart of gold!

worth a stop. This museum is small, built by an ex soldier, but is worth a stop on your way to/from banteay srei. $5 entrance fee goes towards the children they look after affected by landmines and towards clearing more mines.

Great museum. On the back from Kbal Spean , this museum is long the wat to Siem Reap town . Inside building store by all old weapons and landmine. Most visitor that pass from Bateaysrey temple buy a ticket for museum as well like donate a found to rural people.

Prepare to be deeply moved. This is not an easy place to visit, but please go anyway. Modest in scale, it is impressive on many levels, both sad and uplifting. It shows the best in humanity arising from the worst.

So sad, so real, so touching. Something that surprised me from my first day in Siem Reap is to see people amputated, I didn't want to ask for respect, but as my days there started to finish I asked to the guy that was working in the hotel, he told me that it was because the war and if I wanted to know more about it I had to visit the landmine museum, I went the following day and learnd about Aki Ra, this guy is really really a great person, he is working a lot to clean Cambodia of these landmines that are everywhere, please visit this place and if possible contribute with his organization.

Nothing much to see. Though this place is rich in history and emotion, it's quite small with very limited things to see. But if you're interested in seeing bombs and a glimpse of Cambodia's bravery and survival, then please go.

Must Visit. This Museum gives a deep history of what went down when pol pot lost his marbles and the money you spend actually goes into the orphanage that is run by the museum. it has 4 rooms with detailed information on what went down and is still happening in the country.

Please go! . We visited the land mine museum today and are so glad we took the time to visit this place. We hired a driver for a day, and whilst it is a way to go (about 25km) the team at the museum greatly appreciate visitors and its a great drive outside of Siem Reap. We had the advisor Bill Morse show us around the museum and teach us about how they discover land mines, educate villagers, and the great work they do building schools with the Rural School Village Program. The experience was an eye opener, so I recommend everyone visit this special place.

. . . if this doesn’t humble you, then you don’t have a pulse!. As a Westerner who has had the luxury of travelling through much of Asia, I am constantly reminded of what a privileged life we lead and how much we have to be grateful for. Touring through this museum (you pay $5 to enter), you gain a further apreciationg for the Cambodian people, particularly Aki Ra who rightly won the CNN Hero award in 2010. The situation of the millions of live mines still planted in the Cambodian country side garnered the attention of Princess Diana and her HALO initiative. Aki and his team (including and American couple) have made it their life work to demine the countryside. They are humble, hardworking and put their own lives at risk every day to make Cambodia safer. They have also established a refuge for children who are victims of the mines, to date over 30 children reside there and are schooled and given an opportunity to hope for a brighter future. Simply playing in the fields leads many to loose arms and legs. Please take your time going through the museum, buy a gift (proceeds to towards furthering their efforts), and make sure to leave a donation. Again, give wherever you can.

Just a couple of rooms, but still OK. Someone else mentioned its a long way to go just to go to this museum, and that is right, so don't, unless you really want to, but this was on our own private itinerary I thought out of something we wanted to see on the way up to the ACCB (Angkor Centre for Conservation of Biodiversity) with our own private driver we got for the day, and since it was pretty much going to be passed we stopped in. Was interesting to see the landmines and other bombs, and very sad there is the need for such a place as this. We gave ourselves 45min to spend here, but we were out in 10.Entry was cheap, a few bucks I think, but once again, don't make a special trip.

Interesting to see and find out the history. Small place, can be guided on tour or view alone. The reality of the war comes home to you here. We did not want to dwell on the violence during our visit to Cambodia, but this was an interesting diversion and enough to make us aware of some of the past.Worth spending some time there

Excellent information. They offer so many stories and information about Cambodia. It is far from the city, but if you are visiting the temples its not bad. It is definitely worth the distance. If you are going to the temple Bantrey Srie it is on the way.
Heartfelt of the Loss of Life. Hands on and visual photos allowed you to have a clearer picture of the destruction the land mines caused and all the lives taken as a result.

Helping victims of left over land mine . The founder of this museum has the vision to help clear all land mine in Cambodia to make it a better place for the nation. Very good place to understand the history. Please donate if you can.

Not exactly "worth a visit". Since we had the noon available and this was rated 13th on tripadvisor, we decided to make a trip there after lunch. The tuktuk driver quoted us 15usd for return trip from Pub Street. The drive there was about 30-40mins long. There are only 3 rooms of exhibits and mostly just exhibiting the different types of landmines. Don't get me wrong; I do appreciate the owner and his efforts. However, imagine us driving so far to the museum, but ended up finishing the exhibits in less than 20 mins? It was quite a disappointment.Unless you can on the way to Bantrey Srei and doing a stopover, or else I wouldn't recommend anyone coming here specially for the museum.

Disturbing past brought into present.. I find no words in my dictionary to describe and explain the atrocities the masses has gone thru during the evil regime of pol pot. It's literally like your nightmare coming true while walking thru.On the other, a bit of maintenance would do fair to the place. Caution : not for the faint hearted.
Worth a visit. If you are interested in history you should visit this place. The work which was done by this brave man is hilarious. Pay respect to him and his work by visiting and donating.

Interesting if you are a military buff. Went with children 9 and 11. English speaking tour guide was away during our visit or we might have enjoyed it more. Did have guide books available in English. Mostly just examples of bombs, land mines, military uniforms and equipment. If you are interested in that then this is for you. I would have got just as much out of reading the guide book sitting in a hotel in which it told me about all the issues/people involved as I did reading the guide book standing in the heat at the museum. History of the mission is interesting and necessary, but think it lost something by not being able to talk to someone and ask questions.But, as I said, if you are interested in the actual physical landmines and bombs and equipment then this little museum is right for you. And the admission is reasonable.

Informative and thought provoking. Quite a way from town but we decided to make the visit.Well presented history of tragedy.Came away feeling a bit numb.Hard to understand why we do these things to each other .Like the fact that money charged for entry is used for not just the upkeep if the museum but for ongoing mine clearance.Maybe should have tried to combine til til ride out with some other attractions.

If I could rate it higher I would!. It was supposed to be a 'thing to do on the way' to Bantaey Srei. It turned out to be much more. The image of a landline museum is all distressing, yes? Not so. I visited with the family (kids 11 and 13) and 'Bill' walked us around telling us about the place. I learned about the devices, the Cambodian history, and how this organisation is addressing not only the cleaning of mine-infested fields but also provides hope for the youth affected.ABSOLUTELY WONDERFUL. I'll go one step further. If you run out of time [and you have done Angkor Wat temples close to town] and you have to choose, go to the museum and skip Bantaey Srei. (don't get me wrong - we loved the latter) but if forced I'd do the museum!
interesting experience. well organized little museum. very good to visit on the way back from the temple and before the butterfly center.Very educational for kids.

Worth the Time. I visited the museum in February 2015 with a group of four friends from the US. We had an English speaking tour guide who was very informative and although it was my second visit, it was still very moving to understand the devastation caused by land mines.An important note is the tuktuk drivers seem to "piss and moan" that the museum is too far to travel to. It may be 20k from Siem Reap, but we headed there after lunch and were back in town in time for dinner. It was worth the tuktuk ride and our drivers survived the ride!

No visit to Siem Reap is complete without a visit to the Landmine museum. Cambodia's story is a tragedy: first the U.S. carpet-bombed the country for nearly ten years during the Vietnam war, then the Khmer Rouges murdered 1 in every 4 people in the whole population during their reign of terror, and then after the Vietnamese invaded to "free" the country, it split it in two in a proxy war with the Khmer Rouges retreating into the jungle and laying millions of Soviet-supplied land mines. There are still an estimated 3-4 million mines in the ground, randomly killing or maiming the population 20 years after the end of the war, and this charity works to clear the minefields by hand. Go see this. It's eye-opening and heart-warming. A definite must.

Incredible but a sad story. While the temples are incredible, Siem Reap has more to offer.About 45 mins away (you need a car or driver to get there- it's on the way to the angkor Conservation Centre and some temples) is the Landmine Museum. As a westerner it was a real eye opener tp learn about this sad chapter in Cambodia's recent history. The museum is very informative and also contans personal stories.The museum was set up by (the now somewhat famous) Aki Ra who has won international awards for the thousands of Cambodian landmines he has removed. This after being forced to work as a child soldiee for the Khmers Rouges.Most importantly the $5 you pay goes directly to the landmine charity, employing locals and, perhaps most significantly, the on-site children's home for those kids disables by landmines.Please visit. A very worthy cause and definitely an important aspect of Cambodian culture and history.
Great but to far from anything. Awesome, love their work but would be interesting to see someone with money take it to the next level. Being closer to town would be better as well.

Cambodian Landmine Museum - A small but important place people should visit when in Siem Reap. This place has a fascinating but sad story to tell. It was not on our bucket-list but we convinced our cambodian guide and driver to take us there.(We only paid 50 $ for a whole day with driver and guide who took us all the places we wanted).A small fee to enter and an informative video informing about the landmine situation in Cambodia.The museum is rather small but has lots of information about landmines both in Cambodia and worldwide.We found our visit very informative and enlightening, but this was mainly due to Bill who took us around and explained everything,- also discussing and answering questions.Without Bill or with a cambodian guide it would not have been the same for us.More could be said but several of the reviewers have already said it.Visit this place and support it. It is not that far from Siem Reap !

Chilling..... So much to learn here. The work done by AkiRa and his team is just amazing, his story is incredible to hear. TO see the impact of the landmines on the local population is a real eye opener and to realise the that people still die today due to landmines is just tragic.

An Eye Opener. The Museum is located on the road to Bentay Srei along the Palm sugar stalls. It is the result of one man's passion in collecting the bombs from his brevity in de-mining. Aki Ra has also helped children victim of bomb explosions and built them homes next to the museum. There are lists of their needs on the board if you wish to donate. CNN has acknowledge Aki Ra for his incredible work. The museum provides in depth history of Cambodia's political upheavals - this country has gone to so much hardships beyond description. Impressive collections and history.

Much to learn in this simple museum!. This is a small and simple museum, but is definitely worth a trip to. The stories of the children affected by landmines, who are now housed here, are just printed on regular bond paper and tacked on one of the walls, but these will touch hearts. Most of the images here are also simply done, but the lessons learned in this educational place still leave an impact. Make sure this is in your list of places to visit in Seam Reap. And since it is about an hour away from Angkor Wat area, a trip to this museum plus Banteay Srey Temple should be planned together.

Incredibly informative, very emotional and something everyone should visit. If you are visiting Banteay Srei, the pink temple outside Siem Reap I would urge you to stop and visit the museum on the way. Most people have absolutely no idea how much damage landmines do and are continuing to do to families not just in Cambodia, but across the world. The work being done by the amazing people here is outstanding. They should be supported and commended for everything they do to help not just those being cared living here and all the people whose villages have been made safer by having landlines in their area removed. We visited using a local guide and driver Mr Chhin who was amazing +855 0 12948963, email than_chin@yahoo.com. Highly recommend a visit here.

Worth the trip to learn about landlines. This museum was started by a young Cambodian man who has been working to remove landmines that continue to maim and kill Cambodians today, 50 years after they were set. It is a small museum but an important one. I had never seen what landmines looked like before.

Well worth the stop. While it's only a very small museum it offers a wealth of information about the Pol Pot era, the influence of the Vietnam army and the affects of war. Behind the museum is a children's orphanage supported by the museum. Children who are victims of land mines are educated and housed here. Tip: bring some toiletries or school books as a donation for the kids.

a deeper look at the Khemer. Not your average museum. It is like a park wherein all the remnants of the war are showcased. From tanks,guns,bombs and uniforms. It will give you shivers when you see the old photos and read the articles about. Very informative.

This is so interesting, you must go. It amazes me how somebody to spent his was life laying down these land mines and now heads the campaign to have them removed.what a great museum, Its so interesting to learn about all the different land mines from all the different countries. The striking part is how many are still in the country and causing danger to the people.

Lots to learn. We stopped by here while on our temple tour. Though we only spent about 20 minutes in there (there are only four rooms), there was a lot to learn and read about. Do stop by if you're already in that area. $5 admission.

Founded by an amazing man. This is a small unsophisticated museum telling the story of one mans effort to clear mines in Cambodia. This museum now funds the life of up to 20 mine damaged children and for this reason alone it is a must to visit. Your dollars will help these children. I spent at least 2 hours here and was very pleased I did. It is a gentle stroll around the exhibits and accessible to all. Do go, its interesting, educational, a great story of one mans traumatic life and you will be helping the children.

Small exhibit but VERY informative!!. This is well worth the stop. It's a small informal museum with lots of rusty exhibits. The retired couple running it are top notch people! I found this extremely educational, and one can't help but be moved by the destruction of these weapons. I had no idea how many mines are still out there and the efforts being made to locate and remove them. Everyone should see this!!!

Worth the time. The museum may be small however I found it very informative both about the mines themselves and the founder and his team, sadly no guide was available but the self guide information folder is very good. Impressive collection of ordnance (decommissioned) housed in display cabinets. Keep up the good work

A MUST DO!!. Ended our Cambodian visit with a trip to this museum. Awe inspiring tour with Bill learning about the de-mining efforts, school building/educational initiatives and boarding school. These Cambodian children and young adults are examples of what true focus and dedication can achieve. Truly makes one reflect on the entitlement being bestowed on Western children and the long term impact to our society. I can't think of a better way to spend your vacation dollars than in a country where each and every dollar delivers such value. The people and culture are open and inviting. The experience will open your eyes and leave you forever changed.

Thought provoking. the work this man and his team does is simply astounding. His story alone is breath taking sad, but also inspiring. An absolute must to help form and understanding of the tragedy that is Cambodia. Go see this.

Love in the time after cruilty.. A visit to the landmine museum will leave you somewhere between dispondant and uplifted. The cruelty that gave rise to its existence is somehow overshadowed by the tenderness and dedication that keeps it going. My guides most telling observation. "The people and many of the Governments who created and deployed these landmines are dead or no longer exist. It is up to us to address the problem". Us, is the cambodian people and those who are willing to help. The stories about the children will make you smile and in one or two cases make you reassess your own shortfallings. This is a must go place, just off to the side of the other must go places. I encourage you to attend. It is worthwhile knowing if you become despondent or uplifted, you will not reamin unmoved.

Must see. This is a great little museum telling the story of landmines in Cambodia, which has unfortunately been a key aspect of life there for decades now. Museum is very helpful for understanding and appreciating what has happened with these insidious weapons and the impact on ordinary life for so many Cambodians. You can drop in there on the way to or from one of the temple complexes (Banteay Srei I think).

Interesting and informative. A worthwhile cause - we were lucky to be there at the same time as an organised school tour so got the benefit of the talk that had been arranged for them. We were given an interesting and somewhat harrowing talk about the Cambodian and Vietnam wars. Whilst I was aware of the land mines and the devastation that they cause, I was unaware as to the extent of the problem that still exists. They are a charity that deserves a donation for the work and the assistance they are able to provide to the local people. We visited as part of our tour of the temples as recommended by the tuk tuk driver. Glad we went it certainly made me appreciate my own life.

Worth the visit. my heart was broken reading and looking at all the pictures of the victims specially the innocent children. far from the city and the museum is not really that big but its worth the visit ....

A place there make you thinking / Go there. Deep description of a terribly consequence caused the civil war and vietnam war.Landmine issue is a worldwide problem, therfore a visit in the museum is very worth.Follow the very good Amarican guide at the museum, he makes everything even more real through his huge experience.
A scary look at the recent past. This informative museum displays the huge array of scary landmines that still to this day litter areas of Cambodia.

Worth a visit . Although the museum has some flaws, it is definitely worth a visit to learn about the history of conflicts in Cambodia and, of course, the continued problem of the use of landmines. The museum is small but packs a punch. It also houses and supports landmines victims so I was happy to pay the 5 USD entrance fee.

A Solemn Reminder. A reminder that Siem Reap was not always as it was today. The huge number of undiscovered landmines in the Cambodian grounds are stunning. The efforts of Aki Ra and his contemporaries in clearing these mines are to be appreciated. Met an American who moved here with his wife from California who told us a lot more about the history and efforts currently ongoing .He works there and should be there often enough for those who are interested.

A Reminder That The Impact Of Wars Goes On And On. A little out past most the temples you'll see around Siem Reap, past the Banteay Srey Butterfly Centre (a great change of pace), is a tidy and very grim museum to the landmines set in Cambodia by the various warring parties, items that keep exploding and maiming people decades later. Lots of actual landmines and other munitions on display. The Museum supports a school for maimed children. The founder's story is riveting.

A bigger highlight than any Temple for me. It would be easy to visit Siem Reap and miss much of the history of modern Cambodia, but you'd be doing yourself a disservice. This is one of those must-do's, like the Anne Frank House. You don't exactly enjoy the experience of seeing man's seemingly limitless capacity to inflict brutality on ourselves but it's oddly uplifting to see evidence of how much effort a group of thoughtful, committed citizens have put into changing the country and the world.

Well worth a stop. You should stop here and your way back from Banteay Srei. Very informative regarding the Landmine problem in Cambodia and around the world. Cambodia is making some effort to tackle this problem within their country and this place has played a part in that work. Stop and have a look around, the entrance fee will help their work.

Humbled by visiting the Landmine Museum. Although this is obviously not a happy place to visit, seeing the difference those who've worked to improve the lives of Landmine victims, as well as trying to locate & disarm land mines is a humbling experience.There are still land mines in Cambodia, so buy something at the shop or donate to help.
eye opening. The guides have true experiences to share and the place is educational and interesting. Please do not touch some of the exhibits which may contain dangerous material.

You need to know. the sheer volume of land mines in Cambodia and across the world is staggering. Bill Morse and his wife Jill have moved from the United States to support this effort and they need more people to know about their project. If you are at the temples, it is worth the stop to learn about a very dire situation for many.

Worth the stop. We were fortunate to have Bill at the Cambodia Landmine museum tour us through the rooms and explain the actions they were taking, not just in safety but in building schools in remote areas. It is an easy stop on the way back from Banteay Serai (hope I have they spelling correct) and I would encourage you to support their efforts with your visit.

Worth the Journey. It IS quite a drive from town, in the Angkor Archaeological Park towards the Banteay Srei (one of the temples that's further away from the main ones) but not THAT far. Seriously.I arranged transportation with the hotel for US$23. You should be able to negotiate a cheaper rate if you take a tuk tuk from town. Entry fee - US$5 per adultNote: This place is different than the war museum in town. Some locals might suggest that you to go to the war museum instead, as it is nearer to town.I LOVE this place. I learned a lot about the war in Cambodia and the general horror of landmines all over the world. Might be too text heavy for some people though.

An eye opener into the legacy of war. Even If you where standing in an empty room the narrative from Bill was worth the time, the displays only help to get the point across more poignantly. what Aki Ra and the others involved with the museum do for the Cambodian people is humbling.Please visit and take the time to hear what the Cambodians still suffer.

A must see on your way to Banteay Srey. Very useful museum to understand the situation and the underlying issues about landmines in Cambodia and by extension in the world . Had the chance to have a tour with Mr Bill Morse , an incredibly knowledgeable american guy who is working there and it was really a plus so try to do the tour with him .

Worthwhile, educational, hopeful. We were so fortunate to have an English speaking (American) guide. We learned about the history of landmines, Cambodian war history, and the international effort (that is insufficient) to clear the landmines. While it is super sad that landmines are all over the place and still hurting people, I was inspired by the efforts of the individuals working at this NGO who seek to clear the landmines and make the world safer. I was steeling myself to go, but very thankful afterward that I had.

If you are going to Banteay Samre and Banteay Srei, you'll almost be going by the door.. I found this to be a very interesting tour and museum, and I didn't know how many landmines were still in Cambodia today. The tour was eye-opening, and you could tell the how very involved the guides were. Cost was $5 US per person. It is not a "polished" museum, but it makes up for that by how very dedicated and deeply caring the guides were..

Informative and insightful . Although the content is incredibly bleak this is an informative and insightful little nudism documenting the landmine situation across Cambodia. It consists of three of four separate rooms telling the story of the Khmer Rouge and how land mines were used across the country. It also documents the founders campaign to disable the mines. It's only a small museum but it's worth a trip and can be used to break up temple visits.
柬埔寨中文导游服务. 柬埔寨华语导游协会欢迎各位莅临柬埔寨奇迹王国. Cambodian Association of Chinese tour guide welcome you to the miracle of the Kingdom of Cambodia

bleak but educational. There are some things that we don't want to know about, but we should know about. The realities of the land mine situation is one of them. The museum is not fancy by any means, but it tells the story of one man, recruited into the Khmer Rouge army when he was 10, who has devoted his life to ridding Cambodia of the terrible land mines. One learns their history, who is making them, and why there are so many in Cambodia. Definitively worth a visit.

Heart wrenching and so important to support!. The people who have created this place are truly the salt of the earth. They absolutely deserve the support of all of us who had the opportunity to grow and live in peace. Because the people of Cambodia did not have that chance.Well worth a visit, it's on the way to some lovely temples, and gives you a chance to see some of the countryside, which is lovely, especially when enjoyed from a tuk tuk!

What a Story. What a place to visit, you have to listen to Bill Morse tell his story and the story of what they do for this community and its children. Go visit, you will donate and look at the world differently. It was the highlight of my Siem Reap trip. Listening to the story is the highlight, don't expect a fancy museum - they have better things to do with the money for the people they support.

Interesting, but FAR AWAY!. This museum was good, but REALLY far away! It would only be worth it if you were already planning on going to Banteay Sreay. I was already going that way, but only spent about 20 minutes in the museum itself. It really is amazing what Aki has done and how much he has helped his people since the regime ended. There are a lot of de-constructed mines and a lot of reading of how Aki has created his company. There was nobody there to answer questions, but it was kind of nice to be left alone and wonder through the four rooms on my own. Make sure you check out the murals on the front walls, done by the children that the museum sponsors. They are really good!

Fantastic Work. A man who stepped up to do something about a problem when no one else would. This place is really worth checking out. I really liked the jewelery made out of destroyed mines, but I wish there was a larger variety of items. Taking something so terrible an making it into something beautiful is a wonderful concept.

Interesting. If you dont know about what has happened in Cambodia you can see it here. Not a nice story. As a museum I would say rather poor. The only one interested in the visitor was the one charging the entrance fee. The people there are probably doing a good work as also the founder Aki Ra.
Interesting and gave me a new perspective. Excellent guide who went through the history and the part land mines played in Cambodia's past. Worth a visit and is on the way to Bantey Srei.

Thought provoking museum. Very interesting museum detailing one mans life and his amazing work removing land mines from Cambodia. The museum gives very detailed information about land mine use and impact. A very worthy cause to donate to.

Recent history - eye opening. It is easy to overlook the more recent history of the country when hopping from ancient temple to the next. This man, Aki Ra, has found his purpose and what he is doing and making the world aware of is show cased in this 'home made' feel museum. The most important fact that really struck me was that still an estimate 3-6 MILLION pieces of mines / UXOs are lying around somewhere in Cambodia, just waiting to be found by unsuspecting farmers or playing children. If you bring your kids, you might want to talk to them first. This could either be too boring or too shocking.

Worth the visit. As a small side trip this place is certainly worth the visit and brings home just how much of a problem the Cambodians have had to and indeed still are facing. If you can give a donation, but after you have visited you wont need me to have said it you will want to help.
Heart breaking. Very confronting but we should all visit here. Landmines are still a problem in Cambodia. Please donate to this worthy enterprise.

Moving and Challenging. This is a story about a Japanese man who decided to take a stand against landmines and in so doing effectively changed the world and made a significant difference to the quality of life of the Cambodian people. It challenged me as to what I was doing with my life - am I investing in the things that count? Worth taking the trip out there as this is an important part of Cambodian history that shouldn't be missed.

great museam from a brave man. please try to help this group of people, by buying somthing that the children have made.I love my painting from there, if there is a fee, I dont now, I just walked in and nobody asked for anything. I gave a donation.
Tired and dusty. Very relevant museum. Needs some TLC. Children were fascinated. Not to be confused with War Museum which we also visited.

Worth a visit . If you want first hand up to date information from people passionate about their cause and really making a difference to cambodia and Cambodians go here check it out take a tour (free) , its not far from a temple or three (nothing is) the butterfly place which regretfully we bypassed. Learnt a lot not too long very informative and went through some nice countryside on the way, with real life villagers doing real life things. Only $5 admission

Eye opener and a trip to ponder.. It was a 40 minutes long ride to the museum as it was in the outskirts of town but it was worth every minute. Here you will find all the information needed about the museum founder, his life and mission to help his country from the devastating effect of landmine. The museum host all sorts of personal stories by children affected by the mine and it an inspiring and moving story. In the middle of the museum there is a tower of assorted landmines of different countries served as a reminder that these things have a powerful impact on life and country. It is a museum of a man's dream and to make a difference in people's life. Short, meaning and inspiring. Worth our $5 and trip.

Well Worth Your Time. I was lucky and had a tour while at this museum, but even if the guide hadn't been there, the museum had enough information to take in the magnitude of the problem and the difference one man has made in improving things. It was inspiring.

Well Worth The Visit. You'll learn the incredible story of the museum's founder and how land mines continue to threaten the lives of the Cambodian population. It's a moving story that is well presented and explained by an American ex-pat.

An eye opener. This museum is quite a long drive from Siam Reap - its got displays on the effects of land mines . The collection includes guns, weaponry, mortars .The curse of the land mines is visible here.

Tuff to face the truth. Stopped by on tour and the guide (American volunteer) was most informative and helpful. Walked us through the small museum explaining the facts of land minds in Cambodia and how dangerous the situation still is. Funding to find old land mines has been cut drastically, so the number of injured is increasing. So many nations planted them, washed their hands, and walked away. Although there is no entrance fee, you might want to make a donation if you believe in the cause. Worth the visit!

A short interest visit for a day trip out of Siem Reap. Anyone who wants to know more about the landmine crisis going on in Mekong countries like Cambodia, Laos and Vietnam need to give this little museum a visit. Started by a Khmer Rouge deserter and former Vietnamese soldier, it is a good way to make the most of a day trip out of Siem Reap. People should consider it in amongst a range of other options close by and make a entire day out of visiting the Angkor Centre for the Conservation of Biodiversity, Bantrey Butterfly Centre or Bantrey Srey Temple as well.Granted the place is small (it only had four rooms) but Aki Rai and his organisation clearly designed the museum as a way of educating and raising awareness about what conflict has done to these countries. The $5 ticket goes towards continued deactivation operations throughout Cambodia and the care of bomb victims who live behind the property.If you're fortunate enough to have a guide, the experience is no doubt better than going without - but you can still navigate and learn on your own.

A sobering reminder that there is still more work to be done. While looking a little tired, this museum brings home the ongoing problem of concealed, undetonated landmines and the dangers they pose for Cambodians, particularly in villages. Jill and Bill Morse do an amazing job running the facility and the school.

A great place to visit if you are "templed out"!. I am so glad we visited the Cambodia landmine museum near Siem Reap. The exhibits bring home how destructive and terrible the legacy of old landmines are years after they have been laid in the ground. Strangely enough though this was an uplifting experience for me and I left on a high knowing that goodness can prevail over evil. If you are in the area please visit and make a contribution to the vital work these people carry out.

A chance to learn and to support a good cause. Unfortunately there was no guide available when we visited, but much about landmines are obvious enough. The museum is small, but with effective narratives. Clearing landmines and UXOs is a slow and dangerous undertaking, and my hat is off to the brave men and women who take this on.This museum is only about 4 miles (6 km) from the remarkable Banteay Srei temple, so you can combine these visits.

This little museum is so poignant. It is not a large museum, it is not at all high tech, but, it is a sincere and successful attempt to share one mans story and perspective of the wrongs done to Cambodia during the Khmer Rouge time. I almost guarantee that one of the displays will cause you to shed a tear

A balanced and informative view. The American guide gave a very interesting and well informed talk. His knowledge and ability to answer varied questions from the group was helpful. The work that they are doing is admirable and it is good to know that the government are now funding the school that they set up.It is disturbing to know that the legacy of the war will go on for many years despite so many groups' efforts

Not just a museum, it's much more. First I have to say that Mr Aki Ra and his efforts to make his country a safer place to live by clearing up landmines; what an amazing man and what a life story!We were guided by Mr Morse and he gave us a very interesting tour around the museum. Also a lot of honest thoughts and facts about the devastated effect the landmines still have today for the Cambodian people. We were told that the landmines still are and will be active for a hundred plus years.This place is also today a school and home for young children/teenagers suffered and injured by landmines. The fee support the school and the children. A very humble experience.

Uplifting place!. The guy who set up this museum and has been responsible for disarming the many landmines that are still left and continue to kill and maim hundreds of people and children every year. The children who live and school here as a result of the monies raised by the committee is very heartwarming and stories told by the children who have been maimed by these devices is very humbling!A visit here helps to raise those much needed funds and it is also interesting to read about the wars!

Tragic story. Essential to understand what went on in Cambodia. Even if you've already been to Tuol Sleng in Phnomh Penh and to the Killing Fields. It's an orphanage and does fantastic work. Stop off on the way back from Banteay Srei. Pay the 5 dollar entrance fee happily and give them as big a donation as you can afford. You might not have much money but you've got more than they have!

Absolutely worth to see - a must. A lot of information on Cambodia's past. Impressive exposition of all types of landmines and other explosives. Excellent documentation. Should be a must for everyone in the area. Don't miss it, they need your modest entry fee for the support.

History and charity working together to rebuild lives. This is less museum than a living project to clear the country of dangerous mines and unexploded ordinance from decades of conflict - the Vietnam war era, the Pol Pot genocide and the subsequent civil war. And it supports the victims of landmines. Harrowing but an important history lesson and a very worthwhile charity to support.

Great if Bill's There to Give You a Tour. The display would be a little bland if you were just having a look on your own, but we were fortunate enough to listen to Bill's guided tour.The project is helping Cambodians clear their country of mines, making it safer for all. They also operate several schools.Your ticket, donations and purchases all assist in giving Cambodians a better life. Stop at Banteay Srey while you're out there, eat some food at a local restaurant and make a day of it. If you speak to a tuk tuk driver in town, you can hire them for a family for whole day for $15 - $25. You could get them cheaper, but you get what you pay for. A well paid driver will trip over themselves to provide you with exceptional service. if you feel sociable, offer for them to have lunch with you. They'll tel you all about their life and you can get a great insight into the life of an average Cambodian, and they'll get a huge thrill out of being treated the way the should be - like equals.

Bemused by some TA reviews. Visited this place after reading some positive reviews about this place. However, after visiting the place, I was bemused by those TA reviews about this place. Firstly, the whole museum is tiny, only 4 rooms exhibiting the same stuff. Secondly, while the exhibits were well curated, the theme was more about the troubled past of Cambodia than about land mines. Thirdly, and perhaps the most disturbing to me was that the fact the founder of the museum was once a defector who had fought along side the Vietnamese army. In some of the explanatory placards in the museum, he proudly proclaimed to be a marksman and would normally be able gun down his own fellow Cambodians during the war. While I am not Cambodian, I definitely would not encourage anyone to support someone who would join foreigners and turn the gun barrel on his own people. By visiting the museum and paying the USD5, you will be indirectly supporting a person who had such a dubious history.

Everyone should visit this place. This museum is a must for anyone with even a slight intrest in learning about Cambodias troubled past. Created by an ex child solider turned mine defuser this museum is eye opening to say the least. Bill the tour guide speaks with a powerful mix of honesty and passion that left me wanting to learn more about this terrible part of history and it's continuing repercussions. They support children effected by the devastating landmines as well as victims of polio and other diseases giving them education and housing.
Interest place for visit. Shock to see many mines at this place and how horrible used over lots years. Place does very god work and deserves support.

Amazing real historical perspective of the country and people. A must see. A bit out of the way but not not too much. The American who gave us the tour has a story and perspective we found nowhere else. I suggest uf your in the temple area go here

If you're visiting Cambodia this is a "must see". The history of the past half-century in Cambodia is heart-breaking. And this museum pulls no pinches. But it's essential visiting for anyone who wants to REALLY understand what has happened and what is still happening. This museum provokes thought, doesn't gloss-over anything and is brutally honest. Attributes which, to me, are far more important than shiney exhibits is marble halls. This is truth and honesty - and I very much recommend it.

OK let's be honest!. This is not about the badly made up 'soldiers' or the poorly put together display's but about a man who has devoted his life to trying to make his country a better place, I'm not going to ramble on, ill leave that the the excellent American guide, BIll, to do. But what it is is a thought provokin visitors centre to let you know a history of a war torn, ripped apart country and how with places like this that things can get better.It's a wonderfully deep and passionate place that I would recommend to any one who had a heart (that's what Cilla used to sing!)Donate money and see that you can make a difference to local people lives, they have a school they sent children to Univercity, children who have no parents and not life or have been Ill, it's just a great experience of the kidness of human nature, intertwined with the dark side of 3 to 5 million mines sill out there to hurt innocent civilian's.A must for anyone who like to dig deeper in to a interesting country.

A must go if the troublesome past of Cambodia interests you. Whilst in Cambodia it is impossible to miss the effects of the devastating past that Cambodians have endured and by visiting this center you can learn about the gruesome past of Cambodia and put a bit of your holiday money to good use. Aki Ra has done some truely fantastic work and this place is well worth a visit. It is not far from the Butterfly Center also and can be good for some light relief after a dark and horrifying history lesson. Can easily be visited whilst on your way north of Siem Reap to visit Phnom Kulen national park for example. It only requires 30-60 mins to absorb & will leave you with food for thought that will last a lifetime.
Inspiring. A great guide doing a great job.Although small,the museum is an eye opening view of the difficulty and danger of mine clearing.Take time to absorb the exhibits.
Great. We visited it on the way to branTey Srei tele , it is well done with all types of mines on display that were used in the war .

depressing. This museum is shows extensive exhibits of the landmines that were a feature fo the conflicts in Cambodia's turbulent past but I also find it depressing albeit informative about the horror of this weapon of war.

Worth the trip. A reminder of Cambodia's more recent history and how far this country has come in rebuilding after war. Very sad stories but also stories of hope and inspiration of the man who established the museum - from child solider to anti landmine advocate.

Educational, historical, human and a touching museum. An awesome experience - through the eyes of an ex-soldier who used to plant landmines since he was a kid, visitors got to learn about the landmine plagued country and how these mines all started and the damages they have done to the innocent. A highly recommended stopover!

Heartbreaking/Heartwarming. Super informative with lots of interesting facts and stories written by people who have been effected by or are trying to disarm the thousands of land mines still buried in and injuring people in Cambodia. The museum serves also as a home for amputee children and your visit, donation or purchase in their gift shops goes toward disarming the mines and providing a home and education for the amputees.
Special place. Very interesting and moving especially if visiting Banteay Srei.We found this on passing with a guide and stopped but worth the stop, fee but all goes for a very good cause.
Land Mine. We visited the Landmine Museum on our way back from Banteay Srei. It was an interesting place and certainly worth a visit

Gently educational. Was afraid it would be too traumatic, but there was a lot of information presented very matter-of-factly, and was very happy to have the chance to get some nice souvenirs to help support the cause.

Help Support Deminer. Well educated after i get to see all the informations about this crisis. A little bit sad that not so many people will really considered it as a major problem. Visit them and every penny you spend will be for kids support school inside this museum.

Makes you think - a worthwhile charity. This is the museum set up by by a former child soldier who now clears landlines from villages. The sheer amount of US and other mines that were dropped on Cambodia and are still a problem beggar belief. The centre acts as a family for orphaned children providing an education and a start in life. The displayed wish list includes things like toothbrushes, fundamental items for tourists. Raid your hotel bathroom before you visit!!

Worthwhile Visit. We stopped for a few minutes at the Landmine Museum outside Siem Reap after a visit to some temples. We planned on a half hour but wound up spending over an hour looking at the exhibits and talking with a friendly American supporter of the museum. This is not a fun place but definitely worthwhile.

a bit unsettling but worth a quiet visit. it gets very few visitors. we had the place to ourselves. however, the story and history are worth exploring. check it our. there is a fee, no pressure from vendors, and it is a quiet break from the temple hordes.

Grim subject but worthwhile to visit. Obviously this is a very grim subject, but that's no reason to ignore it, so we stopped of at the Landmine Museum for an hour on the way back from temple touring.It was certainly both interesting and eye-opening to learn the history of the landmines and continued threat they pose.We were happy to make our own donations to their cause by buying some very beautiful keyrings made from old casings - definitely a better use for the metal.Recommended as part of getting a fuller picture of the history of Cambodia.

Small Museum. MineThis is a very small museum with artifact of different types of mines and bombs that were used in Cambodia wars. It has a bit of history in the person who started the museum and outline problems with active mines in the rural area of the country. The entry fee around $5 person. The attraction is probably less than an hour long. Most of the mines and bombs are rusted and looks like scraps.

must see. A very informative museum about the devererstation coursed of land mines to people and wild life It takes in young people who have been injured by land mines and help them to rebuild their lives. They have volunteer to explain what is happening at this time.

Sad, but worth it.. Visiting this museum was definitely a sad experience but a must if you want to get a slight idea of what Khmer people went through during (and after) the war.  The museum fee goes toward the children living in the museum, which is another reason why there must be more people visiting it.
A museum not to be missed. A museum not to be missed if you want to catch up on Cambodia's terrible past and see the suffering even today, but with very positive conclusions

On the way to Banteay Srei. If you are going from Siem Reap to Banteay Srei, by all means stop at this small museum. You will learn more about which countries in the world are mined and which are responsible.

Cambodia Landmine Museum. My boyfriend and I really enjoyed going here, its a small place, but we spent over two hours there. Was very educational where we could learn about and see the impacts of landmines in cambodia and what is being done to help remove them. We were lucky enough to have a small tour which was very interesting! It is on the way to one of the temples which is a bit further afield so if you already have a temple pass i'd recommend going to Banteay Srey as well! However a pass isn't required to go to the museum. Takes about half an hour from the central city to get there, but it is an interesting ride and well worth it! would definately recommend. there is a shop at the meuseum as well where you can purchase items that help the children that live at the school. Costs only $5 to enter the museum.
Humbling. A humbling experience to realise the aftermath of the war on Cambodians- this is not just history but a daily reality. Humbling.

Very moving visit. A complete eye opener and very sincere people that conduct the tour. Very worthwhile the visit to understand the on going issues caused by land mines and nice to donate to help these lovely people.

Well worth the stop. This little museum is doing important work by educating and supporting the removing of land mines world wide. I learned so much about the use and misuse of land mines. It doesn't take long to tour the whole museum.

Impact of landmines. We visited the museum on our way from Siem Reap to Phnom Penh. It provided a thorough look at the devastation that land mines caused and chronicles the story of Aki Ra who originally cleared land mines by hand and erected the original museum. We were very fortunate to have met one of the people who taught Ra how to safely clear mines.

Emotive. We dropped into the museum at the end of two days of touring temples and it was very emotional and a great insight into the ongoing battle small villages still are up against with land mines.Entry is $5 and they show you where your money goes, kids under 12 are free.There are four main areas that are intriguing and mesmerising.Do yourself a favour and take the detour to this museum.

A must see. It is so important to know the history of countries you are traveling to. This was a heartbreaking visit, but very important. Had to buy the book "First they killed my father" here, to support the place who still helps victims of landmines.

must visit!. Cambodia has an incredible recent history and this place really captures that. set up by a man who used to lay land mines in the army, he is now on a mission to help remove them from affected areas across the country.informative, humbling and really amazing. places like this should be high on the list of any traveller to truly understand the country they are visiting.and all funds raised here go to support the effort to find and remove land mines from Cambodian rural land.

Simple and straightforward. This tiny museum is funded by donations from visitors and online. It covers the sad part of war -- land mines -- and the awful impact on people over the course years of war. It has real land mines which have been deactivated by its founder, Aki Ra. Any visitor to Cambodia should come here in addition to the temples to fully appreciate the history of the Cambodian people.
Incredible. Well worth a visit, very touching and incredible to see and learn about the landmines. Fascinating to see what has been done and what is continuing to be done.

Very informative. A small museum outside of Siem Reap that shows the devastation of landmines. Throughout Cambodia you see people who have been affected and are missing limbs as a result of landmines. They have a small shop selling products to support their work which includes a home for at risk children and those affected by land mines.

Check when the guide is present. Although the museum might look a but empty at first, check out the days when the American guide is present (4 days a week, I went on a Monday) because he will improve your experience dramatically. Otherwise just stroll through the rooms, read and absorb the info boxes. $5 entrance fee is a donation.

Simple Museum With Impact. Well worth a visit to learn about history and landmines. Most touching are the personal accounts of those affected. I knew this was a problem, but the magnitude of the problem is still so much larger than I realized. This is also the site of a residence and school (and glad to report that visitors can't visit this). A good museum both educates and makes you feel emotion and this did both; I still think about this now we are home in Canada.In regards to location, we didn't realize how far out of Siem Reap it was by Tuk Tuk, but we enjoyed the ride through small villages and fields. There is also another temple to visit along the way.

Landmines. The displays show the many types of landmines used and the awful effect on Cambodians. There is a wish list for the attached school - I wish I was aware of it before I visited so I could have taken something to help. Check out what they need here http://www.cambodialandminemuseum.org/wish-list

Sobering Reality Driven Home.. The fact of life for many folks who live with the injury of land mines.The displays were quite harsh - and the fear that others live in since there are many many more landmines remaining. Worth the visit.

Landmines. Everyone must see this place. It shows you the absolute horror and injury these things can cause. It is certainly eye opening to see the magnitude that the landmines covered and to this day they are still retrieving them.

Very educational! Must see!. It's a bit far outside the city of Siem Reap, but worth the drive out, especially if you're going to Banteay Srei, which is just a few km past this museum. It costs $5 to get in. Grab one of the blue binders and basically read everything. Really great accounts of the founder Aki Ra's personal life in both armies, planting thousands of mines, and later de-mining over 50,000 of them himself!

The guide makes it.
