The museum is a bit outside town so probably best to combine it with some other attractions in the area but that is easily done with a temple nearby, butterfly sanctuary, different craft workshops etc. We also really enjoyed the landscape along the way.The museum itself is a little tired in the displays etc but informative and educational. The day we were there, an English speaking guide was on (American chap) and his passion for the whole project really brought the place to life. I don't think there are always guides available though so maybe double check before you go if that is important to you. Price went up in last few months and is now $5 but given it all goes back into the museum and the centre for children it is well worth it. If you have the time at all would recommend a visit here, to learn more about landmines and the effect of unexploded ordnance on a society, even after war has ended... Something that is an issue worldwide not just in Cambodia and will be for decades to come unless more money is devoted globally to de-mining activities.

Very eye- opening. I'm so glad we visited the Landmine Museum. I basically knew nothing about landmines before the visit and I learned so much. I think it's so great that the founder also started an orphanage and I that it is not open to the public. Overall, it's worth a trip. It's small and doesn't take long to see, but it made a huge impact.

A little rustic but definitely worth the visit. Great eye opener to visit this place. Displays are a little tired but if you look past that you find the facts astounding. Drop into the pal sugar stalls on your way there to see how they make the palm sugar used in many Khmer dishes.

A must see Museum. Whilst the subject of the Museum is quite gruesome , it is a massive part of Cambodias recent past . They do amazing work here . Our guide was an ex US serviceman who spoke passionately about a subject dear to his heart . PLEASE put this place on your Agenda

Please go. I wasn't feeling too well so didn't stay very long but you MUST visit. I didn't have the energy to take it all in but I'm glad just to have paid the $5 to get in. These people do amazing things and you need to support them.
interesting. All types of land mines displayed , also the areas they were placed in cambodia , still so many unexploded ones in the country .
Sad but also uplifting. Tells the story of one individual and his life journey, but also a lot of general information on the complicated history between the 70's and 80's.

Sad reminder of war. This was quite a way out of town, about 45 min in a tuk tuk, but well worth the visit. It is not a very big museum but the guide, an American who works there, explained the whole landline story very well. Our yuk yuk driver charged us $20US to take us there and back. We didn't stop on the way but you could ask your guide to stop and have a snack or take some pics along the way.

Must see... not fancy. This place shows the history of the area. Profound and very educational. Must see if you are in the area. Highly educational, but worth your time going. Definitely, something I would say DO NOT MISS! It is very humbling. Arrange transportation... tuk tuk is $15-$20 USD but a great way to see the country side.

Great experience, Bring supplies to donate!!!!. Good experience as part if our tour of Cambodia. There is a list of items the facility needs for their orphans and for the schools this NGO helps with. Please pack some school supplies for the kids in your suitcase from the your home country or from the cities here. You will need room for all your "happy pants" anyways. The kids need all types of school supplies. Markers, pencils, pens, white boards, hand sanitizer, paper, books, shoes, etc. Contact the NGO for a specific list

Sobering view of events still going on. Sobering place, very thought-provoking. You'll leave feeling very sad but glad you visited since it gives you a further insight into the Cambodian people. Small place so best visited with other places nearby.

A humbling experience. The museum was very detailed and I learned many things that I did not know about the Khmer Rouge and many atrocities that were committed during the late 70's. A touching and worth while experience.

Sad, but must see.. Decided to give our kids a different experience and show them how lucky they are. We all felt very low after visiting and reading and seeing all that was there. There is an orphanage behind the museum which touched our 10 yo very much. Donations can be given and I would highly recommend to give. Things such as toothbrushes, pencils, exercise books are well needed if you don't want to donate money.

Worth the time. The Siem Reap Landmine Museum was a sobering experience.The place was started by Aki Ra, a former Cambodian child soldier, who actually set a lot of mines when he was a child. Since the nineties he’s been working to remove mines and unexploded ordinance from Cambodian soil (left over from various invasions, rebel actions and carpet bombing by the US).The museum partly houses empty casings, and partly explains the rather bloody recent history of Cambodia that makes it necessary for his work, and partly tells his personal story.It's a very long tuktuk ride from Siem Reap, but absolutely worth it, to get a better understanding of recent history. Might be worth fitting it in to a 'further out temples' visit, rather than what I did (a museums day).

Sobering...inspiring. This museum is modest but its contents and message is powerful. You'll view a collection of land mines that have been cleared from parts of Cambodia and see and hear about the devastating impact the weapons have. A visit will help further understand the complexity of Cambodia and its people.
So informative, we highly recommend.. Really informative and well done. I would put this on your list of places to see while in town! It's a little drive to get there, but totally worth it!!!

An informative and moving tour. We stopped by here on our way to Banteay Srei and arrived just in time to take Bill's free tour. An American who who helps out with the amazing work this group has done, he is a dynamic speaker with a wealth of knowledge about Cambodia's history with land mines, and brings to life the experiences, difficulties and challenges they have faced. A small, modest museum, yet rarely have I been so moved.

Small and educational museum. We built this museum into a day trip to the further out temples. I was not sure if it would be too heavy a topic for my kids aged 7, 11, and 13, but the small museum size and real quotes from children actually engaged all of us. We wanted our kids to understand the recent history of Cambodia as well as the grand history that built the temples. After our visit here the kids could emphatically summarise what has happened and how dangerous life in rural Cambodia is due to the land mines.

To acknowledge and appreciate. Sad, of course, but interesting. With so many tourists inundating Siem Reap, why not acknowledge the recent history of Cambodia. It will give you a deeper appreciation of the Cambodian people, their stories and experiences, and their many successes since the end of the war.

A must see, chilling and heart warming at the same time.. Our hats off to the director and founder for the amazing work he does and directs in clearing mines and supporting those affected. Its worth the visit and we just wanted to thank the staff for their works.

Amazing work being done!. We tool a run tuk to the Landmine Museum and were lucky enough to arrive when a tour was just beginning. The guide, Bill I think, is an American that was inspired by the work of Aki Ra in clearing land mines. The work of Aki, Bill and their team is amazing and inspiring and it was extremely educational for us and the kids to understand the background and ongoing work that's required. The museum also takes in and educates kids who have no other options and are often victims of land mines or disease. Their work also includes the building and ongoing maintenance of small schools for villages. Definitely worth a visit and if heading out in that direction from Siem Reap go make sure to travel the extra 15kms to the ACCB, Ankor Centre for Conservation of Biodiversity.

Interesting. Not really on the tourist map but should be. It's a sobering thought provoking place. We took a tuk tuk from our hotel, about 35km, it was a 20us dollar round trip and he waited patiently for us. Should not be missed, they are doing such great work.

A must-see museum. This was one of the best museums I've ever visited. I find museums often overpower me with information but this one had such a great balance of history, personal stories and memorabilia. Aki Ra's story and those of the children the school looks after made me feel quite emotional and it has made me want to raise money for or donate to this worthy cause. There was a great shop where I bought a beautiful brass bracelet made from old weapons. I definitely recommend this place!

A small museum with a big impact. We made a quick stop at this museum and we are so glad we did. One of the museum's advisor's was talking with visitors when we stopped in and it was fascinating to hear his stories and explanations about land mines. He is a retired military officer from the USA, but now lives in Cambodia to work on the land mine problem. It was an educational museum with a powerful message.

Interesting and informative. This small museum is very powerful. It tells the story about all the landmines that are still being found so many years after they were placed. These mines are still doing terrible damage to the poor farmers and preventing them from planting in many areas still

Hope. From a tragic history has risen a people with hope. So much good work is being done in this country to improve people's lives. The work of removing landlines is ongoing to make the countryside safe for villagers and farmers.This museum is a must see

genuine, worth the trip. Decided to make this a half day adventure with the kids 8 and 10. Took a tuk tuk from our hotel for the 1 hr trip out here. Tuk tuk cost $15 for the round trip including our driver waiting whilst we were in there. Drive took us past lots of villages and although a bit scary with traffic at times, well worth the much closer look at the way locals live on the way. The museum itself is informative with an american guide wandering around explaining everything on request included in entry fee. Fee is now $5 usd per adult, kids under 12 free. There are 4 rooms with different displays ( no searching for landmines self attempt anymore that lonely planet talks about) . Nevertheless the kids were engaged and liked reading the stories. We did not go to banterey temple nor to the butterfly farm which we drove past, literally spent the time just to get to this museum and still worth it.

A must see, must feel unique Cambodian experience. Our visit to the Cambodian Landmine Museum is one i do not think i will ever forget. To see the landmines, the damage they have done, the limbs and lives that have been lost is beyond my comprehension as an Australian. The small in size but huge in emotional punch this museum shows all the sorts of landmines used in a outside setting and inside a powerful glass case with which u walk around. I was particularly moved by some of the items in the small shop, i bought a drawing from one of the kids in the school which is part of the project showing a sunny day and a walk way like that of the wizard of oz, all for $1. i also bought the most beautiful pair of earrings and necklace made from the brass shells of the left over bullets, the necklace is a intricate lotus. i wear them often and feel how lucky i am to have not seen such horror and how our problems are so small compared to the continuing struggle of the Cambodians. This is a powerful place that everyone should experience.
Powerful experience . The information and exhibits are simply displayed which adds to the impact!! The storyboards informative and emotive.... Excellent visit..............
The history of Cambodia is powerful and tragic. The Landmine Museum helps to tall some of this story in a very human way. This is a short stop and should be a part of any trip to Siem Reap.

Prepare to be blown away. A humbling, thoroughly worthwhile experience. Reminds you of the issues faced by Cambodians. We were lucky enough to visit at the same time as one of the investors of the museum- I'm afraid his name escapes me- who brought the experience alive. The museum was established in the 90s by an ex child soldier- who now uses his expertise and skill to deactivate the landmines left by the Khmer Rouge. Please look at their Facebook page- there is a wish list of items needed for the school (felt pens etc.) and take a little something if you can. We wish we had known this before setting off. DEFINITELY worth visiting en route to Banteay Srei. A highlight go our trip to Vietnam and Cambodia.

Worth a trip. The museum was very interesting and obviously something worth seeing/experiencing if you are in Cambodia. All sales go towards looking after the museum and running a school for disadvantaged children, so even more reason to visit this place.

Very interesting museum on the way back from Banteay Srei. Worth a 30 minute visit to this museum for the facts on land mines and how many remain all over Cambodia - this really brings home the challenges that ordinary Cambodians still face daily after years of conflict.
Great experience. This is a very interesting museum which tells an amazing story of one mans dedication to removing the scourge of land mines

Admirable initiative, but needs perhaps to be renewed.. As a museum maybe not very well organized and a bit out of date. However well worth a visit if You can spare the time. Take a tuk tuk, lean back and enjoy the landscape. Take a good stop for shopping and maybe a cold beer. Let the museum be a part in Your tour, not the main goal for the trip.

You haven't been to Cambodia if you haven't been here. We visited this museum on the way back from Banteay Srei. The guide was an American who has decided to dedicate his life towards improving the lives of those affected by landmines. This is a serious issue that is affecting Cambodia to this day.

Informative Quickie. This was quite good, and given the serious nature of the topic, I found the place to be amazingly peaceful. The data boards telling the costs of mine removal compared to distribution were sobering. We did not get a chance to leave items for the children, but I encourage you to do so. Well worth the time and the few dollars entrance fee.

By mistake, but worth it!. IT doesn't take long to walk through the museum, and it's not a lot on polish, but it's powerful. Our tuk-tuk to Banteay Srei had a flat tire, so we happened to stop here unexpectedly, and glad we did. Doesn't take long to look through it, but it's inspiring to spend a short time to see what these people are doing, at the same time sobering to see what this country continues to endure after years of war.
ok. A lot of different types of mines shown and tells the history of there use , a good exhibition. still have unexploded mines in cambodia

A must see.... While this is a smaller museum it is well organized and very informative. I think this place is a must if you are wanting a deeper understanding of Cambodias past and present. It's mind blowing to think that they still have areas that are not cleared of land mines and the suffering it has caused.

Small but worth it!. Calling this a museum is clutching at straws a little bit as it is essentially a few sheds and a garden being used to fund an orphanage for children of landmine victims/children with disbailities caused by landmines.Having said that though it is very informative and pretty sobering. Also really interesting to see the positive impact that one man/small group can have in a terrible situation.Its probably 45mins on a tuk tuk from Siem Reap but the journey is actually really enjoyable as you pass through some beautiful countryside and traditional Cambodian villages. Would recommend for anyone staying in Siem Reap for more than 2 days.

Small, simple museum - worth a visit. This museum was an eye-opener for me. Aki Ra's efforts to remove land mines from his country while educating the world about this issue demonstrates how just one person can make a difference. Before coming to Cambodia, I didn't know anything about the challenges with land mine removal. While many have been removed, it's disturbing to know that there are still many more undiscovered mines out there. Every year, dozens of people are being maimed by these devices.This museum is small and simple. An English speaking tour guide wasn't available when we visited so I used the informational booklet. The booklet was very informative and helpful. We thought this would be a quick trip to a museum before returning to the hotel. We easily spent an hour here.

Sobering.. A tuk tuk ride away, this homage to one man's determination to rid Cambodia of landmines - some of which he laid as a young soldier - is a sobering reminder of Cambodia's recent struggles and the daily toll it places upon the people - 15 people a month still falling victim to unexploded ordinance. It's not a neat and tidy, clean and well-organised museum trip we'd expect in the west, and that's not a criticism. It is what it is. Managing on a shoestring and volunteers, linking humbly their experiences with the Holocaust, Bosnia and Rwanda, it's well worth a visit, especially if, like us, you have teenage children.

Really worth seeing. This was a really mind opening experience for me. I learned so much from this simple museum, elegantly done and very moving. I had no idea that Cambodia had been covered in these awful land mines (a truly evil weapon designed only go maim people, not to kill them) and that over 100 people a year are STILL being injured by them in Cambodia. What wonderful work this man has done clearing so many of them from all over the country and taking in those who have been injured. We should all visit and take note and contemplate the costs of war to civilians.

Must see history lesson. I did not realize the extent of the land mines used - and still there- as a result of wars. Several people are killed each year by land mines and much effort goes into finding and disabling them

Inspiring and invaluable experience. Took my kids here and we all will never forget this museum. We learned so much about Cambodia, the Khmer Rouge, the role of the US in the conflict here, and the ongoing battle against landmines. The museum and their work is so important and we were so inspired. I can't recommend this museum enough - stop by during your tour of Angkor Wat!It is so worth it, the entrance fee goes to saving real lives, building schools and more!

Informative and thought provoking.. The museum is located about 40 minutes outside Siem Reap and is absolutely worth a visit. The museum is small; but packed with information and displays. Adjacent is a school and orphanage for children injured or affected by mines; but off limits to tourists. Besides the small entrance fee, you can help by direct donations and by buying from the souvenir shop. In fact, the wrist bracelets are made by the students at the school. I recommend going there by tuk tuk; you feel more “local” (but wear sun glasses to block the wind and dust from your eyes), going past fields, small villages and road side stands. And good luck on negotiating the price for a tuk tuk; our hotel quoted us $22, we negotiated directly with a driver for $17, and locals says $5 is what they pay.
Pleased we stopped for a look. Well worth the $5 - fascinating, sad and positive all at once. Amazing story behind the museum. Stop on your way to Bantreay Srei.

Eye opening. Well worth a visitThe collection of mines and bombs is astonishingAll were defused by Akira the founderHis life story is amazing. He is very honest about life in the army, including killingsThe realisation of so many people in Cambodia affected by land mines and bombs, and that there are so many left is sickening

Definitely visit. Worth a stop for 1-2 hours on your way to Banteay Srei and Beng Melea. It is literally on the side of the road so you can just pull over to spend some time here. Sad part of history, but ignorance will not right previous wrongs.
Museum Visit. Visiting this Museum wakes you up in a hurry; and you begin to wonder about the Madness of Men thinking up these sorts of Mines! It is totally insane and should be a lesson to us all.

Better then the temples!. While the temples are amazing, this was our first real insight to what has happened to Cambodia in the past and still happening with land mines minds. We payed $12 to get there and back from the city centre and it is worth every dollar. Touching work has been done by the founder of the museum. I left i wanted to help the county.

Impressive museum!. The museum is small but really great and it's really impressive how to see and read about the mines in real and not only from the books! The money was really worth spending there,for the future of the museum and the children! It's a nice experience to see the mines in the garden how small and invisible they can be in nature!

Must Visit. Here you will know about the founder of the museum and CNN Heroe, Aki Ra. His stories with the Khmer Rouge, defection and eventual role as land mine remover. A must visit, really. Makes your visit to Cambodia more meaningful knowing its harrowing past and the hopeful future its people are aspiring for. The place though needs a lot of loving attention as it is starting to succumb to entropy. Piles of paper and other stuff that doesn't seem to belong in the museum can be seen stacked in random corners.If you can look beyond the lack or organisational skills of the people who run this place, then you are in for a very informative visit.

Information Loaded. Our tour guide was an American guy who knew everything and anything about landmines. Talked for half an hour straight without a stutter and answered every question in detail. His work along with Aki Ra's foundations are truly incredible and a story definitely worth hearing.

The full story uncensored. Terrible road trip out around 30-45minutes but worth it. Not a big place but it has well written stories, presentations, war and mine stuff to see. There is an orphanage there but you dont get to go in which is great, go and your money helps to support them without making them public.

Experience.... 100% worth to see this. Sad, sobering and yet learning experience to see how this wonderful country(and many others) and its people was (and quite often still is) ruined by landmines. Despite all this you get to see some more inspiring stories of how this museum helps the kids and countless other people who suffered from landmines...

we ought to know about this. history and sadness but also very inspirational! what one man can do !!! they do such good work, both helping to continue to clear minefields and with a school for children -- very impressive.
Not what I had expected. A very small personal museum with lots of interesting artefacts relating to landmines but it was very dusty and looked in need of a lick of paint.
Informative and educational. Learnt a lot from here and reading the stories. Recommended to come here to understand more about the country, its history and problems they face

It will help you understand Cambodia's past. The museum is quite small and filled with old land mines. You could spend at least an hour reading the information boards and watching films. It really is a remarkable story and I marvel at the fact that he is alive to tell it. $5 entry.

A must see if you have a heart. A must see if you have a heart as it explains to you first hand the pain and suffering that these people are still going through on a daily base.this is not a vey big museum and yes by Cambodian standards the gift shop is fairly expensive . But because of the cause and the hurt children ,you are not really in a position to argue the price , as the good you money will do is obvious . Besides it is a lovely ride out in a TuK Tuk . The butterfly museum is just down the road

Small but powerful. Firstly, this museum is about 45 mins out of Siem Reap by tuk tuk, which we weren't expecting. However, I found that it was worth the drive. It is quite a small place, no bigger than your average western house. There are a few rooms which different aspects in each. It was quite confronting to see that many land mines and the damage they can cause. I thought the fee was expensive at first ($5/adult) but most of that goes to supporting the children who are victims of the land mines. The children live out the back of the museum, and attend school there. This area is off limits to visitors, which is nice that they aren't paraded around to try and get more money from you.

A very sobering place. The exhibits are more a backdrop to the stories that the guide tells you. Our guide had been "recruited' into the Khmer Rouge at the age of ten and eventually lost a leg from a landmine. His gentle and sincere approach to such an horrendous part of his life was very humbling. The museum also does give you some insight into the extent of the landmine problem in Cambodia.

Sad but a must see. We visited the museum on the way back from Beanteay Srei and it was important to read about the landmines and unexploded ordinances from the perspective of the Cambodian people. I hadn't understood just how much of a problem the landmines are for the country and how much work there is still to be done.

Very Powerful. I visited this museum on the return trip from Banteay Srei. For me, that made the visit even more powerful. I had just viewed Cambodia's amazing past, driven through it's present, only to reflect on more recent events of the past that continue to affect the present. It only takes about 20 minutes to see this museum, but it is well worth it.

Disturbing. Being from the U S I thought I should gp into yhe museum. It wasn't kept up well and the staff seem bored. Still there were some pretty interesting displays and reminders of the genocide. Hope more people go and they improve the facility

Worth a stop. A great change from all the temples and should be included with a trip out to Banteay Srei. While not flash in its presentation it gives some interesting insight into the country's troubled past & some of the challenges it has faced, and continues to face, due to the evils of landmines.

Fascinating insight into the recent history of this war ravaged country!. Worth combining with a trip to Banteay Srei temple. Very interesting visit and a genuinely worthwhile cause. Learned a lot and the extent of the land mine problem in Cambodia. Worth stopping for.
jia. A interesting lot of mines shown what was used in the war in cambnodia , easy to understand as each type of mine written about.

Confronting experience. A small museum with some confronting information and sobering statistics. Provides context for a better understanding of the reality of life for Cambodians and Is reflected in the number of locals you see with limb amputations. Definitely worth a look.

-. The museum paints a very clear and direct picture about Cambodia. I am able to take away a lot about Cambodia's history- not solely about land mines, but also about the Khmer Rouge era, past associations with Vietnam and the repercussions of US bombs and land mines during the Vietnam war.The founder has done an incredible amount of work disarming land mines in Cambodia, founding and sustaining his NGO and providing a better quality of life for a group of children who live on the museum property. Sometimes it seemed as if the museum was boasting about the founders achievements rather than telling an objective story, but that is nothing out of the ordinary. I really enjoyed the museum, by that I mean I think it was done very well. I went to the butterfly sanctuary and surrounding temples in the same journey and it was a nice mix of activities rather than just temple hopping.

Most of you won't go...but you should.... Alas most travellers are not here for long enough to get here but it is a must see...factor in Some extra days to your stay...It will only take an hour or two...but the drive will be another hour...This is a venue and a story of a man paying back his karma...If you are interested...take school supplies or such items...we arrived and saw a scrawled wish list...if we had known we would happily have bought items or sporting equipment to donate for the school...

A sobering experience. This little museum is on the way to the Banteay Srei temple in the Cambodian countryside and is well worth a visit (US$5 entry fee). We had a retired US army officer as our guide and boy, did he know his stuff about land mines in Cambodia! Everything you want and need to know, delivered in a sincere way from someone committed to making Cambodia a better place after all its troubles.

Must see. We made a special trip out to the museum. It is a real eyeopener to the destruction this country has faced over the past 30-40 years. Very imformative but also be prepared to shed a tear or two. Also great displays for those interested in military history and weapons.Please visit and spend money at the gift shop so they can continue with their good work of clearing landmines in Cambodia.

Combine with Bantey Srei. We stopped here on our way back from Bantey Srei, one of the Angkor Temples. It is a drive from town, so worth doing in connection to other stops. It is small, but has some interesting displays in a variety of languages. I see on the reviews here that a free guide is available, but we were not offered one and having one might have made it even better.
Interesting. clearly a fund raising venture but the proceeds go to a good cause and it gives some history background to the visit to Cambodia

Interesting and sad. We took at tuktuk from our hotel for about 45 min (there are no taxies in Siem Reap, only tuktuks or private cars, which are expensive in comparison), which was fine and the landscape you go through is as interesting as the museum. We found the museum was small, but packed with information in several languages. There are lots of information displays and books to read and it caters for people who like a story and people who like a fact. There are some very moving stories in there. The one note I would draw your attention to is that, as it is out in rural Cambodia, there are a LOT of insects. I would hate to think what could have happened if I was not already covered in my DEETs insect repellent. It could make an otherwise nice trip turn ugly. Oh and pack a fan as there is no air conditioning, but you’re not going for that. Worth a trip!!

Great Stories from War Victims. Not much of a museum if you've been to artillery museums before but what's great are the stories behind the tour guides. From their own personal experience, they are able to tell the story during the PolPot regime and how it destroyed so many lives and families in Cambodia. The tour guide is free of charge inside the museum but it's good to give them a tip at the end of the tour.
Overwhelming museum. The Museum is approximately 25 km north of Siem Reap. You can experience the brutality and damage this landmines can cause as well as see disarmed weapons, rockets and landmines.

Worth A Look For US$5. Well laid out museum with six rooms and a landmine display in the center surrounded by a moat. All the explosives on site have been diffused (incase you’re wondering…I did!). It’s worth a look on the way back from the Banteay Srei temple. The price of US$5 is a bit steep for what it is but worth it when you realize money raised goes towards the relief facility at the back of the museum for youth with physical and emotional difficulties as well as landmine affected children. It took me half an hour to slowly walk through as I was busy taking photos. An average person would probably walk through in half that time. I was the first one there just before 8am as the ticket office was closed although it is open to the public daily from 0730-1730. Hats off to Aki Ra and his team for doing a very important work.

A museum for the brave. The brave who led, first on his own, his manual fight against the landmines, followed by dozen of volunteer, created this museum which is also a orphanage. A small place nearby the temple, a must-seen in order to understand the tragic destiny of Cambodia.

Worths the trip. There are few places capable of giving you so many emotions.Landmine is just a small and simple museum, it will take almost 45 minutes of tuk tuk to get there, and it will take 40 minutes to visit it, but if you have enough time we highly reccomend you to go there.It helps to undertand firstly the background of Cambodian people, then how lucky we are not experiencing the war (and its consequences) as they did.Entry fee is just 5 USD, at the ticket booth you can also find how every dollar is invested to sustain the museum and to help all the kids supported by it.Don't forget to read the wishlist on the website of the museum, with a little effort you can make a difference.

Worth the stop- Learned a LOT. We weren't sure what to expect when our Tuk Tuk driver, tourguide and new best friend Khim asked us if we wanted to visit the Landmine Museum. We wanted to learn about Khim's culture and so we said yes. We learned a lot about the horrible atrocities that were committed in Cambodia within the last 30 years and about the great man Aki-Ra who spent his youth as a boy soldier and dedicated his adult life to ridding the Cambodian landscape of unexploded land mines. This was a very heavy place with a lot of sad history but we were so glad that we went as we learned a lot and left with a much deeper love and respect for the good people of Cambodia.

Lest we forget.. Founder Aki Ra's story has been told world wide and worth researching.Growing up I watched TV images of the senseless destruction, loss of life and terror endured under Pol Pot regime. Walked into this museum and a faded photo I last saw 40 years ago is pinned to a board near the entrance - I promptly broke down and cried.This tiny museum stands as a reminder of how one regime can devastate a country and plunge generations into poverty in a short time.However, there is hope here. It gives survivors a place to be heard, safe refuge and a home. Take the time to come here, contemplate and be the difference!
Worth a go if you are REALLY into History. not really worth travelling all the way there. If you are on the way to Kulen Mountain then its worth to stop by and take a look.

Started from a very little knowledge to a brief understanding. I know very little about Khmer Rouge before I went there. It was very overwhelming, sad, full of knowledge. Those Khmer Rouge leaders, if I could refer them as leaders at all, were smart people. Smart people do crazy stuff. Have you seen a sane professor? I couldn't help but to judge these things by stereotypes. Anyway, it is a must-visit / must-do stuff when you are there!

Take Some Time to See Man's Inhumanity to Man. Land mines are inhumane. So many innocent people are injured or killed from them, and most of the world, without Russia, China and the US, have promised to dispose of what they have and never use them. They are now being used in Syria. This little museum exists because of the efforts of one man tragically a victim of the wars in Cambodia. The museum is a little old. The pictures are faded. But the reminder and the story are real and current. Siem Reap and all the temples have witnessed war over the centuries. We don't see the blood and loss of life of those wars. But the 20th century wars are very evident in the museum and are a part of the Angkor Story. As an American War era American, I now see what happened in Cambodia 35-45 years ago.
Amazing man, worth a short stop. Great story of a guy who fought as a child soldier in Cambodia returning to remove landlines. Its a great cause and an interesting (if small) museum. Do stop in

Really informative and an eye opener. Good place to visit and learn about the history & current realities for Cambodian people in relation to landmines and the struggle to disarm them. The fantastic efforts made by local people to rid their country of these devastating war machines shines through through the information shared.It's amazing how many still lay fully armed in Cambodia!

Awe inspiring. If you are going to Siem Reap you have to find your way to the Land Mine Museum and see and hear the story of this amazing man and his life story and work, you will leave absolutely inspired. The authorities don't allow the museum to advertise for fear tourist might not like the story being told, you owe it to yourself to take the time to visit it.

Inspiring! Good for you and Cambodia. To learn about the impact of landmines on the people and Cambodia. Impressive museum that helped us in our understanding of the why, what and how of this terrible wapon (in Cambodia). We have seen how the founder Aki Ra and all the people involved, help the local community. The story of the founder Aki Ra is inspiring. Somewere he explains that as a kid soldier he had to install landmines. They were his friends since landmines kept him save. He thought so then. After the war was over, he desided to clear landmines himself.. In 2010 CNN rewarded him "Top 10 CNN Hero".With your visit you contribute to this good work. Helping to free Cambodia of landmines and the orphanage & school for (landmine victims) kids.
A must see. Gives one a small insight into what the Cambodian have been through. The landmines continue to kill and maim. It is hard to see but a little bit of reality

One of most immotive places in a siem reap visit. As a westener this place made me wake in a start its real its gritty . Its in your face raw. A must visit for any discerning traveller . This is the real cambodia . The legacy of policys our governments deemed ok as only foreigners and they simply do not count > You will see the debris of these policys Mines to many to mention bombs bullets en masse . Then the victims . I came away with an enlightened perspective and respect for these gentle unassuming nation . i now live here and do what i can . Visit feel something real . It will change you in a good way
detail. great exhibit , still people killed in cambodia by mines , great display of many different types of mines ,

Out of town but worth it. We came here on recommendations from both local tourist guides and TripAdvisor. It was about 40-50minutes from our hotel so quite a trek on a tuk tuk. While basic, the museum has some facts and figures on display on the issue of land mines in Cambodia. There was also a self-guide folder which I found really handy as it gave me more of an insight as to the issue and what's being done now. The weapons on display are pretty good too, no/minimal firearms, just lots of different mines and bombs. If you're into ordinances and weaponry, you should definitely come. It's great to see this place also helping victims of land mines too. Some of the artwork in the souvenir shop was pretty good I must say. The only real complaint from me was housekeeping. The place looks like it could do with a good spring clean! It is a museum after all.

A rare glimpse of the recent night mare history of this wonderfull country. Although of historical interest the history of the Khmer rouge regime has been lost to most tourists the regime of Pol Pot was such a traumatic event it is sometimes over looked and glossed over and forgotten .The Buddha room is awesome

interesting. this was an interesting place. not a long haul visit unless you are really in to guns, army stuff etc. but did enjoy the visit and it was interesting to see the stuff which played a large part in Cambodias history and where they are today

Small But Worthwhile. This is a small but worthwhile museum based on the experiences of a Cambodian man who was involved in both planting and removing landmines. Plenty of information in English and it provides clear files of information in other languages too. It provides brief summaries of the historical context, displays of the landmines themselves, and profiles on the people and children who the organisation helps. One of the staff members was particularly vocal in explaining the current global perspectives on landmines and the associated political issues. Also has a shop selling fundraising items should you wish to contribute further. Was USD $5.
Sad but worthwhile. Very interesting small museum with clever and reflective exhibits..take time over this and you will reap rewards.

An eye-opener to tragedies from not so many years ago. Having visited UXO Laos in Luang Prabang a few days before, I knew more or less what to expect in Cambodia Landmine Museum in Siem Reap. A good insight into history of American carpet bombings of Cambodia in the times of Vietnam war, data on death toll of civilians, info about current efforts to remove still active mines from Cambodia - it's all there and is a must see lesson of our recent history. However, what was the most interesting and giving hope for a better tomorrow after learning again how cruel place a world can be, was the personal story of Aki Ra, the owner of the museum, who used to be a forced kid soldier for Khmer Rouge, then changed sides to fight them and finally dedicated his life to free Cambodia of landmines and unexploited ordnance. The museum is half an hour drive from Siem Reap, but a definitely worth one - we enjoyed it much more than all the temples. By visiting and paying the entry fee, you also support two good causes: 1) the effort to free Cambodia of landmines and 2) orphanage & school for kids who are landmine victims.

A must visit. A great day weather wise - arranged a Tut Tut ride from our hotel - approximately 1 hour leisurely trip - allow 1 to 2 hours to visit - then 1 hour trip back.The presentation at the museum was very well done - thoughtfully presenting the facts then and now. When living in the western world it easy to forget how privileged a life we have. This young man will never be able to undo the past - but he deserves the support to try.

Humbling. An incredibly humbling place - I elected to do it by myself with two friends (one being local) and seeing the weaponry and landmines around was incredibly eye opening to the evils the Khmer people faced during the Khmer Rouge.

Great Stop on Way to Banteay Srey. Really like the land mine museum. It's a very short tour but a great stop on the way to Banteay Srey which is a must-see. I think the donation is very fair and the museum is very informative. I find it crazy as an American that our country still refuses to sign the International Land mine Ban - it made me very disappointed and embarrassed when you think of all the devastation these land mines have caused.

Boy makes mess, man cleans up!!. The man that set this museum up is one man who used to lay the mines and now spends his time educating people on part of the problem he created. Don't know how you could walk past people on the street that are limbless and leg less and not visit this place. Parts are very confronting but history normally is when the word war is included.This is not the largest of places to see, but all the relevant information and the people that can fill in the blanks are there for you to answer your questions. Enough is here in this museum to unnerve the majority but if you visit Cambodia I feel that you must visit these places if you are to understand the country that you are in and traveling around.Entry is a minimal fee considering you can walk in to a place whose history is partly about people who now can't walk.The guides here are very helpful and very explanatory of the museums purpose to educate all visitors through its doors.

very informative and moving. a must do. This museum is a little distance from Angkor Wat but it is definitely worth the visit. If you do nothing else to acknowledge the recent terrible war, you should visit this place. It is truly inspiring and the important thing is that it is a positive place of action to address the problems of so many mines still causing death and disability today. The shop is well stocked at cheaper than market prices with all profit going to the foundation.

A mix of emotions. The Landmine Museum is a little out of town and cost about 5USD to visit. There are English speaking guides available most days however if not there are information sheets available in a selection of languages to read as you go around the museum. It is a fairly small museum however it is packed with information and is worth visiting to understand the history of Cambodia and the struggles they have faced and a re still facing. I was fortunate to visit when an American Bob was doing the tours. He had been there 5 years and was extremely passionate about the plight of the Cambodians and the unexploded mines. The story of the museums founder who himself had been a member of the Khmer Rouge from the age of 10 and then defected to the Vietnamese Army as both a child and adult was inspiring. After visiting one cannot help but donate no matter how small.

It's a part of their history. It's a fascinating place, which gives you a real insight into the terrors of land mines & how it's affected so many people. And its suitable for children (in my view) over 7years old.

Appreciation. Visiting this museum was what I really wanted to do during my trip and I am glad it did. The entrance fee was USD5 per person. It is not a very big place, but very educational and it makes you appreciate the good life you lead, whilst there are others out there less fortunate.

Reflections ....... Almost overlooked this place - only small, but an important work and story that is certainly worth the visit. I recommend a donation, however small, as this supports victim children's education and care and tells it 'as it is': certainly worth a visit. These stories need to be told!
Very informative, sad and interesting. You learn a lot about the history of Cambodia and you find out about how the Cambodian people have suffered over the years because of war and the landmines

A sombering place. We had the misfortune of going on a day when there were no English Speaking guides available, however the printed display information is all in English so you can guide yourself to an extent.The stories of first hand accounts from the war are harrowing and its a very somber visit. As you can imagine, all the ordinance on display are rusted having been recovered from rural Cambodia, however the shear volume of items gives you a glimpse into the scope of the problem. There is a 'fake' mine field containing decommisioned ordinance in a non-displaycase style of presentation which also gives you a feel for the dangers that still lie out there waiting for some poor person to discover them.There is rehabilitation centre for child land mine victims out the back, however tourists are not permitted to go back there. I found that rule incredibly noble as I would hate to see those kids exploited in order to generate more tourist dollars.The Muesum is a good 30minutes from Siem Reap by tuk tuk so take bottled water and be sure to make the most of the trip by doing other things along the way.

An essential part of Cambodia’s story. This is much more than a museum, but the museum itself is well worth visiting. It tells the story of how and why land mines were used in Cambodia, and the terrible legacy they have left. Every year mines and other unexploded ordnance kill and maim Cambodians, often children. They lock up land that could otherwise be used productively. And the legacy of amputees and other injured victims continues.The landmine museum was started by a former Khmer Rouge child soldier who had laid plenty of mines himself. He wanted this part of Cambodia’s story told. The organisation he founded is also active in demining, and supporting children who have been affected by landmines or are otherwise at risk.A fascinating visit, and a very worthwhile organisation. Be sure to leave a donation as well as paying the modest admission charge.
Interesting.. An important part to understand the history of the locals which challenge them still today. Great project.
Jo. A sad place , really terrible how they used so many mines which still kill Cambodians , showed the different type of mines .

A great place to visite. We took a short ride in a tuk tuk ( #9 a truely good guy ) to the land mine museum The man who took us on the tour only had one leg due to a land mine. This museum is old but realy worth the visit. Lots of tanks and artillery and rifles and land mines of every kind.

NGO doing wonderful work - very informative. We were keen to visit to learn about land. Ones, and did not realise this is also an Orphanage. Naturally, we were not allowed to meet the kids (a good thing) but we learned a lot about the good woks and the stories of the kids who are ere,a s well as the history of Aki Ra.My sons rated this their favourite thing to do on Siem Reap.

Great little place! . This museum is a must see on the way to or from Bantreay Srei. Unfortunately as we were travelling on the weekend, there were no guides to talk us through the centre. But, information booklets were provided at the entrance and the various rooms contained plenty of information to help you understand the great work done by Aki Ra. Lots of interesting history, photographs and old landmines, definitely worth a look. They also have well priced souvenirs and tshirts that help raise money.
Sad and eye opening. It is only a small museum, but the displays and explanations are very informative. I had a much better understand of the issue of land mines in Cambodia, even to this day.
Thought provoking. Well worth a visit, easy to get to by tuk tuk from Siem Reap. Very sad that landmines are still causing death and disability even today.

Spectacular. You must go here.The story this man has is exceptional. The work that goes on here is truly magnificent and out of my whole holiday to Cambodia, KL and Singapore this was up there with the highlights.A wonderful and very sad place.

Very interesting and moving.. I'd put this place as one of the must see places in Siem reap, if you need a break from the temples, or are at all interested in the local history (as well as present day issues) then this place needs to be visited.Entry is $5 and this money is not only used for the museum's upkeep but also for the school at the back of the museum that houses youngsters from around Cambodia and helps to give them a good start in life.The museum is divided into 4 rooms each providing you with detailed information on the history of conflicts in Cambodia, as well as the efforts previously and currently made to remove land mines from all over the country.It was very powerful stuff, especially as you can see throughout some of the explosives that have been unearthed and deactivated by amongst others the museums founder.A small gift shop is located beside the entrance , proceeds of which again contribute to help those who need it most, and which charges very low prices (about $3 a t-shirt) for items.

Very interesting to understand better Cambodia's recent history. After two days of visiting temples, we wanted to see something different so we decided to go to the Landmine Museum. The museum is not so big, but very interesting to understand Cambodia's history and the impact of those awful weapons had and still have. In addition, it is run by an NGO so all the money (ticket is 5€) goes to some projects to support affected people and to keep clearing the country from landmines. It is always nice to know that the money spent will go to such a good cause.Just for orientation, we payed $20 for the tuk-tuk. It is almost 1 hour drive from Siem Reap with nice landscapes from the road. Lady Temple is about 5min drive from here, so it was a very good plan for a half-day trip.Would totally recommend it!

A fitting tribute to Landmine victims. An emotional subject handled very tastefully. It was very informative. About 30 children who are either injured or who are orphaned because of landmines live there. The entrance fee is US$5. There is a guide certain days but if not there is a written guide you can take round with you. Easily accessible by Tuk Tuk.Well worth visiting.

Very interesting. Visited the museum in the afternoon from Siem Reep. This is a small, private museum but it has great impact. It hammers home the tragedy of war and the price of a Cambodian people have suffered. What I remember most are the small handmade crutches for small children who lost limbs because of mines. Absolutely amazing.I think everyone should visit this place just to gain a greater understanding of what happened in Cambodia during the war years.

Informative. On our way out of Banteay Srei, my friend and I dropped by this museum. It's informative and self-explanatory. They don't let you in on the orphanage center which is good, so you have four rooms to go around in this museum. A good 30-minute side trip for us!
Very informative! . The tour of this museum opens your eyes! Please visit and donate to a very worthy cause! Aki Ra and his team do an amazing job!
Do it for charity. Tix $5 per person. A small museum with pics & abit of history & defused bombs. Part of purchases goes to funds. Vid show are available in languages. Interesting place.

Informative guide, good museum. The best part about this museum was the guide, Bill (?), who gave us a ton of information on the history of the warring in Cambodia, landmines in Cambodia and worldwide, and everything the museum and its founder, Aki Ra, has done and is still doing to help remove the mines in Cambodia and provide education to landmine victims and other kids who are not well off. The museum has a number of different mines Aki Ra and the others have removed, and general information about his past as a soldier and his present as a de-miner. Very interesting and definitely worth a visit if you're in the area. It can be combined with a visit to the nearby Butterfly Center for some peace and tranquility following learning about the awful past.

Very informative and touching. The museum is a good track out of the centre of siem reap, but it's a pretty nice journey out past all the temples and country side. It's a small and not well funded museum, not what you'd expect from the west, however this makes no difference at all. We were lucky to be shown around by an American man who works with the museum (maybe even in charge) I didn't catch his name but he is clearly very passionate about the cause, he has left his luxurious life in USA to live here in a small home. He really was brilliant, and explained everything so well. The things I learnt today definitely shocked and touched me but if you visit the museum or learn about the presence of land mines in Cambodia I'm sure you'll know how terrible it is. The museum is a great cause and every $ spent here goes towards the museum, bomb squads that are working to clear the mines or schools. For $5 and a the price of a tuk tuk driver (who will wait there for you) you can't grumble and you will be helping a great cause.

A must see and for a good cause. An amazing place showing the landmine history in Cambodia, a very sad tale. We arrived just in time for a guided tour by the very enthusiastic and informative Bill, who took us through the history and the amazing work his team and others are still doing to clear the mines, as well as the school they have set up. Well worth a visit and a donation to a very worthy cause

Please visit and donate. The tragedy of the landmines is still a very big part of this country and even today there are an estimated 2 million mines still active. Unfortunately this takes up a large proportion of farmland and desperate farmers are taking it upon themselves to clear the mines.

Very interesting, worth the trip.. I enjoyed my time at this museum, found it very informative & interesting. Quite a trip by Tuk Tuk but I enjoyed it as well. Plenty of photo opportunities along the way. I enjoyed the documentary that is available. The entrance fee is minimal & all the money goes to running the school, donate extra if you can afford it, as it goes to a good cause.

Must go. Of all the museums and sites we saw, this one ranked extremely highly. Despite being very low key, the huge impact is made by having one of the museum staff ( in our case) Bill talk us through the whole complicated scenario of the long and tragic history of multiple invasions of Vietnam throughout the years. My teenagers were totally absorbed and so were the adults. The authenticity and true humanitarianism was a welcome relief after being rice-scammed when visiting schools in the floating village. Mae sure you have plenty of time- fit it in on your visit to the jungle temple.

A definite must see whilst in Siem Reap. I visited the museum not expecting too much with the entry only being $5. It went up $2 just recently. it is about 45minutes by car from Siem Reap.The museum is only small, however the information and what it has to give is great. The visit was greatly improved by the resident guide, Bill. Bill is from the USA and has been with the organisation for some 11 years and as such was able to provide a realistic picture of this huge Worlwide problem.The museum and its income supports the clearing of land mines and building and staffing of schools in villages.Keep up the great work.

Eye opening. I knew nothing about land mines before going, and embarrassingly little about Cambodian post 1950 history.The information on display is excellent, the $5 entrance definitely worth it as $1 of it goes to clearing mines and $1 to funding kids schools.The highlight was the american working there, Bill, who delivered a brilliant series of rants to me as i wandered round on all kinds of subjects. Down-to-earth, sincere and effortlessly engaging on a very important subject close to his heart.Obviously landmines are a dark and horrific topic, but the people involved in this project are an incredible inspiration, must visit!

An Educational Experience!. This is such an essential experience to your Cambodian holiday. The dedication to help young people who are victims of the Khmer Rouge attroceties is truly inspirational.The museum lacks the polish of Western museum but is a worthwhile visit when in the Siem Reap area.

Informative and Sobering. My wife and I toured the Land Mine Museum during a trip to Siem Reap in early October. The museum is a 45-60 minute tuk-tuk ride outside of Siem Reap (but can be combined with a visit to Banteay Srei temple about 6km away - also the trip out to the museum was also a nice way to see some of the countryside). The museum is informative and worth the $5 cost of admission (of which $1 is used to continue to clear mines, $1 is used for educational programs in villages, and $3 is used to pay staff, support children made orphans by land mines, and pay for rehab of land mine victims). The museum includes examples of mines, mortars, guns, and weaponry from the Cambodian civil war. Interpretive information is in English (and other languages are available as well). Allow approximately 1 hour to view the exhibits and read the information here. Be advised that the museum is indoor/outdoor and while the indoor portion has fans, it is not air-conditioned.

Small museum with valuable collections. This museum was one of the CNN hero nomination with Anderson Cooper. Paid $5 per to enter was worth it. Beautiful setting with land mid collection from throughout the country that found, demand and displayed in this museum. Love it. It is one attraction that you must visit when you are in Siem reap.

Very worth a visit. We stopped on our return trip from Banteay Srei. It is a small and moving museum. Very sad what destruction has and continues to come from land mines. We should all remember the horrors of war.

An incredibly good cause!. This place is a bit out of town but very much worth the visit, we done it on day 3 of our angkor trip but had to tell our tuk tuk driver we wanted to visit as they don't think it's something tourists want to see as much! It cost us $5 each plus what we bought in the shop, full of information and all money goes to he kids that live there and there futures as well as getting rid of the remaining millions of land mines left in Cambodia
a must in siem reap!. This museum is a must If you visit siem reap! Very interesting, the guy from US that works there tells great stories. Dont miss!

Small, but worth the visit.. The Landmine Museum was very interesting. It is so sad to know that there are still so many injuries occuring from landmines that were laid in wars over 40 years ago! The efforts to clear the landmines has been amazing and a real credit to the Cambodian people.

A must see. We visited here, the butterfly museum and Banteay Srei all in one day. We had an excellent tour by one of the men who helped establish the museum and has been involved in the cause for years. It is great work they are doing. The small gift shop helps support the work and has some interesting items to purchase including T-shirts.

Educational. A small museum put together not to make money but make an impression and tell the story of the troubles that have and continue to plague this country. For those that really have no idea about the conflict impacting Cambodia over the past 50 years it will give you an idea.

A very moving experience. This is not to be missed. Bill was a wonderful guide through the museum and we learned a great deal about the mayhem created by these awful devices and the amazing work done to clear them out of the country. Unfortunately there is a lot more still to be done.

A very disturbing museum. A very disturbing museum which shows graphically the misery, disablement and death still being caused by the carpet bombing of the country by the americans and the painstaking dangerous efforts to clear the unexploded munitions with seemingly no help or funding from the people who caused the problem, apparently up to 300 people a year are killed or maimed now and many are children

Interesting for both adults and children. This museum teaches you the story about landmines in Cambodia and also tells about the war and the personal story of the founder. It was an eye opener for both adults and children. We combined this visit with the Butterfly Garden which is located a few km away from the landmine museum. The tuk tuk ride to go there was really nice too.

Glad we visited. This was on my 'to see' list, and luckily it was included on our bike tour itinerary. As we were riding out there anyway, I didnt notice the distance from town. This was one of the best things we saw in Siem Reap. The story of Aki Ra is very moving in itself, but what he has done with the Landmine Museum and setting up a home and school for at-risk and landmine affected children is inspirational. We walked around and read the information in each room and when we were finished we happened upon a tour that was just starting, being led by an American man who was one of the staff (Bill I think?). This was a great tour because we got to hear some personal stories and some information that put the landmine issue in Cambodia and across the world into perspective. Very interesting - I think these tours may run each afternoon. It is a small museum but has the right amount of information and artefacts on display. We came away feeling like we had a better understanding of the impact of landmines on Cambodia and its people. There is also a shop on the premises selling some clothes and other items that have been made by individuals with disabilities which is worth a look. This is an amazing place to visit and even if we hadn't already been riding out there it would have been worth the trip.

An insight into what really happens. The museum is small but extremely good. It is on the way to a temple so a little too far out of town to go to otherwise. I was happy to pay an entrance fee and purchase from their shop to support the wonderfull work being done.

Better then expected. This is something we had on our maybe check list, and dropped in on the way back from the water fall. When we got there, I was not very interested and had a "this is going to be boring" mind frame. After a few seconds of walking in, we were invited to jump in on the end of a tour, in which he said he would start again when finished and then we leave at the point we started! Great idea and very inviting. Within a few sentences I was intrigued and began learning some history! The story behind Nd within the museum is amazing! worth a visit! Do the waterfall, land mine museum and butterfly museum in one day :)

Emotional, great history & see local houses/people on drive out to it. I would put the landmine museum at the top of museums I have been to relating to war and especially given the relevancy in Cambodia's future. The museum has a strong message and provides incredible support to the local community which also makes it a place you feel good about donating to and purchasing gifts from. We were there on Saturday and apparently there is no tour guide but as long as you can read English, my husband and I actually enjoyed walking through and reading on our own. It was shocking to know how many casualties and injuries have happened since the war, especially in children, and scary to know how many armed mines and bombs are still out there, especially in this region. Definitely a great museum for folks that like history and to better understand what this community is dealing with and has dealt with in the past.

Very moving. It took us an hour to get there travelling by tuk tuk, but well worth it, this is an amazing very moving museum, there is a craft shop where disabled people have made some beautiful clothes & gifts.
There is a very small fee.

Landmine museum. A very thought provoking but also inspiring lace to visit . Visit the museum and you will not only learn about the horrific recent history of this beautiful country, but will also be contributing in your own small way to the local community which manages the museum and helps land mine victims.
Good for knowledge. It´s good for knowledge and you learn a lot about the mines and the Khmer Rouge. It is quite small and quite far to get to.

Interesting and thought provoking!. This is a very small and simple museum created by a former child soldier who as an adult has dedicated his life to removing land mines. Although small it helps you understand the impact land mines have made in the lives of so many over the last few decades. The tragedy is that there are still millions of land mines in Cambodia that continue to kill and maim Cambodian people. The entrance fee helps support the orphanage and mine clearing. I realise that some may find this a little hard hitting but I am very glad that I went and would recommend that you visit.

Sad but interesting. Landmines are an evil device but it is interesting to see. Got talking to one of the american born guides. He said there had been 1,200 people injured in the last 9 months which is sad but better than previous years.

Basic, but definitely worth a visit. This place reminded me a lot of the UXO museum in Luang Prabang if you've been there. The museum is quite basic, there's four rooms dedicated to different aspects of land mines (clearing, use in war, NGOs etc) but the story is amazing. Akira, the owner and caretaker, is doing amazing things. He has a house and school behind the museum for disable and underprivileged kids.It's a bit far out but it was worth it to support the cause. (Note: they just increased the entry fee to $5 but all the money goes to supporting the mine clearing NGO and the school Akira has set up.. And it's cheap compared to the other museums in town)

Thought provoking. If you are in the area visiting temples I would really recommend that you spend some time visiting this museum. It costs only 3$ to get in with the money going towards good causes of landmine clearance and services for people affected by these evil objects. This is only a small museum but the message it puts across is a powerful one and you cannot help be moved by the plight of the people who have suffered and angered by the regimes who planted landmines and those who continue to do so across the world. I particularly liked the end of this museum and the testimonies of people, from conflicts across the world, who had hidden, smuggled out and saved victims of persecution. After witnessing the evil that humans can inflict upon one another throughout the museum, this end display brought back the hope and good that helps nations heal. Make the time, spend the 3$ and visit this museum.

A must visit for everyone. A must for everyone. The objective of this museum is very deep and the owner and his friends dedicated their life for the safety of the Cambodians. I have great chance to meet the co-owner and the person that managing the museum. He shared most of the info about this museum. Very amazing experience.

Some insight into the local history. Some insight into the country's history, which has undoubtedly left its mark on the local psych. The museum is quite basic but contains just enough to be informative

Must see! How coould the world stand by and let this happen?. Heart breaking to view, but a must see. The world needs a reminder of man's inhumanity to man, which is now continuing through the evil happening in Iraq and Syria.

Excellent. I was lucky enough to get there a few minutes before a tour started with the American man who has been volunteering in this for 11 years. It was so interesting that it made my day ! I recommend anyone who goes to Angkor to stop by and visit this place. It is a must do and a must Know !Thanks for the great interesting visit !
Sad place but worth the trip!. It is sad, I was almost in tears walking around there but it's also inspiring! Happy to support anyone who is doing such amazing work!

How can our fellow men conceive of these hideous weapons!. This is a basic museum with limited resources and facilities but what a chilling picture it paints. We left shaking our heads at mankind's desire to manufacture and deploy such weapons in the past and the fact that they are still being made and deployed! Go there and be ashamed that Australia dragged its feet in signing the treaty for having these weapons banned.

Interesting Tour. I wanted to tour this museum. Various armaments have been assembled for you to see. This tour gave me a feel of weapons that were used during the war and the damage that was done to the local community. The items are neatly displayed. There is a video that you can view that provides a snapshot of how the museum was started. The area is small but I enjoyed the tour.

Nice to see. Our trip to the landmine museum was a quick one, but we had the privilege of meeting one of the guys who was involved in the war and has lost a leg. He took us around for a tour. The museum is very well preserved.
Nice little museum. Nice little museum near to Angkor. The guide was excellent and went through and explained everything.

A nice pit stop along the way.. The museum is neither a big nor fancy establishment, but this place is very informative and tells us about an important and dark past for Cambodians. The write-ups of the place, found in clear plastic folders available for tourists, make it easy for you to pick it up and walk around the different rooms by yourself. The museum is very concise and compact, so it was a nice pit-stop for us along the way to Tonle Sap Lake. We spent close to 30mins in there, tops, and it is a humbling experience, reading and learning about what Akira and his team has done for their fellow Cambodians.
Thought provoking. Great to see someone trying to make good from something so terrible. Interesting to learn the history of land mines in Cambodia. Well worth supporting.

Educational, but not camera friendly. This place was very educational, and it really pulled on my heart strings. Unfortunately, the rooms are dimly lit, there is no tour guide available, and almost everything is behind glass, so a flash camera is all but useless. Don't get me wrong, I support the cause of the place, I learned a lot, I definitely recommend going there, but just be prepared for a small facility with dim lights.Also, the food outside the place, ran by victims of mines and UXO, has amazing food.

It will blow you away. Land mines are the scourge of so many countries around the world. A deadly legacy that continues to kill long after the conflict is over. Kampuchea was ravage by hostile conflict for over 30 years and the country is littered with land mines and UXO of every type and description. When you come to visit don't forget to bring donations of goods that are listed on the organisations Wish List, because they build,schools and run orphanages for children and land mine victims.

Awe inspiring. So incredible what Aki-Ra has achieved in his lifetime, and what hope he has given to so many families and children in Cambodia. Really a worth while cause as well as a very insightful and interesting museum. Lots of bombs, land mines and other artillery (all free from explosives) to view. Easy to read displays that help paint a picture of what living during the time of Khmer Rouge must have been like and the aftermath. Well worth a visit. If you're going maybe take a few gifts like toothbrushes/hand sanitiser etc as behind the museum is the "orphanage" for the children and these things were on their wishlist (I didn't know and so will make an online donation once we're back from our travels).

Sobering but hopeful!. The people who run the museum are working very hard to help the victims of land mines and the video tells a sobering story of the Khmer Rouge and the amount of mines still in the ground in Cambodia.

Fascinating museum. This is a really interesting museum which is run by a individual. it gives a history of landmines in the region as well as showing a collection of them. Add this on to your temple trip "Srei"

Very small and simple but taught me a few things about Cambodian history.. The museum is situated about 45min outside Siem Reap by tuttut. It was the rainy season and I enjoyed the ride in cool weather.There are folders in the first room that serve as self-serve guides to the museum. I also appreciated certain facts better from Bill, a volunteer at the museum.Don't expect too much from a $3 (soon to be $5 from 1st Sept 2014) entrance fee. Thumbs up to the NGO who is helping disarm the mines and educating the public.

Go! Something different from all the temples & so intresting.. We went there last week and were really impressed. We wanted a day out doing something different than just the temples and saw this in the lonely planet. It’s about 24km away from Siem reap but the ride out there is stunning countryside. When we got there was an American man giving a tour around the museum and explaining all about the history of War and landmines in Cambodia. The guide was excellent and very knowledgeable about all Cambodian subjects. We asked him several questions after the tour had finished and he was more than happy to answer all of my questions. He does lots of good work for the organisation. I learnt a lot that day and this is for a very worthwhile cause. They are putting the price up next month but it is all going back to the charity and to try and make Cambodia a safer place. Thanks again, it was a great trip.

Interesting insight. This is a bit of a way out of town but worth the journey. Its founder has a fascinating history through some of Cambodia's worst times. There is a lot of information and an informative video. The centre looks after children wounded by land mines and has a wish list of things they need (these include mostly stationery and school items - pencils, chalk, etc) so if you can, bring some to donate. Combine this visit with the butterfly park just down the road, Aldo fascinating.

Very interesting, well worth a trip. For most people visiting Siem Reap, they are aiming mainly to visit the temples of Angkor. However, on our last day there we decided to make the journey out to visit this museum. It took about 30 minutes by car and was well worth it.The museum is small but has a lot of detail about the founder and landmines in general. The work they do for landmine victims is amazing and we bought as many things in the small shop as we could to fund their efforts. Fascinating and really worth a visit.

The best initial place to get the modern history of Cambodia. It's not flash, but it is of immense social and political value. We bought the book and learned lots. We took a taxi but a Tuktuk would have been fine.

Very glad I went. The trip here is beautiful and scenic. The museum itself, was small but interesting and informative. It is hard to not be moved reading the museum directors personal story and the story of the children still impacted by landmines. A huge reminder that there are still dangers to people today.
Landmine Museum. An excellent learning experience. Amazing to see all the landmines and read the stories and see the photos of everything that has happened.

Sobering and fascinating. Well worth a visit for those who have an interest in Cambodian history and the great work that these people do in trying to rid Cambodia of landmines. Poignant and worthwhile.
Interesting. A very interesting insight into the land mine problem - we really enjoyed the countryside on the way there too

Great history lesson. You must listen to the man telling his own story and horrific experiences during Pol Pot's regime. Just take it all in and guaranteed, the next time you whinge about dropping your iphone you will remember this man and his words. Brilliant stuff!

well worth a stopover. Small, easily done in about 30 -40 mins
Came with8 and 9 year old - they were taken aback but no blood and gore so just highlighting how these things are important
Worth visiting at least once. a lot of landmines, a nice guide (Bill) and good example for informing us of the actual landmine tragedy

Worth a stop on the way to temples. Its a little out of town but on the way to the womans temple. It has collections of land mines and many sad statistics on their use and how they are still maiming and killing many,

Amazing. This small museum tucked away in the Angkor Wat site was so so interesting. It is small but so informative. Bill who is one of the team members involved in diffusing landmines gave us a talk and answered questions that we had. It was a massive eye-opener and I was glad that we had decided to do it (despite our driver telling us that they would try and sell us things - this didn't happen we just think he didn't want to do it.) and at a cost of $3 each (although this will be increasing to $5) it was definitely worth it.
Well worth a visit. Very educational, gives a good background on the challenges still faced in Cambodia in their ongoing landmine clearance.

Small but informative.
