It's a small museum quite a way out of Seim Reap (about a 45 minute Tuk Tuk ride at least) but worth a visit to see the reality and learn the history of the war.The museum also supports an orphanage at the back of it for children who are directly or indirectly land mind victims, although, rightly so it's a no go area for tourists.
Sobering and educational. I thought the landmine problem was in the past after a visit here you find that it is not, not really pleasant but so important!!
Informative, attractive and positive. Well laid out and explained, it also highlights their aims and goals for the future. I found it a very moving and emotional experience.

Sobering, educational & essential. A highlight of our trip to Siem Reap was the trip to the Landmine Museum. As a keen student of history/politics, I was disturbed by how little I knew of the savagery of the Khmer Rouge social experiment, and even less of the years of "civil war" that followed. You don't hear about it day to day here, at all, to the huge credit of the Camdodians - and there is no family it would not have touched. The museum serves the history and the human cost in a very tangible way. The trip there and back (the museum is 45 mins outta town) is worth it (especially on a tuk tuk) for its sheer beauty & insight into Cambodian village life. Do not hesitate - DO IT!! You owe it to yourself and your Cambodian hosts.

Evocative, Worthwhile. This Museum lies a few kilometres outside the city, on the way to Banteay Srey. If you are not i na hurry, you cazn easily spend half an hour or so here o nthe way back. On July 2014, ticket price was 3 USD, they were going to raise it to 5USD. The place was setup by an ex soldier and current deminer. They carry out demining all over the country. The museum contains hundreds of mines, rockets, shells etc along with lots of information about the evils of landmines. They also run a shelter for victims of landmines. The entry fee goes towards running this place. There is also a small shop where you can buy handicrafts made from metals from the mines and rockets. These are made by the victims who live in the shelter, so buying some will help them.

Sad but extremely informative. We stopped here one afternoon while touring the temples and really enjoyed speaking with Bill. We learned so much about the history of conflicts in Cambodia and the terrible, terrible effects of the landmines that still litter the country. This place is worth a stop, for sure. The museum itself is not in great shape, but the folks who work here are really friendly and informative. Worth seeing!

Sobering but so worth visiting. A small set up a little out of the way reasonably priced entree fees. The displays are interesting though a little depressing when it hits home that it is all so very very very real. I felt humbled and privileged to have lived a life relatively free of the impact of war. Good work by Aki ri

Eye opening. While the 'negative review points' are not wrong, we thoroughly enjoyed the Landmine Museum as well as the story of the creator. Our one hour tuk tuk drive was a substantial part of our enjoyment as we got to see amazing Cambodian rural life.It is indeed a great place to visit if you are 'templed out' after Angkor Wat & Co. The place is small and 'amateurish' but this just adds to the charm and authenticity of this place. We easily spent over an hour here as there is so much to read and learn about.While I would be very much interested and keen to see how the orphan children live in the house behind the museum I find it very good that visitors are not given access so that the children are not showcased for tourist purposes!!!If you go and want to contribute, bring some crayons, coloring books or toiletries as they have a little board behind the entrance counter listing all kind of basic items they are in need of!

Must see place. First arriving Siem Reap I had a brief knowledge of the horrible past. Once visiting the museum you are exposed to the harsh reality and seriousness of the mine problem in Cambodia and in the surrounding countries.The site isn't the biggest however the guide Bill and rest of the staff were excellent at answering a range of tough problem and guiding the tour. Information is detailed and confronting, especially one display where the faces of the real victims of the mines are shown.If you don't know the history of Cambodia its worth visiting, prices are set to rise to $5/pp however this is tiny in the grand scheme and the money does go to a very good cause.
interesting. Glad we went , gives an insight to the terrible war time suffering , a great display , a must see , a huge display of different types of landmines used ..

Interesting, but.... Interesting topic of great importance to Cambodia. The information was valuable.But the museum is very shabby, hot, lots of mosquitoes, disorganized, and serves as a bit of (albeit humanitarian) propaganda for the museum's founder and the students he teaches.

Excellent with the free english speaking (American) guide. I thought this museum was fantastic. Bill, an American guide who has moved to Cambodia with his wife because of the museum's cause made the visit worthwhile. Bill explained the context of the war, the areas affected, the consequences of land mine proliferation and the international efforts to address land mines. He answered all our questions and his clear passion for the topic was very engaging. The museum was well laid out to tell the story with a guide but it's not obvious how it flows if you're looking at it by yourself. If it wasn't for Bill I would have just been looking at remnants of war and not added much to my knowledge. I'm not sure if it's possible, but it may be worth while ringing ahead to check if a guide will be present, all the negative reviews that I've read generally refer to people wandering around the museum with out a guide and therefore not getting much out of it.

Interesting but sad. Stopped off here as a way to prevent temple fatigue today as recommended by our guide. Its a really fascinating look into the terrible problem of land mines and unexploded ordiances. Lots of reading and some of the exhibits are dated, however interesting all the same and only £3 entry.

educational. I took my ten year old to show him mans inhumanity to man. Interesting but you really need someone to explain it and give the background.
Bill from the museum gave us a talk and the background. He made our visit.
It isn't just a museum but a charitable organisation who clear landmines and help local orphans.

A chilling reminder. I love a small museum, as I feel it can make more of an impact that something that needs hours to explore. This is small, but wow, does it tell a story that needs to be told. If you need a reminder of how Cambodia was treated by all the world powers over the past decade and how it still managed to survive, then visit this quiet, sombre but amazing place.

Interesting visit. This was a nice ride to this museum which shows landmines that have been deactivated and unearthed. Small museum but the individual who started it has his story posted and it is very interesting to read. This guy is inspirational in what he has done in creating a school for those who were victims of landmines. Met the couple who came from Florida and decided to move there to help in this wonderful organization. Even though it's a small museum, the story behind it and speaking to the people running it was one of the highlights of my trip. I really loved listening to a life transformed and what good has come out of such tragedy.

Worth a visit.. This is a super small museum which I knew I wanted to visit on the way back from the Bantay Srei temple. We only spent about half an hour here but it gives you an insight into the effect that landmines have had on many of its victims. The museum costs $3 to enter and they support its victims. The museum has a housing/school at the back and most of the money raised goes towards them which is very encouraging to see. If you do decide to visit the museum bring along some donations like toothbrushes, thongs, balls, pencils and writing books. I brought toothbrushes/toothpaste and colouring pencils and they seemed quite happy.

Worth a visit. This is well worth a visit if you are nearby or en-route to Banteay srei for example. Its very small & doesn't take too much time to look around but the story is important and very pertinent to Cambodia. Cost of entry is a mere $3 but you will surely want to give more in respect of the work that they do

Worth a visit. This small museum is about 45mins-1hour Tuktuk outside Siem Reap, with just a few rooms. Visually interesting and gives a first insight into the mine situation in Cambodia. It does tell the story of one man who has spent his life de-mining the country, and his journey along the way. We combined this museum with Bantreay Srei temple which is close by and it made a good half day's trip out of town . The drive through the countryside was enjoyable in July when there isn't too much traffic on the roads.
Worth a visit. Definitely worth a visit. Had a chat to one of the American guides who gave us a very informative 15 min tour, which greatly enhanced our overall experience

Great story. It's a great story and it's a nice site for what it is. However the hour long ride on a tuk tuk and the museum no larger than a living is a let down. Again the story of the man is great but can be read about online or other sources. Check out the war museum. Much closer and has informative guides also the national museum is worth the price of admission.

A little disappointing. Whilst the founder has lead an amazing life and done some inspiring things, I couldn't help but feel that this was more a shrine to him personally than to the tragedy of the landmine situation in Cambodia.

Worth an hour of your time. A small low tech exhibit that certainly brings the horror of the Cambodian civil war experience and it's fall out to the surface. The personal stories are especially telling. And the money raised goes to a good cause. The exhibit deserves further expansion.

A Must Visit in Cambodia. Incredibly informative to visit. A must see when in Cambodia to understand the history and issues faced by the Cambodian people. The museum staff were friendly and spoke to us in depth about the history of Cambodia and the troubles landmines have brought to Cambodia. Definitely a worthy cause to donate to as well.

A must. This is a must for all. Landmines and the grusomme casualties they case have shaped this country, impacted farming and thus Peoples livelihoods, it is necessary to understand if visiting the country.

Worth the trip. The journey was 2hr altogether on a tuktuk we paid 18dollar return.after you get past the temple traffic the journey there is great going past all the local communities.Just to help that little bit worth the effort to get here. we spent under 1 hour here.One thing i learnt was they even though the Americans support the museum, and the work that it does its still happy to continue to make and use mines in warfare. what a sad nation!

Enriching Experience. Apart from the Angkor Complex, Siem Reap's history would forever be entrenched with the Vietnam War. The landmines littered across their farm lands is a lasting reminder of the consequences of combat, like a ghost that haunts their lands. Ask the accommodating staff to give you a walking tour of the facility, so that you can get a feel of Aki Ra's and their organization's vision of a safe Cambodia is. Besides increasing your knowledge, the admission fee goes directly to the orphanage of children affected by the landmines. It's far from the town proper so plan your trip carefully so that your schedule won't be affected.
Landmines, war and history of Cambodia. As a history buff, I have studied the history of Cambodia, and the last 30 years of war. The CLM Museum opened my eyes to the reality and horror of war.

I was expecting more. I just want to start by saying the Landmine Museum has a great story behind it and has a large orphanage, the money you pay entry fee ($3) goes to providing food, education, learning materials etc to the kids, along with any donations made. I was, however, expecting more information, I don't seem like I learnt a whole lot being there that I didn't already know. Its a small museum and you only need about 20-30 mins, even the tuk tuk ride ($8 there and back) from Siem reap took longer (1 hour). It was one attractions I was excited to visit hoping to learn more about the history of the Cambodian war but I just didn't feel I got that.

Eye opening. Went there November 2013, very educational and makes you realise what damage has happened to the people of Cambodia, in particular the children. Please take some pens, books, flip flops, sporting balls with you and donate them to the school they support

interesting place. A worthwhile and fascinating place to visit. It is small but it teaches about this killer that still haunts Cambodia. The stories about the people and the children really make you think about how dangerous and how different landmines are in reality versus how they are shown in movies

Compelling place to visit. A bit of a drive out of the main city. Small museum. There was no guide when I went so it required a bit more effort to navigate through (if you want to spend the time reading everything) but you can go through at your own pace. Very touching/inspiring story. Definitely worth the visit if you have an extra couple of hours and/or are interested in learning more about the impact of landmines on the Cambodian people.

Very informative. The museum, while small, was very impactful. Makes a great stop on the way back from Bantrei Srei.
Worth the time.

Mind Blowing. We visited the museum on our way back from Banteay Srei. This museum captures the war-torn history of Cambodia. So many people lost their limbs from land mines left behind decades ago. Eye-opening and a must to visit.
Read all the information. This was smaller than I had expected but there was so much to read and really explained the struggles of life in Cambodia that is still going on today

Makes you wonder. My wife made me go here and I am glad she did. The atrocities against the Cambodian people is truly horrific. Everyone we met was so friendly, genuine and nice. It's hard to believe most have been touched by such sadness.

Modern History. The story of modern Cambodia is told well through the museum and it is interesting to understand what has and is still being done to make the country safe. I was surprised and saddened by how much damage had actually been done to the people of Cambrian through the was and hom many bombs the USA dropped on the country. It is good to get a real insight into the work done by just 1 man and his team.Worth visiting to support the project and to learn more of the modern history of the country.

Small but worth a short trip. It was small and asks for a $3 entrance fee. There is not much too see inside, but it has enough information on the history of Cambodia to leave a chilling feeling in your bones. Also, the entrance fee goes to supporting young victims of landmines. It's a simple, seemingly inconsequential (to us tourist) way of helping out these children. By the way, if you are planning to visit, the kids have this "wishlist" posted in the entrance, mostly school and hygiene supplies, which you can bring if you could. We spent about 20-30 minutes here.

A spiritual experience. This man, a CNN hero, has had an incredible life, turned a horrible experience as a child soldier into a mission to save the people of Cambodia from the after effects of war, specifically the process of removing land mines. The museum is not ornate, but if you take the time to read all the information, it is one of the most impacting sites I visited in Cambodia

To understand a place, understand its past & its hope for the future. I have to admit, I lasted 2 minutes and had to go outside. The rest of my group took in all the information and they chose to make donations on leaving.Its wonderful that this information is there, its important to understand what happened and what is still happening. Its wonderful that there are people who are helping to clear landmines and help those effected.Visit the temples and the land mine museum while in SR and share Cambodias story and the great work being done here when you get home.

A reality we must acknowledge.. An amazing nonprofit focused on not just safely removing landmines, but helping children whose lives have been changed forever! A must see to know that good triumphs over bad.
So worth a visit. Learn about Cambodia's Khmer Rouge history from a man who planted the mines as a child and is now dedicating his life to removing them safely and looking out for landmind victims.

Must visit!. The Landmine Museum is a great place to stop on the way back or to Banteay Srei. It's a small museum that details the effects that landmines still have on Cambodian people today. It was set up by Aki Ra who began by clearing landmines by himself with a stick and some pliers. We were lucky enough to meet Bill Morse who does great work with Aki Ra in raising funds for landmine clearing. They also provide a home for children affected by landmines and are otherwise disadvantaged. They have a wishlist of items needed for the kids; shampoo, flip flops (all sizes), Khmer Folktales books, hand sanitizer, writing notebooks, pens, pencils, chalk and whiteboard markers. All are available at the bookshops in town. Please throw a few little things into your bag to donate here. Must visit.

Worth a Quick Trip. There isn't much to see, but it's a great stop to learn more about the history of the country. You can learn about the land mine problems that had plagued the country following years of conflict, as well as the good being done by groups to make the country safe from land mines. It may not be the most scenic or robust of museums, but it's a sobering place to visit.

Worth it. Yes, maybe is not the best museum, but is a completly worth it. Not only because is very interesting with an amazing human story behind the founder, but also because this quick stop you will learn and you will help a lot of kids afected by landmines. The entrance fee is to help them.No doubt, while u are visiting the area, go.

Amazing Story by the Founder. This museum tells a piece of history of Cambodia: a darker history of Cambodia. The founder is Aki Ra, a former child soldier, was taught to lay some of these landmines when he was a child. Seeking redemption he started to disable some of these landmines at times using only a stick and a knife to disable them. A must see. You will see his CNN hero award that he greatly deserve when you walk inside the museum.

Interesting. First thing, there are files on the left side of the entrance that guides out through the museum. Take on of those and you can read them as you go into the different rooms. This museum is really all about landmines. Stories of landmine victims, how the landmines work, how they remove a landmine and much more. Very detailed and at the end of your tour, go to the souvenir shop and look for an area where there's seats and a tv. You can ask the helper over there to show you a clip on what the owner of the place does and all.

Very Informative and Interesting. We stopped here on the way back from Banteay Srei and really enjoyed the hour we spent. The museum is really a great cause and gives a lot of information about the more recent history (last 50 years) of the area. This was a contrast to the ruins we were seeing and learning about during most of our time in Siem Reap. I would highly suggest this as a stop for anyone visiting the area. It is obviously a very somber tour but will truly help you understand some of the struggles of the people in this area and also offers a really inspiring story of the museum founder. I felt this was a must-do for all visitors.

If you come to Cambodia this is a big part of their history and should not be ignored. Outside of the temples, which is why everyone comes to Cambodia, is the story of a country that has been through a holocaust of their own and deals with the horrific effects of landmines.Aki Ra is the founder of this small museum that only takes 30 minutes to walk through. He was a Cambodian child soldier and personally placed 1000's of mines in this country. When he grew up he made it his mission to remove as many landmines as he could. This museum tells the story of how the mines got there and the horrific effects they have had. Cambodia has one of the highest amputation rates in the world. Aki Ra was nominated for hero of the year in 2010 by CNN's Anderson Cooper. Behind the museum is a home for poor, orphaned, and handicapped Cambodian children.

Informative, disturbing museum with a very noble cause. Lots of information about the use of landmines worldwide (and in Cambodia in particular) with its horrifying consequences. A large amount of the entrance fee is for the victims of landmines, especially children (some of whom reside and study in a private, closed off part of the museum building). It's too small a museum to make a detour but you'll probably pass it by if you take the large temple tour at Angkor Wat (that's how I found it). Because of its very noble cause you should definitely add this museum to your tour.

Horrors of land mines. It was an inspiring story. A young Khmer cleared landmines with a stick and soon has a house full of defused ordnance. He began charging a penny to visitors using the money to further his cause. If you're going to Kbal Spean, make sure to drop by this museum along the way.

Absolutely necessary to see while in Siem Reap. This museum was founded by a man named Aki Ra who was a child soldier during the Khmer Rouge. It is impossible to go to Cambodia and not see this museum and learn about Cambodia's modern history (from 1970s to 1990s) and the atrocities that took place during the Vietnam War, Khmer Rouge, and years afterward. The museum consists of large posters explaining the history of planting land mines in Cambodia and how there are still millions left that need to be cleared. A fascinating experience and great way to understand Cambodia.

TAKE TIME TO READ THE STORIES. When you first walk into this " attraction" you think it is a bit run down and a bit of a distance from town. But when you start reading the stories it becomes a very sobering exercise. How you could put yourself into that position to survive is a remarkable story in itself. For me I could see the men in the street with no legs and wonder how they even survived the blast. I believe that over 20 were killed just this month alone so there are many devices yet to be discovered and disarmed. It is not one of the best places to visit but excellent if you want a better understanding of the life they had to endure

Small and simple, yet educational. The landmine museum is located in a mango grove. There you could see all the tanks, missiles, landmines and guns that were used during the civil war. The tour guide was a member of the army and his stories made me think of how difficult it was then for the Cambodian people. The place is not very well kept as most of the artifices were placed outside. But it was a good short educational tour.

inspiring private citizen's initiative. This museum is a private citizen's initiative to call attention to the problem of landmines. This is a very good museum to visit at the same time as Bantay Srei because they are located near each other.

Decent Exhibit. It's a small and dirty but ultimately moving memorial to the horrors of war. The stories of landmine victims are quite harrowing but the bulk of the material here is haphazardly presented and interspersed between some almost cult like veneration of Aki Ra, the man who founded the museum. Good if you're paasing by.

Very interesting. This museum is very interesting. A former children soldier who had to lay thousand of landmines founded it. After the regime of Khmer Rouge he become a specialist in defusing land mines. The entrance fee (3USD) is fully donated to the enclosed kids refugee home.A most see

A living proof of Cambodian Genocide. There are not enough words to express while walking thru this museum.Only a stone heart like Pol Pot would walk thru with a smile.This museum is 25km frim Siem Reap near the banteay srei.All money goes to minw awarness campaigns.If in Siem Reap, this is MUST. Its an eye opener Aki Ra.

Must see. This was my favorite part of the trip. All ticket proceeds go to the children they house. It was amazing to see all the land-mines that have been recovered and how many are still out there. They have success stories with the children they have housed. It was an incredible experience

Horrors of war and strife words cannot describe. The Landmine Museum was a stop en route to Bantaey Srei.Although the museum isnt very large, it hosts a range of explosives from many different countries, and have a range of well explained exhibits and rooms.Not having experienced this war and conflict first hand, it is hard to relate to this except through the ubiquitous "Danger! Landmine" tees sold across the night markets. But after the visit to the Landmine Museum, you really feel and experience the horrors of war through pictures, audio, and video carefully constructed by the curator.It was a deeply emotional and reflective experience at the museum.

Moving, most vivid memory of the trip. We stopped at the Landmine museum after going to Banteay Srei at the start of the day, and it was one of the most humbling experiences of my life. The stories of war, post-war tragedies, and Aki Ra's mission were very moving.At the entrance to the museum, there is a whiteboard with a "wish list" of items to donate. Unfortunately, I only learned of this once I got there, so I was only able to donate a few tubes of hand sanitizer. The items on the wish list (from memory, so I've definitely missed a few) were:Pencils, shampoo, soap, hand sanitizer, notebooks, flip-flops, pens, dry-erase markers, and others I can't quite remember.If you have the chance to stop by a supermarket before heading out to the museum, I strongly encourage it.

CLM. its small and maybe not worth the long trip from Siem Reap but Mr. Aki Ra's work definitely has to be honored and his orphanage helped. you learn a lot about the landmines and Cambodia's sad history. so maybe go there if on the way to Bantey Srei. And help!

BEST. MUSEUM. EVER. So moving I was going to cry. Never have I been to such a moving and humbling museum as this. When my boyfriend and I walked in, we were greeted by Bill Morse - a Californian, ex-US Army officer who moved him and his wife to Cambodia to offer full support to Aki Ra's landmine removing NGO. Bill Morse walked us through the museum in one hour and gave us such a thorough explanation of every room - how many landmines are still in Cambodia (~5 million), how they were placed (by child soldiers - up to 300 a day or by bombing nations), the current state of landmines around the world (Afghanistan, Pakistan, Myanmar, Colombia, Yemen, & Cambodia), and how one man (Aki Ra - ex-child soldier and landmine layer and now deminer who won CNN hero of the year top 10) personally removed around 100,000+ landmines - most of which just using a stick and pliers. The museum displayed all types of landmines and bombs found in Cambodia and also displayed a beautiful photo exhibit of heroes who rescued people in their respective circumstances (holocaust, Rwanda, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Cambodia, etc.). Very moving - gave perspective on how one person can make such a difference. Landmines are still a very big issue today and the people getting hurt and just normal people - farmers, children, etc. Please visit and support this museum!

So sad on many levels. All visitors should see this.. Small and simple. Take the time to stop on your way back from Banteay Srei and read all the stories here and be inspired by the work of Aki Ra and his wife. Entry fees support the attached school.We were greatly saddened by this monument to the horrific long term effects of bombing and mines in Cambodia... but equally sad that there were so few visitors and felt that it was possibly bypassed by most tourists on the temple trail.

No Value Add. When we came here, there was no guide around, so we picked up a self-guide. The self guide was overly wordy and did not serve it's purpose well. There was nothing much to see. Mostly pictures.The guide guided a group of westerners who came before us, and another group of westerners who came after us. Not even a word was said to us. We felt largely ignored.Without much display or a proper guide, we could not connect to the story that the museum is trying to tell. Give this place a skip and run Google/Wiki searches on landmines, Cambodia, and Aki Ra instead.

Humbling. A must visit! The dedication of one man's tragic life impacts many. The sheer volume of landmines on display is incomprehensible. The devastating effects of these mines are horrific. The first-hand stories are gut-wrenching.

Really puts things into perspective. Knowing a little about Cambodia's history, this museum really put things into perspective. You can read about landmines, the statistics and all the news articles, but it really brings it home when you walk around the exhibits. It's not a large museum and you get see this fairly quickly, but it's worth the time seeing it. I also strongly recommend taking the time to watch Aki Ra's story in the first room. Truly an inspiration story!

Very interesting, well worth a visit. We stopped in here on the way back from Banteay Srei temple. While I probably wouldn't have gone all the way out here if it wasn't on the way to/ from the temple, it was very interesting and I thought it was well worth a visit. This museum offers a great insight into some of the recent history of Cambodia, and the ongoing challenges that the country still faces with landmines. The stories and information throughout the museum offer an interesting insight, and the museum's founder has a fascinating story. Hard hitting, and very moving experience for me, and I'd recommend a visit for a historical perspective on Cambodia, and in support of a good cause.

Great if you're in the area. It's a bit far away from Siem Reap, but VERY worth it if you're in the area. We saw Banteay Srei in the early morning to beat the heat and the crowds, and stopped at the Landmine Museum on the way back to Siem Reap.There was SO much incredibly heartbreaking and interesting information. I'm so glad we did it, I learned a lot, and the money goes to a great cause.
heartbreaking but must see. Heartbreaking to see this collection of photos around the landmine projects but a must see if you are interested in Cambodian History.

Interesting stop-over when in Banteray Srei. Informative, yet a little dusted. If visiting B.Srei, just make a short 30 minutes stop here. Impressive story and dedication to help clean up a scary past of this country. Its a collection of fotos and explanations.

OK. We visited the landmine museum as it is listed in a number of guidebooks. It has some interesting information, although tends to focus a lot on the founder. We did not learn as much about landmines in general as we had hoped. It was a pleasant visit worth adding on to a trip in that direction (e.g. to Bantaey Srei), but I wouldn't travel all that way from Siem Reap only to visit the museum.

Fascinating. We took a wonderful tuk tuk ride through the beautiful countryside with our 3 young children. We were totally inspired and learnt so much. God bless Aki Ra for all his amazing work. Well worth a visit.

Inspiring story, worth the visit. The museum itself is very small but the message delivered is immense. The museum also serves as a foundation for landmine victims and has their incredible stories written in letters in one of the exhibits. The shop sells a variety of books that document the atrocities of Cambodian history.The museum does not take long to complete so we recommend combining the visit with Banteay Sree temple considering both attractions are close to each other, north of Siem Reap.

How the man can do that?. If you like to understand how the brain in a human being can plan and make such weapons to kill another human being, it is a worth visit. It is a good experience to learn all atrocities the people of Cambodia has suffered.
The guide who gave us a tour around was very nice and very informative. It was very interesting and also very sad. It made me realise just what that war was like. I hope it never happens again.

An absolute inspiration to humanity. This is a fascinating, harrowing and uplifting living museum. The owner is a great role model, has done great work with the museum and the children he has helped with the rest of his family. Well worth a visit in itself. It is also on the way to Bantay Srei.

Not dazzling, but pause for reflection. The museum is small, and limited in its display; BUT, the topic and impact are significant. It basically gave pause to consider that there is no possible justification to causing loss of life of 600,000 people, in a war that is neither declared nor in any respect accurately represented by political leaders of the time. What do we learn from our past experience?

Thought provoking. It's about half an hour out from centre of siem reap, we paid $45 for an Aircon car through the hotel. Museum is well laid out and lots of posters , info sheets about their aims, worthy cause
A place not to be missed!. A great place to learn more about the landmine issue and how it affect Cambodia, there is a information booklet guide while touring.

A great insight into Cambodian war history. We were lucky enough to bump into Bill just as we arrived, a very knowledgable and informative bloke who gave us all of the history of the warfare in Cambodia along with information on the landmines and the removal of them. Would definitely recommend, $3 entry all goes to a great cause. Allow an hour or so.

Definitely worth a visit if you have time.... A very educational museum that helps tourists/visitors understand the ongoing issue with landmines in Cambodia. I was lucky to catch the guided tour with an American Vietnam War veteran (I think his name was Bill Morse - he and his wife live in Cambodia and have helped run the museum). He was very passionate and informative about how locals have been affected by the landmine situation in the country.It's a 45-minute tuktuk ride from the city center. Quite a long ride but worth it if you're staying in Siem Reap for at least a week or two. It's also located about 15 to 20 minutes from Banteay Srei temple.

A place to learn. A well put together little museumn that is truely making a difference, it's founders story is just inspirational and I wish I could have met him. Bob was very knowlagable and honored the founder and the Cambodian people. He was an amazing guy and gave an excellent tour.

A must see. If you have an interest in what is going on in Cambodia, this is yet another important glimpse below the surface (and may I also recommend the book 'Cambodia's Curse'). On top of the many other problems faced by these wonderful, if unfortunate people, is the millions of landmines and unexploded ordinance strewn across the country (you will see the victims in the cities). The guy who started this museum should be considered a national hero.
Very informative. We visited this museum after going to Banteay Srey (about 15 minutes distance with the car).The ticket was $3.It was very informative and touching.
Moving experience.. Not to be missed. lost lives so un-necessary, bought back to me how lucky I am and never appreciated it.

Go for the guide. We had already visited the Killing Fields and the War Museum when we went to the Landmine Museum. Quite an interesting place. The American guide Bill fields questions about any and everything. Invaluable.

Humbeling place that gives one an idea of the war. I'm usually n ot one to spend lots of time at these kind of museums, but this was worth every minute. It's small outdoor museum, founded by Aka Rai and run by war survivors. Aka Rai was a child soldier and knows the insight of the terrible war in Cambodia before and during Pol Pot's reign, having 'finished off' about 5000 landmines and still doing more. A very brave person that has become not only a Cambodian hero. The museum shows lots of pictures and gives a really good overview. It's located on the way to or from Banteay Srey and really a must see. All money and donation go towards the after-war-cause. If you plan a visit, take along soap, hand sanitized, pens/pencil, not paper, etc. These are things that were listed on their wish list on the whiteboard!

Landmine Museum a Must-See. The Landmine Museum is a must-see for anyone who wants to understand what happened to the Cambodian people in the past and how it influences what is happening now. You can spend an hour or several hours depending on how much detail you want to read about the nature of the land mines. The museum focuses on the work of one of CNN's Heroes, Aki Ra, who has led the demining activity in Cambodia. The current lives of many Cambodians cannot be understood without knowing how the presence of land mines affects their daily lives. There is also an orphanage on site caring for children whose lives have been directly affected by land mines. The school and living environment cannot be visited as this is their home and is completely separate from the Museum. You can take a self-guided tour with the appropriate folder in your language. Please consult Landmine Museum for a list of items you can bring to benefit the children. I left knowing so much more about the current work being done in this country and elsewhere in the world affected by land mine devastation and the brave and heartfelt efforts of people involved in demining.

Very Informative. The Cambodia landmine museum follows Cambodia's history after Pol Pot and how it left 5,000,000 landmines left buried in Cambodia. The museum focuses on one man who deactivated 50,000 landmines by hand and set up an orphanage for landmine victims. Make sure to pick up a packet in your language before walking around, it's very easy to follow and has lots of good information. It isn't a big museum so you can see every room that they have.
Small but worth it. The museum is super small , but what is told in there is unbelievable about the man whom goes around dismantling landmine. and supporting orhpans

Privately owned Museum.. My driver and tour guide Rin Ra, who is self employed and has a facebook page "Cambodia in Comfort", took me here which is also a must see. There is a very wide display of military planes, guns, tanks and is a reminder of the past.
Very interesting. There is not much to the museum, but the story of the man who started it is just amazing, heart-breaking, heart-warming, and inspirational.

Interesting!!. For the museum lovers out there this is a must visit. We were pulled along with another couple on our tour and we were so glad that we went. It is very interesting and lots of fantastic artifacts to look at.

Inspiring and educational . Take a temple time-out and head over to the Landmine Museum and Children's Relief Centre to learn more about Cambodia's bloody and war torn past. The museum and centre are 30 mins from Siem Reap and in a couple of hours you will learn about the impact and ongoing work to clear landmines and other unexploded ordnance, not just in Cambodia but around the world. Ever think that Morocco was a heavily contaminated country? Me neither. We were shown around by Stephane who has been mapping minefields for over 10 years and knows a huge amount about this as well as a whole lot of other subjects. We also met Bill and his wife Jill who are a couple of genial Americans doing some amazing work at the museum and also the relief centre, looking after and educating children who have been impacted by landmines in some way. A touching and inspiring place.

Important part of Cambodia's history. The museum is located quite a ways outside of Siem Reap (further than the temples), but it's a nice truk tuk ride. Lots of beautiful scenery along the way and I feel like I got more of an idea of what Cambodian life is like by seeing people outside of Siem Reap/Pub Street/Angkor Temples. The museum itself is a series of rooms that tell of the history and utter destruction that land mines have, and continue to have, on the Cambodian people. It's not fancy but that's not the point.

Interesting place and nice drive to get there from Siem Reap. The museum is an informative place with examples of the destruction that land mines cause. This place helps to put a perspective on how this weapon is indiscriminate in its choice of victims.The school that is onsite and housing the children also could use donations if you are planning on going. The have a wish list, although I don't see it posted on their site. Most of it is common sense items for basic hygiene and learning materials, some games or sports balls etc. are recommended, along with cleaning detergents and flip flops or sandals for ages into the early 20s. We both went back out there with the wished for items. We bought most of our items at Lucky Mall. We had to go to a local market to get the balls and larger children's flip flops. Whatever you decide, just remember to bring the kids a gift or two since you're going all the way out there anyway to see the museum.

well worth a trip. Bit of a trek from Siem reap (20km) but well worth it, only a small place but with a lot of information and nice gift shop. One of those must see places just to learn about history. Don't go with high expectations its not all that well laid out and a bit higgledy piggedely but that's part of its charm.

Sobering but very worthwhile to see. The museum was founded by a Cambodian who planted landmines in the war as a child, and found/decommissioned 50,000 of them or more. as a result of his work, they have made an NGO which serves children who live there at the center and go to school. They also are instrumental in the continuation of removal of landmines and unexplored ordinance (bombs), of which there are 4-5 million left. It is a worthwhile visit, and you can contribute to their mission by purchasing souvenirs at the little shop. The founder was awarded "CNN Person of the year."

It's a simple museum but for a good cause. The museum is simple, but it is for a good cause. We can appreciate the effort by individuals to recover their country from war. On the other hand, the War Museum near the airport is a waste of time and money.

Must visit in siem reap. The Cambodian landline musem,was a excellent visitThe talk by bill morse was very interesting ,and told direct what landmines are doing to the people in Cambodia,I donated money for a very worthy charity.Please visit on your travels.

Important Context for any Cambodian Trip. The landmine museum was well worth the visit. It is not large and could be done in 20 minutes if you are in a serious hurry, or more like an hour depending on your energy level.We stopped by on our way back from Banteay Srei which is in the very northern part of the Angkor national park. Given the travel distance from Siem Reap and the rest of the temples, this is a nice pairing. And given how well preserved Banteay Srei is, it seems foolish to miss it.The Cambodian Landmine Museum is well done although it doesn't have any high tech installations. Mostly large photos and graphics with text explanations. Actually, I think there is a video in one of the rooms that we missed.The ravages of war continue to have a profound and lasting impact on Cambodia. The museum puts some of that history in context which was very helpful for us. It also shows the impact of millions landmines as well as unexploded bombs from the US. The NGO developed to deal with this issue is doing an admirable job. I give this place high marks and it can easily be integrated into visiting Angkor National Park.

Good intro to Cambodian recent history. We didn't have much expectation for the little museum 25km from town, but wound up receiving a lot of education for the minimal entrance fee. The museum is definitely worth a visit, as they go through some political history, as well as some very personal history through Aki Ra's story. We hired a tuk tuk and the whole trip including time to read almost every placard & the guide book at the museum was probably around 2.5 hours.
Worth a Visit!. It is a small museum but worth the support for the work that Aki Ra and many others have to do to de-mine Cambodia. Do sit down to watch the documentary played at the museum.

Interesting little museum, with a chance to support a great cause. The Landmind Museum is a ways away from the main tourist areas of Siem Reap, but definitely worth a visit if you're touring for the day. All the proceeds benefit a great cause that helps to care for victims of landmines and polio in the area. Plus, it provides some great info on the recent history of Cambodia from someone who was in the thick of it all. Best advice, visit Banteay Samre, and stop here on the way back. It's right along the road. Can't miss it.

Impactful and sad. Aki Ra is certainly a hero for establishing this center. It is not big or fancy, but an hour there can impress upon you the idea that 1 person can make a difference if they choose to. There is this side garden with banners between trees. It leads you on a walk of regular people who tried to save others. What a memorial! What a reminder to us all! Go there and spend your money. Best money spent for the whole vacation!

Memorable, eye-opening. I stopped by here on the way back from Banteay Sare. It's a tiny little museum that I thought would take less than half an hour to visit. However, there was an American worker there who acted as our tour guide as soon as we walked in, and he ended up talking to us for at least an hour and a half. He was so knowledgeable about the wars that were fought throughout SE Asia and the ongoing repercussions that are still felt today. This museum is so worth visiting, and I learned so much about Cambodia's modern history in a short amount of time.

Deeply saddening. I hadn't even arrived in the exhibition rooms and I had already been totally shaken up by a display board detailing the bio of the museum's founder. It's so incredibly shocking to learn and see what the Cambodian people had to endure and still have to struggle with on a daily basis. There is lots to be learned about mines and their existence and use today, in 2014. Even though it is a 50 minute Tuk Tuk ride from Siem Reap it is absolutely worth it and I recommend to anyone who is interested in Cambodia's history and 21st century reality.
Worth visiting!. This museum comes to life with a guided tour by the wonderful American (Bill?). It's interesting and compelling history. Do visit!

Important place to visit. This is a place of reflection. Landmines lined up in display remind you that there are over 100,000 live mines in Cambodia still. They can cost less that $10 and blow off a leg. the display also marks where the land mines were sourced from. Russia, China, France, America all feature. An important reminder that most of the weapons that are tearing apart third world countries are sourced from 1st world countries including major western powers. If those weapons were not sold. Tens of thousands would be alive today in Cambodia who are not, perhaps hundreds of thousands. This museum is a positive story of one mans quest to remove mines from his country and the funds support victims of mines a couple of whom find refuge and work in this musuem. Highly recommend a 40 minute visit.Peter

Small Museum with Large Emotional Impact. The title of the museum is misleading. This is not a museum about the history and development of landmines, it is actually dedicated to the efforts by Cambodians to safely remove all the land mines left in their country from many wars and conflicts that swept through over the years. Our American docent was very knowledgeable and provided a very clear explanation without any political propaganda, one way or another. As others have pointed out, the museum is well out of town (mostly because of local politics), but it is on the way to Banteay Srei temple, which is a popular and frequently visited site connected to Angkor Wat, and it is well worth the stop on the way there, or back. Viewing the museum does not take very long and it is important to learn about the impact of landmines and the efforts to eradicate them.

A place of sadness and hope. This is a place that every visitor should come to, a reminder that we are very lucky that we are not subjected to these risks in our daily lives. The work the volunteers do here is phenomenal and should be supported far more, so please do be prepared to donate to keep this good work going.Did you know that many of the land mine clearing teams consist of women that go out daily into fields and jungle and manually search for remaining ordnance?This is a Museum that brings back dignity to many that would continue to suffer greatly and deserves to be visited.

Well worth a visit. This museum is well worth a visit and your donation in the form of a $3 entry fee. It covers historical information related to how the present situation of landmines and unexploded ordinance came to be in situ in Cambodia - and gives present day updates on the work to clear landmines. Lend your support to this NGO by visiting.

Worth the stop.. Simple but hard hitting. Very realistic and quick to go through...20 minutes would serve, but you could take longer. Makes it hard to pass the music groups playing at the temples without stopping to listen and drop in a donation. Still an estimated 5 million land mines out there.

land mine museum. I liked the fact that it exists for public education. I also like the fact that they sponsor children's education but that tourists are not able to go and see the children but can leave donations.

Amazing history and great cause. Before i went to Cambodia, i heard a lot about how many active landmines the country has. But i never tought that i would be so close to this sad reality. This museum shows a lot of desarmed bombs and has a lot of information about the founder and owner of the museum and this issue that still cause a lot of deaths every year. Is in the road to the Banteay Srey, so you can go there when visiting the temple. Is trully amazing.

Informative, inspirational museum. We visited the Landmine Museum on the recommendation of friends. We were returning from Bantay Srei, and stopped. The admission is $3, and we learned a great deal about recent Cambodian history, the rise of the Khmer Rouge, the devastation caused by land mines, and amazing efforts to remove them from the country. It is definitely an important stop for anyone interested in learning more about this amazing place.

Informative and worth the stop off. We stopped off here on our way back from visiting Bantery Srei, as much out of curiosity as to break up the journey in the tuk tuk.We were glad that we did. The museum is informative and isn't blatently biased as I've found many of the museums in SEAsia to be. Aki Ra just tells it as it was and is. It's not expensive and you learn a lot. If nothing else it's a break from the temples and the money goes to a good cause.

Small Private Museum. The Entrance Fee is 3USD per pax. The museum has a collection of deactivated APM and ATM on display. These show the visitors what the landmines had done to the Cambodian people. a sad story.

Very informative.. One of those places you don't necessarily enjoy but you are glad you went. A great place to learn about the history of Cambodia and help by paying you $3 entrance fee. Good exhibits, and English folder to take around and displays in English , also in other languages.

Take some time. Important to understanding some of the history of Cambodia - this museum inspires one to commit further to paying close attention to the continued support of global governments for stopping all production of land mines.

Moving experience. If you want a full picture of Cambodia, visit this little museum and check out the history of land mines and I exploded ordnance in Cambodia. There are still 5,000,000 undetonated mines on the Thai - Cambidian border. It is easy to stop by the museum when you are visiting temples and you modest entrance fee helps them with their work.

Very small musuem with a message. The museum is pretty far out there with the route we took from the elephant wall. It is $3 to enter. It has thousands of weapons, mines, and rockets on display. It is neat to see the displays of weapons and read the details, but the museum is pretty small and doesn't offer as much information as I was thinking would be available. I walked out with just a little more knowledge then before I entered museum and ended up researching more online.

The russian chopper blew me away.. Its an outdoor museum, if you ask you might be able to have one of the amputee mine victims give you a guided tour. The highlight for me was the Russian chopper but they have an extensive collection of rifles, small arms, mines, grenades, large artillery, armoured vehicles, tanks and associated military vehicles. They also have a great little gift shop on sight.

Touching and shocking. I'ts very primitive, I would almost say naive, but the story that it tells is so autenthic and touching that it for sure vill leave You affected after a visit. Visitors are automatic using a very low voice while walking around. Absolutely at visit worth, if You a planning to visit Pnom Kuhlen and/or Bantey Shrei

Sad history but good to know. The museum is on the way to Bantey srey temple on the right hand side. As its name, there are a lot of different types of mine that they found in Cambodia and was deploy during Khmer rouge and after that.

Shocking but worrth a visit. We visited the museum due to the previous reviews. Took a tuk tuk out there - great way to get there as you can see the countryside as well. Born in that era i was really not aware at how much the country suffered with the bombings and the mines. A real eye opener. The good outcome is that the museum does fund a home for kids injured or left as orphans to due explosions that are still happening today.

Great exhibits and information. We stopped by the Landmine Museum after seeing Banteay Srei in the countryside. The entry was only $3 per person, a great price for such a wonderful little museum. The exhibits are all well-thought out and provide a great deal of information on everything from types of landlines to the history of the de-mining process. The museum is also home to survivors and family members of landmine accidents, and there's a great board with the pictures and stories of some of their kids in one of the rooms - I thought that this was a wonderful human face to the horrible history of mines in Cambodia. If you're on your way to and from Banteay Srei and Banteay Samre, I definitely recommend a stop at this museum.

Shocking but worthwhile. We went to this museum after visiting Banteay Srei. Spent sometime taking to an American who helps out in the museum and the foundation attached and he was very informative. Fact is the amount of ordnance dropped on Cambodia by the USA and the land mines laid by the Khmer Rouge and Vietnamese Army is just mind boggling. The landmines in particular are a reminder of how evil people are. Go and support this worthy museum.

Please visit. The museum was established to help the victims of Cambodia's past and ongoing massive problems with uncleared land mines, and whilst the exhibits are a touch on the macabre there is a great deal of information which is interesting, and a visit here (and similar sites in other parts of Cambodia) really should be compulsory for all visitors to the country. Visiting the temples and not coming here to learn and try to understand something about their history is hugely disrespectful to all Cambodians who have and continue to suffer from these indiscriminate weapons. Your entrance fees will help to continue the excellent work here, as will profits from anything you buy.
sad. a dreadful reminder of the suffering that still goes on , wel worth a visit , all types of mines on display and interesting information

Excellent guided tour. We arrived as a guided tour was about to start (around 9am) and it was excellent, a gentleman from the USA conducted the tour and his summary of the Vietnam (American) War, Khmer Rouge, landmines (past and present situation both in Cambodia and beyond), Aki Ra, the local founder's story (ex child solder) was excellent. I learnt so much in my one hour that I spent there. I thought the approach to the children who lived there was very ethical and it was interesting (and frustrating) to hear how little western governments care about the ongoing problem of land mines.

Worth a visit.. Take a morning away from temple spotting & visit the landmine museum,even if only for an hour or so,take a tuk tuk,its about 30 - 45 mins from Siem Reap itself.The museum is not particularly big,but take the time to listen to Bill,who gives a very good explanation of the history & the on going work of the museum.Obviously the history is is sad,but the work of the people who clear the mines will hopefully make the lives of the people in these areas safer.It is ironic that some of the countries involved in the making of these landmines,do not contribute to the resources needed to clear them,yet the countries that used / dropped them do.Cost is $3,which goes to help in future mine clearing.

Humble museum , significance history. Visited this museum on December 2013.Located south of the Banteay Srey Temple complex , 25 km north of Siem Reap ,inside the Angkor National Park .Accessible by Private car , tour buses ,Ranmork (Tuk tuk), bicycle and motorcycle.There's a small fee to enter the museum , $ 3 for foreigners, Cambodians are free to enter. Opened from 7.30 am until 5.30 pm. A humble museum , built by Aki Ra , a former soldier who used to clean landmines scattered all over Cambodia , with help from his wife ,sadly deceased by illness.The story and history about Cambodia, the Museum and the Khmer Rouge was told by Bill a US citizen, a volunteer ,whose already relocated to Cambodia.The Museum consists of 4 galleries , and a home for 27 children, most of them are victims of the landmines.In one of the gallery ,we can watch the method of Aki Ra , defusing some Land Mines.A sad story of war , evil practice of human kind in the name of war, and the aftermath of war now still continues for the Cambodians.Worth to be visited !

Self Guided. Having never seen a bomb or mine before, the visuals of them in the center housing of the pond was something. The rest of the museum is divided into rooms and can be done at your own pace. Was happy to have seen it once.

Thought provoking and emotive. The museum brings home the futility of war and the evil practice of land mining. The stories of war, indoctrination and suffering pull at your heart strings but this experience is overall positive as it is linked to the future of Cambodia as well as a record of the recent past.

Worth a morning trip. If you are in Siem Reap for more than the typical tourist 2-3 nights and Temple tours, this is OK for a morning excursion. Hire a Tuk Tuk driver for the morning and plan on stopping at some nice places, along the lake, for lunch on the way back (buy the driver lunch too) The Landmine Museum itself is a rather sad commentary on human nature from the carpet bombings by the USA to the subsequent rise of the Khmer Rouge it can be enlightening. To this day Cambodians are maimed or killed by undetonated explosives. You would think in todays high tech world it would be an easily solved problem.It has been awhile since I visited ( I was not active with Tripadvisor then) but I think there is a small fee for foreigners and Khmer get free entry. Do visit the gift shop where monies go to support the cause.

Find time to visit. Was very fortunate to be at the museum during one of the talks given by Bill , who really educates the group on the history of the museum and land mines . Even without the talk the museum is well laid out and easy to follow with plenty of literature available to read. Really worth finding time to visit here with the entrance fee going towards a very worthy cause.

Touching. I got to the Landmine Museum more "by accident" - and I am very happy for that. The story of Aki Ra and his work for a better life in Kambodia is deeply touching.Very valuable experience to get a better insight about the difficulties Kambodia still has after the Khmer Rouge Regime.

Don't miss this. This isn't a fun visit, but I would recommend it to anyone visiting the area. A real insight into the work done by a few individuals, without much help from government, to tackle the atrocity of ongoing killing and maiming of Cambodian people by landmines planted by Vietnam and the USA in the 1970s.

Interesting and sad. Not a must but if you are in the area, have a look. The landmine situation in Cambodia is frightening and it would do us good to know how the Khmers live with this on a daily basis

Worthy and worth the stop. This museum displays the various land-mines that the founder unearthed and deactivated in the area. The guides are knowledgeable and will soon disabuse you of the Hollywood fiction of that they go off when you step off them. Anti-personnel mines go off when they get stepped on. There still millions of land-mines in Cambodia. This is also a worthy stop as the proceeds of the museum help support an orphanage behind the museum.
Visit and tour. Bill gave an exceptionally interesting and comprehensive tour around the museum. Allow an hour for this, plus longer if you can for the exceptionally good lunch at the restaurant

Quite an eye opener!. So glad we went to this place. Its amazing work that they are doing there and in the school/home out the back for the modern day victims and their families. So informative too. I had no idea about so many things that I learnt from coming here. All very sad but so worthwhile. Make sure you buy some gifts from the gift shop as every cent raised keeps this place going!

very informative. Worth a visit. It's really informative and interesting and quite absorbing for an hour or so. It does explain some of the questions we had and brings home some of the realities this country has had to deal with by way of the landmines. There's quite a good short film to illustrate some of the issues further. And only $3 admission. Interesting way to spend a couple of hours if you have a spare morning in siem reap.

Well worth a visit. The museum was started by a former Kmer soldier turned mine clearer. We got the potted history of Cambodia from Bill, resident guide, instructor and orator. Despite being from the US he explains about the Kmer Rouge and where and how land mines fitted into the story. He is totally factual and unbiased. The centre houses 30 local, young people who are housed, fed and watered and may stay as long as they are in education. If memory serves me correctly they also have 30 accredited mine clearers who work in the villages. With a mine detector costing $4000 they need all the support they can get. Go visit, be moved and help financially.

Make it bigger.... The stories and examples here are raw and rough which makes it all the more interesting in my opinion. In no way a criticism, my main feedback is I wish this place was bigger, there is obvious enthusiasm for detailing the ill's of these horrid and deadly creations and I just wish that had more financial backing to spread the word about it.Make sure you go out of your way for even just 30-60 mins and learn from this place.

Sobering Pause. This small place reminds you of just how bad things have been in Cambodia. Yes you go to Siem Reap and it's a bit like Khmer Disneyland. But you need to stop here just to get refocused on how lucky we all are.
Extremely interesting. Even though the museum is small, it is full of interesting information that truly explains Cambodia's everlasting issues with the land mines still scattered around the country.

100% recommended. Interesting and informative. I went to the landmine museum yesterday and thoroughly enjoyed it. It took 45 mins to get there in a tuk tuk but it was a nice journey out. We paid $18 return in tuk tuk and $3 entrance fee. Although the museum is small it has so much information and it is a really humbling experience. We were given a tour by Bill who was fantastic, he knew so much information and was happy to answer any questions.  We gave donations but there was a sign asking for toothbrushes, toothpaste, shampoo, flip flops, sports balls and pens and pencils for the children who have been affected by landmines and who live in the museum. If I had known this before I would definitely have taken these items so something to keep in mind.

Interesting and worth a look. We visited the Landmine Museum which gave us some perspective about the history of the country. The movie was sad but good to watch to understand how some champions have worked for years to clear the landmines.

Really interesting and thought provoking. We visited this on our last day in siem reap before beginning our journey home. I had missed out on the genocide museum and killing fields in phnom phen due to time restraints so was keen to visit this museum to learn a bit about the country's history.A lot if the reviews I read said the museum was small and it was a relatively long journey from siem reap so better to incorporate a visit to nearby temples. We couldn't afford another days entry to temples so visited the museum alone and were not disappointed.The journey was a pleasant 45min tuk tuk ride and the museum itself was an extremely informative experience. There is a children's home that is run by the museum owner and seeing the art work by the children in the museum is very moving.I would recommend a visit to this museum as it is a humbling experience and allows the visitor to understand what horrors Cambodian people have experienced in recent history.
Husband moved beyond belief. My husband went ( I was sick from the exception air quality in SE ASIA) and he RAVED - moving well curated worth a visit

Both sides of the story. I met and spoke to several people while in Cambodia who had been "victims" of the Khmer Rouge and I found myself looking at anyone over about 45 wondering if they had actually been on the KR side. So I found it particularly interesting to visit this museum and read Aki Ra's account of being a child soldier with the KR. That he has gone on to clean up some of the mess he helped create, and is giving back to the community, speaks volumes about the person he is. I visited here on the way back from Banteay Srei, well worth the $3 admission.

Informative and definitely worth a visit if you are passing. We visited the museum en route to another temple and it is eye-opening and informative. It's amazing that the man who founded it, Aki Ra, is still alive after all he has endured. It is also a school for victims of land mines. The short film is worth watching before walking around the museum.

Very interesting and eye opening.. We read about this place in the lonely planet guide and are so glad that we went. It was almost an hour by tuk tuk from Pub street in Siem Reap. It is very well run and informative. We were given a tour by the American man that helps Akira run the show and he was excellent. He knew exactly how to keep you engaged and wanting to know more. It was definitely an eye opening experience for us. Highly recommend it!

See this while in Siem Reap. My 20 something daughter and I visited this museum. It was a beautiful tuk-tuk ride from Angkor Wat, and well worth it. The US guide/volunteer, Bill, provided a great overview of the wonderful work this institution is doing. The center isn't much, but they do so much good for the country, especially the youth.

Informative and moving. Worth a visit if you're nearby but probably not one to go out of your way for. A small but informative museum with lots of detail of the personal story of one man who has tried to make a real difference (and is succeeding) in dealing with the terrible impact landmines have in Cambodia.

Definitely worth a visit. We visited the museum as part of our tour of ancient Angkor temples. I've noted that a couple of people have said it was difficult to get to but we didn't find this to be so at all as we simply told our tuk tuk driver that we wanted to incorporate it into our trip and did so on the way back from one of the temples. Thought provoking and admirable. The tuk tuk driver we had was a treasure to find and a wealth of local knowledge. You can book him via his own website at www.siemreaptuktuk.net.( see also his reviews on here) Would highly recommend you do so to make the most of your trip.

Worth it even though a bit out of your way. We thoroughly enjoyed the museum, its definitely not as commercial as other museums. A bit of a small hidden gem. Although the drive is long (1hour), we passed really small villages and a butterfly farm which is apparently really good. The museum itself is very informative (as I was completely ignorant about land mines in Cambodia before). To this day I still remember reading the stories I read when I was there about Aki Ra and the various children. I think this museum is very important as it is from the perspective of a local person. Highly recommended.

Landmine museum. A difficult place to visit but we thought important. Chronicles the effort to find and remove the unexploded ordinance left from the long conflict in Cambodia. People are still being killed and maimed from land mines.

An eye opener. It is small museum. It has diffused land mines, bombs etc of various types which were collected from Cambodia. We visited this on the way to Banteay Serai. Certainly it is worth visiting.
Worth the trip.... Very informative and interesting...inspiring work. Do the Butterfly Garden at the same time, on the way to/from the temples.

Worth a look. We stopped here on the way to a temple. Its quite small, but worth the visit. Fascinating story of the guy who found the mines and ordinance. He went on to set up an orphanage behind the museum.

Worth the fee.. Entrance fee is cheap.The US$3 per person goes back into a system to help community.So make your way there to view the simple and touching museum.It was during visit that I knew there were mines in Cambodia made from Singapore.Save yourself some money and time, plan this visit with your temple tour. Talk to the Tut Tut driver to arrange it.

Cambodia: not only temples but much more.. We stayed in Siem Reap not just for the temples of the ancient times but also to understand more the recent past and the present of the Khmer.This is the perfect spot to have a feeling to what has been the life not just during the war, but also now for this population. A life where bombs have been a constant worry and that even today (and for the nest 50 years at least) are a threat for the rural population (80% of Cambodian are still earning a living through farming).Well worth a visit. We saw it on our way back to visiting temples.

Long way but worth the visit. It took over an hour to get there by tuk tuk but it was worth it. The museum has an orphanage at the back which looks after under privileged children affected by landmines and the children's stories are particularly touching. This is a small museum but it does bring home to you the horrors of this type of bomb. There is an American there who will talk to you and tell you more or answer any questions you may have which is excellent. It is a long way out so rather than just go there try and visit something else nearby at the same time or go with a tour in a minibus, it really is a long trek just to go there and back by tuk tuk. Definitely a place to visit.

Important Visit - English tour available. Everyone should visit this museum to learn about the genocide suffered by the Cambodian people and lend support to the effort to rid the country of landmines forever.

Sad reminder but worth a visit. It is a sad reminder of Cambodia recent past but I would recommend to visit this museum. The entrance is only $3. You can visit this museum while visiting Banteay Srei or Ta Phrom.

Well worth a visit. A small museum but very moving. Brings home how innocent lives continue to pay the price for past wars.Inspiring to read the personal stories of the people involved and the work they are doing to reclaim their country from the landmines laid during the civil war.

Opens your eyes. We've been here twice now - it will never cease to amaze me that landmines are STILL in the ground and people are being injured or killed to this day. Very, very sad. The American who runs the museum gives a great informal information session. And it is only $3 entry fee. We will go again.

Well worth stopping by. We stopped here on our way back from Bantay Samre. It is a harrowing but honest portrayal of the horrors of landmines and recent Cambodian history. I found the personal story from the owner very humbling, and for the first time in Cambodia felt I was experiencing the actual essence of the country (I found Siem Reap the epitome of everything wrong with tourism). It was poignant to read of a childhood of Khmer Rouge killing and the horrors of mines, and the inspiring courage to dispel rumour and attempt to clear up a near impossible carpet of nightmaresThe orphanage behind is an inspiring lesson in humanity and I applaud the charity for the incredible work they continue to carry out. Thank you.

Mind-Blowing..... A museum documenting a really terrible and tragic period in Cambodia's history (thanks, 'Merica) and also shows the noble efforts of Aki Ra as a minesweeper. It was amazing to see his mines defused and gathered together, as well as Russian rockets and anti-tank mines. Really sad but important part of history that needs to be remembered and lessons learned.

Interesting if you have time. We found this very interesting ,especially as the gentleman that set this place up was actually laying landmines during their conflicts,his wife,who has sinced passed away,actually cleared over a thousand landmines herself.They have also set up an orphanage at the rear of the museum,wonderful people doing something positive for their country.Quite confronting to browse through the exhibits as we usually only hear about the celebrities,in other areas,these people are the unsung heroes quietly going about their amazing work,Great job people.

Sad history. A must visit to see the suffering endured by the Cambodian people inflicted on them by other nations. To see the challenges they still face. Have a tour whilst there with the American who has dedicated his life to helping the people of Cambodia. A must visit

The Inhumanity of War. Everybody should pay a visit here, as it brings home to you the inhumanity of war & how not just in Cambodia but over the world people suffer. The people working for the museum have done & still do sterling work & I can only applaud their efforts. They also help orphans & under priveleged chidren. $3usd entrance fee is a very small price to pay to give them a bit of help. Very moving & very informative.
Sad and uplifting. run by a child soldier who now de-mines the area, this was a great reminder of how we can change and do good.

I felt blue, depressed, sorry to those people injured by landmines, but they also taught me to cherish what I have.... I knew there are landmines in this world, I knew there are still many landmines in Cambodia. But I didn't know what landmines caused to Cambodia people. The Cambodia landmine museum was founded by Mr. Aki Ra. Inside the museum, there is a poster says:"TOURISTS DO YOU KNOW...? That the Kingdom of Cambodia counts more than 45000 landmines victims, every month 120 new victims, 5 dollars to purchase a mine 500 to clear and destroy one mine.ALL OVER THE WORLD 100 to 200 million mines are laid and activated today! TOURISTS WHERE DO YOU TRAVEL TOMORROW...? to Angola?Afghanistan?Bosnia?Mozambique?Today 52 countries are mined!ONCE YOU ARE BACK IN YOUR HOME COUNTRY PLEASE HELP TO flight against this curse created by human,he production and use of mines world wide.Think about victims and deminers...."While you are visiting the great Angkor Wat, please do not forget those innocent people who were killed by war...
Go here if you go to Banteay Srey. Really interesting, especially if you are interested in weapon's technology like me. Entrance fee is $3 and the money goes to helping the children in the area.

Worth a visit if visiting Bantey Shreay temple complex. This little museum is set up by ex child soldier, land mine expert and now runner of school and home behind the museum for those children whose lives have been ripped apart by the legacy of landmines.It is inspiring, educational and an insight into the daily devastation caused by this countries very recent, bloody history. The museum is small and a little out of the way for those just going ankor watt , however is perfect to stop by if visiting the Bantey Shreay temple and those wanting to understand more of impact of landmines in Cambodia and around the world.The entry price is $3 a small sum for such a cause.We overheard two American tourists on our last day saying loudly "who are the kemhr rouge?" I hope they made it here.
A must see. Allow an hour and best to have a guide, they are free but will expect a tip. Very moving and brings home what local people experienced
Makes you think.. Its a sad place because of the stories it tells of innocent shattered lives. But inspiring too to see how much effort is being made to avoid further tragedy.

Very informative. Glad we chose to stop! It wasn't on our agenda for the day but we spotted it on the drive by. We are going home to do some reading to understand more about this awful situation with so many landmines and explosives left behind for innocents to stumble onto :-(

One way to get to know Cambodia's bitter past. After spending a day or two on the temples, it is good for the soul to drop by this museum, located on the way to the city from Banteay Srei Temple. The museum houses a collection of ordnances and land mines and explains the work being carried out by Aki Ra and his group of deminers.

A chilling insight into Cambodian Challenges. I had heard about the land mines that were dropped/planted/placed all over Cambodia but I had never realised the inordinate numbers that are still 'alive'.

Combine this with a visit to Banteay Srei. The museum is quite a drive from Siem Reap, so to avoid wasting time and fuel (or energy if you're biking), combine it with a trip to Banteay Srei. It's a small private museum where the atrocities of the Cambodian Civil War and the US bombing during the Vietnam conflict are well documented. You'll see the literally thousands of mines deactivated around Cambodia. You'll see the man-sized bombs US B-52s dropped around the Cambodian countryside. You'll learn about the sad and depressing Khmer Rouge period. Admission is only 2USD but you can contribute more since they support landmine victims around Cambodia.
