The only complaint about this attraction is it's too small, you'll be over it in less than hour, which is faster than the journey going there, so it's best to combine it with your Grand Circuit temple tour.

to more understand the terrible history of Cambodia. We did apart from the temples the cambodian cooking class, the circus and the landmine museum. You can of course combine this museum with temples that are close to it. We were lucky that a guided tour with perfect explanation just started. We were impressed by this reality that is an eye opener for a better understanding of the Cambodian people and the way they still suffer. It is a little museum which makes you realise how lucky you are if you have never endured war.

An eye opening experience. A must see for everyone who visits Siem reap. It will give you a true and clear picture of what these lovely people have endured. Aki, the owner and landmine expert, has an amazing story to tell. Give a generous donation as well. We are all so lucky living in our world of travel, work, travel. We tend to forget what others have suffered.

Cruel. When you go in the Cambodia Landmine Museum, you completely forget about Angkor and you think about XX Century history. You think about how cruel the USA and the war was to the civilian Cambodian population. There are similar museums like this one in several cities in Laos, Vietnam and Cambodia. I enjoyed the visit because it made me aware of the situation in the country.

Great insight into some great work. We stumbled upon a tour from one of the guys who works there and it was so interesting - this is just a little place on the side of the road on the way to one of the temples, but definitely worth a side trip.
Glad we stopped. I wasn't sure about going at first because I'm just not a museum person, but I'm glad I did. Proceeds help the children that have been affected by landmines.

Small museum that offers good insight. If you are going to visit Banteay Srei stop here on the way. It will take no more than 45 minutes to walk around and read all about the past as well as present problem being faced by undetonated landmines. It is extremely sad to see and read about innocent victims who even now are effected by the landmines that have been left behind. They also have a collection of the various mines found as well as other ammunition dating back to the Vietnam War.
Important museum. very informative museum that opens your eyes to the difficulties that Cambodians are still dealing with.

Interessant und für einen guten Zweck. We visited the landmine museum after a long day at Kbal Spean and Banteay Srei. The ticket lady wasn't exactly friendly and we had to insist on our change, but apparently she had just run out of dollars.Anyway, the whole museum was very informative.There is some reading to do but it's worth it as it really helps you understand what actually happened in the country under the Khmer Rouge regime. Also, they give a lot of info about the charity project they are running (there's a home for children and a school attached to the museum and the entry fee is used to fund these). It is a small museum but I spent over one hour in there. After seeing the ancient temples, I found it very valuable to gain some insight into the country's more recent history. Landmines are still a very real danger in Cambodia and this museum helped me understand the dimensions and the efforts being taken to deal with it.

a sobering visit. It is all too easy in Cambodia to ignore the history and go from temple to temple. So just stop and look at this low key museum and read some of the stories posted on the walls. We were very lucky to talk to the Canadian gentleman who worked there and gave a great insight into the continued challenge of mine and unexploded device clearing to prevent further loss of life in Cambodia. A small entry fee also helps support the housing and education of vulnerable children.

Authentic artefacts in their gruesome reality. Get a whiff of what freaks we have on this planet. Land mines still kill here and elsewhere. They maim innocent folks and rip the legs off people. Shoot all mine laying groups in the world!

A way to see a bit of real life in Cambodia. We visited here on the way back from the Bantay Srei temple. It was a small museum, mostly done with information, rather than exhibits (except for the sobering collection of landmines in the centre of the museum). The Museum is small, but incredibly sobering and an essential perspective on modern Cambodia: As my son put it upon leaving, ‘I hated that, but it’s really important to know about it.’

Incredible museum - a must for all visitors. This museum really shows the brutal reality of war and the after effects which are still causing deaths to this day, 20 years after the war ended. It is well worth watching the film and hearing about the Aki Ra and his family, it is also a very moving and humbling experience.

Cambodia Landmine Museum. Make no mistake, the museum is a short trip out of Siem Reap. We did the trip via tuk tuk & taking road conditions into account etc. that is about as far as I would want to go in a tuk tuk. We had checked a map and had a yarn with our driver before we left so we knew the distance. I was amazed at the number of tourists heading in that direction on push bikes.That said, travel is relative & we had covered more than a few thousand to get to Cambodia & I wasn't leaving without seeing the landmine museum.Although I had already done some reading on the subject I found the museum informative & added substance to what I had only read. I was offered the guided (free) tour but declined only due to my time constraints. Unless I missed it I would like to see some current maps on UXOs & cleared areas etc. I have found some info via the web but the resolution hasn't been great.I agree that there are a number of improvements that would benefit the museum but also appreciate the museum's limited funds.

You will leave speechless and tearing. I had studied Cambodian history but the stories you will read here will change your life. Tragic, heroic, sobering and inspiring. The museum is incredible and the profits are fed to future landline removal products and the attached orphanage. You will leave wanting to give everything you own to this incredible institution

Cambodian Landmine Museum. I was truly moved by the activites relating to orphan children that have been taken in and educated. To look at the wall of picutres and hear that this one is a doctor and this one a lawyer and this one a teacher is a true credit to the spirit of this undertaking. The immense task of landmine removal is absolutely essential but it was so refreshing to see that alongside this the Cambodian Landmine museum is also helping to foster the future generation. If you visit, be sure to take along your hotel toiletries as little gifts for the kids......

Opened my Eyes. I guess this is something that you don't think about too often but when visiting here it is a mere twenty minutes to get a very good insight into just how many of these things were placed and how much turmoil this country has been through and mostly by other countries. Don't expect a flashy museum it's nothing but a few rooms housing a few exhibits. It's the story that holds the interest. There is no charge but you will understand why a donation would be very helpful.

very confronting but worthwhile. IT is worth visiting this place because your money helps support the museum and the school and the work they do, but it gave me nightmares about the Khymer Rouge and Pol Pot and the carpet bombing of Cambodia at the time of the Vietnam wars.

Not worth the stop. Like many museums in Asia, small and big, this one also doesn't have a clear concept, pedagogy and story line. Everything looks like it had been thrown together in a hurry without any care, the presentation of photos and texts is poorly conceived. Poor video presentation. The weird manikins representing Khmer Rouge soldiers, with the papermache faces holding AK 47s and rocket propelled grenades are counterproductive and least capable to convey the horror of that Cambodian period when 3 million people lost their lives. Entry fee is supposedly spend to support the children. I can only hope that this is true. Otherwise this museum is a waste of time.

Excellent talk on the impact of landmines. We stopped for "30 minutes" but were there for almost an hour. We received a talk/tour from Bill on the background of the museum, history of the conflict and the mammoth task still ahead to rid Cambodia of the balance of 6 million mines laid. I was embarrassed as a Canadian to learn our government reduced aide to Cambodia for land mine removal by 80% and that US has still not signed the ban on land mines.

Sobering. By Western standards, this museum is not spectacular. Put aside your Western judgments and understand that this represents a critical part of the Cambodian peoples' history. Sobering, thoughtful. Don't miss this among all the other place to visit nearby (Angkor Wat complex).

For the museum,USA is a benefactor, not responsible of landmines. learn about the situation in Cambodia and the world about landmines is very important and in that sense I think a big task that takes the museum's founder. however, it seemed very light position that the museum taken to refer to the degree of guilt that united states goverment had regarding the placement of mines in other countries. in the front door the first thing that you can see its the Cambodian flag next to the usa, canada and australia. and upon entering, a big win that cnn gave to the owner of the museum. I understand that the united states donates money to solve the problems that caused when they planted landmines but I do not find reason to exonerate him of blame.

Landmine history and current status mueseum. Wow, if you don't know the story of on this place you are in for a lesson that will change your world veiw! Donation at the door and free guide that walks you thru the museum. About 30 to 45 minutes long. If you go to Bantrey shrei it will be about halfway from Seim Reap, right along the highway. You will truley see the human spirit at work in this place. I highly recommend.

A Worthwhile Experience. After spending the weekend exploring the temples in Angkor, my husband and I visited the Landmine Museum, which was a little way out of Siem Reap, but there are other attractions and temples on the way. A note of warning, the road quality on the way is not great because of pot holes and our tuk tuk driver was almost injured as a result - luckily he was fine. This was an incredibly sobering experience and I did end up becoming emotional - understandably so. These people went through hell and back and the amount of landmines what were displayed were shocking. The saddest thing is that there are still more that are still to be found around Cambodia. The museum are undertaking charitable work to help improve the lives of those who continue to be affected from the wars that have torn this country apart (i.e. injuries due to landmines). The founder of the museum had found and deactivated 100s of not 1000s of landmines and continues to undertake this work - a lot of these can be seen at the museum. It is a small and simple museum but there was a lot of information, with personal stories.Despite the sadness I felt by being at this museum, I would recommend a visit because if it was not for the founder of this place, a trip to Siem Reap would not be as possible or safe to undertake.

Very moving. A wake up call in regard to how the Cambodian people have suffered in recent history. Lots old shells and mines and pictures. Worthy of your $$ to support a worthy cause of clearing the mines.

Not easy. This museum is very sobering, but you must go as there is no point in pretending that the problem doesn't exist. It gives a matter of fact overview of the problem, not just in Cambodia and the people working at the museum are inspiring.
Keep up the good work!. Very impressive. We got a free tour from Vietnam veteran Bill. Don't miss it! He is a great guy who can tell you many stories.

Well worth a look. Quite a small place so it doesn't take long to see it all but full of information and I found that it brought the reality of how landmines have impacted the Cambodian people into focus for me. It is full of ordanance that has been decommissioned by the NGO.The $3 ticket goes towards the relief facilty for adults and children set up by Aki Ra is a small price to pay.There is also a very good shop, proceeds again go towards the facilty.It's on the way to Banteay Srey and just a small way past the Angkor Butterfly Centre.I'd consider it almost a have-to-see while in Siem Reap.
Worth a short visit. Worth a short visit to get a sense of what this is all about but not very-well laid out and no apparent attempt to preserve the artifacts.

Please pay this a visit. This is not a wow factor visit- this is to educate you all on what happened in Cambodia and the fact that no great power seemed to help them in any of the devastatuion that they endured- and indeed still do as the only way now that most of the remaining (many) landmines are found is when a farmer gets blown up...is is so sad to see and read...some of the foties are quite disturbing- but this really happened and these people are denied the justice that they truly deserve. Anotyher place is further in Seam Reap one of the modern temples which shows a casket of skulls as found in the countryside when the Khmer Rouge rounded up folk and murdered them by hitting them in the back of their heads with a bamboo pole- saving money on bullets...many of the skulls show the signs of being broken at their base...Cambodia is a beautiful country with many of its people such gentle and generous welcoming souls- but there are still many of the former Khmer rouge in power nowadays and they should be brought to justice for the horrors that were perpetrated.

Thought provoking museum. This is a must visit museum. Just take the time to read and reflect. It is astounding how destructively creative man can be. I travelled here with my 14 year old son and there is nothing gruesome or celebratory about it. The displays of mines were not that exciting but the stories and impacts are very powerful. Well worth the beautiful tuk tuk ride!

Small in size, big in impact. The history of Cambodia is powerful and tragic. The Landmine Museum helps to tall some of this story in a very human way. The story of the museum's founder - from former Khmer Rouge child solider to humanitarian is amazing. My 6 year old daughter was especially moved by the museum and wanted my wife and I to read all of the information to her. This is a short stop and should be a part of any trip to Siem Reap.

A bit tired. I don't know. It's a great resource, just not carried out very well. Lots of munitions in cabinets and landmines in an inaccessible pond but nothing particularly interactive. Why not have some hidden landmines that set off a light, or others in various stages of dismantling. What the guy has done in clearing landmines across Cambodia is extraordinary, as is providing proper support for victims, but the museum could be an awful lot better without a lot of effort. Still, I recommend a visit.

Important history here. Our 3 children (6-13) spent more than an hour here and we found the visit very worthwhile as this museum puts much of Cambodia's recent history and current challenges in context.You see maimed middle-aged people in the streets everyday and now I feel I am a little closer to understanding what they have had to endure.
Fascinating display. A small but powerful museum. Little shop to help the good cause. Helped my kids understand some of Cambodian history.

It's a disgrace this place is 15th. It's so disappointing to read so many average/poor rated reviews on this place. It's also very difficult to read such rubbish people write. Everybody is entitled to their own subjective opinion but its very wrong when people are writing what can only be described as lies about this place.Firstly yes this place maybe a little further out than the temples, maybe a half hour journey in a Tuk Tuk but should that really put you off? In that very same half an hour which you've had to endure such dreadful conditions such as beautiful views and beautiful weather Aki Ra may have painstakingly finger tipped a few centre metres of dirt around an item that's very purpose is designed to seriously injure or kill...With the reality check hopefully over and done with this place is a must visit. For two reasons- the place is very informative especially if you are lucky enough to get a guided tour from Bill Morse (who IS American not maybe Canadian) and secondly because you are supporting a great cause.I am astounded at how people feel they have been "ripped off" paying 3 dollars knowing full well their money is going a long way to help eradicate a very serious problem. You would have to be very naive to only spend 15 minutes in this place, I was in there with my girlfriend for over an hour and a half and would have liked to have stayed longer.The tour given by Bill was very informative, not just on landmines but on the bigger picture of Cambodia itself. I kept quiet about my background, I work in EOD myself so I am well educated in mines, explosives and ammunition in general (and the injuries they can cause). I was quite surprised at how knowledgeable Bill was at the more intricate details. If for some reason a tour isn't available, there are guide booklets you can walk around with, there is plenty to see. People need to realise that these items don't just become magically safe, each and every one of the items you see as you walk around has been made safe with a large amount of risk and danger involved. If you feel like there isn't enough to see- by all means get down on your front and start prodding, see how many you can retrieve from the ground. I would hope my point has been made, this place is very interesting and just by paying your 3 dollar entrance fee you are helping fund a very good cause.
Small museum but eye-opening. An eye-opener for those (like me) who have never seen such horrible weapon of destructions inflicted on human race and its ugly history.

Keep up the good work. We visited the Cambodian land-mine museum today we were very happy we did. We had no idea the magnitude of the problem here in Cambodia. We would like to give kudos to everyone involved in hype museum and the great work they do.

Vietnam Veteran. It was a trip that answered a lot of questions for me. I joined the military at the end of the Vietnam War as a teenager. The museum is small, but it tells a big story. Now I can understand how hollywood makes up their Rambo movies.

Must see eye-opener!. If you are familiar with Cambodia's history, you probably know that they have civil conflicts until 1999.Landmines were all over the place and a lot of Cambodian have suffered because of it. This museum is run by an organization who helps out landmine victims and they also use funds for information campaigns to avoid landmine explosions.The museum will walk you through the plight of the Cambodians who suffered from landmines. They have photos of the victims and mock landmine site and some helpful information about landmines in Cambodia. If you have a humanitarian heart and love history, you'll surely live this place!

Heartwrenching and inspiring. This is a small museum.. There was not a lot to see or touch but the stories behind it were heartwrenching and inspiring at the same time. The museum was the result of the efforts of a former child soldier who removed landmines from small villages by himself. The photos and stories of the child soldiers and land mine survivors made me tear, while their strong will to live and improve their lives were truly inspiring.Please visit .. You'll learn something and your admission fee will contribute to a good cause.

good trip. We were asked by our Tuk Tuk driver if we wanted to visit the Landmine Museum on the second to last day of our stay.i found it very sobering we were taken around by a very humble guide who told us a lot of what had happened in the war. A must place to go visit.

Great History Lession. As an American, interesting to see the affects of the war first-hand. Presented very well, very informative and honest. I wonder if the negative reviewers expected a circus of kids with missing limbs walking around telling stories and doing tricks. This is not that kind of place, and frankly I found that refreshing.

An eye opener of what we have left behind.. We went as a group of 25 (19 high school students) to this worthwhile NGO and museum. The students and parents were horrified at what the 'western' world had left behind and impressed by what Aki Ra and his supporters are doing to improve the situation in Cambodia. The museum is small but jam packed with information. A definite highlight of the trip.

This is an eye opener...I suggest you stop. This is along the way to Banteay Srey and worth a stop. The film takes 20 minutes and speaks of this one man's efforts to remove the myriad of land mines left from the wars in SE Asia. Good on him! We learned the phrase "Land mine survivor"....humbling but educational.

Very sobering experience. We spent at least an hour here and learnt a good deal about some of the horrors of the land mine problem that remains to this day in Laos. Well worth a visit on the way to or from Bantey Srey temple.

frightening and inspiring. here we come face to face with the tragedy of the Khmer people and may meet some of the children injured by land mines, now in school thanks to this NGO. You can buy cards drawn by the children and read there stories. some of the landlines have been recycled into jewelry and there is a lovely local restaurant on the premises. A must for any trio to Banteay Srei.

Small, but Inspirational!. I visited this en route back from Banteay Srei temple (which is fairly "out of the way" from Siem Reap and the other temples).It is a small museum and I expected to breeze through it, but there was a guide there - an American from California - who did an excellent job of explaining the history and the scope of the problem, as well as the very inspirational story of Aki Ra (which was further explained via an educational film they showed). The reason I gave this 5 stars was because I left here amazed and inspired. Aki Ra was a child soldier, then turned his life around and took on a crusade to start de-mining Cambodia. He started de-mining using only a stick and leatherman tool, which is simply mind-boggling to me. To see the work he has done and how much good he and his small team are accomplishing is well worth the trip. A gift shop and opportunities for further donations (beyond just the price of admission) are available on-site, as well. Please go and support the great work Aki Ra and his team are doing!

Very interesting small museum. Well worth a visit. The displays are a bit tired, but there is lots to read and learn. Landmines have been a defining part of Cambodia's recent culture. It is small and if I'd recommend them trying to install some video footage of demining operations.

Make the trip out of the city it is worth it!!!. Very interesting and a real eye opener about the issue of land mines in Cambodia. You cannot appreciate this information and the importance if the work being done by just reading on the Internet!

Historical & Touching. Forty minutes into our journey from Angkor Wat, we stopped to visit the Siem Reap Land Mine Museum. The Museum showcases Cambodia’s history with the Vietnam War and the Khmer Rouge. The visit to Land Mine Museum is a touching experiences, it voices how so many Cambodian’s had lost their limbs, their lives and their loved ones and have been part of a bloody skirmish. Old land mines, rocket launchers, AK-47s, hand grenades, anti-aircraft weaponry, the land mine museum has everything to showcase what went down hear couple of decades back. This place is highly recommended if you want to learn about Cambodia’s violent past.

OK only. A fair way out of town run by an American or Canadian, not sure which!, who refuses to accept historical facts that the USA played a major part in dropping bombs on this country. Museum is small and you can get around it in an hour.

Well worth the 40 minute tuk tuk!. This is just an awesome place to visit. It is about 30-40min tuk tuk ride from Siem Reap main area which costs between 10-15 dollars to hire (we went onto the museum after so maybe cheaper if you just go to the landmine museum?!) It was then only $3 to get in and that goes towards the great work they do clearing landmines on Cambodia and supporting children and adults who have been affected by landmines. They actually house victims and educate them on the site but you cannot access this, and rightly so to allow them privacy and to live without constant tourists coming in. The museum is quite small but it is very educational and emotive. The story of the founder and his late wife is truly inspiring. I hope they continue to get enough resources and support to carry on an amazing job and eradicate their fantastic country of landmines.Well done Cambodian Landmine Museum!

Remember the children. A thought provoking stop, it is well worth your time. We were fortunate enough to have Bill Morse himself there on the day to give us a tour and tell us about the work they do. There is a small fee for entrance and a small souvenier shop with items made by the children in the attached orphanage. Fortunately, thanks to the hard work of the de-miners like Aki Ra's team, the number of injuries and deaths via landmines is steadily dropping, and we were told there have been no new children injuries for at least a few years now. Even so, there is still work to be done, and I am humbled by the hard work put in despite all the tragedies suffered by men like Aki Ra and his team. May their effort continue.
An important Visit. Small and unassuming museum...but adds depth and real meaning to a visit to Cambodia. The war only recently ended....but the challenge to de-mine the country remains a priority.

Though provoking, must see. A must see while visiting Siem Reap. Incredibly moving exhibit will change the way you think about war and politics. We visited at the end of day, tuk tuk ride from Siem Reap took about an hour but was very pleasant. After visiting the museum the kids from the school invited us to play hacky sac, they were so welcoming and friendly. You can see what good the school is doing.

Stop landmines !. If you go to Banteray Sarei you should stop there!! I knew some facts of the landmines before but didn't know the extent of the land mine problem. It helps you understand the scope of the problem in Cambodia that exists even today.

You must visit this museum. This was a highlight of my trip to Siem Reap. It's a modest museum but rich in history and spirit. It's one of the few places that acknowledge the repercussions of war in the 20th century. It was inspiring to hear about the resiliency of folks involved in demining and it was enriching to understand the politics of the region through the experiences of everyday Cambodian people. It's on the way to Banteay Srei and WELL worth the stop.
Museum. The museum guide was very informative. He provided us with stories that brought us to understand the events that he was also part of.

Good side trip. I never knew the extent of the land mine problem until I went here. It was a great educational experience and helps you understand the scope of the problem in Cambodia that exists even today. Stop on the way to Banteray Sarei

People making a difference. We visited the Cambodia Landmine Museum and Relief Center while on a day trip to Banteay Srei. Everyone should visit this place, learn the story of Aki Ra and his mission to make Cambodia safe for its people. Monies donated, or spent at the small shop, help support the Relief Center and the dozens of children who live there. We were fortunate to meet Bill Morse, a retired American who, with his wife, now lives at the Center where she teaches school and he is the Project Manager. We were educated and humbled by their dedication.

Touching Attraction.. It's not the biggest or most impressive museum you will visit, but it does a great job in setting the chronological scene of how so many landmines came to be in Cambodia.The visit here was very moving. Reading and gaining an understanding of what occurred makes you appreciate how lucky we are. Thanks a lot. Highly recommended.

good effort that deserve a visit. tbe museum is rather small with only a few rooms filled with display, but I really applaud and respect the effort of Aki-Ra in his de-mining mission, and a visit here do shed a light on the seriousness of the mines in Cambodia and the impact it had on the local society

Not to be ignored. This was half an hour well spent in amongst the relaxation and enjoyment of this country. The people you encounter have such an open friendly attitude that its easy to forget the horrors they've lived through and in many cases still do.

Great artworks. Because of the passion of art, I decide to visit Khmer kids art gallery alone. Walking in here, I was surprised by kids' artworks. paintings and printed products made by young, talented, and passionate artists. These kids are very talented. The gallery is dedicated towards providing a creative and welcoming environment that would make one’s visit truly memorable. I am sure I will come back when I have a chance to visit Siem Reap again.

Well worth the drive. Excellent presentation of the recent history of Cambodia and its aftermath. The sponsoring NGO explains its work very well and offers opportunities to contribute, but nothing feels coercive. Worth visiting!!

See the biggest problem that Cambodia still faces. I've been past the Cambodian Landmine Museum before, this time I stopped in for a look, if your going out to see banteay srei temple stop off on the way up or back, Cambodia still has a hugh landmine problem and the museum will show you how big it really is, there is a small entry fee, but the money is used to help some of the less fortunate kids from the area, it will only take about 30 min to an hour out of your day but it will change your view on what the Cambodians have faced in the last 40 years or more, and the mine problem that they still face.

Worth the stop. This museum has lots of English in written form so you can understand what is being told to you, our guide asked if the tour guide was available but unfortunately he was out shopping. We probably spent 1/2 hour. It was very informative and is really about supporting a single man who is doing a lot by himself to protect his country. They do take donations of soap, hand sanitiser, toothbrushes (not the hotel ones) to support the orphanage attached. Take a look at their website as there is a long wish list. We did take some soap but did not donate money as it said only half of the money went towards the children.
Loved it!. thoroughly enjoyed this museum. we learned much about a genocide that as Americans we learn little about. very well put together - extremely informational but not dry in the slightest.

You would need to care about how these work. No English guide was available when I was there. There is a bunch of papers you can pick up to use and return in different languages. It didn't make it come to like in the way the Killig Fields did in Phnom Penh

This Story Needs to Be Told. This is a very simple museum but it has an important story to tell. Akira is an inspirational human being. To do what he has for the people of his Country after what he had to go through as a child is an amazing story. It is just terrible that the legacy of another of the many wars that should of never happened is still effecting so many people in such a terrible way till this day, so many years after the war ended. Please visit and make a donation to help erradicate this lovely country of the mines and munitions that are still causing havoc only a daily basis and maiming people that don't deserve to suffer through the wrongs of others.

Worth a stop to see part of Cambodia's darker side.. The museum is worth a visit though it is not overly spectacular. But when you think it was put together by one man and his helpers it is pretty darn good. The story it tells is a sad one but needs to be told. They run the place on donations and I recommend you donate. No donation is too small in helping Cambodia rid the countryside of live munitions that kill or injure people every year.

Very moving. The visit here was very moving. Reading and gaining an understanding of what occurred makes you appreciate how lucky we are living in Australia. The CSHD is a wonderful project helping people that have been affected by the horrible land mines. Very moving and brought tears to my eyes but thankful that the project is done to educate people

Positive. Tip: They accept donations of soaps, shampoo, toothbrushes, etc.. for the students. I didn't know so I couldn't donate but bring some stuff with you. This museum is so positive and they help so many people, you will be touched when you leave, definitely.

Insight in to aftermath of decades of war on northern Cambodia. Staff was passionate about their cause. Watched English guide Bill engage school children and educate them on Landmine eradication. Very interesting and insightful

Impressive story. The founder of the museum was a Khmer Rouge soldier as a kid and used his mining skills later on to dismantle mines.It is really impressive to read his story and see how dismantling a mine works (and how dangerous it is!)

Incredible story of giving back. The founder, Akira, was a child soldier fighting for the Khmer Rouge when he discovered he was on the wrong side - he defected and fought for his country, ultimately becoming instrumental in de-mining efforts after the war. He made a huge impact with de-mining in Cambodia as well as founding this museum to share the history and help provide for orphans and victims of landmines. Well worth a visit - especially for Americans. The drive to the museum offers a great opportunity to experience Cambodian villager life as well.

Sobering, informative. Really personal and human view of the landmine crisis in Cambodia. Aki-Ra has an incredible and ongoing story. Spend a day trekking in the temples and then spend a little time in this museum learning about the realities many Cambodians face. The museum contains lots of landmine relics, but what I found more interesting was just learning about Aki-Ra's story, his wife and the youth that live at the school. (On one of the walls they have posted bios of each of the children and the stories of how each child got to Aki-Ra are varied but always heartbreaking.)Very interesting, informative museum.
Life changing. If found this to be a profound, eye opening and life changing exhibit a must see for travelers in the area
A noble cause. Brilliant and very informative commentary from Mr Morse who helps out in the centre. A very noble initiative by founder Aki-Ra.

Extremely emotional, but a necessary experience if one wants to get a whole story of Cambodia and its people. The Landmine Museum got on my "must see" list while planing the trip to Angkor Wat/Siem Reap couple of months ago. I hail from one of those "most landmine-contaminated countries" on the list, and I really wanted my teenage children to see it in order to better understand the human condition as a consequence of war, as well as learn about Cambodian history. Besides the personal story of Aki Ra and his work on de-mining and helping out children-victims of landmines, as well as information on mines, mortars and other weaponry used during the civil war, the museum features materials related to history of Khmer Rouge terror rule and genocide of Cambodian people. The visual elements are well combined with non-visual ones. Photographic exhibition of limbless victims is particularly shocking, but very tastefully organized and exhibited. Small museum shop offers a collection of souvenirs, museum logo t-shirts, children's drawings and books and provides a visitor with an opportunity to support its work by purchase or donation. Definitely recommend for anyone willing to go beyond the usual sight-seeing experience and learn more about Cambodian history and the perseverance, bravery and optimism of its people.

Deserves to be visited. A great cause that should be supported, there are few people in the world that would risk their lives over and over again to secure the safety of their country. Then to set up a museum to continue the work amazing :)
Shocking but informative. The work being done by the team at the Landmine Museum is great. Learning about the source of the mines was interesting.

Emotional and Educational. "You must go to the landline museum" said a friend who had visited 9 years ago. He said it was a cycle ride out of Siem Reap but unknown to him the museum moved to 40+ minutes out of town by car a few years ago. "You must go" was the message again from England.We did as told and that was a very good decision.The journey back from the museum was a daze as my wife and I were left with heads spinning through the education and emotion from the experience at the museum.It is fantastic to see beautiful Cambodia but the history is shocking (and it happened in my life time). The story of Aki Ra is incredible.Watch A Perfect Solider on the web and if you are in Siem Reap take the time to visit this museum and support what this man (and his support team) are doing for their country and people.

Worth a visit. Stopped off at the museum on the way back from the waterfall and Banteay Srei and so glad we did. It is very informative and interesting. An amazing story of one man's war against the landmines he set as a child. Moving and well worth the visit. Take extra dollars to buy jewellery made from recycled mines.
Worth a visit. We visited on the way back to Siem Reap after visiting the Lady temple and the waterfall. Very informative and interesting. Fantastic to see how one man can make such a difference.

Well worth the time to see. This is a very interesting and informing museum. It took about an hour and a half for us to go through. It is a tragedy that this day in age that landmines are still active. It is great the work is being done to make Cambodia clear of the horrible landmines. The giftshop has some great items to take home that are very reasonably priced with the procedes going to a great cause!

An Amazing Organization. I admit, when it was suggested that we go to the Cambodian Landmine Museum, I balked. I didn't want to hear about how people lost limbs and all that sad stuff, but it is important and I was admittedly very impressed with the whole experience. My kids (age 8 and 5) were absolutely mesmerized by Mr. Morse during the entire visit.We were lucky when we arrived that the Museum Director, Bill Morse, was actually providing the Tours. I learned an incredible amount about the land mines, how many are still out there (how many are live and still dangerous), and was very impressed both by what the organization is doing and the sphere of influence they have. They employ about 30 people to disarm land mines, and are continuing to work to return farmland to the people. They also help children that have been injured by a land mine. They can come to the organization, be provided a home and education. They have continued on and children harmed by land mines are also provided a scholarship to go to university. Our experience was absolutely wonderful, and this is due fully to the fact that Mr. Morse provided the tour. Thank you for the wonderful experience and I hope your organization will continue to grow. My recommendation is, please go see the museum. Learn what they are doing to return the land to people, and drop a huge donation when you leave. The actual admission fee is only $3, so I am sure you can leave a bit more!

A brilliant museum worth the trek. If you're planning on not going to Banteay Srei you should change your plans and on the way or on the way back you must stop at this brilliant museum. Someone said to me when I got home "A LANDMINE museum? What do you want to look at those for?!" The answer is that it's not a tribute or exhibition dedicated to landmines but to their victims and the efforts that these people led by an inspirational man go to, to rid the country of these evils. We were lucky enough to get here in time to hear Bill Morse give a tour. I think roaming about looking at the displays and reading the stories wouldn't have been so rich in emotion if it wasn't for him.It's amazing to see the vim behind the group of people who dedicate their time to demining Cambodia on such little funding so please go and spend your $3 and then spend some more in the gift shop or donate to this amazing work.
Well worth the journey. This is an amazing place. Please make the journey and help support this worthwhile cause. Take tissues and be prepared for some upset when you read some of the stories.

Cambodian Land Mine Museum. On our way back from visiting Banteay Srey we stopped at this small and poignant museum. The museum shows the dedication and persistance one man has to tell the world how land mines can contribute to the devestation of innocent children and farmers years after a terrible war. Contributions help house and educate children effected by land mines and keep the work of finding and diffusing them in the spotlight.

Contribute. We visited the Landmine Museum so not only us but our children could see how war has a lasting effect decades after is over. This is to also pay respects to the many who have lost their life or their limbs to the landmines that still have yet to be removed.We had a fantastic American guide who gave us spot on information and if you have some spare cash, please donate so these people can go out into the fields and bring more of these nasty landmines up out of the ground.

Small museum, big impact. A museum with a story and a job to do - visit and support the work done there supporting orphaned children and read the story of one mans ambition to do something about landmines.
Historical and Gritty. Want to see landmines up close and personal? You've come to the right place. It definitely gives you an insight into these weapons and how awful they truly are.

Informative, sustainable, and a good cause to take part in. This museum may not be the biggest, but they do big work for Cambodian people and you can learn about these efforts in great detail upon your visit. Attached to the museum is an orphanage/home for children disabled by landmines or whose parents were lost in a landmine accident. You are not permitted to interact ( which is a good thing) as this home offers them the opportunity for a stable and normal life including education and future scholarships for university. During our visit at the museum, an expat de-miner was present and was offering help along the tour and interesting anecdotes. The museum is a ways out of town ( roughly 45 mins), so it is best to make the visit while doing other activities in the area, such as Banteay Srei, the butterfly museum, and even the shooting range if your feeling adventurous. Consider bringing donations when you visit. They had a message board saying that they needed things like Cambodian books for the children, blank journals for writing, toiletries, etc.. If you can't make it to visit, consider donating to this wonderful cause! http://www.cambodialandminemuseum.org/

Worthy of a visit. This museum is easily accessed on the way back from Banteay Srei temple. Hopefully you will also be able to meet Bill Morse who talks about some of the displays. The museum has a wish list for its attached home. We took coloured pencils to donate. Money, sanitizer gel and sports balls are on the list.
Quite upsetting. Lots of guns, lots of sad tales and lots of limb missing guides. The souvenir shop at the end was quite good to wander round with a beer.

Hopeful. Perhaps if we hadn't met Bill who provided a running commentary for the displays, giving fascinating personal insights to the organisation & the man behind it; it would have been a little dry to read through the small displays and exhibits.It's still worth a trip. As sad as it is to learn how men can make devices to hurt fellow men, it's also inspiring to see how one man's resolve to change brings about so much good and hope for Cambodia. Highly recommend. Do support them.

This is worth visiting.. We visited here and left some clothes (T Shirts) for these guys to distribute to children in some of the villages they are working with. The museum highlights the plight of land mined Cambodia and outlines the efforts provided by these people. We bought souveniers from here as they help with the costs of running the museum and the school. We were luck enought to meet Bill, the director, and were humbled to hear of their efforts.

humble and poignant. Almost one hour to get there via tuk tuk (great sights of rural life on the way).The museum was not particularly 'staffed', but the pictures and the large amount of posters/printed information tells ALOT.The museum is founded by a man who was in the Khmer Rouge, planting devices, but has not devoted his life to unearthing these devices safely. He seems like a modest saint and what an honour it was to read the information about his work and see the kind of devices he pulls from the ground.What a shock it is to read about the issue of landmines and get an idea of the number of still unexploded mines hiding somewhere in the ground,.Very touching.

Powerful reminder of a not so distant past. This museum does an excellent job interpreting the war and highlighting the dangers still present from unexploded ordnance. Worth the time to stop, and I would encourage a contribution to support this important ongoing effort.

Wonderful and saddening so happy we went!!!. We had not heard a lot about the museum but it was recommended by our hotel and driver and we were so happy we took there advice.The history is both interesting and upsetting and gives real insight into the ongoing concern about mines in the country post war. The work undertaken by the founder and staff is amazing and I am so happy that we had the chance to contribute to such a worth while cause. It really is a must!!!!!!!!

Highly recommended. We were lucky enough to have a tour by Bill Morse and he gave us a very powerful account of the impact of land mines in Cambodia. I feel it is very important to understand the role that land mines played in the civil war and still today. I was really glad that my two teenage children also got to hear Bill talk about the power of getting involved to do something about these terrible things. Thanks to Akira and everyone at the museum for giving us a better insight into the impact of landmines. If you would like to find out a bit more about the museum before you go you can visit the website at http://www.cambodialandminemuseum.org/

Please help!. This was probably the most confronting episode of our visit to Cambodia. The senseless inhumanity and carnage wrought by this practice was vividly (but not sensationally) brought home to us by William Morse's insightful narration. Imagine a child throwing what (s)he thought was a disc (frisbee?) and losing limbs, eyesight or life!I would urge every visitor to Cambodia not only to view the museum and take the tour but also to support the great work done by Cambodian Self Help Demining financially. Every effort should be made to encourage their governments to stop both the manufacture and use of landmines and to contribute to landmine clearance.

A must visit to understand Cambodians better. Most tourists pass by...what a shame. A ticket is just $3, and the visit will take u about 30 minutes, u will not regret..I was impressed with what I saw..

Sad story, but amazing museum. This museum is simple, small, but the message in transmits is very powerful. The story of one man, who was a child soldier, than deserted to the other side, than became a landmine "cleaner" could be a movie story. The museum has a lot of information - don't forget to get the laminated booklet in the first room - and explains very well the political history of Cambodia and the landmine problem that still threatens the Cambodian people.Besides, the social work they do, taking care of kids that were hurt by landmines, is admirable. Really worth a visit.If you are really into the political situation of Cambodia, reserve at least 1 and a half hours for the visit.

Admirable, informative and an interesting attraction. This museum is not like any normal museum. I am not a fan of museums and I enjoyed this one. It is setup by Aki Ra who was a Khmer Rouge child, laying landmines in Cambodia to wound soldiers. He has setup the museum and an adjoining school to repay his wrongs and reform those affected by landmines in Cambodia. Make sure you pick-up the booklet (available in many languages) at the beginning which guides you around the museum and helps you to understand and look for artefacts within the museum. Lots to see and learn here a definite for your holiday! It is also a beautiful tuk-tuk ride through the countryside.

A sobering must-see near Bantreay Srei. The Cambodian people have suffered much from war and still do to this day from an estimated 2-3 million landmines and other unexploded ordinance. Aki Ra has dedicated his adult life to removing these deadly devices while caring for and educating those directly impacted by these body & life-shattering devices.The museum is small & unpolished but poignant. It is certainly worth the $3 admission and helps fund this noble effort initiated by a man who knows both sides of the war all too well. Consider it a hour well-spent if not a duty to attend.

Just go there!. The museum itself is small, but it has all the information you need, and above all an extremely moving story, because it is so much more than 'just' a museum. When I was there, Bill told me so much about the background and the people that are involved.At the end of the day, I had to admit that the time in the museum had impressed me more than the temples I visited...

Big impact for a little museum!. Don't expect a flash museum this has been created on a tight budget but the story is worth hearing. We visited the Pink Lady Temple, Banteay Srei, first as the museum is on the same road a distance out of town. The villages you past through show how basic life is in Cambodia! The video about Aki Ra shown at the museum is worth watching first and then you can read the stories around the museum and look at the photos. It is very interesting and gives you a good insight to their recent history in contrast to the ancient history of the temples. Worth a visit.

It's a heart breaker truth. Is very informative, and even if is some times really hard to know about, I think is important to be informed and understand this terrible reality about this country and their beautiful people

Extremely interesting and moving. We thought we would spend half an hour at the Landmine Museum and spent 3 hours instead. These folks are true saints for the work they are doing. The task of removing mines is dangerous and very labor intensive yet the team keep at it in spite of limited resources and other obstacles. I learned so much about not only landmines but also about many other aspects of Cambodian life. It was particularly useful that the manager of the Museum was there to speak about their efforts. He is devoted, passionate and very articulate. This is a true inspiration.

Heartwrenching. Although the place was just small and not well maintained, it really opened my eyes about Cambodia's recent war history and about how it is still affecting their present. I am in awe of people like Aki Ra who, even in their own small way, are able to help their country to become better. I just hope I was able to help more in improving this humble museum, and I hope more people will also help in sustaining this place for it to be able to educate more people regarding landmines. and its dangers.

Small, Shabby and unmaintained. I understand the importance of this museum. Unless you read every poster posted on the walls, it is rather hard to understand the significance of the museum. It would've been much better if the museum was maintained and some sort of guide who could explain the history and importance of their mission every two hours or something. The museum seems significant but a little disappointed by the outcome after visiting. Paid around USD$3 pp to get in.
Sad place to visit. It is amazing what bombs and other destructive devices mankind makes to hurt other mankind. It is wonderful what some of the previous soldiers are doing helping clear mine fields

Must see. This is a highly important museum which, while being physically small, packs in a lot of history relating to the past fifty years of Cambodian war history and the toll it has taken on the people. It also shows the heroic efforts of one soldier to undo the damage he contributed to while fighting the Khmer Rouge. It costs only a few dollars to enter and that goes to the school for land mine victims and orphans in the back of the complex. Highly informative and sobering.
Worth the visit. This was god to learn not only about the Khmer rouge history but the ongoing work that the museum is doing to support current victims of landmines

Interesting, but far away for such a small place. I really enjoyed learning about Cambodia's history of landmines, but sadly for being so far away from town, the place was small and was only about a 15 minute visit.
Go in the afternoon. Good - especially if you have young sons - as long as its not raining you can go at anytime of the day. Beware of the touts hanging around

For all who are interested in the Khymer Regime. An eye opener into what this regime was like and what effect it had on the Khymer people. It's an open air museum that's not very large, but their is lots to see. I suggest you make a donation to the initiative that is still trying to rid this country of landlines. We really enjoyed this visit although we werea bit rushed for time. Would have liked to have spent more time .had an excellent guide. I recommend you use one as there is lots to be explained. The whole family will enjoy this experience as it is a real history experience.

Landmine Museum. This museum made me more grateful that I am born and raised to a country who's already economically developing and free at 90's. This museum gave us information on history of Cambodia landmine. The museum also presented the ammunition preserved but are safe for viewing.

wow.. This place is a must see! The work Aki Ra, his late wife and team have done has changed and saved lives - it is a very sad trip to do but also so inspiring to see what can (and has!) been done! They rely on donations and sell t - shirts etc for very little - definitely support them - such a worthy cause!
Eye opener. Worth the visit and to contribute to their ongoing struggle in locating the mines still in the country. Amazing the work that has already been done.

Tour here if you have spare time. This is obviously a critical part of recent Cambodian history and it does have some interesting facts but those facts could easily be gained via text or even internet reading. Attending this attraction/site is only of benefit because your entry funds and donations assist in the cause of rehab for vicitms.

A real eye opener. My boyfriend and I came into the museum on our way to a few temples. It used to be free entry but now it's $3 per person but I was very happy to hear that the money is put towards the children who live behind the museum.The museum is a real eye opener - it's sad to read some of the stories but there is so much hope for their future that just being able to create awareness feels good. Definitely worth the trip!

Perspective changing. I loved this place and have huge admiration for its founder. Well worth a visit to read about Aki Ra's journey and about the vile landmines. There is also an orphanage on the site so bring pens, hand sanitiser, copy books, etc to leave behind for the children. Also, visit the Butterfly center on the way back as they are both on the same road.

A nice stop for an hour. We stopped at the landmine museum for about an hour and really enjoyed it on our way to Banteay Srei. The museum is small and contains a nice mix of information specific to mines and background information on the broader historical context. We also requested that the gift shop attendee play a video for us (recommended by our guide Sun Same), on the work of the museum's founder Aki Ra, a man who has successfully disarmed thousands and mines. I think it was the video that the organization submitted to CNN for its application on behalf of Mr. Ra for CNN's annual hero of the year award, which Mr. Ra won as a top 10 hero in 2010. The musuem also provides a nice contrast to the temples if you are feeling a little templed-out.
Wheelchair accessibility. Easy to get into and around museum. Found the displays OK, and the audio-visual displays insightful. Worth the effort. Didn't see any accessible toilets.

Everyone should go. Going to this museum was such a worthwhile use of time, I learnt an awful lot about landlines and the efforts undery to clear them in the country (from Bill one of the advisors who just happened to be walking around and was happy to chat to us). The museum is well presented, and the money goes towards the actual clearance of mines, everyone should go and gain an understanding of the significance of this problem.

Informative, well presented , confronting. Well set out history of the sad era of the Khymer Rouge in Cambodia and the sad legacy they left behind The Cambodians are still suffering with millions of mines yet to be destroyed.

Thought provoking. The stories and pictures are informative and horrifying. The work that is being done by the landmine committees necessary and inspiring. The school and orphanage worthy matters. Would like to see the place updated a little bit. The money they are making from admittance fees certainly isn't going into the museum.

interesting, a place shoud to visit. it is very interesting to learn about how land-mines have and still affect the people of Cambodia. This museum should really be named the de mining museum. It was set up by a former child soldier Aki Ra (named 2010 CNN person of the year) in both the Khmer Rouge, Vietnamese and Cambodian armies, who was saved by finally escaping into Thailand and then working for the UN, de mining. The entrance fee is just $3 and is money very well spent. There was a wish list on the board at the Museum which included the following items: hand sanitiser, writing notebooks, laundry soap, hand bar soap, shampoo, pens & pencils, flip flops (ages 8 to 24), white board markers, white & coloured chalk, toothbrushes and toothpaste, sports balls (all kinds). If you are planning a visit and can contribute some things from the list above, I'm sure they would be very grateful.

Worth the trip. very confronting and the girls in our group were pleased that they went.Great story of the founder and now his commitment to clean up land minesDefinitely worth the drive and stop in on the way back from the female temples

interesting. Interesting to read the stories of some of the people affected by landmines set by the Khmer Rouge. Also interesting to see the variety of devices displayed in a small shed in the center of the pond that were manufactured in different countries. The write ups gave a unique perspective on the legacy of the Vietnam War.

An educational and worthwhile visit. The Landmine Museum and Relief Center is a great addition to a day out when visiting Banteay Srei. Definitely include this in your visit to Siem Reap.The museum is more than just about landmines, but the entrance fee helps the de-mining organization and educational opportunities for local students. You can definitely gain an impression about the history of landmines in Cambodia and what is being done. The nice thing is that it's not focused on the negative, but provides a very honest and personalized picture of the issue.

An educational and enlightening experience. Everyone must visit.. This is a must-visit kind of place. The story behind the reason this place exists is incredible, thought-provoking and almost life-changing. The great work being done by the CLM Relief Fund to continue to train people to remove landmines safely and to inject monies into education for those affected is truly inspiring. True heroes exist here.
Must visit. torrid torture display of pol pot Khmer regime on torture of Cambodian by planting Landmines thru out the country...bom missile,weapons of many countries also on display..

Interesting. Worth checking out if you are heading out to Banteay Srei. Seems like a very legit organization that is doing some very good things for the people of Cambodia (not only by demining, but also by supporting a school). Aki Ra's story is an interesting one and Bill Morse, an American who works for the organization, gave a very interesting and informative tour. There are so many scams going on in the country, it is nice to see an organization that is really working to improve Cambodia in more ways than one.

A good source of information on the war. The exhibits were cluttered but there was a lot of information. It would have been special if the head could have been there. After having been to S21 and the Killing Fields in the capital, this was less impressive. Nevertheless, the story is still raw and brutal. But, again a personal touch would have been good.

A must visit for serious travellers. For those of you that want to know more about landmine status in Cambodia and also all around the world, then, you have got to visit this Museum, that's being set up by a personality named Aki Ra, who used to be a demining soldier. All the mines that you see here are from his days of demining. At the rear of this Museum is where Aki Ra looks after over ten children. And so, the proceeds from the tickets and gift shop are going to a good cause. Here, you may be surprised to learn about a Hollywood movie maker who's donating the money to have this Museum built. It's an informative place that you can easily spend for an hour or two. Remember, only for the travellers out there who are keen to know more about Cambodia.

A dose of reality. This museum 'tells it like it is'. Cambodians are still being blown apart by landmines and the profits from your visit go towards supporting as many as possible of those affected by missing limbs. The site includes a 'school' (not for public view) where young people are aided to continue with their education and learn a trade.Extremely worthwhile for the US$3,00 entrance fee.

Worth the trip. This can take a reasonable time to get to but is really worth a visit. You get to fully understand what it was like for khmers to live in Cambodia during and after the khmer rouge reign. Its only 3 $ to get in. If you really want an insight into the later cambodian history and can accept and understand the dark history that it has this is the place for you. It has lots of different disabled mines and bombs to see what types there were and also information on the history of the khmer rouge and also of the founder that started this project. He helped disabled a vast amount of mines and has made it his mission to make cambodia safe for its nationals. He also set up a relief center with his late wife to take in children affected by these mines whether it be them it their parents. There is a shop selling items which helps give money to help support the relief center. This is not only a complete eyeopener to cambodias dark past but is also a worthy cause.

This is a "must see" while in Siem Reap. This is a very worthy cause, and this organization is doing great things for Cambodia and its people. If you have been in Siem Reap for more than a day, then you have experienced the children constantly trying to sell you things and begging for money. They broke my heart, but I could not buy from them because I didn't want to encourage their parents to keep using their children like that. Instead, I went to this museum where they help children who are victims of landmines. The children live there and go to school. This organization has also helped build and fund schools around Cambodia.

Not worth a special trip. If you are in the area already, you may like to stop by this museum, the centerpiece of which is a clear column filled with munitions and pieces from landmines that have been found. Certainly a disturbing exhibit. Very small--you will need less than 30 minutes to see it.

Moving, ethical and worthwhile. I can only agree with all of the previous positive comments. The museum itself is not massive, but what is there is fascinating. The staff members are fantastic and spent a lot of time explaining the history and details of the laying of landmines. It is close to Banteay Srey, which is a gorgeous temple, so please look in to this museum if you go to this temple - it is well worth it and your $3 entrance fee is going to an excellent cause.

Fascinating museum. The museum is an amazing repository of information about Cambodia's tortured history, the incredible malice of landmines, and difficulty of removing them. It was very uplifting to learn of the work of the museum's founder, and like-minded people, and the political efforts to ban the use of landmines in the future.
Good insight into the issue. This museum is very basic, but really informative and well worth a visit. It does good work too, so any donations will be well spent.

informative, worth the visit. Has many examples of the sorts of land mines in use, an explanation of where and why they were placed, and seems to be a worthy charity. Can be combined with an early morning visit to a temple in the area, for about a $23 tuk-tuk ride.

The museum is small. The museum is small and less impressive than I thought it would be. i am glad i didn;t travel there by tuk tuk. having said that it was interesting to learn how the land mine museum funds are being used to support victims of land mines

Definitely worth a stop. This is a simple museum but with a compelling message. It is not far from Banteay Srei so stop by if you are going there. It's just $3 to enter. Some of the displays are dated but overall, it is a chance to learn about landmines, if you don't know much about them. We met Bill, the American project manager. A very interesting man who can tell you a lot about the museum and about Cambodia. Their children's home is right next door. You can't visit it but there are stories about the children who live there.

Better museums around!. The land mine museum is a half an hour drive from the Angkor Archelogical Park. Having visited numerous landmine museums around the region, I hardly think this place is impressive. There are some exhibits and some write-up on the founder, Akira. If I remember correctly, the entrance fee is 3 USD.

Very Informative and Interesting $3 USD per entry. My husband and I recently visited this site. After previously visiting S21 and the Killing Fields in Phnom Pehn, this is an extension to the travesties war has caused to the Cambodian people. Come to learn more about how land mines and other explosives are being removed from the country in a safe and locally-sustainable way. The history of land mines and other explosives is very sad, but informative! Note: Bring Toilet Paper for the Washroom Facilities :)

Worth A Visit. Very interesting to learn about how land-mines have and still affect the people of Cambodia. This museum should really be named the de mining museum. It was set up by a former child soldier Aki Ra (named 2010 CNN person of the year) in both the Khmer Rouge, Vietnamese and Cambodian armies, who was saved by finally escaping into Thailand and then working for the UN, de mining. He set up this museum to display his finds and also an orphanage next door to house children of mining disasters. A very moving and meaningful stop if you are in Siem Reap, that portrays with artifacts, photos and stories, the horrors that Cambodian people have faced. A bonus if you ask and can get to speak with Bill an American who now runs the museum and his wife Jill that runs and teaches at the orphanage to get more first hand knowledge. They were on site when I visited and were very happy to come and chat. As I did, taking school supplies for the kids was much appreciated.

Attraction Place!. Aki Ra fought for the Khmer Rouge until 1983 when he was captured by the Vietnamese. He was conscripted into the Vietnamese army on threat of his life while still a boy. He later served with the Cambodian army as a teenager and still later received landmine clearance training with the United Nations.Having laid thousands of landmines as a soldier and working for the UN to remove them he discovered he was quite adept at clearing landmines and UXOs, and decided to make it his trade.Having no demining tools, he used a knife, a Leatherman, and a stick. He would defuse the landmines and UXOs he found in small villages and bring home the empty casings. Sometimes he would sell them as scrap to help fund his work.Tourists began hearing stories about a young Khmer man who cleared landmines with a stick and had a house full of defused ordnance. Aki Ra began charging a dollar to see his collection, using the money to help further his activities. Thus began the Cambodia Landmine Museum.Aki Ra cleared landmines where he had fought, when he heard about an accident, or when village chiefs and farmers would call him at the museum and tell him of mines in their villages and ask for his help.While working in these villages he found many injured and abandoned children. He brought them home to live with him and his wife Hourt. Some of the children who moved to their home were also street kids from Siem Reap and Phnom Penh. Eventually he had brought home over 2 dozen boys and girls.The first child Aki Ra brought home was a 9-year old boy who had lost his leg to a landmine and was living on the street. His wife Hourt had no idea Aki Ra would be returning with the little boy, but when he returned home she took the child to her family and said "Look, now I have a son".

The exhibition of a multitude of various landmines. The exhibition of a multitude of various landmines, placed in a pavilion in the middle of a small pond, which is at the centre of the whole museum, is startling. Other exhibitions talk about how modern-day deminers do their work and the children who are being taken care of by Aki Ra's charity.

Interesting, inspirational, horrifying. This place is small but packed with information and stuff to look at. Cambodia has had a really rough time in recent history and it was good to learn a bit more about it, and how they still suffer from landmines. It's quite a way out of siem reap and a tuktuk cost us $15 there and back, but it was worth it.

well worth a visit!. This small museum is a 'must see' for visitors to the Siem Reap area. It provides information and insight into the tragedy of the Khmer Rouge era in recent Cambodian history, and also the legacy of the landmines and the work being done to remove them. The story of land mine removal and of the ex-child soldier, Aki Ra who has been highly involved in landline removal and rehabilitation of children and youth wounded by land mines is particularly engrossing and memorable.
Very sad. This was very interesting to read the story behind this man's life and makes you have a lot of feeling for the people of Cambodia.

Amazing charity. Joined a tour by an American guy who is living in Cambodia and helping A Khmer man clear landlines and rehabilitate child victims. You don't realise the devastating effect and the hard road ahead these children have. This foundation is fantastic. Every child gets a good education and a university scholarship if they want to continue with their education. They are also doing great post traumatic stress work. Well worth a visit and your support.

Eye opening experience. Really opened my eyes to the troubles of Cambodia past & present. I brought some small toys and gave them to the children and there gratitude was unreal. Just a really nice trip and very incitful.

Well worth a visit. We had seen a documentary on the amazing work that Aki Ra, the founder of this museum, is doing to clear land mines in his country and we committed to visit the Museum on our trip to Cambodia. We found the displays and information at the museum fascinating and were in awe of the fantastic work Aki Ra has done not only himself, but also his training of others to defuse the mines and other ordinances, and additionally to provide a safe haven for children who have been affected by these terrible implements. We were so impressed with the commitment that Aki Ra and his people have demonstrated and continue to demonstrate in pursing their goal of ridding the country of the scourge of millions of mines left behind from wars decades ago and in doing so making the countryside a safer place and freeing it up for productive activities such as farming.The entrance fee is just $3 and is money very well spent. There was a wish list on the board at the Museum which included the following items: hand sanitiser, writing notebooks, laundry soap, hand bar soap, shampoo, pens & pencils, flip flops (ages 8 to 24), white board markers, white & coloured chalk, toothbrushes and toothpaste, sports balls (all kinds). If you are planning a visit and can contribute some things from the list above, I'm sure they would be very grateful.

Worth the visit. Our tuk tuk driver took us here on the way home one day. It is a basic down to earth museum but gives real in-site to how horrible things were for the Cambodians and how many peoples lives have been effected by land mines. We visited here in Jan 2013, a very sobering experience

Worth a visit. If you aren't going to read online about this place, then take the te to come and read the articles, see the land mines, and look at photos of survivors and ALSO heroes in other conflicts (holocaust, Bosnia, and other atrocities)

really interesting and informative better than angkhor nationaluseum. I found this to be really interesting. I didn't even know what a landmine looked like. They even show a small field that has mines in it. They show the various methods they used to use to defuse the mines. There are lots of stories to read about the children who live behind the museum. they show maps of which areas of cambodia were mined the most. they also talk about rwanda, jewish holocaust and serbia. Lots of pictures.
Good idea. Small museum and not much to see, but again this here is not commercial and gives some people a little hope in a bad world

Surprisingly good. In particular, if you have not had any exposure yet on your trip to details of the Khmer Rouge and the lengthy civil war in Cambodia's past, this would be a valuable visit. A touching story of the creation of the museum and the ongoing work centered here on landline removal and care of orphans, there are also good displays explaining why the landline problem exists in Cambodia as well as other areas of the world. By googling "Aki Ra CNN hero" you could probably find a video clip that would help you understand a bit about the man behind the museum.

this museum is worth a short visit. If you have time, this museum is worth a short visit. See it in conjunction with your tours of Angkor Wat. What is more interesting than the museum is the work of the people who have founded it. The services that they provide to those who have been landmine victims is more significant than the museum itself.

Let the teenage boys see this. I see some teenagers, esp. boys, like to talk about guns and bombs in jest sometimes. Here is a place for them to face reality on why they should not kid around such matters. The horror of war involving child soldiers, the landlines that ruin lives by maiming, the courage of people who tried to demine ,.....etc. are all teaching moments. My son was horrifed to hear that the were still 3 million mines in Cambodia. He was happy to hear that UN has banned landlines and we had a discussion on why China, Russia, and US have n signed the accord.
Great Story. Stopped there as it was raining that day. Interesting story. Movie would be too long, but that we couldn't be outside anyway.

Important for all travelers to Siem Reap to see!. I think that this is a must see for all travelers to Siem Reap; it is a rather small exhibit, but provides great information on the brutal history of Cambodia and the on-going problems with landmines. The Khmer people have been through so much horror, and it is easy to forget this when you are waltzing through the beautiful temple complexes. This museum puts it all in perspective a bit; also, the founder, has taken in many landmine victim children who live behind the museum, and at the museum you are able to make donations for them and for the organization, which I highly recommend doing. On Wednesdays, there are no guided tours; I would recommend going on a different day, as a guided tour would be helpful.

Ugh! totally worthwhile and enlightening. It will open your mind to how bad it really is and what a compassionate person looks like.-I felt awful and inspired.-definitely swing by if you check out Bantay Srei. -Not worth the drive alone. You need too have other activities in the region planned-very small but very informative-LOTS to read but it can be a quick in and out if you don't have much time -$3.00 at the door goes to help fund their mission - a great thing to support!

Very Interesting.. What a horror story land mines are in Cambodia, but how uplifting to know a single ex-soldier has dedicated his life to ridding the country of this nightmare, so rural people, can tend to their land, without losing life or limb. A story that needs to be told. A story that needs to be heard.

very enlightening. Amazing and so sad history lesson in the pre and post Vietnam/Pol Pot era. So many mines and countless horrific injuries as a result of the mines. Great job of CSHD in removing and demining areas to prevent further injuries and deaths.

Please stop by!. As others have noted the museum is small. What makes it worthwhile is the powerful history behind it. Today Cambodia is very peaceful. But 30-40 years ago it was simply hell in a very small place. The museum displays stacks and stacks of disarmed bombs and mines. Aki-Ra's NGO not only de-mines as they still kill/maim people today but also supports education in the remote areas. Ask for Bill Morse as he tells the Aki-Ra story very eloquently.

Definitely worth a visit!. It is a Cambodian NGO, run by and for Cambodians, established in 1997 by ex-child soldier Aki Ra. After years of fighting he returned to the villages in which he planted thousands of mines and began removing them, by hand, and defusing them with homemade tools. In 2008 he established a formal demining NGO, Cambodian Self Help Demining (CSHD) - a separate NGO from the Museum, which clears landmines in small villages throughout the country.The Museum hosts a Relief Facility for at-risk village children.
