The money raised by the museum allows this facility to continue. At the present time (late 2012) the Museum supports a community of nearly 75 men, women, and children.This is a small museum, but definitely worth a visit, especially if you are going to Banteay Srei. It's on the way and only $3 donation to visit. Not only is it informative and interesting, it is very inspiring to see how one man has faught to make his country a better place and how one man can make a difference.

Something to ponder..... Travelled to the museum from our hotel by tuk tuk. Nice trip on good roads. The museum is very sobering, it brings to your attention how much of Cambodia was actually bombed and mined in the last 40 years. I do suggest getting a guide to walk through with you, as we didn't but followed a group who did, and they give you so much more information and history. The group still de-mining areas are doing such a great job. Can't help but do a donation whilst there.

Small museum, but interesting. This is a small museum, but does give you an insight into the Landmine's and decades of war Cambodia has suffered. It is only approximately $2 US to visit and has some worthwhile souvenirs you can purchase which supports their program's and school etc. To visit some of the temples ou drive right past it, so you might as well stop, it's worth the visit!

Educational. Worth a visit if it is on your way to or from a temple visit. It is very educational and gives you another reality check as to how bad the poor people had it! It is also great to see how many people got involved and helped!

Knew little when we arrived, left much wiser.... Our travel tour guide for Siem Reap (Sopheap Prem) asked if we wanted to stop at the museum after our out of town visit to Lady Temple. We thought 'why not', and we were really glad we did. This NGO is run by Aki Ra, a self-taught de-miner, who, barely more than a boy, was forced to lay the mines as a Vietnamese conscript. After seeing the damage caused by these awful tools of war, it became his mission to rid his country of all land mines. He has personally destroyed about 50,000 of them. We were lucky enough to have an ex-US army sergeant who now works for the organisation visiting at the time, and got a personal tour of the museum. His commentary and the answers he gave to our many questions made this visit extremely interesting. There are still millions of land mines in Cambodia to find and destroy. Their mission is not to de-mine the land as much as release farming lands back to the people so they can eke out a living.

Excellent Museum - a must see. I wasn't sure what to expect but this museum is very informative, well laid out and has a variety of things to see. It is a sobering experience but if you are interested in what life has been like for so many Cambodians then you should pay this a visit. there is a lot of good work being done here and we should all support it.

Very interesting worth the visit. Mostly static displays and a bit run down but definetly worth the visit. Some of the information and pictures are confronting but this is part of the reality of this country and lots of others around the world.

Great work, museum just ok. The work of the owner is fantastic and needs support of us all. The museum is interesting, a bit dusty and with faded information and photos. Anyway, it is money well spent.

Eye opening experience -well worth a visit. This is a small museum, and tells the story of land mines in Cambodia and generally around the world from a very personal perspective. Mr. Morse was there, and his explanation and guided "tour" of the museum made it very informative and compelling. His commitment and the commitment of Aki Ra is what makes this place special. Love that it helps children injured by the mines, and to hear how they help each other and the success they are seeing in making a good life for themselves is heartwarming and inspiring.Highly recommend.
Do stop and view. Tells the story of the boy that used to be in the army used his knowledge of land mines to help clear some of the 6,000,000. Built an orphanage to help some of the victims.

Cambodian History. While it is a 30 plus minute drive to the museum it is worth a visit. Set up by Aki Ra (a child soldier) the museum is part of a Cambodian NGO that assists children impacted by landmines. The museum is informative and provides a good historical background. Take the time to go and on the drive back there is time to reflect on how lucky you are. Support the cause at the same time
A sad reality, please help!. A glimpse of history and human madness. One hour of sad thoughts to put things into perspective and understand a little of the past of this unfortunate Country

Good to see - try to support this worthy cause. This was a good place to visit and get some insight into the ongoing problem of land mines in Cambodia. Fairly small but informative. If you can, donate a few dollars to the charity that looks after children affected by land mines.With a 10 year old, we didn't want to do the killing fields in PP, but found this a great place to carefully discuss the brutal history of Cambodia without scaring him too much.Keep up the good work!
Emotional visit. Great work in this small museum. It is good that they show the harm that landmines have made to a country as Cambodia, and good to see people working hard to get rid of them.

An interesting a thought provoking experience. I won't repeat the history as it is already on here and in the museum - that you must visit. You need to have the time and patience to read a lot of the information, but the staff are full of info so they'll be happy to walk you round and tell you about it. The man who started it and today continues to work for the Cambodian people, training mine disposal teams and houses many orphans, is incredible. It needs your support - please go.

Sobering and thought provoking. The museum was set up by a person who laid land mines as a child soldier with the Kymer Rouge, and who, as an adult, has worked to rid Cambodia of landmines. He has received a lot of recognition for this work. He is now using income from the museum to support a number of children who have been orphaned due to landmines. Very informative, and very reasonably priced entrance fee. Example of landmines from many different armies eg Russian, US, English .There is a shop there, but they only do cash sales. Items on sale include brass jewellery made from mines and bullets, which is beautiful but relatively expensive. I am sure sales (and therefore revenue) would increase if they accepted credit cards.

Add some recent history to Angkor visit. First, know that this a homemade, labour of love exhibit (museum might be overstating it). But that's absolutely what makes it worthwhile -- it's personal, and it's a working refuge for children in need. Combined with the ancient history of Angkor, it offers important perspective on Cambodia's recent past. At just $3 to enter, and a couple bucks more if you want to buy a souvenir from the shop, you can't beat the price. The self-guided written tour (English version, at least) is adequate if you miss one of the guided tours. Our guide had not planned to stop here, but I asked and it's easily accessible on your way to Banteay Srei; I recommend adding it to your itinerary.

Be prepared to cry. This is a true but sad legacy of the Khmer Rouge daysThe controversy lasted until late into the 1990's and the maimed people who survived it are evident on the streets of Siem ReapThey are the ones who truly need your help!

Very Informative and a great cause. My wife and I visited the Cambodia Landmine Museum on advice from our tour guide and are very happy we did. The museum tells the story of its amazing founder, Akira. He, his staff and their team do incredible work for the people and children of Cambodia. The museum sheds light on the history and the continuing problem of landmines and unexploded ordinance. The museum houses, educates and cares for more than 3 dozen children. It creates awareness of how big of a problem anti-personnel landmines continue to be, and their team goes around to rural areas clearing areas of land of landmines.

A Remarkable Museum and Not What I Expected. I avoided visiting this museum on my first trip to Siem Reap, because I thought it would be just another pile of glorious military junk. But it was far from it. The museum is constructed around the life experience of a man who suffered the horrors of the Pol Pot regime at first hand, and who has dedicated his life to removing the plague of land mines that the regime bequeathed to Cambodia.You are not invited to gloat at displays of military technology. What you see is a well-documented display of land mines and their effects - in all their horror and obscenity. What struck me most was how sordid the whole business is - to think that governments are still manufacturing these devices and businesses are still making money from them.I had also expected displays of victims and wounds. There were almost none. There was absolutely nothing self-indulgent or self-pitying. This museum does not dwell on the past. Its real purpose is to focus on the future, and on how to tackle to enduring danger of the mines.I found the museum a chastening and inspiring experience, and I would like to record my admiration for the founder and wish him well in his work.

A moving experience. Visiting this museum is very humbling, as you see the troubles the Khmer people had to go through during and even decades after the war. It is an important part of their history and kudos to its founder, Aki Ra, who started it all by painstakingly looking for the landmines to protect his fellowmen.
Worth a visit. Good exhibition explaining the use of anti personnel mines in Cambodia. Inspiring story of the founder Aki Ra. $3 entrance fee.

landmine museum. It was started by a former Khmer Rouse child soldier who ran away and has devoted himself to destroying landmines and helping victims. I found it very moving, interesting and important. It was short and on the way to temples.

Inspiring. Take time out from the temple visits to support this worthy cause. The museum is very informative and strives to maintain awareness of the terrible legacy of landmines in Cambodia, whilst providing help to some of the victims. The atmosphere is very positive despite the threats and challenges which landmines continue to present.
A very sobering experience;. Well worth a short visit if only to try comprehend the holocaust experienced by Cambodians during the Khmer Rouge period, and the aweful impact of landmines

Well worth a visit. We found our visit here to be well worth while and informative. The founder of this museum was once a child soldier with the Khmer Rouge and was responsible for laying many mines himself. After Pol Pot's regime of terror finally came to an end, he returned to the area and began finding and defusing these land mines - the basis of the exhibition we can see today. Proceeds from the museum help support the adjacent school and its range of programmes for children (a number of major donors - including Renee Zelwegger - also support this facility financially). Although quite a long way out of Siem Reap, a stop at the museum can easily be combined with a visit to Banteay Srei temple. (Also make time to stop off and buy a few containers of palm sugar from one of the many roadside stalls in this area. Freshly prepared, it's soft, warm, and tastes just like fudge!)

Visit to the LANDMINE MUSEUM. We visited the Landmine Museum outside Siem Reap, Cambodia today. This nonprofit organization not only has exhibits and displays that remind of us of the horror and inhumanity of landmines, they mentor disabled people, giving them housing and job training. Given the nature of the exhibits, it is uplifting and hopeful to see the progress in the lives of the people this wonderful organization is able to help. Highly recommend a visit.
Small, not what I expected. Very small, but informative museum. Looks like the founder put it together and it's a side bar to the phalange behind.

An Incredible Story - past and future.... The vestibule and the centre of the museum is full of landmines Akira has deactivated himself, a truly inspirational man. Run completely by Khmers this museum now supports 37 children, either from disadvantaged backgrounds or landmine victims as well as continuing the work of Cambodian Self Help Demining (CSHD). The 4 rooms clearly describe Cambodia's and Akira's entwined history giving the reader a deeper understanding of what has happened in the recent past. There was no preaching, no boasting and no righteous indignation, just a group of people who are all working towards a collective goal.If you are going out to Banteay Srei, there is absolutely NO reason why you shouldn't stop for 1 hour of your day here, in fact go anyway it's closer! At only $3 it's a steal. You may even bump into one of the organisers and have a good chat as we did.

Go see it. Informative, interesting. Only $3 (proceeds to go landmine victims). Don't understand why it isn't more crowded. This place is run by a former Khmer Rouge soldier who used to place the landmines and now works to demine as well as aid landmine victims. The stories, movie, and exhibits are extremely informative as well as heartbreaking. Take a break from seeing temples and go see it.

Hmm. LIKE: An innocence to the place - says it as it is without thought to whether it sounds like bravado or boasting.DISLIKE: It depressed me to see all the bombs and mines and other ways humans mess up each others lives.
Cambodia Landmine Museum. A good place for the tourist to aware about landmine in Cambodia and how war has destroy the harmony and nature of a country.

Important musuem to visit, eye opener. If you are interested in the history of cambodia and learn about one of the main challenges still faced by the country, this is an important place to visit. It was a real eye opener and we were enlightened to learn about this situation and what we can do to help.

Interesting piece of history. This is very interesting but left me feeling very bereft. How can we do these things to one another? Wonderful how this man had a conscious and helped his countrymen. Better to love one another than make war.

Heartbreaking, interesting and the most worthy few dollars to give. Initially you walk in and think it so small and ramshackle that you'll be just a minute in here.But when you start to read about the stories you get quite absorbed.It's not just about people with no limbs etc its about the history of how so many came about, the wars pre Pol Pot and during, the ongoing task of demining etc.its really worthwhile and for a few dollars to get in, when you see where the money goes, you will be wanting to put more int he donation box s you leave.This is on the road to Bantey Srei, so worth combining both, also a hort turn iff away in Bantre Samre which is also lovely.We used a car for these 3 sites as it is a far distance and I think that was a good choice rather than being ina tuk tuk all the way out there.

Powerful learning expereince. This is a must do to really understand more about how Cambodia was impact , especially by the USA and Vietnam. Also give, or donate things to help support the work that they continue to do.
Landmine museum worth a visit. This museum was probably worth a visit, but if you are short of time dont bother. Same goes for the Butterfly Garden (both on way to Banteay Shrei).

Interesting museum! bring supplies for the kids in the school. We stopped on the way to Bantey Srey temple at the landmine museum. Def worth having a look.The museum is small but shows you how the owner worked the last 20+ years? to clear Cambodia from its vicious mines. They also support a school and landmine victims. What caught my eye entering the museum is that need lots of supplies for supporting the local kids and schools. They had a flyer asking for pens, paper, pencils, toothbrushes and any school supplies really. Wish we knew that before we came so we could have brought some things that they can use!

eye-opening!. One of the better stops in Siem Reap. Very informative about the landmine situation in the world and a great story about how one person can make a difference. It's a social and political education not found at the war museum.

A moving insight into cambodian history. Lots of excellent information, although the layout was sometimes a little confusing. Good explanations of the background to landmines in Cambodia and the history of the region. Inspiring story of how individuals can make a difference both in working to eliminate unexploded landmines and in providing a chance for young people.

An essential stop while at Siem Reap. This is a small museum but so touching in many ways it has to be an essential stop when you are in Siem Reap. It only takes less than an hour to visit but will give you so much insight into the continuing effects of Cambodia's history and the potential horrifying danger that the people are still living with today. Make sure you read the stories of the children who now live at the museum. It is a very easy stop on the way to or from the Banteay Srey Temple. You will see it from the road.

very important stop. We stopped at the museum during a temple tour.The museum is set up in a very thoughtful and interesting way.There are rooms that show the mines and others that have the stories of the victims.On one side very upsetting on the other there is a clear message of hope for a better future.It is important to stop at the place to show support for this very important mission.The explanations in English are very concise and clear

Extremely Interesting. If you can get a guide to show you around and explain things - it is very helpful. The work that Aki Ra is doing is so commendable and the programs that he has set up to help local children are really incredible. This is a very educational and terrific place to visit.

Worth a visit. Aki Ra is a mine clearer and opened his museum in 1999. We first visited in 2006 when the museum was very simple, just a corrugated iron building, some rickety sheds plus open air eating and sleeping quarters. This museum has now moved and is located on the road to Banteay Srey.  As a young child Aki parents were killed and he spent years in various armies, fighting with the Khmer Rouge, then against them. One thing he learnt all about was Mines.In 1993 Aki worked with the UN clearing mines, this was a good time in his life as he also had the opportunity to go to school and study, so life took a turn for the better. Once the UN left, Aki kept clearing mines and amassing a huge collection of guns, bombs, mines etc. This collection is now the Cambodia Land Mine Museum.    Aki and his wife Hourt have 2 sons, they also have a small group of children who are land mine victims living with them. The children are supported and sent to school by the Museum. Sadly Hourt died on April 14th 2009, she was only 28 years old.There is now a small charge to see the museum and a small shop there where you can buy drinks, books, T Shirts etc but I do not think it was a good as the original museum which had a lot more displays and less text information.

Thought provoking experience. We stopped at the museum on the way back from Banteay Srei (and we also had to be back in Siem Reap in the afternoon for another excursion) and so our visit was a bit rushed. However, what we did see and learn gave us a fascinating insight into Cambodian history and what the Cambodian people have had to endure over such a long period of time. We found the displays very informative and have complete admiration for the guy (a former child soldier) who set up this museum and has also had so much involvement in de-mining Cambodia. Please take time out to make a visit here and donate whatever you are able to afford.

Very unsettling - must see. This doesn't take long to see, it's a stop on the way to or from something else. But, it's a museum that you must see while in Siem Reap. It's impossible to really understand what life must have been like for the last half a century in Cambodia, but this small museum will crack the window on a slice. It's not a good slice.

learn about what is still going on with landmines. It shows what landmines do today to the local people and how this museum helps the children of these tragedys because there are still lots of landmines around which maim and kill people every year

Disappointing. If you know the story, there's not much to add. But if you don't, you might like it better. Far from the city, but close to the wonderful Banteay Srei. If you are going to that temple, a little stop at the museum may must be considered. Very cheap.
impressive. A special kind of museum - landmines and rockets, all deactivated by the founder of the museum. Very impressive.

Average but... compared to the phnom penh landmine museum, it's smaller. and although there wasnt much space to roam around, the mueum was very informative for me. The life of Aki Ra even moved me. It's worth visiting to see how one man made a difference for his country :)

Ok museum. Actually the museum is fine but i think we got a little disapointed, maybe because last week we visited the COPE visitor center in Vientiane, Loas, which is much better than this. But the museum has a lot to show, it is just a pitty that there are so much text instead of showing the thing in another way. But definitely a good course which should be supported!

Grounding. This was an excellent introduction to the tragic history and suffering that the Cambodian people have endured. Also a good way to contribute to a the clearing efforts and to support the refuge for children who have been affected by land mines, which is on the premises of the museum. The drive to the museum through rural areas was also very nice. This can be easily included on the way back from some of the temples.

Thought Provoking. This is a small and a long way from town.Best if you make it part of the Temple Tours.We didn't want to got to the Killing Fields or the genocide Memorial ,but wanted to pay our respects to the Khmer People.So many have and are still being injured by Landmines .Donate Generously,

powerful, ernest, must-see!. This little museum should not be missed! Take a lovely tuk-tuk ride out there past small villages and beautiful countryside and temples, or add the stop onto your temple tours. Staff was very friendly, professional and helpful. The exhibits and artwork are very moving and memorable.

An important reminder of Cambodian history. An interesting series of exhibits showing the effects of landmines, some of their history globally, the history of their use in Cambodia and the work going on to "demine" the land.
I was horrified to discover that USA has not signed up top any of the anti-landmine treaties. Any US citizens reading this please start lobbying your Government!

Excellent and eye opening. Excellent small museum. Worth seeing. We were aware of some of Cambodia's history but seeing the work that has gone on here this was quite an eye opener and very inspiring. It's definitely worth taking an hour out from visiting temples to get an idea of the more recent history and what people are doing today.
Great guide. Very fortunate to have heard one of the founders of the museum taking a group around. He had the group hanging on every word and he was very passionate about his work in mine clearing.

Really great visit here. I would definitely recommend this place while in Siem Reap as I think its important to learn and see a different and very important side of the history here. The members and directors of the museum do amazing community work. A must in SR.

Outstanding History. This place is excellent for learning a bit about the history of the conflicts in SE Asia that aren't focused on much in the US. They've done an excellent job with this little museum.

unbelievable. after never seeing what a landmine etc looks like this was a true eye opener. with a grandson in the airforce due to go away it really brings to mind what the armed forces are up against everyday by choice. we should commend our forces for not allowing this type of thing to happen to us tucked up safely at home. many thanks for the insight .

Amazing story of a man's efforts. The museum is small, but the story is fascinating. Make sure you take time to watch the video that tells the man's story. The visit shouldn't take more than an about an hour. The museum didn't have many visitors while I was there & it does seem a bit neglected. However, the importance of the work makes the visit worthwhile.

very few visitors. We stopped off here after visiting Banteay Saray and it was like being on a differant planet. I am very much in favor of the work that they do here with sponsoring the children who have become victims of landmines and I thought it was a shame that there were not more visitors. However the museum had a slightly neglected air about it. I am not saying that they need to go out and spend thousands of dollars but a little bit of care would make a great differance.

A must see to learn about Cambodia's hardships. This is a small museum located on the road to Banteay Srei , Phnom Kulen, Kbal Spean and the Animal Conservation Centre. Small but loads of information. It was put together by an ex-child soldier whose life is a sad sad tale but he has done amazing work de-mining Cambodia. If you leave this country without learning of the genocide by the Khmer Rouge and the Landmine crisis you have done Cambodians an injustice. Only $3 entry. A small shop with goods to purchase which help fund the work of this organization (still millions of mines to clear!). Behind the museum is a complex which houses children affected my landmines and educates them (not open to public) all funded by the same man (and kind donations).

Small, but good to see.. En route Banteay Srei, this is a very small museum. reminds you what this horrible thing did to poor farmers, animals. Go on the way as you ll be tired if you think of visiting on the way back. Lot of curios shops on the road, very friendly & simple vendors. I bought a few items seeing their attitude. take a stop to help those good people.

Lasting Impression. The Cambodian Landmine Museum and Facility was our last stop before heading to the airport. I'm so glad we managed to spend some time there. The land mine exhibit quietly explains the relatively recent Cambodian war tragedy and the lasting legacy of land mines that still plague the countryside and villages. The museum was founded by Aki Ra a former child soldier to promote awareness and establish a base for himself and a small staff that are involved daily in searching out unexploded land mines and clearing them. He has also established a relief facility for children affected by land mines. The children are raised and educated in a safe, loving environment. The museum and facility are dependent on donations. Stop in for a visit, it's a great way to learn about Cambodian history and help some very dedicated people make a difference.

heart breaking-a quiet modern day hero. The museum is a heartbreaking insight into a current horror that is a blight on the international conscience--where are all the countries that planted these 20 million mines in the first place? The presentation is quiet, not overly dramatized and very powerful.Aki Ra is a quiet modern day hero by any definition. The museum will ensure you stay on the "beaten paths" in Cambodia--is worth the visit and is really worth supporting however you can.

Sobering and an educational experience.. Cried at the stupidity of these weapons and how they continue to kill, maim and destroy families. Small but powerful museum, felt like I had to do something about the insanity of these weapons, a true killer of the most innocent. Lot of blame to go around, Russia, China and the USA...stop making mines as a tool of war.

Very well done. The landmine museum is a must see. I appreciated that I was allowed to walk through at my own pace and nobody ever bother me or tried to sell me anything. The displays are well done and the statistics are something everyone should be aware of. I highly recommend this stop on your temple tromp.
A significant place. It's hard not to visit Cambodia without a trip to see the impact of the land-mines. The exhibits tell the tale.
Thought provoking. Well worth a visit if you want to know more about the sad and relatively recent history of Cambodia and the impact of mines and unexploded ordnance on its people.

Essential. A samll museum with a big impact. A reminder of another side to this amazing country and it's painful history. It is sure to move you when you see the evil weapons and read the stories of what they have done and can still do.

Interesting view of history. We decided to visit this museum and we were glad we did. Quite a bit of information to read, but an interesting and important part of Cambodia's recent and ongoing history.If you are in the area it is worth an hour or so to visit the museum and the entrance donation helps keeps this important centre open.

Worth seeing just to provide a level of understanding.. It does teach you the terrible history of landmines in Cambodia but seems to place a great deal of emphasis on fund raising. I found it to be a good place to explain to a child why there were so many people in Cambodia who had been unfortunate enough to experience this crisis.

Well worth the trip. I like museums that are small and manageable, especially when I'm travelling with my kids! This one fits the bill perfectly. It was interesting and educational, and moving. It's a tragic story, but told from a hopeful perspective, so not downright depressing.We didn't take the good advice about combining it with a visit to Banteay Srei, so made the trip out there twice. Best fun is to do it in two tuk tuks (if there are 5 of you) and let the natural competitiveness of the drivers turn it into a race. (Not much traffic on the road, so it never felt too dangerous!) All in all, a good trip.

Interesting but frightening. The museum also is a charity, the sad thing about this place is the amount of munitions and mines dropped and laid in Cambodia and the fact that the countries who make these horrible devices are not held accountable and made to clean the mess up.

A break from all the temples. I really wanted to visit this museum to learn more about Cambodia and catch a break from all the temples. Didn't want to suffer temple fatigue.It was worth the trip. Since it's a bit far from the town, schedule your visit together with a visit to Banteay Srei.
sobering. very interesting display , a terrible legacy left , seems crazy that it all happened and caused so much pain for nothing
Learned a lot!. Our guide took us here, and we found it to be so interesting and educational. Definitely a must see!

Interesting and confronting. This museum is very informative. You learn about the countries which have signed the Anti-mine treaty and the number of mines available in the world. Interesting and worthwhile a visit.

The museum is worth a visit. The museum itself isn't anything exciting, but gives you another perspective of how war has plagued humanity. We took a tuk tuk to the museum and saw beautiful country life. Stopped and bought some home made palm sugar candy. Yummy! The owner works on demining the countryside. Horrific amounts of landmines still exist. Also runs an orphanage and they have a wish list, if you are so inclined to donate. They do not allow tourists to contact the children there.

Haunting experience. Very confronting experience - lots of sad stories of kids who live in the relief centre there and so many land mines. The man who runs the museum was a former child soldier with the Khmer Rouge who laid many landmine and now devotes his life to demining the country. A very interesting place and a welcome break from all the temples. Combine with a trip to Banteay Srei.

Interesting. An informative look at how this atrocity has affected Cambodia. Has a great facility at the rear that is helping victims of UXO's. after everything this country has gone through farmers still need to be cautious. An interesting place to visit well worth your time.

One Man's Work. This small museum showcases one person's efforts to clear land mines and to publicize the effects of these weapoms. That said, there's not a lot to see. However, these weapons ahve left a terrible legacy and they continue to cause injuries and death in various parts of the country

Great insight. Small museum well worth visiting to get a good insight into the Khmer Rouge and landmines. Tickets are $3 and money goes back into the museum. Children (of landmine disasters) live at the museum and there is a wish list including soap, toothbrushes, sporting equipment, pens, paper etc so if you have spare soaps etc in your hotel it may pay to take them with you to the museum. Overall a good way to spend an hour.

Very informative. Smallish although very informative museum on the landmine situation in Cambodia (both past and present). Lots of details on the different mines as well as information on de-mining techniques. A sombre topic but definitely worth a look and helps support their onsite Landmine Relief Facility.

Go here if you want to understand why landmines need to be outlawed. A small museum set up by a dedicated former Khmer Rouge soldier who has dedicated his life to eradicating landmines from his country. The museum provides stark reminders of the horrors of war and the need to ban landmines and prevent their use in conflict zones.
Scary stuff!. The landline museum is yet another reminder of the horrors of war. Go there and help the victims of land mines.

Interesting visit, supporting a wonderful cause. It's not the biggest or most impressive museum you will visit, but it does a great job in setting the chronological scene of how so many landmines came to be in Cambodia and what is being done to clear them, and how that is being done.We combined our visit with a visit to the Bantaey Srei temple and spent about 40 minutes at the museum. Both visits together make it a lovely half day tour from Siem ReapThe drive out to this part of the country from Siem Reap is really quite scenic, making you think even more about the awful unnecessary destruction landmines can cause to so many innocent individuals. Equally, many of those unfortunate individuals live in a country where medical facilities and care costs money that most people don't have... I am priviliged to live in a society where the majority of us are able to freely roam around our local countryside without the concern of being injured through no fault of our own. A visit to this museum with it's small entrance fee of just a few dollars helps them to continue their charitable cause to rid Cambodia of landmines. It's all about the gesture, rather than how "impressive" the museum is. I also bought a very pretty, good quality scarf from their on-site shop for a very reasonable $3 to further support their cause. The little shop sells t-shirts, purses, scarves etcThey are doing an amazing job, long may it continue with everyone's support.

A history lesson. Amazing to see the landmines up close and personal . Never thought somehing as big as a few inches can cause so much damage to a man. The museum is a bit out of the way but worth seeing.

overwhelming. this place will show you all about the land mines and stir you up inside. It is educational and i believe the funds go to the charities to help victims of land mines. Its out of town but worth a visit.
A true hero. What an inspirational story, humbling! Take the time to visit if you're passing & look on their website 1st for a list of things you can easily take them, pencils, soap, toothbrush etc

Excellent Museum!. The Cambodia Landmine Museum is worth every penny of the $6 you will spend to walk around and learn about the work this gentleman has done to properly defuse land mines across Cambodia. Its a small museum but it is done very well and its such a great educational experience for anyone visiting Cambodia.

A very sad story. It is so sad to walk around the museum and read all about the land mines, the damage they have done, the lives they have extinguished or mutilated - thank goodness good people are working hard to remove these awful mines.

Thoughtful place. If you have time, this museum is worth a short visit. See it in conjunction with your tours of Angkor Wat. What is more interesting than the museum is the work of the people who have founded it. The services that they provide to those who have been landmine victims is more significant than the museum itself. If you can, make a donation so that their work may continue.

landmine museum. took a tuk tuk from siem out to the landmine museum,through the angkor archealogical park was a good ride very picturesque.is a small musuem and a solem reminder of the recent history in cambodia,great to see the work being done by some extraordinary people who are helping to make there local community a safer place,donation boxes and an information outlet are available for anyone wanting to help support their cause

a moving experience. the museum is small and less impressive than I thought it would be. i am glad i didn;t travel there by tuk tuk. having said that it was interesting to learn how the land mine museum funds are being used to support victims of land mines

A sense of hope. This is very informative museum. We learned a lot about the recent history of Cambodia and the legacy of war and conflict in the country. This place is a must if you want to learn about the country. You soon learn how difficult it is for ordinary people to go about their everyday lives in some parts of Cambodia. Clearing mines and unexploded ordnance is never ending and the centre does a great job in supporting the clearance operation as well as raising awareness of the problem.
Touching stories. Worth a trip to get an understanding of the war that affected the region. Bill was very helpful with the tour.

Make an effort to stop by here. This is a moving and interesting place which is not only a museum, but a great cause too. In open air casual displays overloaded with information you learn about the war, the landmines, the current situation and what they are doing about it. We had some school supplies we wanted to donate and were able to meet the director when we did. He explained so much more and told us about the projects the group is working on including building schools in places that were so heavily mined, they didn't exist. Our guide didn't want to go in with us, it seemed too upsetting for him, but try to go to learn something and help them out.
very moving and humbling experience. take shampoos,shower gel,soaps and toothbrushes for the little ones, paper , pencils .. anything that the children can usebring hankies

A must see if only for a good cause. This place isn't a built-up magnificent experience like some museums can be, it is plain and simple, yet it carries a powerful message. Cambodia was a place ravaged by violence at one time in the not so distant past, and they are still recovering. Clearing explosives from their countryside is a big part of that recovery. Educate yourself and contribute if you can. Talk to some of the staff there too.

Fascinating museum to be combined with another trip. Visited here after having already been to war museums in Saigon and Hanoi, and the UXO centre in Luang Prabang, and still think this was a brilliant visit. At first glance it seems to be a museum about the man who made the museum, but it is a lot more than that and he seems to deserve it anyway. A very inspiring individual. When you go, make sure you pick up one of the free laminated guides available in the first room. This gives you much more information and context. However, it is a good distance into the park so I was glad we combined it with visits to the lady temple and river carvings.

Great museum. The personal stories that are told in this museum make it worth visiting. Land mines have ruined the lives of many Cambodians and this museum helps you to understand how and why they have been used in the past and contiune to be used. Some of the money from visiting this museum goes towards supporting families who are victims of land mines. We combined a visit here with a trip to Bantrea sri and Kbal spean.

Short visite. It's a nice, very small museum but it's founded by a former soldier. He did a great job telling his story and the story of others. By visiting the museum you help him and the people who live there.

Heart wrenching.. Worth the visit, but be prepared for horror stories. Its disgusting what the country has had to endure. With this set up it gives us all hope that the country and the people have come through this awful war and are keen to make the country safe for the people and foreign tourists too. Make a donation buy something its all so cheap to us westerners and it will make a difference there.
Don't miss this. This is well worth a visit as the issue of landmines is one that is still with us. A small donation will go far.
Very informative. Quite a lot of information packed into this little museum and worth the trip. Im not a "war" sort of person but i found it interesting.
Most touching in Cambodia. The museum is easy to access and for me it was the highlight during a four days visit to Siem Reap. I knew little in advance but have now taken revenge.

Very, very interesting!. This was one of the few museums I have been that I read almost all the material they had available inside. The story of the museum and the life of Aki Ra are very interesting and definitely worth a visit. Do it together with a visit to the Banteay Srei temple, which is also worthy it.

Don't leave Siem Reap without having been there. If you are interested in more than the ancient landmarks, but also want to learn about the current Cambodia, this is a great place to learn how the more recent history shaped what you see today and it links it into the present. The subject mater is a sad and cruel topic, but it is also sharing a positive story of how people can make a difference - and how you can help.
A must do. Besides enjoying the ultimate beauty of the Angkor temples everyone should find time to visit this place that reflects the very dark side of Cambodian history.

Worth a visit. The subject matter of this museum is tough, but the story it tells is a positive one, of amazing people, and a country moving forwards. Well worth taking the time to visit, and the tuk tuk ride out through the countryside is a delight in itself as well.

Off the beaten track gem. This place was way off the usual tourist trail but combined with trip to Bantreay Srei it was a great eye opener into the tragic landline epidemic. The story of this man and his Helpers was amazing
Well worth a visit. Many might not want to make a special visit, but if you are passing nearby this is a must do salutory experience
Humbling. This is a true museum, meaning very little structure, but a lot of substance. I would strongly recommend seeing this to get a glimpse of the horrors so recently experienced by Cambodians.
Well done Diana. The museum was user-friendly, interesting, cost-efective and well laid out. All attendants spoke good English and it explained the horror behind the solumn and awful history fully.
Worthwhile. Very well done and educational, surprisingly non-biased. All proceeds towards the orphanage attached.

Great museum, lots of exhibits, good video to watch. Interesting museum, lots of very interesting information
Entry was 3US p,p, Tuk-tuk was 18 return (for up to 4 people, ask then to wait)
Clearly a very dedicated individual who set this museum up.

Do not miss this on trip to Angkor Wat. We are a family of five and dropped by this museum on way back from Banteay Srei. It is incredibly moving and worth the time to understand the incredible work happening to clear landmines from Cambodia. The story of its founder, Aki Ra, a former child soldier who has dedicated his life to removing mines as well as helping kids whose lives have been impacted, makes the museum that much more incredible and compelling. Learning about the modern day Cambodia is a perfect complement to seeing the centuries-old Khmer temples. Do not miss!

A sobering museum that should not be missed. This is a tribute to a man who has dedicated his life to ridding the country of its land mines. It is an wakening museum that gives one a glimpse into how a war can effect generations of innocent children and adults. It is worth spending an hour here. You may leave as a different person.

A Must!. It really is worth taking time from the Wats to visit this little museum with such a huge tale to tell. It is a very thought provoking place and you certainly will be thinking of the things you've seen and read about for a long time afterwards.

Excellent experience, well worth the ride out to see and hear the stories.. Aki Ra's and other stories as well as what the foundation is doing for land mine victims and the work they support to continue clearing land mines is inspirational and impressive. It is well worth taking the time to talk with the staff and learn about the stories and displays. Another review mentioned that it is low tech and this is true, they operate on a budget since they also support land mine victims and other at-risk kids in Cambodia as well as working toward the goal of a landline-free Cambodia. That doesn't make it any less compelling. There is very interesting artwork done by the children who had been affected that blew me away. This is a bit outside Siem Reap city but well worth the Tuk Tuk or taxi ride.
A must see. My husband and I visited the museum and I was overwhelmed with the tour guide and his story. Amazing collection of artefacts and stories

Small and old style. Was a bit disappointed by the extent of the museum. I think there are only four rooms located around the central display of mines. Also the museum was very old fashioned... use of modern technology (interactive displays, video on demand, audio commentary etc) could have made it a richer experience. I went with my daughter but there was nothing I could use to safely engage her with information without scaring her to death! I think educating kids about mines and explosives needs doing, but there was nothing I could see that was targeting children's education there. The price of admission was fine and worth it (good cause too). The shop was pretty poor and small, I bought a few items but would have bought more if there were more choices. Finally all of the staff were indeed excellent, smart, friendly and approachable. If anything the people here make the place worthwhile. Overall pretty average, especially on the education front. As a kid I played near mines and saw a few up close and had a few close calls so I know the need for education at a museum like this!

Worth it. The museum is not very big but the story behind it is! Ask for a guide and your tour will be worth twice the money! You also get to hear about what the museum does for orphans and ill children, very moving!

gruesome attraction, but necessary work being done. Westerners consider a war is over when television and newspapers stop reporting on a Third World conflict. Over the past three decades, thousands of Cambodian civilians have been maimed or killed by explosives left behind by the Americans and Vietnamese. This quiet little museum explains the work that is being done - and the people who continue to suffer - because of military/political decisions made in other countries back in the 1950s.
Exceptional. Mind blowing, Aki Ra is an inspiration to all of us and what he has achieved is truelly remarkable. Another must see for any visitor to SIem Reap

A moving location. This was a very sad but inspirational Museum to visit to understand the history of Cambodia and understand the devestation that has been bought onto it's people by the activities of other nations...

A man on a mission. Not only is he compassionate but you get a history lesson about this country. Very interesting facts about the people as well as medical issues. A huge amphitheatre for the concert as well. Very comfortable seats, confronting facts.
touching. This was the highlight for me. It is a testament to the uselessness and destruction of war and the heroes who are working to clean it up.
ticked!!. It was on my list of things to see and do in Cambodia. Inspiring to see what one man is doing to help his country and people...reminds me of how fortunate we are...

Heartrending. Called here on way back from Kabal Spean. The stories are incredible and moving. Definitely visit to try and appreciate what the Cambodian people have gone through and many are still paying the price. A humbling experience

A must see. Small but fascinating. here you can learn more about the atrocious landmining of Cambodia and the even more devastating effects of unexploded ordinance as well as the heroic efforts being made to clear land and stop the continuing deaths and injuries.

Cambodia's heroes. The place is not that extravagant as you are expecting. It is a mere depiction of what happened during the war and what Khmer did to save children and locals from the installed landmines. Truly inspiring!
Good stop off. Get an insight into recent events by stopping off here in your tuk-tuk. It at first appears tacky, but it is pretty informative and worth half an hour of your time.

A good cause but not really worth going out of the way for.. Not much to see here other than a few rusty old explosives, although a very worthy cause. It's a shame that this is not better supported by the Cambodia Government.

Sad but real. This is a must visit to see what this country had to go thru during the recent crisis. This man is working very hard to correct the mistakes of others and his own. Most impressive small museum.

Just alright. The American guide was not around when we visited, and it was also pretty quiet during our visit. So we had to rely on a laminated set of explanations about the various rooms and exhibits, which left us rather confused at times about what we were looking at. It is a pity, since there is much to be learnt from the museum.The exhibition of a multitude of various landmines, placed in a pavilion in the middle of a small pond, which is at the centre of the whole museum, is startling. Other exhibitions talk about how modern-day deminers do their work and the children who are being taken care of by Aki Ra's charity.

Inspiring and disconcerting.. A truly wonderful and horrible story and lesson. What we continue to do to one another as humans is so sad. It is inspiring to see how much one man can do to right a wrong and change the lives of many for the better. Thank you Aki Ra

Excellent work. The assistance this museum brings to the children of Cambodia is absolutely outstanding. I hope that as more donations are received, the exhibits and building could be upgraded to further enhance the visitors experience and to educate people as to the horrific outcome and cost to lives and also budgets in the removal of land mines in all countries.

Amazing to hear a first hand account.. It was an eye opening experience to read first hand stories of the war and the huge impact it still has on Cambodia and its people. Team it up with a visit to Banteau Srei, the butterfly centre is also in the vicinity.

little sad place. I say dont stop by here unless you are on the way back to banteay srei and have time on your hands. There is little to be learnt about the landmines here, a lot is publicise on Aki Ra, the guy who runs the place and how he helps the children.

This place opens your eyes!. A fantastic charity who help Children who have lost limbs due to land mines. They live on site (although and rightly you cannot go into that bit) and live off the money from the museum. They say there is over 2 million landmines still in Cambodia and it will take decades to clear them all.A very very worthy cause!
Lisas tick no 4. Not really sure what I wanted from this museum but I left a little underwhelmed.Still interesting to see what one man is doing though for his people

A very moving experience. A lack of sleep and an emotional day of playing with street kids led my tour of the CLMM to be a teary one. This place will blow your mind. The story of the man who founded it, in itself, is novel worthy. An absolute must see for American, Russian and Chinese tourists who need to see first hand the effects their super power countries have on the lives of millions even 40 years after Vietnam and the Cold War.

Very interesting & informative, worth a visit. We visited the Landmine Museum with our two children (9 & 10) after seeing the Banteau Srei temple. I found it very interesting and informative. The museum provides a lot of context for why you see so many amputees around Siem Reap and the Angkor area. You will learn a lot about land mines and other munitions that have had such a huge impact on the people of Cambodia, and the extraordinary efforts to demine the nation. The story of its founder, Aki Ra, is inspiring and really quite extraordinary. To visit, you need at least 30 minutes, but 45-60 is best in part so you can watch at least some of the video. Definitely worth a visit.

Just across the Road from the best value hotel in Siem Reap - 'Angkoriana'. Allow plenty of time theres plenty to see. Quite a lot of walking but upper stories are acessed by a long circular ramp but it's stairs to decend so you need to be reasonably mobile. Each gallery is well set out and there are ample film / slide shows on hand to enhance your experince with a range of language options.It's a bit expencive if your staying at the Angkoriana you can save a dollar but purchasing your ticket there.

Touching Stories. It is a good place to learn about the Pol-pot regime. Different types of ammunition and bombs were are displayed with descriptions as well were it was taken from. The very touching story is about the founder Aki-ra who has made an effort to have built this small museum with the help of a Canadian NGO. Cambodia's leaders previously opposed this site. It's quite a distance from downtown, an hour travel by tuk2. By car i think will only get about 25-30 minutes. But the trip is worth it with a $3/person entrance fee. If you choose to do the Bantay Srei trip, you can have a stopover on this place.

informative moving and worthwhile. You never realize just how much explosives were dropped or buried on this tiny country. The museum shows how big the problem is and what ts brave staff are tying to do. Worth visiting to support their good work and interesting in its own right.

Hearbreaking.. If you hire tuktuk to go to Bantey Srei, please do not give this museum a miss. The entrance fee is USD3. The proceeds from the entrance fee and donation will be funded to the school and land mine awareness programmes.
Worth seeing, run by a good man. Very informative. Help clear land mines with your admission fee. Recommended. Easy to get to. Nice staff. Lots of land mines.
So sad. Anyone going to this part of Cambodia should visit the Landmine Museum it really brings home to you the problems these people have faced and are still facing today.

One person can make a difference. We visited this place on way back from River of the Lingas. Land mines are such a big part of Cambodias past and present. It showed how the courage of one person can make a difference.

American gentleman gives tour. This gentleman gives the complete history of the multiple invasions and fighting in Cambodia. There are thousands of landmines still to be diffused so any donation will help to fund and train people to safely detect landmines. Highly recommend.

Dr. Richner. An admireable man with a great love to the people of the country of Cambodia. As a young physician he came to Cambodia to help the children of Cambodia and after the delverance of the Khmer Rouge he came back. Working since about 20 years. absolutely worth to be supported by our money, what will reach to 100% the children.
Worth it. I was hesitant about visiting because of the seriousness of the issue but glad I did, very informative and buy some merchandise to help these kids out.
average... not much thing to see except old mine bullet and gun, not bad but not so instructive, maybe i was inspecting too much.

Very humbling!. An excellent museum with and interesting filmshow and exhibits for this excellent cause. the volunteers did put us off a bit as they were a bit loud/intrusive when some of us just wanted to read in peace.

Unnerving but interesting. Explains the work demining land mines. I would have liked toknow more about how each mine differs and where in Cambodia this is still a major issue...perhaps i didn't read enough. In four languages,Khmer, English, French and I thonk Japanese or Cantonese.

Worth a visit. Definitely worth a visit, very informative and interesting. The history has been well documented and the museum very well laid out, you can tell alot of hard work has gone into the set-up. Was a real eye opener.

Mind opening. Makes you wonder why some countries use these truly offensive items as well as manufacture them... A very interesting and mind-opening exhibition. Definitely worth popping in as you explore the temples, remind you of the tragic recent past Cambodia has suffered.

Small and consise. Worth a visit after the temples it is a small informative museum.
I think it cost $3 when we visited

Sad, but everyone should see this. It was hard to see some of the exhibits because of the tears. The proceeds from this museum help orphans. Please, if you are in the area, make this one of your stops.

Worth a visit. This is worth a visit and is on the way to Banteay Srey temple so you could combine the two. It really gives some insight into the horrors of the landmines and the legacy they have left.

Ban Landmines forever.. What an experience! Wee done to the people who put this shocking exhibition together. I had never imagined the appaling damage these horrible devices can do. To think there are still between 1million and 6million still out there in the ground in Cambodia and still maiming and killing people. From the evil minds that conceive these devices to all associated in their trade, use, deployment etc SHAME SHAME SHAME... To those brave people clearing them up well done ...well done indeed.
Interesting. This is a good educational place to visit. What other countries did to Cambodia is just wrong - and then leaving so many mines after they'd finished their war.

Informative. It was informative to learn the different shapes and sizes. Also that landmines were manufactured by so many countries and obviously supplied to the Khmer Rouge. The location was good in that it provided an opportunity for us to get out to the countryside and see the type of communities where many of these landmines would have been buried.
A must visit! Great history piece.. Impressive, breath taking exhibition that shows a man's life transformation. I Am glad my driver recommendd a stop.

Interesting for a quick visit. Plenty of landmines from all over the planet make this an interesting roadside stop. Also, outside the buildings are carcasses of some other large ordinance and rockets.

A museum with a difference. We spent an hour at this museum and really enjoyed the mixture of information and exhibits. I had read about this museum some years ago and the people who had set it up. They have done such a marvellous job in helping to rid Cambodia of dangerous ordinances. The museum is worth a side visit and brings home the realities of living in a country riddled with land mines.

Well worth the drive. Located a little less than an hour from the downtown area, it's definitely worth the drive. There is a $3 entrance fee for the museum and there is also a list of needed items for donations. I wish I had known and would have brought some toiletries from my hotel or stopped at the supermarket on my way. I would recommend anyone bringing donation items with their visit if possible. The museum is small, but take the time to read all the articles and clippings to get the most out of your visit.

The cause makes it worth the visit. This museum is definitely worth a visit for anyone headed out towards Banteay Srei. The museum is basically the life work of one man - Aki Ra - a former Khmer Rouge soldier who has committed himself to clearing landmines in his home country. The museum has a collection of different landmines and unexploded ordinance and includes numerous stories of people who have died or been disabled by these devices. Behind the museum is a school that caters to disabled children. The museum is a bit haphazard in its layout, with likely too much reading for most visitors. However, there is one room with stories written by some of the children at the school, which are emotionally powerful and worth a read.Overall, this museum is worth a visit and it makes you realize that amidst all the beauty of the temples and friendliness of the Khmer people, there is recent and sometimes overlooked tragedy that has and continues to effect some people in this beautiful land.

Wonderful work. If in Siem Reap you should make this one of your stops. Aki Ra with his demining team has given so much back to his country demining the landmines left behind saving so many lives. Bill and Jill Morse support Aki Ra with running the museum and the relief centre and orphanage and provide education, care, vocational and scholarship opportunities to give a bright future to so many.
Definitely worth the stop. I was so glad that my tour guide recommended stopping at this place. The story of the man who opened this place is truly captivating.

A Great Experience. Yes this museum is small and out of the way, but is an well worth the time on the way back from Banteay Srey and the waterfalls. Altogether very humbling and I had an excallent tour from the Canadian(?) guy who works there. Thoroughly recommended to get a handle on how the recent past is still affecting Cambodians today - plus a very worthy cause to support.

Recovery. Visiting this place is worth the time and effort just like visiting the archaeological sites. It is a humbling experience to know that a few people care by putting a lot of effort in making the country of Cambodia safe for the next generations of Khmers. The foundation/museum will be glad if you buy souvenirs from them.

Interesting and meaningful. Interesting but tiny little museum with $3 cover fee. They show all types of landmines and some other munitions too like air drop bombs. Very interesting if you a interested in the recent history of the country in the past 30-40 years or so. But it is quite out of the way. Not worth a dedicated trip out if you live in Siem Reap as it will take less than 1hr to see. Its prob at least 30-40 min outside of downtown siem reap. I went on the way back from the blasting a machine gun at the shooting range.... sort of ironic eh?(the two activities are very close distance-wise to each other)
Landmine Museum. Amazing story of a man and his life-someone with a terrible start who has turned his life into something special.
Good cause but not worth the trip. Too small a museum. Most exhibits rooms are not lighted, making it very too dark to read. It's really not worth to make a trip just to visit.

Well worth a visit when going out to Banteay Srey. I unfortunately did not actually stop myself, which I still regret. The owner is a Mr. Akira who is well famed for his efforts to disarm landmines. A former Khmer Rouge soldier (as were most, who were forced to join Angkar... or die), he later joined the opposition and has since dedicated his life to personally clearing landmines. This is his own private collection of thousands, where he employs many victims of such horrific tragedies. Mr. Akira was voted one of TIME magazine's top 10 heroes in 2010, and deserves your patronage
Sad reminder. Worth a trip. The guy who started this was a child soldier and now helps to remove these horrendous devices. A reality check and a chance to contribute to the great work they do here

Akira is truly the hero of Cambodia. The landmine museum visit not only show us what weapon of destruction can do to the victim but also the impact is has to the victim after the war. The work that Mr Akira & his team has done to the people of Cambodia is truly worth mentioning.

Worth the visit. The person who established the museum was responsible for laying many of the original landlines in the country and came to the realization after seeing the deaths and injuries they caused felt remorse and has since spent many years of his life dedicated to finding and destroying active mines Although not a large museum for the sum of $3 it is worth the visit to understand more about what the people gave had to endure

Excellent - don't miss it. My sons (pre-teen and teenagers) had a fantastic tour and visit here. Very eye opening for them. The Cambodian people are safer because of Aki Ra and the staff. Children are benefiting from the school, food, shelter, care and education that this center provides. I am grateful to other reviewers for putting this in Trip Adviser, as that is how we learned of it. The museum itself is small, but the experience is worth it. We took a Tuk Tuk from town, which cost about $15 US round trip, and took about 30 minutes to get there.

Well worth a visit. About 30-40 minutes out of Siem Reap but a lovely drive. We learnt more about the history of Cambodia and more of the trials the Khmer have been through. We learnt about the different bombs and guns however were even more impressed with the work of Aki Ra. One man can certainly make a difference! Certainly could be improved however I think with the limited funding they have ( they have a wish list printed on a white board and they certainly weren't wanting for anything over the top ..chalk, white board markers, paper) I think they have done a fantastic job.

Truely Amazing. There are so many different kinds of bombs there. The best part was a movie that was shown about this amazing man who is now helping his country to have a safer environment for the people who live there. There are many pictures and stories written about what happened to the country.
landmine museum. Very historical and gives you a rough idea of what Cambodians went through during that time. It showed a great deal of artifacts and even a video detailing the history.

Landmine museum visit. The museum shows you hunders of differen land mines and war left overs found in Cambodia. It also tells you a lot about the work of Aki Ra and his fascinating story. However, it takes some time to reach the museum as it is located pretty far from the city of Siem Reap (about 40 minutes) - also, the presentation of the exhibition could have been better. I felt that more explanations would have been useful.

Homemade heartwrenching displays. we visited this museum with our 3 children ages 8 - 11 it took us around 50 mins to get there from Siem Riep (apprx 13$ round trip). The museum is quite primitive in design but the message is strong and clear, as are the wounded people that work there. Aki Ra's story really drills home what a traumatic time the country and the people have been through. It was very educational for the children to understand a bit of the history.  I noticed this museum is not in the lonley planet guide in 'things to do around Siem Riep', very disappointing Lonley Planet??!!

A meaningful trip. Drop by the landmine museum to get a better understanding of the landmine situation in Cambodia. Entrance is $3, and it is along the way to Bantaey Srei! So do drop and spend about half - 1 hour in this place for an educational excursion!

Worth a visit! Buy souveniers here as it helps charity!. Aki Ra's story is inspiring - a movie about him should be made as his story is amazing. Its not all about landmines at this museum - he has an orphanage out back and has collected many weapons of distruction that fell to Cambodia during the conflicts of last century. Chinese, American and Russian made bombs as well as countless landmines. You'll appreciate the story when you go see for yourself. If you visit Banteay Srei, tell your driver to stop here on the way back to Siem Reap.

So informative - well worth a visit. We were very impressed with this small, but very informative museum. It really made us appreciate the great work that has been done in clearing land mines and the damage these mines have caused

please go there. This place is not just for sight seeing. You see this museum on your way to Bantaey Srei temple and a 30 mins stop here would help you to understand the tough time of people in the past and their on going fights with the land mines. By buying a pass and getting into the museum you are actually supporting few children who lost their normal childhood due to land mines.

Worth a Visit. We almost didn't make it over to this small-ish museum, but it was truly worth our time. This was a somber yet terrifying reminder of Cambodia's past (and present). This organization is still working hard to prevent horrendous injuries and casualties. You can help.

life changing. a small museum that most people will overlook. but i assure it is a must see. the staff are amazing and they work for such a good cause. they house and provide education for many cambodians and they are very strict about the museum being about cambodia not the children that are there. they by no means use the children as part of the tour but have them help out and help the cause. a little known place that is a must see.

Great cause, average museum. Aki Ra's story is an incredible one and I loved reading about him and his past. He's doing great work and has a great cause. Those are great reasons to visit the museum since it helps his foundation. But the museum is average at best. We spent about 45 mins there.

land mine museum. I would recomend everybody to go and see the work this group of dedicated volunteers do in not only showing the public the dangers of the still present land mines but their continuing defusing the mines. hats go off to all involved . make sure you watch the video if the power is on .

touching. i was volunteering near by at Knar School and stopped here after one of my sessions. very informative and amazing to see all the landmines that have been found. small museum with a big impact and definitely worth a visit.

Very informative and your visit helps Cambodians effected by landmines. This was an amazing experience. We stopped here in between temples and it was very heartwarming to see what the owner is doing to help his people ravaged by landmines. His story is very impressive. He was a child soldier who put many of the landmines in place and now his life mission is to remove those landmines to prevent the unintended casualties and also help those who have been affected by landmines.The $3 admission was well worth it and also the gift shop is a nice place to buy souvenirs and the proceeds help people effected by landmines.

A must see if you want to understand the history. This museum is not like other museums, it offers guests an opportunity to help better understand the devastation civil war has had on Cambodia, and how Cambodia is still in need of rebuilding. It is a short visit and should fit into any tour activities, allowing everyone an opportunity to visit. Please if you want to learn about the country you are visiting this is an ideal place to visit.

A must-see!. Quite small and dingy inside, but the message brought across is powerful. It should be seen to try to understand contemporary Cambodia. Really sad - there are statements in the museum by the founder saying how lucky he is that his wife supports him in his dangerous work and how wonderful she is etc. You only learn at the end of the exhibition that his wife passed away in her sleep a few years ago.

Eye-opening..... We were lucky enough to have the museum to ourselves. Plus, we were very fortunate to have met the main man behind it- Mr. Aki Ra (I believe he was one of CNN'S hero's of 2010). We arrived just shortly after closing; however, our drive/guide persuaded them to open the museum for us. There is a display of various types of mines, and an in depth explanation of the work Aki Ra has done in the past, and continues to do. I was informed that he had just recently returned from Korea, where he had received an award. It is a small museum, so I imagine if you just want to go for a "quick look," you might be disappointed. However, if you go and look, and read all the literature, I am certain you will find this museum a very, very, educational experience. After visiting this museum, in the jungle areas of Cambodia, I decided to stick to the trails rather than being possibly killed by some one-dollar device.Truly a must see, especially if you are coming back from Banteay Srei-the donation helps so many in need.
my sons favourate. lots of history in the museum,cheap to get into,we had a guide to exsplain things to us,what happened in the war.well worth going
Small museum with a big mission!. This organization supports handicapped children as well as de-mining efforts. I would recommend stopping here after Bantaey Srei. Not to be missed.

Definitely worth a visit,amazing man with such a story. I wasn't too sure what to expect when I went to this museum but I was definately surprised and learnt so much . The museum was set up by local de-miner and ex Khmer rouge child soldier Aki-ra, who has had a lifetime of fighting and killing after being inoctorated at a very young age and didn't know any different way of life. His story is on boards around the museum along with thousands of uxo and landmines he has removed over the years. I could write for pages about this place but just go ! Also check out his DVD documentary in the shop there as it's defiantly worth a watch !

Frightening. It was a small museum. There are many landmines to see which were all found in Cambodia. You can appreciate the different types and sizes of landmines and why they should be banned around the world. The video presentation was amazing, showing how he finds the mines and deactivates them. Every single mine in the museum he deactivated himself. Sometimes even banging them on the ground to loosen the detonator. Now that is frightening!!!

A must see for any visitor to Siem Reap. We found this to be a sobering reminder of the troubles Cambodia has been through, and the dangers still faced by them. The story of the owner is truly fascinating, having fought for the Khmer Rouge as a child soldier, then the Vietnamese army, then the Cambodian army against the Khmer Rouge. Well displayed with some interesting insights into army life in the jungle. We went on a very hot day, and there's no ac, and very little seating. Also there seemed to be a few tags missing, could have been a bit more informative on some items.

You must go. This is a tragic story of a man who loves his country, dedicates his life to de-mining it and then has three children with his beloved wife who dies because the country has very poor medical care. The history of Cambodia is very sad and triumphant. I would strongly suggest a visit here and donate if you can, it's a very worthwhile cause to help the very gentle and kind people of Cambodia.

Eye opener. Although it's pretty far from the city (further than Angkor Wat) it's worth the trip. I had no idea Cambodia, and other places in the world, were so saturated with landmines. I read everything when I was there. The stories were so captivating and gave me a reality check as to what people go through during war. Don't miss this museum!

Sobering reality. On our way back from Banteay Srei (our favorite temple of all) this is an 30-45 stop and a stark reminder of the years of brutality faced by the Cambodian people. Frightening you learn just how many land mines are still out there.

Informative, nicely curated, and well worth a stop. The Cambodia Landmine Museum was founded by Aki Ra, a former child soldier of the Khmer Rouge who went on to devote his adult life to defusing landmines around Cambodia. The museum is only partly a testament to his work, however, and also details the major points of Cambodian history that introduced such destructive weaponry.The museum is open air and a bit dusty at times, but the exhibits are well-signed in English. We learned a lot from the 45 minutes or so we spent there. Particularly in comparison to other museums in Cambodia, this one is surprisingly well-done and really worth your time. It's also right on the road to Banteay Srey, and so makes for an easy stop either before or after seeing the temple.The museum is also affiliated with an orphanage that Aki Ra now runs, and some of the older children work in the museum. This seems to have upset some visitors, but I found it an appropriate merging of interests. Contrary to other reports, we experienced no pressure whatsoever to offer a donation (beyond the minimal entrance free to the museum).

Worth a stop on the way to Banteay Srei. Though a small museum, the Cambodian Landmine Museum is very powerful. Aki Ra is a noble man - a former layer of mines as a child, he has now cleared over 50,000 landmines from Cambodia. Physically there isn't much to see (piles of dead landmines and some examples of weaponry), however, if you stop to read the all the stories, you will never quite be the same. It is a fair drive (particularly in a tuk-tuk) so I might not choose to make the long trek to just visit the museum. Instead combine it with a trip to Banteay Srei as it's right on the way.

Stark reminder of the brutal years. i disagree with previous reviews that a visit here is a waste of time.When you read the literature that is available in the various rooms you can then build a picture of how the people of Cambodia suffered during the war years under a brutal regime.Aki Ra has over the years dedicated his life to rid the country of these landmines and the donations that visitors made have been used to help the victims of these horrific weapons.And if for that reason only it is worthy of donations made by visitors and would urge visitors to the temples not to drive by it on the way back.It is also worrying the number of counties that still make landmines that injure between 10,000 to 20,000 people each year

An important stop between visiting temples. I'm really glad we stopped at the landmine museum on the way back from Banteay Srey. It's important to reflect on the tragedy that occurred in Cambodia and the havoc landmines continue to cause. The museum is a testament to the good people can do in the face and aftermath of such horror. We appreciated the commentary and explanation we received from the older American gentleman who works at the museum (sorry we didn't catch your name) and fully endorse the sentiment that children are not tourist attractions!! This is really important people so please think before you visit an orphanage or take photos of kids at the temples/in the street. Would this be appropriate behaviour in your home country?

Needs more background to make sense. The museum was a collecton of landmine and guns and individual stories.
