I would have liked to have seen more about the history of how the landmines got there in the first place.The books that they sell which are wrapped in plastic turned out to be photocopies. This was disappointing as they were well priced. I dont mind copies as long as you know what you are paying for.

Every traveler should see this.... A shocking reminder however all travelers should take the time to visit this museum. Really brings home the heart breaking history of Cambodia, whilst also highlighting how these beautiful people have managed to get back on their feet.

Aki, you are an inspiration. I came here with my 2 children, aged 7 and 11, and they were entranced by this small and informative museum. It approached the topic of landmines and the devastation of the Pol Pots regime delicately and with respect. We were all touched and read stories taken directly from children and other people who had made a difference through the turbulence of war. Aki, you are indeed a hero.
Insightful. Aki Ra is one of the most inspiring people I have ever learnt about. The museum is small but full of history and breathtaking truth. I am so glad I went there.

Take the time to visit. I didn,t think I would like visiting this museum but I am very glad that we went. Visiting this place gives you such an insight into what this wonderful country has had to endure. You walk away more knowledgeable and with a sadness in your heartI am really glad that we took the time to go.

Highly educational. A visit to this place made me aware of the vast amount of destruction and havoc that was wrecked by the Khmer Rouge and others and that thousands of landmines are still there which the people are trying to defuse. But it takes time, money and patience.

Interesting but pretty far from Siem Reap. We really enjoyed looking around this museum, learning about how big a problem landmines still are in Cambodia. The museum is quite small but make sure you watch the video near the shop as it really brings to life the impact of some of the mines as you watch them being detonated to make them safe. We had to ask for them to play this so make sure you don't miss it!In the garden area you can also see how the mines would typically be hidden in the earth / along paths which is really interesting. Every time you look, you see a new one.It is however quite far from Siem Reap so best to couple it with a trip to the near by butterfly centre.

Sobering. This small museum tells the horrific story of the thousands of landmines deposited in Cambodia, and their many victims. The Museum supports many children who have been injured, so visiting is not only informative but does good in a country with so many poor people and a less than perfect government.
Definitely worth a visit. So informative and at the same time confrontational. Hard to believe many countries are still making landlines given the devastion they cause

Go and support the work. it was quite rustic but worth seeing the work that continues to be done de-mining Cambodia. I was shocked to know that these mines continue to maim farmers and their children to this day

an eye opener to what Cambodia goes through for the past dacades. This museum set up by Aki Ra is nothing like your ordinary museum, it house thousand of defused landmine and bomb shells that he himself and his team cleared from around Cambodia. This museum tell a horrific story of Cambodia civil war from the eye of Cambodian people. There's no replica displayed in this museum, all items are actually collected from the people backyards. Since this museum is set up by people's fund and donation, don't expect a world class display or audio visual, but you can bring along your guide to help you better understand what is Aki Ra trying to tell us.
Worth a visit on way to-from temples. Sobering. And some nice branded stuff for sale (without any hard sell, at all)

AKI RA you rock. Small but very interesting, we loved it and loved what the place represents, Aki Ra is a special man to have set it up and to look after all those kids. Great place to visit and get some history

Hard to see. I was hesitant to visit this site, but we did so anyway. Lots of photographs and displays. Not so interesting to focus on the war in Cambodia, but the English-speaking proprietor was an excellent conversationalist and educator about it.

Land Mine Museum. Land Mine Museum. In Cambodia, where unavoidable. Know whether there was really so many mines. When you witness the disastrous failure, and at a loss for words. Many people with disabilities still, mine has not been completely eliminated yet. Had been donated hope to be able to force even a little. Let's gather the feelings of everyone
Gripping.. Going inside the museum is a heart warming experience. I am in awe by the effort of the people involve to clear all land mines in Cambodia to make it a safer place for its people.
Great Education. Very informative and supports a very worthy cause! A good stoping point on a trip to Bantei Serei.

Definitely do this!. This was such an informative museum and it gives you insight into what these people have been through and a greater appreciation for their kindness and openness. Pair this with the butterfly center and waterfalls. 3 full days in siem reap is about right. Enjoy it!

Great museum, Crucial Information that We All Should Know. This museum is a must-do for all visitors to Siem Reap/Angkor Wat. It has an amazing displays that highlight the fact that the Pol Pot and civil war eras can't yet be discussed in the past tense - they are still affecting many people today in the form of the 3 million or more landmines still in the ground. Stories from residents of the children's shelter make the displays all the more real, and really give crucial information about this issue and about the UN Anti-Landmine Convention that has yet to be ratified by some very big-name countries. The personal story of the shelter's and museum's founder, Aki Ra, is also quite inspiring - he went from laying mines as a child soldier to working tirelessly to remove them from the ground. It's absolutely worth the tuk-tuk ride out to the museum, and it's on the way if you're headed to Bantae Srei (which you ought to be).

Cheap at twice the price. Explanation at front door apologises for raising the entrance fee from $2 -$3 !!!
They do a mighty job here, not only explaining the dangers of finding and detonating landmines but they also house, educate and provide work for victims of land mines.

Collection of land mines. When you visit banter Srey or butterfly garden, have a visit to this museum. Admission is US$2 per person and you will be able to see the land mines that used during the war in Cambodia
Worth a look. We enjoyed our tour around the place. A chatty American showed us through and he was very helpful. It's only a small place but worth a visit if in the area.

Aki-Ra. This place embodies the spirit of a man. A man who was a soldier that laid mines, and now a hero that dedicated his life to ensure that no more of his fellow countrymen become victims of the eternal soldier.Here visitors can learn about the atrocities of war. The problems with mass mining. Read about the stories of victims, who innocently lost their limbs or life of loved ones to a war that ended decades ago. Very interesting place to visit. Also interesting to learn that Singapore, my native country's neighbor didn't sign the Ottawa Treaty (Anti-personal mine ban). Strange isn't it?

In some ways nothing - But in others one of the best things to see in Siem Reap. There is not much to this museum. There are mines on display and the tales of horror of war that have visited the people of Cambodia. It is small. You can experience it in 30 min or less. But what this does have going for it is the spirit of a man: Aki Ra. Aki Ra went from a child soldier (slave) stolen at age 5 to become an avatar of peace and humanity. Landmines are a plague and unlike others who tried to come up with solutions, he took it upon himself to personally deal with landmines by doing nothing less than going out with a stick and a pocket knife and digging them up. He has personally removed tens of thousands. He then went on to found an orphanage for victims and more. He is quiet. He does not do it for fame or fortune. He lives modestly and stays out of the spotlight, preferring to be in the field removing mines. There are videos and stories about Aki Ra online. He was a 2010 CNN "Hero." He was featured in National Geographic in 2012. Etc. One man, a stick, a pocket knife and 50,000 fewer landmines. Their motto is "One mine - one life" for a reason. It is also worth noting his organization removes landmines at a cost of about $5 per mine. The U.S. Government spends $500+ to remove a mine.

Definately worth a visit. This is a really interesting place definately worth a visit. Try to find one of the staff who will tell you more about the work they do, the children they look after and where their funding comes from.It is terrible that a place like this that genuinely wants to help Cambodians and is so dedicated to the kids they lookAfter is lower on the list of things to do in Siem Reap on trip advisor than a trip to a local orphanage to watch kids who are made to dance. Fellow travelers should support this worthwhile facility.

Ultimately Uplifting. We stopped on the way back from Banteay Srei, which combines nicely with a visit here. The subject matter is grim, but the work that Aki Ra has done is ultimately a story of human triumph. Formerly a Khmer Rouge child soldier, Ra has spent his adult life defusing and removing landmines that still dot the Cambodian countryside--many of which he may have originally set. The center has also become a foster home for many of the children who have lost limbs because of landmines. Although it's hard to visit without choking up, ultimately one comes away feeling hopeful about the human condition.

Stark reality but humbling. There is an orphanage attached and this place is actively involved in assisting those still affected by the horrors and losses caused by landmines. We were fortunate to meet one of the US men who is a major sponsor here and heard first hand just how horrific the injuries are and the complexity faced with demining Cambodia today. The mines are still thick in some places and every year many still injured. Go here, listen,read the displays, understand a little more and donate. There is also a small shop with crafts etc that raises funds for the initiatives.

Honest insight. It's worth a visit, particular if combined with a visit to Banteay Srey. The exhibition is a painfully extensive collection of various mines and other weapons. An important insight to the near history of Cambodia.

Small, but interesting. We stopped here on our way to a temple (B Srei) It was interesting to read the displays, thinking about the use of mines, tragic effects and the efforts that are being made to help. Take a little spare money to buy gifts to support the work that is being done. I think it was $3 each entrance fee.

Interesting. We visited this Musuem on the way back from visiting some of the Angkor Temples, it is approximately 30kms from the city centre. It was a extremely interesting learning about the impact the land mines have had on the country and the removal of them. Aki Ra the man who has establisbhed the Musuem continues to remove the land mines along with a team. He has also set up an orphanage for victims of landmines.If you are not visiting the outer Angkor Temples I would not make the effort to visit the Musuem.

Very intresting. to see the damage these mines cause is a wake up call that they should be banned world wide.it only costs $3 entry and is well worth it even just to read the owners story from when he joined the Khmer rouge as a kid laying mines then fighting against them with the Vietnamese to now dismantling the land mines.

A CNN Hero's Important Little Museum. We took a wonderful 40-45 minute tuk-tuk ride from Siem Reap out to this engrossing little museum beyond the temples and just past the power grid.Aki Ra is a 2010 CNN hero, and a man who continues to make important contributions to the de-mining of Cambodia.You will be filled with awe and admiration for his work, and that of Bill and Jill Morse. We were fortunate enough to encounter Jill on our visit, and she told us a great deal about the orphanage they run for landmine-related victims.Don't miss it. It might be the best $3.00 you've spent recently.

Must see in Cambodia. A small museum constructed by a true hero-this should be a requirement for everyone visiting Cambodia. A totally engrossing and inspiring experience-the horror of the effect of land mines on this country cannot be understated. A true educational experience for everyone.

Sad story with silver lining. Tje museum s a little out of the way but defiantly worth a trip. The owner, who is a former child Khamer solder has dedicated his life to disarming the millions of unexploded mines and bombs that plague Cambodia and its people. The 3 dollar entrance fee goes to the 20 kids he is putting through school and housing at the compound. It's a sad day but ultimately worth it

Not just a museum, real action behind it. We chose this museum by purpose - it is not ran by a government but by an ex soldier, Mr Akira who helps demining Cambodia himself. A $3 fee and money spent on souvenirs pay for clearing landmines and also support children (mines victims).It is a small museum but worth stopping at, especially if you are on the way to Banteai Srei.
Stop and Look. Only $3 admission and worth looking at all the mines that have been collected , money goes to continue mine clearance.

interesting and educational. It is a great cause as the $3 admission fee goes toward clearing landmines and supporting the poor, orphaned, and wounded children who live there. Of course you can also make an additional donation or purchase souvenirs from their gift shop if you want to help out more. It was founded by an ex-child soldier as a way to tell the world about the horrors landmines inflicted on his native Cambodia. I really enjoyed reading the letters written by the children who lived there and I was shocked and disappointed to learn about America’s role in placing the landmines in Cambodia, as well as their refusal to sign the International Campaign to Ban Landmines. Combine a trip to the museum with visiting Banteay Srei and the butterfly center.For more info and photos, check out my blog post at http://growninsouthernground.wordpress.com/2012/03/22/siem-reap-day-4-banteay-srei-landmine-museum-butterfly-center-angkor-balloon/.

Putting Cambodia history in to perspective.. After days of walking though all the temples and thinking about ancient history, it was a dose of reality to go to the Cambodia Landmine Museum. You can't help but notice the lack of certain generations and the number of amputees in the Siem Reap area. A visit to this museum puts it in persecutive. This is a country that has had far too much blood spilled on it's soil. This history around the Khymer Rogue is one that is easy to forget and yet those in this area will be impacted it for generations to come! This is an important addition to your visits to the Temples. We had a delightful lunch at the food stand right outside the museum!

Be prepared to be affected by what you learn. Bill Morse and his wife moved here nine years ago from Palm Springs to work for the landmine effort. Bill leads tours in his spare time and is excellent at explaining the history of the land mine placement in Cambodia and the efforts to clean it up. His wife runs the orphanage in back of the museum. The museum itself is small but never mind, you will find yourself engrossed in conversation with Bill. Well worth the visit. Not to be missed. Combine it with a visit to one of the ruins nearby.

A very humbling experience. Before visiting the museum, my husband and I already knew Aki Ra's story and we knew that our trip to Siem Reap wouldn't be complete without a visit to the Landmine Museum. It's sad that some tuk tuk drivers try to dissuade you from going there, since the place is 7 km south of the Bantey Srei Temple complex in Angkor National Park (about 30 minutes). We heard from a few of them that "there's nothing much to be seen there". It's true that the museum is very small but it's the story behind it and the work they do for the community that counts.Also, it's a shame that you don't really get to see signs in Siem Reap pointing you to the museum or guides telling you about this place. It's more common to see the War Museum. You don't need a temple pass to visit and the museum entrance fee is very low.Do not miss the opportunity to travel through countryside villages and to know about the war and the amazing work they still do clearing landmines in Cambodia. You can also read the stories of the kids who have been injured by landmines and are know currently living at the house behind the museum. You cannot visit the house but it's very good to learn what Aki Ra had done for these children.

Informative and Worthwhile. This museum is on the way to Banteay Srei, and it well worth the short stop to check it out. The site is divided into several buildings, each filled with information as well as defused examples of the many bombs and landmines that littered Cambodia following decades of war. Well worth a look, and if you have the time, stay for a viewing of the very well produced film that is shown at regular intervals.

Inspiring, Shocking and Humbling. I can not tell you how glad I am to have had the opportunity to visit the Cambodian Land Mine Museum and learn so much in a short space of time. It was incredibly inspiring to hear the unbelievable story of Aki Ra, and the work he had done, and continues to do clearing landmines in Cambodia, as well as the residence he has built up for a number of young Cambodians who have been injured by landmines. One man is truly making a difference for his country. The land mine museum is small but a wealth of information. I was fortunate enough to meet an American woman who works at the museum, who took me around and spoke about Aki Ra, the work he does, and about the displays in the museum. I'm very appreciative of her time; her knowledge gave me a more indepth understanding of what I was looking at. Don't miss this important museum; you'll learn about the very real dangers of landmines, that Cambodians unfortunately still face, and the incredible tireless work that Aki Ra has dedicated his life to.

Not to be missed. While the temples give us an idea of life in Cambodia hundreds even a thousand years ago, the Landmine Museum gives information about life in Cambodia today in the aftermath of years of war. We fortunately timed our visit so that we were guided around this small museum by an American who works with the founder of the museum. One man's life is making a difference but there are many more mines to be deactivated. Just a couple of weeks ago three people in the rural area near Siem Reap triggered a landmine and are now being treated for the injuries received. The foundation behind the museum covers their medical expenses. However their lives are forever changed. We were impacted by our time learning about the work of ridding the countryside of landmines. This is a very small museum but the horror of landmines and the necessary work of removing them is well portrayed. Admission is just $3 and the money will be well used.

Enlightening. In our travels around Cambodia, we became increasingly aware of the brutality of the country's recent history and the terrible toll it continues to exact from the people. This museum gave a concise and balanced explanation of the problems and it offers hope for a solution. This is a private museum, designed to support continuing demining activities and to support children who have been maimed by the mines.

Informative and thought provoking. When deciding whether to go here, one should not compare it to large government / publicly funded institutions. This is a privately financed exhibition of one man's (Aki Ra) crusade against the destructive force of UXO and landmines. It is a very personal experience and a trip well worth making. It is a very enjoyable tuk tuk ride from Siem Reap and you don't need to pay the USD20 fee to the Angkor Wat Heritage Site provided you are not intending to visit any temples as well. The Siem Reap is steeped in history and its not all about the temples. The sight of maimed children in the housing behind the museum (off limits to visitors) is a sobering reminder of the more recent turmoil.

Worth the stop~buy souvenirs here!. Great Museum; not only do you learn more about Cambodia's history, including a video that they loop in one of the rooms, you are also able to walk around, and see the artifacts. The museum also supports some of Cambodia's orphaned and underprivileged children. Though it is a bit somber, it's great to see the good that this small group is doing (and be prepared, it is small, the museum can be walked through in about 5minutes if you don't stop to watch the video and look at all the literature and photographs in the different rooms). I was sad that I had already bought all the souvenirs I was planning on getting, but I ended up getting a few more scarves and such (the scarves I'm pretty sure were only $5) in my desire to give a little bit back to an organization that does so much. I would recommend stopping here after Bantaey Srei, and following the Landmine Museum, I loved the Butterfly Museum, which is close by and on the way back to Siem Reap.

Excellent Cambodian NGO to Support. Excellent, grassroots work being done here. Clearing Camdoian villages of land mines AND running a school and home for children effected by land mines. Simple museum with old mines and other explosives on display. Lots of printed information to read. Small shopp to buy items, some made (willingly) by the children. Very moving. Stop here on your way to the temple and give them your support.

Informative and personal. We stopped here on the way back from the river of 1000 lingas and Bantay Srei. It is a worthwhile stop. Both in terms of educating yourself on the prevelance of landmines and their affects as well as history of Cambodia but also seeing great hope and the difference individuals can make. The man who set this up is a former child soldier and previously set landmines but has done much much more in his lifetime to eliminate them and campaign against them and educate on a worldwide basis. An enlightening story and highly inspirational in a world of large corporations and influence that as individuals we can have a huge effect and make impact! They have a school/orphanage there too where they educate and support children affected by landmines which you cannot visit (good to see Cambodia protecting children and stepping away from orphan-tourism) but great to know that visiting here and subsequent donations really is doing good work.

Sobering. The museum is full of information about landmines and one man's crusade to remove them. As a child growing up during the Vietnam war, I was only slightly aware of what was happening in SE Asia. It is important to face the wrongs our countries have committed so that we can stand up the next time and say No! Not in my name!

Not much to see. Our driver seng seila drove us on his tuk tuk to the museum and it looked like a house from outside but it was a museum. It's more about the history of the country and where land mines can be found and how a founder, can't remember his name decided to start an awareness charity organization to educate people on the land mines and how can one with experience deactivate them. It was pretty interesting but limited things to see. The money that you use to buy the t-shirts and souvenirs from the shop goes to the kids that stay behind the museum who were affected my the landmines. Great place to visit after visiting the temples. Something different!

Fascinating Insights Into Recent History. Our family loved this quick visit on the way back from Bantreay Srei. The highpoint was a personal tour from an American that retired and moved here to work with the founder and help advance the mission of removing landmines and unexploded ordinance as well as offering education to children that had suffered from this scourge. Fascinating.

Lots of information; good cause. You’ll learn the devastation that landmines inflict to soldiers and civilians during and after the war. The founder, a former child soldier, collected and displayed several landmines from various countries (U.S., Russia, etc.) and actual missile casings that were dropped during the war. This attraction does not draw a large crowd of tourists by itself so it is better to combine it with a visit to the Angkor Butterfly Museum, the shooting range and the nearby temples (Banteay Srei and Banteay Samré).

Confronting. To read about 10 year olds playing with each other and killing them later was quite confronting. See this small museum and see how history repeats itself and people still do not learn about the futility of war. Aki Ra remove landmines with no modern equipment for free. Donate to this cause as monies goes to an orphanage.

Good break from the temples. Although this museum is small and possibly over-filled with information it makes for a welcome change from the temple grind. I would recommend combining it with a trip out to Kbal Spean/Bantreay Srei as it's on the road out to these temples. It's only a small fee to get in and the money goes into the work this man is doing on removing cambodian landmines. It is informative and it doesn't have any propaganda in it like other museum (ie Vietnamese museums). A few bits and pieces of UXO (deactivated of course) are around for photo's. It's only a small museum and doesn't take long to get through (<1 hour) so it's worth a look.

The scourge of landmines. This is a nice way to break up temple visits. informative and eyeopening reading the founders story of child soldier to landmine hunter of today. So many landmines and EXO left to be found and diffused. Sad and shameful to see the US has not signed the anti landmine treaty along with a couple of other large countries.
Informative. Combined this museum with a trip to one of the temples further out and Kbal Spean. A small but informative museum also showing a short film of the demining that's going on.

Eye opening. A 10 year old soldier who once lay land mines for the khmer rouge, who then joined the vietnamese army is today risking his life to get rid of these land mines and helping those affected by them. A visit to siem reap is incomplete without a visit to this small but great truely eye opening museum.

excellent little museum. We combined this with a trip to the waterfall, Banteay Srei, and Beng Mealea.While it was directly on our way to the other sites, I kind of wish I had just taken a taxi there on a separate day since we were paying for a guide the full day who sat and waited outside for us, and I probably would have stayed longer if we didn't have such a full day planned.There is a worthwhile DVD with English subtitles you can watch in the gift shop (if it's off, just ask the cashier to turn it on).No landmine victims were visible at the museum/school/orphanage the day we visited, which is okay by me. I was affected enough by seeing their photos and reading their stories. They post a list of things they need as donations so you may want to call ahead to see what they need. What I remember from the latest list is rice and flip-flops. :-)

Worth an hour of your day!. We visited the landmine museum on the way back from visiting Banteay Srei temple; it's on the same road, and definitely worth an hour of your time to explore. There is an excellent video detailing some of the operations, and information, which is worth watching. The museum is very small, but packed with information, and also has a small shop where the proceeds from anything you might buy will go to supporting the school for landmine victims which lies just behind the museum. All in all, a great cause, a nice pit-stop from the temple trail and a reminder of the huge and devastating presence of landmines ... not just in Cambodia, but all over the world.

Informative place to visit. While the temples around Siem Reap are certainly amazing, there is a lack of places to learn about the history of the nation and some of its other challenges. The Landmine Museum fills in that gap and provides some brief information on its past wars and how it has shaped the country. The museum itself is not too big, but is a good place to spend an hour while visiting the other temples. Due to where it is, I highly recommend that you try to slot it in if you are visiting the more remote temples (Beng Mealea/Banteay Srei) as it is along the way. While you are in the area, also visit the Butterfly Garden! It is a little steep by Cambodian standards ($4/pax), but it is also a great break from the temple grind.

SEE and THINK !. Really is diferent, take a tuc tuc and will be arrive without problems, was founded by exchild soldier, you need sed the movie ( complete ) and read the places and country ddnt signed the deal against humanbombs... Really is small but powerfull experience. Buy a shirt and show at the world > NOT PersonalMines !

A very good cause. We called in at Landmine museum, $3 entrance fee. We mere met my an American guide who gave us info on the centre. All the money is put back in to the centre which houses an orphanage. They do not exploit the kids by allowing tourist in. Good info on landmines and helping the kids at the same time. Go and visit!
Small but very interesting place - worth supporting. Very confronting when you consider it is still going on despite what we know land mines cause. Well worth a visit as a rest from temples.

A stark reminder of how devistating landmines are! Very worthwhile to visit - near Banteay Srei Temple. A small museum near Banteay Srei that is strictly about landmines. Lots of history and information about Cambodian landmines.A stark reminder of the devastating effects of the landmines. This is the reason you see lots of people in Cambodia without arms and legs, as they either stepped on a mine or they were trying to help diffuse them and were unlucky. The museum is not much to see, but still worth a visit. They have a video playing in one room outside that is about how they disarm the landmines. I wish I had bought the video while I was there, oh well. Very worth to visit. I hope in the future they have more funding to build a better museum as this is a historic thing that no one should forget as it is still ongoing today!

Small, Important museum started by amazing man. The man who started this museum was a child soldier during the war and planted hundreds of landmines. Now he is a de-miner and helps out poor children and orphans. The museum is small and simple, but the message is powerful and you will be supporting a great cause.

Fantastic experience. We visited this museum with eagerness since we were told about it sometime before making the Indochina tour. The museum had shown us a lot about the hardship of the mining job. we felt sorry for the accident happening to miners. it's a dangerous job. and it taught us a lot about the value of working. we liked this museum very much.

Interesting and informative, but we expected more.. The landmine museum was about a 45 minutes ride by tuk-tuk from the city centre. My friends and I took a look at the website before our trip there.The museum itself was interesting and informative. However, we were rather disappointed and had expected to see more. The viewing area in the museum was rather small.It was not totally a wasted trip, but can probably be skipped if you don't have enough time.

Life Changing Expierence. Our tuk tuk driver took to us thankfully because without knowing where it is it would be very easy to miss. I has made my trip to Cambodia, the ruins were great and amazing but the museum was life altering. I wanted to really get something out of my trip to Cambodia and after an hour in the landmine museum I got what I was looking for. It is so fascinating/educating/upsetting all at the same time. I would not change it for the world. The American couple that lives and works there were just great and have a real joy for their work. They do not treat these children as "victims"or anything like that they treat them like normal children because that is what they are. The have an orphanage in the back for land mine victims, polio or just kids whose parents can not care for them. Never have a felt better paying to get into somewhere, the ticket is a mere 2 dollars US but you know it is going to a good cause. A MUST see if you are in Cambodia, its small from the outside but the impact it will have will last a life time.

opens your eyes. Our trusty tuk tuk driver Mr Than suggested we visit this place. we are not too much into war but he pointed out that landmines were a part of everyday life now some 15 years since the last were laid in his community.We spent about an hour and read all the interpretation panels which were very informative.I all came to reality later that afternoon - our Tuk Tuk driver took us for a walk in the jungle to a rarely visited ruin. It was so peaceful and we were well relaxed when the ground shook and he heard a loud explosion. He just kept walking while we stopped and asked. It was just another land mine being exploded. It was followed a minute later by another explosion.Land mines are being detonated dialy - some on purpose - others continue to maim and kill.

Definitely worth the tuk tuk trip from Siem Reap--not to be missed!. After spending a day touring Angkor Wat and the temples nearby, we took a 45 minute tuk tuk ride out to Banteay Srey, which we probably wouldn't have done except that the Cambodia Landmine Museum was on the way. After spending the entire previous day learning about and seeing some magnificent temples, Banteay Srey was interesting but couldn't compare. However, the Landmine Museum made the journey entirely worthwhile. Watching the video of the history of landmines in Cambodia was somber yet fascinating to learn about, and viewing the relatively small but powerful exhibits was an eye-opening experience that shouldn't be missed by anyone who visits Siem Reap. The Landmine Museum is only about 30 minutes from the heart of Siem Reap, but if you go there you might as well go see Banteay Srey as well, if for no other reason than the landscape and the people that you'll see along the road is somewhat different from Siem Reap. Also, for only USD20 per day plus another USD15 for the tuk tuk driver plus tips, I'd highly recommend a guide even for this day--and definitely for the day at Angkor Wat--just to hear firsthand all about the Cambodian people and their culture.

well worth the visit. Although quite small,its very interesting and quite powerfull.There are u number of exhibits,photos and explanations and a good documentry to watch at the end.Theres a school behind the museum for children who are landmine victims or orpahned,though the public cannot gain access.45 mins tuk tuk from Siem Reap,but on the way to bantrey srei

well worth a visit. I'm not into guns and weapons, but I also hate to be ignorant so thought that this would be a good start in brushing up my knowledge on Cambodian history. This museum is about a 45 minute tuktuk ride (cost us $18 return) outside of Siem Reap, but that in itself was very interesting and nice to see everyday Cambodian life. It only costs $1 to get in and all funds raised are used, not only for the upkeep of the museum, but also to look after and educate children whose lives have been affected by landmines. I would advise you to watch the video first and then go into the different rooms to see the collection of landmines. You can easily spend about an hour at the museum and it is well worth the effort and time and very educational into the bargain. Highly recommend.

Poignant. The war will not be over until all these landmines are found and destroyed. After viewing the wonders of Angkor Wat ask your driver to take you on a short trip to the landmine museum for a confronting but ultimately uplifting story of one man's attempt to repair the damage that he and others caused. You won't come away with a dry eye

Must see attraction!. The land mine muesum was so interesting, its Aki Ra a man who once was a soldier for the Khmer Rouge and he was laying land mines but today he risks his live and goes to towns around cambodia and gets rid of mines. He now has this small but great muesum which is very well done

Don't miss this museum when you're in Siem Reap. This is a small museum that is privately owned and is dedicated to distributing information about landmines and the harm that they can do. The owner, formally a member of the Khymer Rogue, became an expert at laying mines and is now one at finding and removing them. The museum contains just about every type of landmine that you can name with pictures of people maimed by them. It has artillery shells from various countries and a stack of military gear on a table in one room of the museum. Admission is $1 but it's worth a lot more to tour this museum.

Small but good information. This is a very small museum with some information about mines and a good compilation (video) of Aki Ra's work in demining around Cambodia. The museum used to be near Seam Reap but know is near Banteay Srei. So if you plan to visit this temple or the River of the Thousand Lingas, you can include the Land Museum in your way back to the town.The tickets cost US$1 that help to support the activities of the Land Mine Museum. Every dollar you spent there goes not only to demining but for 24 students supported by this ONG. (see photo )

Disappointing. Whilst the work done to help landmine victims and locate mines in Cambodia is wonderful, we found this museum to be uninformative and unstructured. We had hoped to learn so much more about the work going on and the current state of play in Cambodia, but it just appeared to state general opposition to landmines world wide. Rather short of content. This was a surprise given the external support which the musuem has. An opportunity missed (unlike at Tuong Slay in Phnom Pehn) Visit if passing the door, but not worth a special trip.This is a comment on the museum, and not the wonderful work they do, but it could be so much more influential and informative than it was.

A must-see for any visitors to Siem reap. The land mine museum has shifted to a bigger premises along the road to Bantay Srei. There is an entrace fee of $1 which goes to the good work that Aki Ra and his team is currently doing. This is the place to visit for the visitor to appreciate Cambodia beyond the usual touristy activities.. Highly recommended - i'm sure it'll leave a deep impression on you jus as much as it did on me.

Blown Away !!!!. Jus came back from Siem Reap, and was glad that I included the museum in my trip. The museum might be small, but the explaination of the landmines and the stories of the victims have been life enriching. Pls. note that the museum has shifted and is now situated to inside the Angkor park, and you will need the temple pass to visit it. The best approach is to do it on your return trip from Banteay Srei. There is a 1 USD/ person for the entrance.

You have to go!. You have to stop in at this museum before you leave Siem Reap! It is a hugely sobering experience. They have all the different types of landmines, posters with stories of people who have lost limbs to a landmine, as well as a deactivated test field.To correct the previous post, a donation of $2 will clear 3 mines (based on Aki's team of 32 who earn $30 a month and all the supplies they need). Please either make a donation, buy a shirt, or use a guide. One guy offered his services as a guide for $5. Shirts are only $3 (one Japanese lady thought that was too much and left in a huff saying that it should only be $1....this is not a place to bargain - the money goes to an excellent cause!). His handout also says that the people living in the fields where Aki is clearing are very poor and have nothing, so gifts of unwanted clothes, shoes or medicine (with instructions) can be donated to Aki and he will bring them to these people. He also has a Western Union account.

You can't leave Siem Reap without visiting here. We have just returned from Siem Reap and I cannot recommend visiting this museum enough. As the previous reviews have mentioned, it is out of the way, and is really only accessible by taxi or car. Going by tuk tuk is an option but only for the brave hearted as it is a 10 minute drive down a very bumpy unmade road full of potholes. Be patient as we had to ask about 8 people who worked in our hotel before anyone could tell us exactly where it was (nearest landmark is Le Meridien hotel).The museum is free entry although as most of the work of Aki Ra depends on donations, it is worth donating as much as you can to this worthwhile cause. There are posters around and if my memory serves me right they say that it costs $3 to safely disarm each landmine. Seeing as there are still hundreds of thousands of landmines in the more remote areas it puts it all into perspective.The museum is situated in the open and there are displays, films to watch and piles and piles of landmines. It really is a disturbing but very moving place to visit and highlights how bad the problem still is. Many of the children that Aki Ra & his wife have adopted who have lost limbs will act as your guides (posters say offer them $1 for their tour so they can make sure that each child gets the same).There is also a shop there that sells t shirts, linen and other souvenirs & this is one place where people tend to not start bargaining down the price. There are also small books & guides that you can take away with you. You are also free to take photos but it's probably best to do so in a tasteful way. Allow at least an hour for the visit. This was the last place we visited before we flew back to Bangkok and it left a very lasting impression.
Great cause. I would recommend everyone who visits Siem Reap to go visit the Land Mine museum in Siem Reap as they do great work with the child land mine victims as well.

A must see for Siem Reap, but out of the way. Here's a guy who is actually trying to do some good in the world. Apparently the government has forced him to take down his signs on the road, but every tuk-tuk and car driver knows where it is, so definitely make sure you go there - it gives you a very real sense of what the country has been through.

A moving experience ...... We visited Aki Ra's Landmine Museum in July. We hired bikes and pedalled out and this was great fun in itself. The museum was an eye-opener and the scale of the landmine problem made patently clear by the simple information and personal accounts that were pinned around the walls. The summary of Aki's work in the villages was a sobering testimony of what one man can achieve. We met and talked to a number of the young people with missing limbs who had made the museum their home. They even helped us with a problem with our bike! Go see it. Well worth the visit. Unfortunately we don't seem to be able to access the museum's website.Maxwell MeyerLondon
